quotes.quote: AI is a powerful tool which can be used to enhance things like medicine and education. But in the wrong hands, it can be weaponized. By feeding sensitive data into systems like DeepSeek, we give China another weapon.
quotes.source: Press Release on DeepSeek Legislation, May 2025
quotes.context: Statement introducing legislation to ban federal contractors from using DeepSeek, a Chinese AI platform with ties to the CCP

quotes.quote: A sweeping, one-size-fits-all approach for regulating AI will not work and will stifle, not foster, innovation.
quotes.source: White Paper on AI Framework, September 2023
quotes.context: From his white paper outlining Congress's framework for AI regulation, emphasizing context-specific approach

quotes.quote: Government should not stifle innovation in AI, but it should absolutely make sure that privacy is protected, that families are protected, that children are safe and that there are safeguards in place between AI and workers.
quotes.source: HELP Committee Hearing, January 2025
quotes.context: Statement during hearing on AI's impact, outlining his balanced approach to regulation

quotes.quote: You want that incredible innovation to occur, but you want to make sure that it doesn't deny people agency. And I think that regulation should be there to preserve the individual's agency.
quotes.source: Columbia Business School Fireside Chat, October 2024
quotes.context: Discussion about AI regulation philosophy, emphasizing individual autonomy as key regulatory principle

quotes.quote: When companies seek to develop, they typically seek to develop in a lower regulatory state, which is the United States. And we benefit from the economics of that.
quotes.source: Columbia Business School Fireside Chat, October 2024
quotes.context: Discussing competitive advantage of U.S. regulatory approach compared to EU's AI Act

quotes.quote: AI holds enormous potential to improve people's lives, but it carries risks.
quotes.source: HELP Committee Hearing, January 2025
quotes.context: Statement acknowledging both benefits and dangers of AI technology

quotes.quote: With regards to the workforce, there will be disruption, no doubt. But it does not have to be a bad disruption. Although some jobs may be lost to AI, many predict that AI will create even more jobs.
quotes.source: HELP Committee Hearing, January 2025
quotes.context: Addressing concerns about AI's impact on employment and job displacement

quotes.quote: I think there's a lot of damage being done to people's privacy now that people don't realize.
quotes.source: Columbia Business School Fireside Chat, October 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing privacy as a critical concern in AI regulation, particularly regarding health data

quotes.quote: If China's use of tech is causing citizens in #HongKong to wear masks to avoid retribution, how should we feel about Google opening an AI Center in China?
quotes.source: Twitter, August 2019
quotes.context: Early statement questioning U.S. tech companies' AI collaborations with China

Bill Cassidy.notes: Cassidy has been particularly active on China-related AI threats, introducing legislation to ban DeepSeek from federal contracts due to national security concerns. He has also worked with Senator Hawley on child safety issues related to AI chatbots, writing letters to OpenAI, Anthropic, Character.AI, and Alphabet demanding stronger safeguards. His white paper examines AI's potential in healthcare (drug development, clinical trials), education (personalized learning), and labor (workforce efficiency). He has criticized the EU AI Act as too broad and potentially stifling innovation. Cassidy has floated the novel idea of using AI to help regulate AI itself. While he does not discuss AGI or existential risk directly, he focuses on high-risk activities that could deny people agency, such as facial recognition and surveillance technologies. His approach is pragmatic and sector-specific rather than focused on frontier AI safety concerns.

Kathy Castor.summary: Rep. Kathy Castor (D-FL) takes a strongly pro-regulation stance on AI, focusing primarily on consumer protection and child safety rather than existential risks. She opposes Republican efforts to block state-level AI regulation and frames AI as an issue of competitiveness with concerns about protecting Americans from corporate exploitation, particularly regarding children's safety with AI chatbots and companion bots.

quotes.quote: What the heck is Congress doing? What are you doing to take the cops off the beat while states have acted to protect us?
quotes.source: House hearing on AI regulation, May 2025
quotes.context: Castor criticized Republican proposals for a 10-year moratorium on state AI laws, citing cases of Florida teenagers harmed by AI chatbots, including one who took his life after forming a relationship with a chatbot.

quotes.quote: You're putting the cart before the horse. You've now passed out of this committee a 10-year moratorium on all AI regulation at the state level before you even have that framework.
quotes.source: House Subcommittee hearing transcript, May 2025
quotes.context: Castor argued against Republicans blocking state AI regulation while Congress had not yet passed federal AI legislation.

quotes.quote: [This measure] is a shocking surprise addition to the billionaire tax giveaway.
quotes.source: House Energy & Commerce Committee markup session, May 2025
quotes.context: Castor characterized the Republican 10-year moratorium on state AI laws as a gift to Big Tech companies.

quotes.quote: It is our understanding that Meta facilitates inappropriate 'romantic role-play' with these companion bots that alarms even employees of your own company. These inappropriate AI systems pose significant safety risks to children and teenagers who use Meta's platforms.
quotes.source: Letter to Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg, June 2025
quotes.context: Castor led a congressional letter urging Meta to halt deployment of AI chatbots to users under 18, following reports of minors engaging in explicit conversations with AI.

quotes.quote: Back home in Tampa Bay, families and small businesses are already facing rising energy costs and growing demands on our electric grid. The SHIELD Act makes sure massive new power-hungry facilities like data centers pay their fair share.
quotes.source: SHIELD Act introduction, 2025
quotes.context: Castor co-introduced legislation to prevent AI data centers from driving up electricity costs for consumers, showing concern about AI's infrastructure impacts.

quotes.quote: We're here today to determine how Congress can support the growth of an industry that is key for American competitiveness and jobs without losing the race to write the global AI rule book.
quotes.source: House hearing on AI regulation (quote from hearing context), May 2025
quotes.context: This quote from her colleague Rep. Bilirakis reflects the framing of the hearing Castor participated in, which emphasized US-China AI competition.

quotes.quote: The Republicans' 10-year ban on the enforcement of state laws protecting consumers from potential dangers of new artificial intelligence systems gives Big Tech free reign to take advantage of children and families.
quotes.source: Democratic press release on reconciliation bill, May 2025
quotes.context: Statement from Rep. Schakowsky that Castor supported, characterizing the Republican AI moratorium as prioritizing profits over people.

quotes.quote: A lack of legislation altogether puts Americans in a dangerous place.
quotes.source: Congressional hearing, May 2025
quotes.context: Castor argued that without federal AI regulation, Americans face significant risks, particularly citing cases of minors harmed by unregulated AI.

quotes.quote: It is paramount that social media platforms such as Instagram, Facebook, and WhatsApp keep wellness, safety, and the best interests of its youngest users at the center of all designs, and we do not believe that these chatbots meet these criteria.
quotes.source: Letter to Meta CEO, June 2025
quotes.context: Castor demanded Meta answer questions about child safety protections and mental health impacts of AI chatbots.

quotes.quote: Families should not be forced to subsidize massive energy costs for billion-dollar companies. As we advance the future of artificial intelligence and data centers, we need to ensure that there are clear rules that protect consumers.
quotes.source: SHIELD Act co-sponsor statement, 2025
quotes.context: Castor's concern about AI infrastructure costs being passed to consumers, showing she views AI through a consumer protection lens.

Kathy Castor.notes: Rep. Kathy Castor's AI focus is overwhelmingly on consumer protection and child safety rather than existential risk or AGI scenarios. She is a strong advocate for AI regulation and opposes Republican efforts to preempt state AI laws. Her primary concerns center on: (1) AI chatbots harming children and teenagers, particularly citing Florida cases; (2) Meta's AI companion bots engaging in inappropriate conversations with minors; (3) AI data centers driving up electricity costs for consumers; and (4) preventing Big Tech from exploiting families. While China is mentioned in the context of hearings she participated in about US competitiveness, Castor does not personally emphasize China competition as a primary concern. She does not discuss AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, or transformative AI scenarios. Her stance is firmly pro-regulation, positioning herself against what she characterizes as Republican giveaways to Big Tech. She co-leads COPPA 2.0 legislation and has repeatedly confronted Meta about child safety issues. Castor chairs the House Select Committee on the Climate Crisis and also focuses on AI's energy infrastructure impacts.

Judy Chu.summary: Rep. Judy Chu's public statements on AI are narrowly focused on healthcare policy, specifically addressing the use of AI and algorithmic tools by Medicare Advantage insurance plans to deny care to seniors. She has led legislative efforts to increase oversight of these systems but has not made public statements about broader AI policy issues such as AGI, existential risk, transformative AI, or AI competition with China.

quotes.quote: In recent years, problems posed by prior authorization have been exacerbated by MA plans' increasing use of AI or algorithmic software to assist in their coverage determinations
quotes.source: Letter to CMS Administrator, November 2023
quotes.context: Leading congressional letter with Rep. Nadler urging oversight of AI use in Medicare Advantage plans

quotes.quote: Plans continue to use AI tools to erroneously deny care and contradict provider assessment findings
quotes.source: Bicameral letter to CMS, June 2024
quotes.context: Co-leading with Sen. Warren and Rep. Nadler to demand increased AI oversight in healthcare coverage decisions

quotes.quote: The use of AI by Medicare Advantage insurers to deny needed care to seniors and people with disabilities represents the most recent and dangerous step by greedy companies focused on profit instead of patients
quotes.source: Press release, November 2023
quotes.context: Statement accompanying congressional letter about AI misuse in Medicare Advantage

quotes.quote: I plan to introduce legislation that would mandate transparency in how Medicare Advantage health plans use artificial intelligence
quotes.source: House Ways & Means subcommittee hearing, July 22, 2024 (reported by Inside Health Policy)
quotes.context: Announcing plans for AI transparency legislation specific to Medicare Advantage

quotes.quote: We believe CMS must be more proactive in monitoring plans' use of AI and algorithm-driven tools. MA plans cannot be allowed to side-step oversight by claiming that these tools are mere 'guidance'
quotes.source: Letter to CMS, June 2024
quotes.context: Calling for regulatory action on AI tools used in healthcare coverage determinations

quotes.quote: Now is the time for CMS to crack down on companies that are using AI and other mechanisms to deny care that would be covered if the enrollee were covered by Traditional Medicare
quotes.source: Congressional letter, November 2023
quotes.context: Urging federal action against AI-enabled care denials

quotes.quote: [DOJ] started with either the ethnic background or family ties or professional research collaborations. There was clear racial bias.
quotes.source: Interview with Axios, February 2022
quotes.context: Commenting on the China Initiative's targeting of Asian American researchers and scientists - not specifically about AI, but about technology espionage concerns

quotes.quote: They have turned the China Initiative into an instrument for racial profiling. They have turned it into a means to terrorize Chinese scientists and engineers.
quotes.source: Quoted in Xinhua, December 2021
quotes.context: Criticizing the Trump-era China Initiative that targeted researchers - relevant to tech/science policy but not AI-specific

quotes.quote: I have always emphasized to my colleagues that they distinguish between the Chinese people and the Chinese Communist Party. Because, I tell you, when it just becomes the Chinese people, then it becomes, in American's minds, everybody.
quotes.source: NPR interview, April 2023
quotes.context: Warning about anti-China rhetoric and its impact on Asian Americans - technology policy context but not AI-specific

quotes.quote: When you listen to what the members of the select committee said, most of the Democrats portrayed the tension between U.S. and China as one of competition, where the U.S. must regain its leadership in the world in innovation and technology
quotes.source: NPR interview, April 2023
quotes.context: Discussing U.S.-China technology competition - mentions innovation but not AI specifically

Judy Chu.notes: IMPORTANT LIMITATION: Rep. Judy Chu has not made substantial public statements about AI policy in the broader sense (AGI, existential risk, AI safety, AI competition, transformative AI, etc.). Her AI-related work is exclusively focused on one narrow application: Medicare Advantage insurance companies using AI algorithms to deny healthcare coverage to seniors. She has led multiple congressional letters (2023-2024) and announced plans for legislation to mandate transparency in how these algorithms are used. While she has spoken extensively about China-related issues, particularly regarding the racial profiling of Asian American scientists and engineers under the China Initiative, these statements are about technology espionage concerns generally, not AI specifically. She co-sponsored the AI Civil Rights Act (December 2025), which addresses AI discrimination and algorithmic bias, but has not made public statements explaining her position on this legislation. She does not appear to have publicly discussed: AGI/superintelligence, AI existential risk, AI safety/alignment research, AI companies (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google DeepMind, etc.), transformative AI capabilities, or AI as a strategic technology competition with China. Her stance is 'cautious' specifically regarding AI use in healthcare contexts where it may harm vulnerable populations.

Yvette D. Clarke.summary: Rep. Yvette D. Clarke is a pioneering advocate for AI regulation focused on civil rights, algorithmic accountability, and protecting marginalized communities from AI bias. Since 2019, she has been one of Congress's earliest and most consistent voices on AI regulation, viewing algorithmic bias as 'the civil rights issue of our time.' Her approach emphasizes practical harms from current AI systems—particularly deepfakes, discrimination in housing/employment, and election security—rather than speculative existential risks.

quotes.quote: Bias in AI is the civil rights issue of our time … We must take care to ensure the harms of the past are not entrenched in the technology of the future
quotes.source: MeriTalk, 2023
quotes.context: Clarke's keynote speech at a Center for Civil Rights and Technology event, emphasizing her core focus on algorithmic discrimination

quotes.quote: Today we find ourselves amid a technological revolution, the new age of AI. [And] as we seek to innovate, we must also work to enshrine values into the technology of the future
quotes.source: MeriTalk keynote speech, 2023
quotes.context: Clarke framing AI as transformative while emphasizing the need for values-based regulation

quotes.quote: Throughout my career, my priority in this space has definitively remained reducing biases and all forms of discrimination found in algorithms
quotes.source: Fast Company, September 2023
quotes.context: Clarke explaining her consistent focus on algorithmic bias despite broader Congressional attention on generative AI

quotes.quote: We have not protected ourselves in time for this election cycle. That's scary because AI and the deployment of deepfake technology is vast and very, very quick
quotes.source: The Record from Recorded Future News, September 2024
quotes.context: Clarke warning about AI-fueled disinformation and election interference

quotes.quote: With few laws to manage the spread of the technology, we stand at the precipice of a new era of disinformation warfare aided by the use of new AI tools
quotes.source: MeriTalk, 2023
quotes.context: Clarke discussing the urgency of regulating deepfakes and AI-generated content

quotes.quote: I commend the Administration for issuing this landmark Executive Order to ensure that America is a global leader in AI by prioritizing innovation and competition while also emphasizing new standards for equity and civil rights
quotes.source: Statement on Biden's AI Executive Order, October 2023
quotes.context: Clarke supporting Biden's AI executive order, emphasizing both U.S. global leadership and civil rights protections

quotes.quote: once we get into the age of quantum computing — we are already into the age of artificial intelligence — being attacked will happen at lightning speed
quotes.source: The Record from Recorded Future News, September 2024
quotes.context: Clarke discussing AI's transformative impact on cybersecurity, mentioning adversaries including China, Russia, and North Korea

quotes.quote: At the end of the day, companies have a profit motive. There may be blind spots that they're not taking into account
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, February 2024
quotes.context: Clarke expressing skepticism about voluntary AI commitments from companies like OpenAI and Microsoft

quotes.quote: We can all speak to the potential of what AI can and cannot do. However, at the end of the day, it's critical that we not get ahead of ourselves, but that we, again, build a strong foundation to assess how those harms can manifest themselves
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, February 2024
quotes.context: Clarke's measured response when asked about AGI and dystopian scenarios discussed by AI company leaders

quotes.quote: I applaud the Administration for securing commitments from some of our nation's leading AI companies for voluntary safeguards aimed at reducing bias, mitigating national security risks, and protecting the rights, information, and safety of the American people
quotes.source: Statement on AI company commitments, July 2023
quotes.context: Clarke welcoming voluntary commitments from major AI companies while planning to introduce binding legislation

Yvette D. Clarke.notes: Rep. Clarke mentions China, Russia, and North Korea specifically in the context of cybersecurity threats and adversarial behavior, but not in the context of an AI race or AGI competition. When asked directly about AGI and existential scenarios discussed by AI company leaders, she gave a measured, pragmatic response emphasizing the need to build strong foundations rather than getting ahead of ourselves. She has engaged with major AI companies (Meta, Google, Microsoft, OpenAI) through letters and statements, expressing both support for voluntary commitments and skepticism about relying solely on corporate goodwill. Her legislation (Algorithmic Accountability Act, DEEPFAKES Accountability Act, AI Civil Rights Act, REAL Political Ads Act) focuses on accountability, transparency, and civil rights protections. Clarke has been described as 'one of the most forward-looking lawmakers on the issue of AI' since introducing the Algorithmic Accountability Act in 2019. She serves on the House AI Task Force and the Congressional Black Caucus AI Working Group. Her stance is distinctly focused on present harms rather than speculative future risks, with particular attention to how AI affects marginalized communities.

Emanuel Cleaver.summary: Rep. Emanuel Cleaver takes a cautious, equity-focused approach to AI, emphasizing workforce protection and racial justice concerns. As Co-Chair of the Congressional Black Caucus Tech Initiative, he consistently advocates for ensuring AI benefits are distributed equitably, particularly to Black and underrepresented communities, while warning about job displacement and algorithmic bias. He expresses concern about AI's risks while acknowledging its transformative potential.

quotes.quote: While there is much excitement about the potential of AI and the benefits it can bring to our communities, there is also much concern about the impacts it will have on American workers, their jobs, and their wages. It is critically important that we take steps today to prepare our nation and our workforce for the economic consequences that are rapidly approaching with the growing adoption of AI.
quotes.source: Press release on Workforce of the Future Act, December 11, 2025
quotes.context: Statement upon reintroducing legislation to study AI's impact on workforce and provide worker training programs.

quotes.quote: We've been warned for some years now – if we were paying attention – we were warned by 'I Robot,' 'The Matrix,' 'The Terminator,' and most fascinatingly, the movie 'Her.'
quotes.source: House hearing, December 2024 (reported by Missourinet)
quotes.context: Cleaver expressing his concerns about AI during a House hearing, referencing popular culture warnings about AI risks. He stated he was 'very, very nervous and concerned' about AI's growing grip on American life.

quotes.quote: AI technology is almost limitless and we don't know where it will end up. If we're not pushing it or involved in it, we will get run over by it.
quotes.source: Congressional Black Caucus panel discussion, September 20, 2023
quotes.context: Speaking at CBC Annual Legislative Conference about the importance of Black community involvement in AI development.

quotes.quote: We want to make sure the technology we use is working to solve, rather than magnify, our most difficult social challenges.
quotes.source: Letter to Internet Association, July 2022
quotes.context: In a letter demanding accountability for racial and gender bias in AI systems used by tech companies.

quotes.quote: People tend to develop things from their own way of thinking and their own world. We would be wise to make certain that they don't build into their systems exclusionary practices.
quotes.source: Investigation into online lenders' AI use, July 2017
quotes.context: Launching an investigation into whether AI algorithms used in lending discriminate against minorities.

quotes.quote: With the rapid development of technologies like artificial intelligence and quantum computing, there is boundless opportunity to boost innovation, productivity, and prosperity across the nation. However, as with all new technologies, we must work to ensure the benefits will be distributed equitably across society.
quotes.source: Press release on Workforce of the Future Act, September 19, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to prepare workers for AI-driven changes to the workforce.

quotes.quote: The Workforce of the Future Act will provide the investments necessary to ensure American workers are ready and able to capitalize on those opportunities and that nobody is left behind.
quotes.source: Press release, December 11, 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing the need for proactive worker preparation as AI adoption accelerates.

quotes.quote: AI is making decisions about mortgages to figure out who can get one.
quotes.source: Congressional Black Caucus panel discussion, September 2023
quotes.context: Warning about AI's role in financial services and potential for discrimination in lending decisions.

quotes.quote: The impact on minority communities – especially the Black community – is not considered until something goes wrong.
quotes.source: Attributed to context of CBC panel (quote from Rep. Barbara Lee at same event)
quotes.context: Co-hosting a panel on AI's impact on Black communities, emphasizing the lack of diverse perspectives in AI development.

quotes.quote: We're not saying that fintech or alternative financing systems are innately evil. They can have a positive impact.
quotes.source: American Banker interview, July 2017
quotes.context: Discussing AI in financial services while investigating potential discriminatory practices in algorithmic lending.

Emanuel Cleaver.notes: Rep. Cleaver's AI policy focus is heavily centered on racial equity, workforce protection, and algorithmic bias rather than existential risk or AGI concerns. As Co-Chair of the Congressional Black Caucus Tech Initiative, he has been particularly active in demanding diversity in AI development and on AI company boards (notably sending a letter to OpenAI in December 2023 about lack of board diversity). His Workforce of the Future Act has been endorsed by major AI companies including OpenAI, Anthropic, and Microsoft. While he references pop culture warnings about AI (Terminator, The Matrix, I Robot, Her) suggesting awareness of catastrophic risks, his legislative and advocacy work focuses primarily on near-term harms: job displacement, algorithmic discrimination in lending and hiring, and ensuring Black and minority communities are not left behind. He discusses foreign entities in the context of Russian interference on social media platforms but does not frame AI as a geopolitical competition with China. His approach is pragmatic and equity-focused rather than focused on technical AI safety or alignment research. He has met with tech executives including Facebook's Sheryl Sandberg and has corresponded with Twitter/X and OpenAI leadership about diversity and bias concerns.

James E. Clyburn.summary: Based on extensive research, James E. Clyburn does not appear to have made substantial public statements specifically about artificial intelligence, AI policy, or related topics. While he is a prominent Democratic leader in Congress, his public focus has been on other policy areas such as healthcare, civil rights, education, and infrastructure.
James E. Clyburn.notes: James E. Clyburn (D-SC-6) has served in Congress since 1993 and is currently Assistant Democratic Leader. Despite his senior position in Democratic leadership, there is no substantial public record of him making speeches, issuing statements, or taking positions on AI-specific policy issues including regulation, safety, competition with China, or the activities of AI companies. His daughter, Mignon Clyburn, served as FCC Commissioner and was appointed to the National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence in 2019, where she did make statements about AI bias, particularly in facial recognition technology. However, the congressman himself does not appear to have developed or articulated a public position on AI matters. His legislative focus has historically centered on healthcare access, voting rights, infrastructure investment (particularly in rural and underserved communities), and social justice issues rather than emerging technology policy.

Steve Cohen.summary: Congressman Steve Cohen has shown support for AI as an economic driver while expressing serious concerns about environmental and ethical issues. He initially welcomed xAI's Memphis facility as beneficial for the local economy and tech industry, but has become increasingly critical of Elon Musk and the environmental impacts of the facility, particularly air quality concerns. His legislative work focuses on AI workforce development and environmental regulation of data centers.

quotes.quote: This is great news for Memphis and the Memphis economy and will make our region a focus for the future of artificial intelligence.
quotes.source: Press release, June 5, 2024
quotes.context: Statement welcoming xAI's Gigafactory supercomputer facility to Memphis

quotes.quote: Mr. Musk's smart decision to locate his supercomputer in Memphis will be a boon to our growing tech industry, attract new businesses and create good jobs.
quotes.source: Press release, June 5, 2024
quotes.context: Initial positive reaction to xAI choosing Memphis for its facility

quotes.quote: I am concerned about its use of natural gas turbines to power it while adding to the poor air quality and its negative health effects, as well as its massive local tax breaks.
quotes.source: CNN interview, July 2025
quotes.context: Expressing concerns about xAI's environmental impact on Memphis

quotes.quote: Musk's access to sensitive national security information is more than problematic.
quotes.source: CNN interview, July 2025
quotes.context: Discussing Grok's Pentagon contract and national security concerns

quotes.quote: This substantial investment in computing power will improve the quality of research into AI affecting intelligent health, cybersecurity, educational technology, smart transportation and computational biology.
quotes.source: Press release, September 14, 2023
quotes.context: Announcing $1.1 million NSF grant to University of Memphis for AI research

quotes.quote: By creating a standardized system and language for AI-related tasks and qualifications, we will be better equipped to meet the growing need for qualified employees in the AI field.
quotes.source: Press release, July 2, 2020
quotes.context: On his AI Careers Act included in the National Defense Authorization Act

quotes.quote: I expressed skepticism over Musk's track record of integrity in his business dealings, encouraging local authorities to carefully examine any and all contracts involving Elon Musk — including with xAI.
quotes.source: Town hall meeting, March 19, 2025
quotes.context: Addressing constituent concerns about xAI and Elon Musk

quotes.quote: (Elon) Musk said that the great weakness of Western civilization is empathy. You fool. Empathy is the glue of humanity.
quotes.source: Newsletter, July 18, 2025
quotes.context: Criticizing Elon Musk's philosophy and approach

quotes.quote: No company—no matter how high-profile—should get a blank check to do business here without community input and strong environmental safeguards.
quotes.source: Op-ed in Commercial Appeal, May 2025
quotes.context: On xAI's gas turbine plans and environmental concerns in South Memphis

quotes.quote: Congressman Cohen also talked about the need to defend voting rights and voting integrity, the Elon Musk xAI supercomputer and clean air issues.
quotes.source: Town hall report, August 12, 2025
quotes.context: Continuing to raise concerns about xAI's environmental impact at public meetings

Steve Cohen.notes: Congressman Steve Cohen's AI stance has evolved significantly over time. He initially welcomed AI investment in Memphis as an economic opportunity, specifically praising xAI's decision to build a supercomputer facility in his district. However, his position shifted to become increasingly critical as environmental and ethical concerns emerged. His main focus areas are: (1) AI workforce development through legislation like the AI Careers Act; (2) Environmental regulation of AI data centers through the proposed Clean Cloud Act; (3) Concerns about Elon Musk's integrity and the national security implications of Musk's access to sensitive information; (4) Local environmental impacts, particularly air quality issues from xAI's natural gas turbines in South Memphis. Cohen does not appear to engage with more theoretical AI safety concerns like existential risk, AGI, or alignment. His approach is pragmatic and focused on immediate local impacts - jobs, environmental quality, and accountability. He has also introduced the Clean Cloud Act to establish air emissions baselines for high-demand energy users like data centers. Limited information was available about his broader views on AI policy, regulation, or international competition.

Tom Cole.summary: Based on available public information, Rep. Tom Cole has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence policy. As Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, he has mentioned AI in the context of U.S. global leadership and energy infrastructure needs, but detailed policy positions on AI safety, regulation, or competition with China are not well-documented in public statements.

quotes.quote: solidifying our position as a world leader in AI
quotes.source: Oklahoma Farm Report, December 18, 2025
quotes.context: Cole mentioned AI leadership as one of the Trump administration's accomplishments in a year-end recap, indicating support for U.S. AI dominance but without elaborating on specific policies.

quotes.quote: emphasizing the importance of addressing increased energy demand for areas like AI
quotes.source: News On 6 interview, August 24, 2025
quotes.context: In discussing Secretary of Interior appointments, Cole acknowledged AI's energy demands as a practical infrastructure concern requiring policy attention.

quotes.quote: VideoWise uses Artificial Intelligence Capabilities to do so in a timely manner
quotes.source: Press Release announcing 2024 Congressional App Challenge Winners, January 2, 2025
quotes.context: Cole praised student winners who created an AI-powered app, showing general support for AI innovation among young people, though this is ceremonial rather than policy-focused.

quotes.quote: using AI, they can crib photos of you and your kids and turn them into violating images
quotes.source: Opinion piece calling on Tom Cole to act, Yahoo News, August 2, 2024
quotes.context: This quote is from an opinion piece about Cole (not by him), discussing AI-generated child exploitation material and calling for increased funding for Internet Crimes Against Children task forces.

Tom Cole.notes: Tom Cole's public statements on AI are extremely limited. As Chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, he has significant influence over AI-related funding but has not been vocal about AI policy in public forums. The only substantive reference found was his mention of 'solidifying our position as a world leader in AI' as an accomplishment, suggesting general support for U.S. AI competitiveness. He acknowledged AI's energy infrastructure needs in one interview. However, I could not find public statements from him addressing: AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, specific AI companies or figures, detailed China competition concerns, or whether he views AI as transformative vs. overhyped. His role as Appropriations Chair means he votes on funding bills that may include AI research and development, but he has not been a prominent voice in the AI policy debate. The limited public record suggests either he has not prioritized AI as a public messaging issue, or his views have not been extensively covered by media.

Jim Costa.summary: Congressman Jim Costa (D-CA-21) has shown limited public engagement with AI policy broadly, with his only significant AI-related work focusing on the practical infrastructure impacts of AI data centers on rural communities. His approach is pragmatic and constituent-focused, emphasizing energy costs, utility rates, and ensuring rural areas benefit from AI industry growth rather than bearing disproportionate costs.

quotes.quote: AI Data Centers are expanding rapidly and using more energy and water than entire cities. That energy demand is driving up utility costs for consumers.
quotes.source: Press release, September 11, 2025 - Unleashing Low-Cost Rural AI Act
quotes.context: Costa introduced bipartisan legislation with Rep. Blake Moore to study the impact of AI data center expansions in rural America, focusing on energy and water consumption.

quotes.quote: My legislation ensures we take a hard look at how this growth impacts rural communities that are powering the AI industry, and make sure families aren't left paying the price.
quotes.source: Press release, September 11, 2025 - Unleashing Low-Cost Rural AI Act
quotes.context: Explaining the purpose of his AI data center study legislation, emphasizing consumer protection and rural community impacts.

quotes.quote: But at the same time, it's important that rural communities are not left behind in the new opportunities that AI data centers will provide for agricultural sciences and an improved ability to compete in this modern era.
quotes.source: Official statement, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Costa acknowledging potential benefits of AI for agriculture while introducing legislation to study data center impacts.

Jim Costa.notes: Jim Costa's public statements on AI are extremely limited and focused exclusively on infrastructure and economic impacts rather than broader AI policy, safety, or geopolitical concerns. As a representative from California's agricultural Central Valley and a third-generation farmer, his AI engagement centers on practical concerns: energy consumption, utility costs for consumers, and ensuring rural communities benefit from AI development. He has not made public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, China's AI development, or major AI companies. His only legislative action on AI is the 'Unleashing Low-Cost Rural AI Act' (H.R. 5227), introduced in September 2025, which requires federal study of AI data center impacts on rural energy infrastructure. This narrow focus suggests either limited engagement with broader AI policy debates or a strategic choice to focus on constituent concerns. No evidence of participation in congressional AI hearings, task forces, or broader AI policy discussions was found in available records.

Joe Courtney.summary: Insufficient information available. Congressman Joe Courtney (D-CT-02) has not made substantial public statements about artificial intelligence policy, safety, or development. His congressional focus has been primarily on defense (particularly submarine programs), healthcare, education, and veterans' issues.

quotes.quote: They can't plug in AI or, you know, unauthorized devices. Again, this is like a black box that has personal information, you know, names, home addresses, social security numbers.
quotes.source: NBC Connecticut Face the Facts interview, February 9, 2025
quotes.context: Courtney was discussing concerns about DOGE (Department of Government Efficiency) personnel accessing sensitive Treasury Department data systems. This was a comment about data security rather than AI policy.

Joe Courtney.notes: Congressman Joe Courtney represents Connecticut's 2nd Congressional District and serves as Ranking Member of the House Armed Services Subcommittee on Seapower and Projection Forces. His legislative focus has been primarily on defense (particularly submarine programs and naval issues), healthcare (especially the Affordable Care Act), education, workforce development, and veterans' affairs. While he visited ThayerMahan, a company working on autonomous maritime systems in 2019, no public statements about AI policy or broader AI implications were found. The single quote identified relates to data security concerns about unauthorized access to government systems, not AI development or policy. It appears AI policy has not been a significant focus of his congressional work or public statements to date.

Mike Crapo.summary: Senator Mike Crapo views AI as offering transformative opportunities across sectors, particularly healthcare, but emphasizes the need for sector-specific, adaptive regulation rather than rigid, one-size-fits-all approaches. His focus is primarily on practical oversight of AI deployment in federal agencies, ensuring proper guardrails against algorithmic bias while avoiding overly bureaucratic regulations that could stifle innovation. He does not appear to engage with existential risk or AGI concepts.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence, or AI, offers seemingly endless applications and opportunities for every sector of American society, including health care.
quotes.source: Senate Finance Committee Hearing on AI in Health Care, February 8, 2024
quotes.context: Opening statement at hearing on AI and healthcare, expressing optimistic view of AI's potential applications

quotes.quote: One-size-fits-all, overly rigid, and unduly bureaucratic laws and regulations risk stifling life-saving advances and becoming outdated before they are even codified.
quotes.source: Senate Finance Committee Hearing on AI in Health Care, February 8, 2024
quotes.context: Advocating for flexible, sector-specific AI regulation rather than comprehensive federal mandates

quotes.quote: Rather than legislate first and ask questions later, Congress needs to build a better understanding of how AI operates in specific contexts, including health care.
quotes.source: Senate Finance Committee Hearing on AI in Health Care, February 8, 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing cautious, informed approach to AI legislation

quotes.quote: Without the proper structure and guidelines for the procurement, deployment, and monitoring of AI systems, SSA's use of AI could reduce the effectiveness of its benefit administration processes, exacerbate improper payments, and jeopardize beneficiaries' financial security.
quotes.source: Letter to Social Security Administration with Sen. Wyden, August 7, 2024
quotes.context: Expressing concern about proper governance frameworks for AI in government agencies

quotes.quote: To mitigate the risks associated with deploying AI across its programs, SSA must have strong governance frameworks in place that, among other important aspects, clarify the role of human discretion.
quotes.source: Letter to Social Security Administration with Sen. Wyden, August 7, 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing importance of human oversight in AI systems affecting benefit decisions

quotes.quote: As game-changing AI-enabled devices and other technologies emerge, Medicare coverage and payment policies must keep pace.
quotes.source: Senate Finance Committee Hearing on AI in Health Care, February 8, 2024
quotes.context: Describing AI as 'game-changing' and calling for policy adaptation to support innovation

quotes.quote: Our federal programs should expedite, rather than undermine, access to medical breakthroughs, including those enabled by AI.
quotes.source: Senate Finance Committee Hearing on AI in Health Care, February 8, 2024
quotes.context: Advocating for pro-innovation policy approach to AI in healthcare

quotes.quote: In the case of algorithms applied to expedite utilization management, for instance, improper denials or delays of needed services warrant government scrutiny.
quotes.source: Senate Finance Committee Hearing on AI in Health Care, February 8, 2024
quotes.context: Acknowledging need for targeted oversight of AI systems that could harm beneficiaries

quotes.quote: We have warned for years that either the United States would write the rules for digital trade or China would. Now, the Biden Administration has decided to give China the pen.
quotes.source: Statement on U.S. Trade Representative's digital trade policy, October 2023
quotes.context: Criticizing administration's retreat from digital trade negotiations, framing as competition with China (related to data flows and technology, though not AI-specific)

quotes.quote: Without proper guardrails, CBP's use of AI could result in trade facilitation and enforcement systems that are ultimately less effective.
quotes.source: Letter to DHS and CBP with Sen. Wyden, November 2023
quotes.context: Requesting information on AI use in border security and customs, emphasizing need for proper safeguards

Mike Crapo.notes: Senator Crapo's AI engagement is primarily focused on practical oversight through his role on the Senate Finance Committee, particularly regarding AI use in healthcare, Social Security, and federal agencies. His statements emphasize: (1) AI's transformative potential across sectors; (2) opposition to rigid, one-size-fits-all regulation; (3) need for sector-specific approaches; (4) importance of guardrails against algorithmic bias; (5) ensuring human discretion remains in critical decisions. He references China in the context of digital trade and data flows but not specifically regarding AI competition. He does not engage with concepts like AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, or mention specific AI companies or figures. His approach appears pragmatic and innovation-friendly while acknowledging need for targeted oversight, particularly to protect vulnerable populations in government programs.

Eric A. \"Rick\" Crawford.summary: Rep. Rick Crawford, Chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, views AI primarily through a national security and geopolitical competition lens, particularly focused on the race against China. He appears moderately AGI-aware, discussing self-improving AI and viewing AI as transformative for economic and national security dominance. His statements emphasize urgency and the need for U.S. leadership in AI development.

quotes.quote: The global AI race against China is moving much faster than many think, and the stakes couldn't be higher for U.S. national security.
quotes.source: House Intelligence Committee Statement, July 29, 2025
quotes.context: Statement released after the Committee hosted a briefing with industry experts on the global AI race

quotes.quote: Frontier labs may soon achieve self-improving AI, and the U.S. must reach this threshold first to secure economic and national security dominance and potentially enjoy an enduring advantage.
quotes.source: House Intelligence Committee Statement, July 29, 2025
quotes.context: Crawford discussing the importance of reaching self-improving AI capabilities before adversaries

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence can certainly be a game changer and we need to be on the leading edge to be competitive with countries like China who are quickly adopting AI technology to try to do everything they can to supplant the American economy to become the preeminent economic superpower in the world. It's the only way we're going to be able to maintain our status.
quotes.source: Talk Business & Politics interview, August 2025
quotes.context: Crawford explaining why AI leadership is critical for maintaining U.S. economic status

quotes.quote: We must be taking all necessary steps to protect U.S. technology leadership in microelectronics and artificial intelligence. The CCP does not play by the rules and will stop at nothing in its mission for global dominance.
quotes.source: Twitter/X statement, August 2025
quotes.context: Crawford commenting on Trump administration's revocation of chip technology waivers for China

quotes.quote: The United States should not be aiding, involuntarily or voluntarily, the advancement of Chinese AI technology and must ensure all safeguards are in place to combat this glaring national security threat.
quotes.source: Twitter/X statement, August 2025
quotes.context: Crawford on protecting U.S. AI technology from Chinese acquisition

quotes.quote: The briefing helped inform our efforts to make sure the IC is incorporating advanced AI technology into its activities while staying ahead of our adversaries, most notably China.
quotes.source: House Intelligence Committee Statement, July 29, 2025
quotes.context: Crawford on integrating AI into Intelligence Community operations

quotes.quote: We were so focused on the global war on terror, what that's done is opened up opportunities for countries like China.
quotes.source: Fox News interview, March 2025
quotes.context: Crawford explaining how U.S. focus on counterterrorism allowed China to gain ground in technology competition

quotes.quote: The threat of the Chinese Communist Party is at our doorstep and we must be aggressive in our response to their malicious behavior.
quotes.source: House statement on COMPETES Act, April 2022
quotes.context: Crawford as conferee for China competition legislation

quotes.quote: It is imperative that Congress take action today to bolster U.S. growth and competition and ensure China is not permitted to steal and cheat its way to the top.
quotes.source: Senate Conference Committee remarks, May 2022
quotes.context: Crawford testifying on the America COMPETES Act regarding China competition

quotes.quote: At this HPSCI briefing, Members heard directly from industry experts working on the cutting edge of AI development.
quotes.source: House Intelligence Committee Statement, July 29, 2025
quotes.context: Crawford describing engagement with AI industry leaders for intelligence briefing

Eric A. \"Rick\" Crawford.notes: Rep. Crawford's AI views are heavily shaped by his role as House Intelligence Committee Chairman. His focus is almost exclusively on the geopolitical competition with China rather than technical AI safety concerns. He demonstrates awareness of advanced AI concepts like 'self-improving AI' and 'frontier labs,' suggesting he has been briefed by industry experts. However, he does not publicly discuss existential risk, alignment problems, or AI safety in the technical sense that AI safety researchers use these terms. His stance is supportive of rapid AI development for national security purposes, viewing it as essential for maintaining U.S. economic and military dominance. He has engaged with AI industry experts through Intelligence Committee briefings and supports legislation to prevent Chinese access to U.S. AI technology (Chip Security Act). His statements indicate he views AI as genuinely transformative rather than overhyped, particularly in terms of its impact on economic and military power. Crawford's background includes serving on the House Agriculture, Intelligence, and Transportation committees, and he was selected as Intelligence Committee Chair in January 2025.

Henry Cuellar.summary: Representative Henry Cuellar (D-TX) has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. His engagement with AI appears primarily focused on supporting AI education and workforce development in his district, particularly through federal grants to Texas A&M International University. There is insufficient public record to assess his detailed views on AI policy, safety, or regulation.

quotes.quote: As we move through this economy, we can see that engineering and artificial intelligence are going to be so important
quotes.source: KGNS TV, August 4, 2023
quotes.context: Announcing federal funding for STEM education at TAMIU, emphasizing AI's economic importance

quotes.quote: However, funding is needed to attract future engineers and computer architects, especially in the area of ​​artificial intelligence. This is where competition will be in the future: to get the most data in the shortest amount of time.
quotes.source: Laredo Morning Times, July 1, 2024
quotes.context: Speaking at TAMIU grant announcement about AI workforce development and future competition

quotes.quote: China is aggressively stealing technology from the United States and foreign militaries to advance and modernize its military. This legislation will take the first step in stopping the theft of U.S.
quotes.source: Press Release, June 27, 2019
quotes.context: Co-introducing the China Technology Transfer Control Act of 2019 with Rep. Mark Green, focused on preventing Chinese acquisition of sensitive American technology

Henry Cuellar.notes: Representative Henry Cuellar has made very few substantive public statements about artificial intelligence policy. His documented engagement with AI is primarily limited to: (1) Supporting federal funding for AI education programs at Texas A&M International University in his district; (2) A 2019 bill focused on preventing Chinese technology theft, though not AI-specific; and (3) Brief remarks recognizing AI's economic importance for workforce development. There is no public record of Cuellar discussing AI safety, alignment, existential risk, AGI, specific AI companies, or detailed AI policy positions. His focus appears to be on local workforce development and education rather than national AI policy or regulation. As a conservative Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, he may have views on AI policy, but they have not been publicly articulated in sufficient detail to assess. The limited available information suggests a practical, education-focused approach rather than engagement with technical AI safety debates.

Danny K. Davis.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or policy positions from Congressman Danny K. Davis regarding artificial intelligence could be found. His public focus has been on social justice, healthcare, criminal justice reform, education, and economic equity issues rather than technology policy.
Danny K. Davis.notes: Congressman Danny K. Davis (D-IL-7) has served in Congress since 1997 and sits on the House Ways and Means Committee. Despite extensive searches of congressional records, press releases, speeches, hearing testimonies, and media coverage, no public statements from Rep. Davis about AI policy, regulation, development, or related issues could be identified. The only AI-related mention found was a February 2024 controversy when his campaign used an AI-generated photo that made him appear younger and thinner. His office defended this as a communication tool but did not elaborate on broader AI policy views. Rep. Davis's legislative focus has been on healthcare, criminal justice reform, poverty reduction, civil rights, education, and social services. He announced in July 2025 that he will not seek reelection in 2026. Without any substantive public statements on AI, it is not possible to characterize his views on AI safety, China's AI development, AGI risks, or related topics.

Diana DeGette.summary: Diana DeGette's AI focus is narrowly centered on healthcare applications, particularly AI chatbots and medical devices. She emphasizes the need for proper oversight, human involvement in clinical decisions, and protecting patients from harmful AI applications. Her stance is cautiously supportive of AI innovation in healthcare while demanding stronger regulatory frameworks and scientific rigor.

quotes.quote: Chatbots Are Not Doctors
quotes.source: House hearing on AI chatbots, November 2025
quotes.context: DeGette questioned experts about the usage of AI chatbots for health reasons, emphasizing that AI should not replace medical professionals.

quotes.quote: About one in six adults use AI chatbots at least once a month to find health information and advice. Even more people under 30 use AI chatbots for health information.
quotes.source: House hearing transcript on AI chatbots, November 2025
quotes.context: DeGette highlighted the widespread use of AI chatbots for health information, particularly among younger populations.

quotes.quote: We have to insulate scientific judgment from politics and ideology. And as the Health Subcommittee of Energy and Commerce, we must base our decisions on science.
quotes.source: House hearing on AI in healthcare, September 3, 2025
quotes.context: DeGette emphasized the need for science-based decision-making regarding AI regulation in healthcare, while criticizing the Trump administration's healthcare policies.

quotes.quote: Rome is burning. More important than this is the peril that the Trump administration's policies have put my constituents and the constituents of every single person on this panel into.
quotes.source: House hearing on AI in healthcare, September 3, 2025
quotes.context: DeGette expressed frustration that Congress was discussing AI while she believed more urgent healthcare crises needed attention.

quotes.quote: An overreliance on AI could erode the physician–patient relationship if the correct oversight mechanisms aren't established.
quotes.source: House hearing on AI in healthcare, September 2025 (paraphrased by MedCity News)
quotes.context: DeGette warned about the risks of AI replacing human judgment in medical care.

quotes.quote: ChatGPT and other general information chatbots don't have to comply with HIPAA... What dangers are there in disclosing sensitive health information to a general information chatbot?
quotes.source: House hearing transcript on AI chatbots, November 2025
quotes.context: DeGette questioned experts about privacy concerns with AI chatbots not covered by healthcare privacy laws.

quotes.quote: What challenges does the FDA face in promoting safety in this way? Are there improvements in the FDA's authorities that we could look at that would be useful to drive innovation while ensuring patient safety?
quotes.source: House hearing transcript on AI chatbots, November 2025
quotes.context: DeGette inquired about FDA's ability to regulate AI mental health tools and whether the agency needs expanded authority.

quotes.quote: Digital infrastructure and AI is underpinned by electric infrastructure.
quotes.source: House hearing on AI and energy resources, June 2024
quotes.context: DeGette discussed the energy infrastructure needs for AI development, focusing on transmission planning and grid capacity.

quotes.quote: We're fiddling while Rome burns
quotes.source: House hearing, September 2025
quotes.context: DeGette criticized holding AI hearings while she believed more urgent healthcare policy issues were being ignored.

quotes.quote: [Co-authored] Cures 2.0 legislation which includes provisions for digital health technologies and AI regulation in FDA oversight
quotes.source: 21st Century Cures 2.0 discussion draft, June 2021
quotes.context: DeGette co-led bipartisan legislation that addressed digital health and AI regulation, building on her signature 21st Century Cures Act.

Diana DeGette.notes: Diana DeGette's public statements on AI are exclusively focused on healthcare applications. She has not made public statements about broader AI policy issues like AGI, existential risk, AI competition with China, or major AI companies like OpenAI. Her AI focus is very narrow: (1) AI chatbots for mental health and their risks to youth, (2) FDA oversight of AI medical devices, (3) Privacy concerns with health AI not covered by HIPAA, (4) The need for human oversight in clinical AI applications, (5) Energy infrastructure needed to support AI data centers. She views AI as potentially transformative for healthcare (drug discovery, clinical documentation, diagnostics) but demands proper scientific validation, regulatory oversight, and protection of the physician-patient relationship. Her stance is that AI should augment, not replace, clinicians. She has not engaged with the broader AI safety community's concerns about existential risk or alignment. She co-authored the Cures 2.0 legislation which includes digital health provisions. Her Republican colleague Rep. Morgan Griffith has made more enthusiastic statements about AI being a 'huge revolution' in healthcare, while DeGette has been more measured and focused on oversight needs.

Rosa L. DeLauro.summary: Rep. DeLauro's public statements on AI are limited and primarily focused on economic and national security concerns related to China. Her most prominent AI-related comments came in December 2024 when she accused Elon Musk of undermining legislation that would have restricted U.S. investments in China's AI sector. She views AI as a critical technology that should remain in American hands and supports AI oversight, but has not made extensive public statements about existential risk, AGI, or technical AI safety issues.

quotes.quote: It would have kept innovation and manufacturing in semiconductors, artificial intelligence (AI), quantum computing, and other cutting-edge technologies in the United States
quotes.source: Letter to Congressional Leadership, December 2024
quotes.context: DeLauro explaining why she supported a provision to screen U.S. investments in China that was removed from a spending bill. This shows she views AI as a strategic technology alongside semiconductors and quantum computing.

quotes.quote: It is particularly disturbing that Musk may have sought to upend this critical negotiated agreement to remove a bipartisan provision regulating U.S. investments in China in order to protect his wallet and the Chinese Communist Party at the expense of American workers, innovators, and businesses
quotes.source: Letter to Congressional Leadership, December 2024
quotes.context: DeLauro accusing Elon Musk of protecting his business interests in China by opposing investment restrictions. Shows her concern about AI companies' ties to China.

quotes.quote: This is something that simply must be done to safeguard our supply chains and our critical capabilities
quotes.source: House Floor remarks, December 2024
quotes.context: Speaking about the need for outbound investment screening for AI and other technologies to China. Demonstrates she sees AI as a 'critical capability' for national security.

quotes.quote: It is a credit to your presidency that Ambassador Tai is proceeding in a manner that respects Congress' role in setting domestic policy and that honors your digital competition, privacy, and artificial intelligence (AI) oversight goals, which we also support
quotes.source: Letter to President Biden, February 2024
quotes.context: Co-signed letter praising the Biden Administration's approach to digital trade policy. Shows she supports AI oversight and believes Congress should retain authority to regulate AI domestically before it's locked into trade agreements.

quotes.quote: The Trump Administration inserted several 'digital trade' provisions favored by Big Tech interests... designed to limit the regulation of domestic online privacy and data security matters, gig worker protection, AI oversight, tech anti-monopoly, and other important policies
quotes.source: Letter to President Biden, February 2024
quotes.context: Criticizing the previous administration's trade policies that would have limited AI oversight. Shows she opposes tech industry efforts to avoid AI regulation through trade agreements.

quotes.quote: It increases funding for the National Institute of Standards and Technology to modernize research facilities and promote responsible innovation in artificial intelligence
quotes.source: Statement at FY 2025 Budget Request Hearing for Department of Commerce, May 2024
quotes.context: Supporting increased funding for NIST's AI research. The phrase 'responsible innovation' suggests she supports balanced approach to AI development with appropriate safeguards.

quotes.quote: It provides additional funding for the International Trade Administration to fight China's unfair trade practices
quotes.source: Statement at FY 2025 Budget Request Hearing for Department of Commerce, May 2024
quotes.context: Part of the same statement about the budget. Shows ongoing concern about China's trade practices in technology sectors including AI.

quotes.quote: Musk's investments in China and his ties with the Chinese Communist Party have only grown over the last few years with Tesla's Shanghai plant producing about 50 percent of Tesla's global automobile output
quotes.source: Statement on Government Funding, December 2024
quotes.context: Highlighting Musk's business ties to China, including his AI and autonomous driving ambitions. Shows concern about tech leaders' conflicts of interest regarding China policy.

quotes.quote: He wants to build an AI data center there too — which could endanger U.S. security. He's been bending over backwards to ingratiate himself with Chinese leaders
quotes.source: Quoted in CNBC article, December 2024
quotes.context: Expressing concern about Musk's reported plans to build AI infrastructure in China. Demonstrates she views AI capabilities as having national security implications.

quotes.quote: It is extremely alarming that House Republican leadership, at the urging of an unelected billionaire, scrapped a bipartisan, bicameral negotiated funding deal that included this critical provision to protect American jobs and critical capabilities
quotes.source: Letter to Congressional Leadership, December 2024
quotes.context: Criticizing the removal of AI investment screening provisions. Shows she believes AI represents a 'critical capability' that needs protection from foreign competition and influence.

Rosa L. DeLauro.notes: Rosa DeLauro's public statements on AI are notably limited and context-specific. Unlike some legislators who have engaged deeply with AI safety, AGI timelines, or existential risk, DeLauro's comments focus almost exclusively on: (1) China as a competitor/threat in AI development, (2) the need to restrict U.S. investments in Chinese AI companies, (3) conflicts of interest of tech leaders like Elon Musk who have business interests in China, and (4) the importance of Congressional authority to regulate AI domestically. Her December 2024 confrontation with Musk over the removal of China investment restrictions from a spending bill represents the bulk of her public AI commentary. She supports 'AI oversight' and 'responsible innovation' in general terms but has not articulated detailed views on technical AI safety, alignment, or transformative AI scenarios. Her stance appears to be that of a traditional progressive Democrat concerned about corporate power, workers' rights, and national security vis-à-vis China, rather than someone deeply engaged with AI-specific policy debates. She has not discussed existential risk, AGI, or technical alignment issues in any publicly available statements.

Scott DesJarlais.summary: Scott DesJarlais (R-TN) has limited public statements specifically about AI. As a member of the House Armed Services Committee's Future of Defense Task Force (2019-2020) and currently chairman of the Strategic Forces Subcommittee, he has been involved in reports calling for major AI investment to compete with China, but direct quotes from him on AI are scarce. His focus appears to be on space, nuclear weapons, and defense technology broadly, with China competition as a key concern.

quotes.quote: We're assigned with trying to stay ahead of the Chinese and protect our warfighter domain in space because everything we do on the ground comes from there, and we need to stay ahead of the Chinese who are moving at a frightening pace.
quotes.source: Herald Chronicle, March 2025
quotes.context: Speaking at a community event about his role as Strategic Forces Subcommittee chairman, discussing space and defense technology competition with China

quotes.quote: I think it's worth noting that the three officers in front of us today represent different combatant commands, with different missions, and different priorities, but they each face a common problem. All of you are responsible for mission areas where the United States once enjoyed superiority, but we are now increasingly confronted by adversaries.
quotes.source: Breaking Defense, November 2025 (from 2025 posture review)
quotes.context: During DoD Strategic Command hearing, discussing how adversaries are challenging U.S. technological superiority

quotes.quote: Tennesseans working at nearby research and testing facilities are at the forefront of nuclear, hypersonic and space technology to protect America. My goal is to provide them and soldiers on the battlefield with all the resources they need to win, and to save taxpayers money.
quotes.source: House.gov press release, January 2019
quotes.context: Statement upon joining Armed Services Committee subcommittees on Strategic Forces and Intelligence, Emerging Threats and Capabilities

quotes.quote: Entrepreneurs and innovation drive the U.S. economy, and small businesses provide most jobs.
quotes.source: DesJarlais.house.gov - Economy page
quotes.context: General statement about innovation and economy on his official website

Scott DesJarlais.notes: Scott DesJarlais served on the bipartisan Future of Defense Task Force (2019-2020) that produced a report calling for a 'Manhattan Project for artificial intelligence' to compete with China and Russia. The report recommended the U.S. 'undertake and win the artificial intelligence race by leading in the invention and deployment of AI while establishing the standards for its public and private use.' However, I could not find any direct quotes from DesJarlais himself specifically about AI, AI safety, AGI, or AI companies. His public statements focus on China as a competitor in space and defense technology broadly, and he emphasizes staying ahead of Chinese technological advances. As chairman of the Strategic Forces Subcommittee (2025-present), his portfolio includes space, nuclear weapons, and missile defense, but specific AI policy statements are not publicly available. He has advocated for procurement reforms to help smaller innovative companies compete for defense contracts. The lack of direct AI-specific quotes suggests either limited public engagement with AI policy specifically, or that such statements have not been widely reported or published.

Mario Diaz-Balart.summary: No substantial public record found of Mario Diaz-Balart making statements or taking positions specifically on artificial intelligence, AI policy, AGI, AI safety, or related topics. His legislative focus appears to be on foreign affairs, national security (particularly regarding Cuba, Venezuela, and China), immigration, and appropriations.
Mario Diaz-Balart.notes: Mario Diaz-Balart is a Republican Representative from Florida's 26th district, serving since 2003. He is Vice Chair of the House Appropriations Committee and Chairman of the Subcommittee on National Security, Department of State, and Related Programs. His legislative priorities focus heavily on: (1) National security and defense, particularly regarding communist China as a geopolitical threat; (2) Foreign affairs related to Cuba, Venezuela, and Nicaragua; (3) Immigration policy; (4) Appropriations and federal spending. While he has spoken about China as a 'mid- and long-term existential threat' in the context of military defense (not AI), no public statements, hearings, legislation, or positions specifically addressing artificial intelligence, AI regulation, AI safety, AGI, or AI companies were found across congressional records, press releases, C-SPAN archives, or news sources. He does not appear to have participated in AI-related hearings or sponsored AI-related legislation. This absence of AI-focused commentary is notable given his senior position on appropriations, which would typically involve technology funding decisions.

Lloyd Doggett.summary: Based on available public information, Rep. Lloyd Doggett has not made extensive public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. His technology-related work has focused primarily on data privacy, internet freedom, net neutrality, and semiconductor manufacturing support. He has been involved with the Responsible and Ethical AI Labeling Act (REAL Act) as a cosponsor, but detailed statements about his AI views are not readily available in the public record.
Lloyd Doggett.notes:
Representative Lloyd Doggett (D-TX-37) has been serving in Congress since 1995 and is currently Ranking Member of the House Ways & Means Health Subcommittee. While he has been active on technology policy issues—including data privacy (particularly regarding Palantir Technologies), internet freedom, net neutrality, and supporting the CHIPS and Science Act for semiconductor manufacturing—he has not made extensive public statements specifically about artificial intelligence.

Key technology-related activities found:

1. **Data Privacy & Surveillance Concerns**: Doggett has been leading efforts to investigate the Trump administration's partnership with Palantir Technologies to build a centralized database of Americans' personal information. He has described this as creating 'a master file on every American' and warned about surveillance state risks. While Palantir is an AI/data analytics company, his focus has been on privacy and data protection rather than AI capabilities themselves.

2. **REAL Act**: He is listed as connected to H.R. 6571, the 'Responsible and Ethical AI Labeling Act,' which requires federal officials to disclose when content has been created or altered using generative AI. However, he appears to be a cosponsor rather than the primary sponsor (Rep. Bill Foster introduced it in December 2025).

3. **CHIPS Act Support**: In 2022, Doggett voted for the CHIPS and Science Act, emphasizing Austin's role in semiconductor development and national security, though his statements focused on semiconductors and manufacturing rather than AI specifically.

4. **Technology Policy Generally**: He has been a consistent advocate for net neutrality, internet privacy, and protecting consumers from tech company overreach. He opposed repealing internet privacy rules and has supported policies fostering innovation while protecting privacy.

**Limitation**: Despite extensive searches across congressional records, press releases, speeches, and news sources, I could not locate any direct quotes from Rep. Doggett specifically discussing:
- Artificial general intelligence (AGI)
- AI existential risk or safety concerns
- China's AI development or AI competition
- Views on whether AI is transformative or overhyped
- Specific AI companies (beyond Palantir in a data privacy context)
- AI alignment or technical AI safety issues

This absence of public statements on AI may indicate that AI policy has not been a primary focus area for him, or that his views have not been extensively documented in accessible public sources. His technology work has been more focused on traditional tech policy issues like privacy, net neutrality, and telecommunications regulation.

Charles J. \"Chuck\" Fleischmann.summary: Rep. Fleischmann's AI statements are limited and focused primarily on U.S. competitiveness and winning the 'AI race' against China. His perspective emphasizes AI development through national laboratories and energy infrastructure, with a strong focus on maintaining American dominance. He does not appear to have made extensive public statements on AI safety, alignment, or existential risk.

quotes.quote: I'm honored to have welcomed Energy Secretary Chris Wright to East Tennessee and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory to highlight the outstanding work that ORNL is doing to advance breakthroughs in AI and supercomputing
quotes.source: Press release, March 6, 2025
quotes.context: Statement regarding hosting Energy Secretary at Oak Ridge National Laboratory to showcase AI and supercomputing work

quotes.quote: In order for the U.S. to win the Artificial Intelligence race, we need computing power and energy, and Tennessee has both
quotes.source: Senator Hagerty quoted in Fleischmann press release, March 6, 2025
quotes.context: Context of visit to Oak Ridge National Laboratory, emphasizing infrastructure needed for AI development

quotes.quote: I look forward to partnering with Sec. Wright over the next four years to create America's New Golden Age, win the AI Arms Race, and make our country energy dominant again
quotes.source: Press release, March 6, 2025
quotes.context: Statement about working with Energy Secretary on AI competitiveness

quotes.quote: I applaud the Department of Energy and Secretary Dabbar for the creation of the new Artificial Intelligence and Technology Office. This facility will help enable DOE to advance its work in the field of AI and keep our nation at the forefront of innovations
quotes.source: DOE press release, 2019
quotes.context: Supporting the creation of DOE's Artificial Intelligence and Technology Office

quotes.quote: [Fleischmann] questioned the Directors about how the country's National Laboratories are partnering with private sector companies to develop and commercialize groundbreaking technologies such as fusion energy and AI
quotes.source: Congressional hearing description, House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology
quotes.context: Participating in hearing with National Laboratory Directors about public-private partnerships in emerging technologies

quotes.quote: Given the economic and national security implications of high-performance computing, falling behind China in this race is not an outcome the United States or the world can afford
quotes.source: The Hill op-ed, June 25, 2020
quotes.context: Op-ed about high-performance computing and supercomputers, discussing competition with China

quotes.quote: It is incredibly important that we continue to support our American high-performance computing so that the United States can not only remain competitive but also continue to dominate the globe in our technical advancements and research capabilities
quotes.source: The Hill op-ed, June 25, 2020
quotes.context: Discussing the importance of maintaining U.S. leadership in supercomputing technology

Charles J. \"Chuck\" Fleischmann.notes: Rep. Fleischmann's public statements on AI are very limited and primarily focused on: (1) U.S. competitiveness against China in AI and supercomputing; (2) supporting AI development through national laboratories, particularly Oak Ridge National Laboratory in his district; (3) the importance of energy infrastructure and computing power for AI development; (4) framing AI as part of an 'arms race' that America must win. He does not appear to have made public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, AI ethics, or specific AI companies/figures. His focus is on maintaining American technological dominance and supporting research institutions in his district. As Chairman of Energy and Water Appropriations with Oak Ridge National Lab in his district, his AI interest appears primarily tied to funding and supporting national laboratory research rather than broader AI policy questions. He sits on the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology but has not been a prominent voice in congressional AI policy debates. I was unable to find 10 substantive quotes specifically about AI from Rep. Fleischmann - the available public record suggests he has not been extensively engaged in public discourse about artificial intelligence policy beyond supporting research funding and U.S. competitiveness.

Virginia Foxx.summary: Virginia Foxx, Chair of the House Education and Workforce Committee (R-NC), has made very limited public statements about artificial intelligence. The only identified AI-related statement concerns her criticism of the Biden administration's use of AI in student loan forgiveness policy. No comprehensive AI policy positions, speeches, or testimony on AI were found.

quotes.quote: uses the term 'hardship with great ambiguity and proposes to enact a regulation using a 17-factor artificial intelligence data model to determine who automatically receives loan forgiveness
quotes.source: Letter to Education Secretary Cardona, December 3, 2024
quotes.context: Foxx criticized the Biden administration's proposed student loan forgiveness rule that would use AI to automatically determine eligibility for loan forgiveness based on financial hardship, calling it 'clearly unlawful.'

Virginia Foxx.notes: Despite extensive research across multiple databases, congressional hearing records, committee documents, and news sources, only one substantive quote about AI was found from Virginia Foxx.
