quotes.quote: And when you see some states starting to put a patchwork of limitations, that's why it's come to the federal government's attention to allow for an open marketplace, so you don't have limitations that hurt innovation
quotes.source: The Hill, December 2025
quotes.context: Scalise explaining why federal preemption of state AI laws is necessary

quotes.quote: over-burdensome regulations could make the U.S. fall behind competitors like China
quotes.source: Fox News Digital, June 2024
quotes.context: Scalise expressing concerns about AI regulation in the context of international competition

quotes.quote: We need to find a place to do it... But we're still looking at other places because there's still an interest. You know, you've seen the president talk about it.
quotes.source: The Hill, December 2025
quotes.context: Scalise discussing continued Republican efforts to block state AI laws after failing to include it in the NDAA

quotes.quote: If there are gaps in the laws, those are things we'd want to look at. But no new heavy regulations and billions of dollars of government money to do what's already being done in the private sector. Those aren't areas we are interested in.
quotes.source: Punchbowl News, November 2024
quotes.context: Scalise clarifying that House Republicans would only address specific legal gaps, not create comprehensive AI regulation

Steve Scalise.notes: Steve Scalise's AI views are primarily focused on economic competitiveness and maintaining American technological dominance. He frequently references China as justification for minimal regulation. He compares state-level AI regulation to Europe's approach, which he views as having 'wrecked their innovation.' Scalise has been actively working with the Trump administration and tech industry lobbyists (including companies like Meta, OpenAI, Google, and investors like Marc Andreessen) to block state AI laws. He views AI through an economic lens - emphasizing the billions in investment at stake. Notably absent from his public statements are any discussions of AI safety, alignment, existential risk, or AGI. His position represents the House Republican leadership's stance: no new agencies, no licensing requirements, no significant government spending on AI R&D, and opposition to regulations that could slow innovation. He has met with President Trump to coordinate on AI policy and has been described as 'effectively charged with developing policy for House Republicans' on this issue.

Janice D. Schakowsky.summary: Rep. Schakowsky approaches AI primarily through a consumer protection lens, viewing it as a technology that poses significant risks to families, children, and vulnerable populations if left unregulated. She is highly critical of Republican efforts to prevent AI regulation and consistently frames AI issues around concrete harms like scams, deepfakes, privacy violations, and healthcare denials rather than abstract existential concerns.

quotes.quote: That's what I'm always, always thinking about and the very idea that we are going to allow 10 years of right for the intelligence, for all kinds of scams that could be happening and instead of 10 years for AI. I mean that's just insane and I can't understand why we would do that.
quotes.source: House Subcommittee Hearing on AI Regulation and the Future of US Leadership, May 29, 2025
quotes.context: Schakowsky strongly opposing a Republican proposal for a 10-year moratorium on state AI regulations, emphasizing the need for immediate consumer protections

quotes.quote: Our job right now is to protect consumers and we know that even now that people are getting scammed by issues that come out and we want to make sure that we have that kind of protection. And so I think it is absolutely something we should say zero time. Zero time as we watch AI develop not 10 years.
quotes.source: House Subcommittee Hearing on AI Regulation and the Future of US Leadership, May 29, 2025
quotes.context: Arguing for immediate regulatory action rather than waiting, emphasizing consumer protection as the primary concern

quotes.quote: The Republicans' 10-year ban on the enforcement of state laws protecting consumers from potential dangers of new artificial intelligence systems gives Big Tech free rein to take advantage of children and families. It is a giant gift to Big Tech and once again shows that Republicans care more about profits than people.
quotes.source: Press Release, May 2025
quotes.context: Criticizing Republican AI regulation ban proposal as favoring corporate interests over consumer protection

quotes.quote: This ban will allow AI companies to ignore consumer privacy protections, let deepfakes spread, and allow companies to profile and deceive consumers using AI.
quotes.source: Statement on GOP AI regulation ban, May 2025
quotes.context: Detailing specific harms she believes will result from blocking state AI regulations

quotes.quote: As of late, Artificial Intelligence (AI) has made matters even worse by deceiving people who think they are talking to another human, when in actuality, they are talking to a bot.
quotes.source: Press Release on R U REAL Act, January 29, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to curb AI robocalls and require disclosure of AI use in telemarketing

quotes.quote: This means that patients' medical decisions — from what medications they can take to which procedures they can undergo — will be made by a bot run by private contractors who prioritize profits over patient safety.
quotes.source: Resolution condemning Medicare WISeR Model, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Opposing the use of AI in Medicare prior authorization decisions, citing concerns about profit-driven healthcare denials

quotes.quote: Moreover, some Medicare Advantage plans that already use AI in prior authorization decisions have been found to have error rates as high as 90%.
quotes.source: Resolution condemning Medicare WISeR Model, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Highlighting the unreliability of AI systems currently being used in healthcare decision-making

quotes.quote: We're talking about AI today, but I have to tell you that I and Gus Bilirakis on the Republican side have been working on the issue of privacy for a very, very long time and even more before that with all kinds of tech interests, but we have never done anything to reign in big tech, nothing whatsoever.
quotes.source: House Hearing on AI's Role in Energy and Climate, July 12, 2025
quotes.context: Expressing frustration with Congress's failure to regulate technology companies, viewing AI as part of a broader pattern of inadequate tech oversight

quotes.quote: I appreciate the work and the thought that you've given to this, and I think all of us members of Congress ought to put consumers first. And if we need to do some smart regulation, then that's what we ought to be having a conversation about.
quotes.source: House Subcommittee Hearing on AI Regulation, May 29, 2025
quotes.context: Advocating for consumer-focused AI regulation and expressing openness to thoughtful regulatory approaches

quotes.quote: My bill restricts any telemarketer from using an AI bot that sounds like a human without first telling you that it is AI, and it holds telemarketers accountable for using AI
quotes.source: Press Release on R U REAL Act, January 29, 2024
quotes.context: Describing her legislation requiring disclosure and doubling penalties for AI-powered robocall violations

Janice D. Schakowsky.notes: Schakowsky's AI stance is heavily focused on immediate, tangible consumer harms rather than abstract or long-term concerns. She does not engage with debates about AGI, existential risk, or AI alignment. Her statements never reference China or international AI competition, which is notable given that many of her Republican colleagues frame AI policy around competing with China. Instead, she consistently frames AI issues through the lens of consumer protection, corporate accountability, and vulnerable populations (children, families, seniors). She is particularly concerned about: (1) AI-powered scams and deepfakes, (2) AI in healthcare decision-making (especially Medicare denials), (3) Big Tech's influence over policy, and (4) the need for immediate rather than delayed regulation. She views Republican efforts to preempt state AI regulations as gifts to Big Tech. Her approach is pragmatic and focused on specific use cases (robocalls, prior authorization, deepfakes) rather than the technology's broader societal implications. As a retiring member (announced May 2025), she has been outspoken in her final term about the need for stronger tech regulation. She is the Ranking Member of the House Innovation, Data, and Commerce Subcommittee.

Adam B. Schiff.summary: Senator Adam Schiff views AI as a transformative technology with both significant potential and serious risks that require robust regulation. His primary focus has been on protecting creators through copyright transparency, addressing AI-generated misinformation and deepfakes as threats to democracy, and ensuring proper guardrails are in place. He emphasizes the need for federal action while supporting state-level protections when federal leadership is absent.

quotes.quote: AI has the potential to improve our lives and fundamentally change the way we work and live, but it's critical that we ensure there are guardrails to mitigate potential harms to users and consumers.
quotes.source: Senate statement on Trump AI Executive Order, December 12, 2025
quotes.context: Schiff criticized President Trump's executive order that preempted state AI laws, emphasizing the need for regulatory safeguards.

quotes.quote: AI has the disruptive potential of changing our economy, our political system, and our day-to-day lives. We must balance the immense potential of AI with the crucial need for ethical guidelines and protections.
quotes.source: Statement on Generative AI Copyright Disclosure Act, April 2024
quotes.context: Schiff introduced legislation requiring companies to disclose copyrighted works used to train AI models.

quotes.quote: There are a whole set of areas where I think AI regulation is necessary to protect children, to protect privacy, but also to protect creators, to make sure that they are compensated for their work like anyone else.
quotes.source: Deadline interview, December 12, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the need for comprehensive AI regulation across multiple domains.

quotes.quote: There's no doubt that AI has the potential to change our economy, our political system, our day to day life in potentially very good ways and also very disruptive ways.
quotes.source: House Judiciary Subcommittee hearing on AI and Intellectual Property, April 2024
quotes.context: Testifying about the dual nature of AI's impact on society.

quotes.quote: This is about respecting creativity in the age of AI and marrying technological progress with fairness.
quotes.source: Statement on Generative AI Copyright Disclosure Act, April 2024
quotes.context: Explaining the philosophy behind his AI transparency legislation.

quotes.quote: For more than a year, I've been pushing government agencies and tech companies to recognize and take action against the next wave of disinformation that could come in the form of 'deepfakes' — AI-generated video, audio, and images that are difficult or impossible to distinguish from real thing.
quotes.source: Statement on Facebook's Deepfake Policy, January 2020
quotes.context: Expressing concern about AI-generated misinformation as a national security threat.

quotes.quote: In that environment, people just fall back on party affiliation or other associations as a proxy for the truth. And that's a dangerous thing for democracy.
quotes.source: The Hill interview on deepfakes, June 2019
quotes.context: Warning about how deepfakes could undermine democratic discourse and truth.

quotes.quote: AI-powered chatbots present an unprecedented and unique danger to minors engaged in longer and unsupervised interactions with these systems.
quotes.source: Letter to FTC on AI chatbot risks to children, October 2025
quotes.context: Urging federal action to protect children from harmful AI chatbot interactions following a teenager's suicide.

quotes.quote: You would be hard pressed to find a(n) occupation, profession, job that AI couldn't do some part of. And this is the danger that...the increased productivity of the country over time has not been shared...It has left too many millions of people behind, and it threatens to do so again, and even in a more accelerated fashion.
quotes.source: Council on Foreign Relations discussion, July 2023
quotes.context: Discussing AI's potential to displace workers and exacerbate economic inequality.

quotes.quote: America must maintain its competitive edge in artificial intelligence and remain the world leader in innovation. To do that, we need adequate data center infrastructure...This infrastructure must be developed responsibly and in accordance with federal environmental statutes.
quotes.source: Letter to EPA and Army Corps on AI data centers, September 2025
quotes.context: Balancing AI competitiveness with environmental protection concerns.

Adam B. Schiff.notes:
Adam Schiff's AI policy focus is primarily practical and regulatory rather than focused on existential risk or AGI scenarios. His concerns center on: (1) Copyright protection and creator compensation through his Generative AI Copyright Disclosure Act; (2) Deepfakes and AI-generated misinformation as threats to democracy and national security - he was an early voice warning about this as Chair of the House Intelligence Committee; (3) Protection of vulnerable populations, especially children; (4) Worker displacement and economic inequality; (5) Balancing innovation with environmental protection. 

He references China in the context of his broader intelligence and national security work, particularly regarding technology-driven authoritarianism and surveillance, but not specifically in AI competition terms. He has engaged with major tech companies (Facebook, Google, Twitter) about their deepfake policies and criticized their responses. He co-sponsored the TRAIN Act with bipartisan senators including Marsha Blackburn to help creators protect copyrighted works from AI training. 

Schiff does not appear 'AGI-pilled' or focused on long-term existential risk scenarios. His approach is grounded in immediate, tangible harms: misinformation, copyright theft, child safety, and economic disruption. He consistently advocates for federal regulation while defending state-level protections when federal action is lacking. As the top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Intellectual Property, he is well-positioned to influence AI policy going forward.

Charles E. Schumer.summary: Senator Schumer views AI as the most important and transformative development of our time, requiring urgent bipartisan action. He emphasizes both the tremendous potential benefits (curing diseases, improving national security) and serious risks (job displacement, election interference, national security threats from China). He advocates for a balanced 'SAFE Innovation' framework that promotes innovation while establishing guardrails, with significant federal investment ($32 billion annually) to maintain U.S. leadership over China.

quotes.quote: AI is the most important development in our time. It's broad-based. It touches every aspect of society.
quotes.source: SCSP AI Expo for National Competitiveness, May 2024
quotes.context: Explaining why he prioritized AI policy despite a divided Congress in an election year, comparing its importance to major legislation like CHIPS Act

quotes.quote: What the locomotive and electricity did for human muscle a century and a half ago, Artificial Intelligence is doing for human knowledge today, as we speak.
quotes.source: SAFE Innovation Framework Launch at CSIS, June 21, 2023
quotes.context: Characterizing AI as a revolutionary, transformative technology comparable to major industrial innovations

quotes.quote: If we don't do anything, China could get ahead of us.
quotes.source: SCSP AI Expo for National Competitiveness, May 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing the urgency of action on AI due to competition with China

quotes.quote: If China gains the lead in AI, they will become the number one economy in the world, they will set the values – authoritarian, not democratic values – and Americans will suffer.
quotes.source: Senate Floor Remarks on Second AI Insight Forum, October 25, 2023
quotes.context: Warning about the geopolitical and values-based stakes of the AI race with China

quotes.quote: In the hands of foreign adversaries—especially autocracies—or domestic rogue groups interested in extortionist financial gain or political upheaval, the dangers of AI could be extreme.
quotes.source: SAFE Innovation Framework Launch at CSIS, June 21, 2023
quotes.context: Discussing security risks from AI as part of his SAFE Innovation framework

quotes.quote: We do not know what Artificial Intelligence will be capable of two years from now, fifty years from now, one hundred years from now.
quotes.source: SAFE Innovation Framework Launch at CSIS, June 21, 2023
quotes.context: Acknowledging uncertainty about AI's future capabilities and potential risks

quotes.quote: AI is going to be the most transformative thing affecting us in the next decades. It's going to affect every aspect of life.
quotes.source: Interview before First AI Insight Forum, September 2023
quotes.context: Justifying his unprecedented focus on AI policy as Senate Majority Leader

quotes.quote: The idea of curing cancer, that's going to make billions of people around the world happy, or curing world hunger, or prevent us from being attacked.
quotes.source: SCSP AI Expo for National Competitiveness, May 2024
quotes.context: Highlighting the positive potential of AI development

quotes.quote: I asked everyone in the room does government need to play a role in regulating AI, and every single person raised their hand, even though they had diverse views.
quotes.source: Press conference after First AI Insight Forum with tech CEOs, September 13, 2023
quotes.context: Reporting unanimous agreement among tech leaders including Musk, Zuckerberg, Altman, and Gates on need for government regulation

quotes.quote: The Chinese Communist Party, which has little regard for the norms of democratic governance, could leap ahead of us and set the rules of the game for AI. Democracy could enter an era of steep decline.
quotes.source: SAFE Innovation Framework Launch at CSIS, June 21, 2023
quotes.context: Warning about the threat to democratic values if China leads in AI development

Charles E. Schumer.notes: Schumer is deeply engaged with AI policy, having organized nine bipartisan AI Insight Forums with major tech CEOs (Musk, Zuckerberg, Altman, Gates, Pichai, Nadella) and diverse stakeholders. He frequently references China as the primary competitive threat, mentioning China/Chinese government dozens of times across speeches. While he acknowledges existential risks and held a 'doomsday scenarios' forum with OpenAI and Anthropic representatives, he's not fully 'AGI-pilled' - his approach is more balanced, focusing on near-term risks like election interference, job displacement, and national security. He released a comprehensive bipartisan AI roadmap in May 2024 calling for $32 billion annual investment. His SAFE Innovation framework emphasizes Security, Accountability, Foundations (democratic values), and Explainability. He views regulation as necessary but warns against moving 'too fast' like the EU. Notable quote about Eric Schmidt: praised his leadership at SCSP. His stance is pragmatic: maximize benefits while establishing guardrails, with strong emphasis on maintaining U.S. technological leadership over China.

David Schweikert.summary: Rep. David Schweikert (R-AZ) is a strong AI advocate who views artificial intelligence as essential and transformative for addressing America's fiscal crisis, particularly in healthcare and government efficiency. He emphasizes AI adoption is not optional given demographic and debt challenges, warns about societal disruption from deepfakes, and advocates for flexible regulation that doesn't stifle innovation.

quotes.quote: The industrialized world, particularly in the United States, we're in trouble. We have remarkable debt build up, we have a demographic curve, we're getting old very fast and along with a number of things we have to do, we have to get dramatically more efficient and we have to cut down cost externalities.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast interview, March 2025
quotes.context: Schweikert explaining why AI adoption is critical for the U.S., linking it directly to fiscal sustainability and demographic challenges.

quotes.quote: It's shocking how many people freak out about starting to use AI and these things. You don't have a choice!
quotes.source: House Floor Speech, January 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing that AI adoption is mandatory, not optional, for maintaining economic growth and productivity given declining birth rates and aging population.

quotes.quote: I don't think society is completely ready for a natural language voicemail you get that sounds like your grandma or a video like this where someone has taken our language and changed us, and I see chaos coming in society.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast interview, March 2025
quotes.context: Warning about societal disruption from deepfakes and AI-generated content, particularly regarding misinformation and manipulated media.

quotes.quote: Technology has to be part of the way we bend the borrowing and debt curve. [AI] can make government better, faster, cheaper in responding to the needs of Americans.
quotes.source: Nextgov/FCW interview, July 2024
quotes.context: Articulating his core belief that AI is essential for fiscal responsibility and government efficiency.

quotes.quote: Design policy that allows the disruption, allows the creativity, and maybe move away from everything we thought we knew from a previous decade.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast interview, March 2025
quotes.context: Advocating for flexible AI regulation that adapts to rapid technological advancement and doesn't stifle innovation.

quotes.quote: We need a more educated and questioning public to combat the dangers of manipulated media.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast interview, March 2025
quotes.context: Addressing concerns about deepfakes and misinformation, emphasizing education over heavy-handed regulation.

quotes.quote: Unless you have a revolution in the cost of providing health services of making our brothers and sisters healthier, I don't know how we're going to finance it.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast interview, March 2025
quotes.context: Explaining why AI-driven healthcare transformation is financially necessary, not just beneficial.

quotes.quote: We can make digital twins of the human body to take the drug discovery from decades down to months, maybe a hundred days for the next vaccine.
quotes.source: Joint Economic Committee hearing transcript, June 2024
quotes.context: Describing AI's transformative potential in healthcare and drug development, showing understanding of advanced AI applications.

quotes.quote: It turns out a couple of the audit companies, CPA companies, compliance companies have come up with audit AI — artificial intelligence — that crawls through the books, crawls through the inventory, crawls through the asset lists.
quotes.source: House Floor Speech, May 2024
quotes.context: Explaining his proposal to use AI to audit the Pentagon after six consecutive failed audits, demonstrating practical applications.

quotes.quote: Schweikert also underscored the importance of international cooperation in AI regulation, noting that global collaboration is necessary to curb malicious use of the technology and ensure ethical standards.
quotes.source: American Bazaar article, March 2025
quotes.context: Acknowledging the need for international coordination on AI governance and security concerns.

David Schweikert.notes: Schweikert is one of the most pro-AI members of Congress, with a focus heavily weighted toward practical applications rather than theoretical concerns. His AI advocacy is driven primarily by fiscal concerns - he sees AI as essential for addressing America's debt crisis, aging demographics, and healthcare costs. He has introduced multiple AI-related bills, particularly the Healthy Technology Act allowing AI to prescribe drugs, and amendments requiring Pentagon AI audits. While he acknowledges risks like deepfakes and societal disruption, he does not discuss existential risk, AGI, or technical AI safety/alignment issues. He mentions international cooperation for ethical standards but does not specifically reference China or AI competition (though he generally references 'the industrialized world'). He emphasizes the need for flexible regulation that enables innovation rather than restricts it. His stance is pragmatic and economically driven - viewing AI as a necessary tool for government efficiency and cost reduction, particularly in healthcare. He serves as Vice Chairman of the Joint Economic Committee and has held hearings on AI's economic potential.

Austin Scott.summary: Rep. Austin Scott (R-GA) has maintained a very low public profile on artificial intelligence issues. Despite serving on the House Intelligence Committee and Armed Services Committee, there is minimal publicly available information about his views on AI policy, development, safety, or risks. His public statements focus primarily on agriculture, national security, and China as a general adversary.
Austin Scott.notes: After extensive research, I was unable to find 10 quotes (or even a single substantial quote) from Rep. Austin Scott specifically about artificial intelligence. While Scott has made statements about China being an 'existential threat' to the United States, these comments were in the context of general national security concerns, not AI specifically. His statement that 'Communist China is an existential threat to the United States' (October 2022) referred to broad geopolitical competition, not artificial intelligence development. Scott has spoken about China's 'soft warfare' through cyber systems and technology in agriculture (July 2025), mentioning that China is 'getting ahead of the U.S. on the technology front with farming,' but did not specifically address AI. His committee assignments (House Intelligence, Armed Services, Agriculture) would position him to engage with AI policy, but he has not made public statements on AI safety, AGI, alignment, transformative AI, or AI companies. The only AI-related activity found was his support for the Congressional App Challenge, a STEM education program for students. This lack of public commentary suggests either that AI is not a priority issue for him, or that his views on AI have not been publicly articulated through speeches, press releases, hearings, or media interviews.

David Scott.summary: Rep. David Scott has extremely limited public record on artificial intelligence policy. While he serves on the House Financial Services Committee and Agriculture Committee (where he was formerly Ranking Member), and has been involved in fintech and digital assets regulation, extensive research reveals virtually no substantive public statements specifically addressing AI technology, policy, safety, or governance.
David Scott.notes: Rep. David Scott (D-GA-13) has been in Congress since 2003 and currently serves on the House Financial Services Committee and House Agriculture Committee. While he co-chairs the bipartisan Fintech and Payments Caucus and has introduced legislation related to fintech regulation (such as the FINTECH Act of 2019), and serves on a subcommittee dealing with 'Commodity Markets, Digital Assets, and Rural Development,' there is no substantial public record of him making statements specifically about artificial intelligence. His legislative focus has been primarily on agriculture, financial services, fintech, digital assets/cryptocurrency, and rural development. The House did receive a bipartisan AI Task Force report in 2024, but Scott was not a member of that task force and no public statements from him about the report were found. He is 80 years old (born 1945) and has faced recent scrutiny regarding his engagement level. Without specific quotes or policy positions on AI, it is impossible to assess his views on AGI, transformative potential, existential risk, AI safety, alignment, or China competition in the AI domain.

Robert C. \"Bobby\" Scott.summary: Rep. Bobby Scott's public statements on AI are limited and primarily focused on worker protection and workplace impacts. He has expressed concern about the Trump administration's approach to AI regulation and appears cautious about AI's potential harms to workers, but has not made extensive public statements on broader AI policy issues.

quotes.quote: Congress should not stand idly by while the Trump administration may be ingratiating itself to big tech CEOs and preventing states from protecting Americans against the dangers of AI.
quotes.source: House Education and Workforce Committee hearing, January 15, 2026
quotes.context: Scott made this statement during a committee hearing on AI regulation in schools, expressing concern about the administration's approach to AI oversight.

quotes.quote: The rise of AI in the workplace—as with any new technology—may displace jobs, violate workers' privacy, pose obstacles to workers' right to organize and collectively bargain, and exert a disparate impact on people of color, women, older people, and people with disabilities.
quotes.source: Roundtable on Artificial Intelligence in the Workplace, 2023
quotes.context: From Scott's opening remarks at a roundtable he hosted as Ranking Member on the Education and Workforce Committee, focusing on AI's risks to workers.

quotes.quote: But our job in Congress is to do everything we can to ensure that the changing economy does not undermine the financial security, civil rights, and labor-market opportunities of American workers.
quotes.source: Roundtable on Artificial Intelligence in the Workplace, 2023
quotes.context: Scott emphasized Congress's responsibility to protect workers amid technological change during his AI workplace roundtable.

Robert C. \"Bobby\" Scott.notes: Rep. Bobby Scott has made very few public statements specifically about AI. His focus appears to be primarily on labor and worker protection issues related to AI adoption in the workplace. As the Ranking Member (formerly Chair) of the House Education and Workforce Committee, his AI engagement has been through that lens—examining how AI affects workers, education, and employment. He hosted a roundtable on AI in the workplace in 2023 and participated in recent hearings (January 2026) on AI in education. However, he has not made extensive public statements on broader AI policy issues such as AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, or competition with China. His recent statement criticizing the Trump administration's approach to AI regulation suggests he favors more oversight and state-level protections. Scott's legislative focus remains on traditional labor issues (minimum wage, union rights, civil rights) rather than AI-specific policy. The limited public record suggests he views AI through a workers' rights and civil rights framework rather than as a transformative technology requiring specialized governance.

Tim Scott.summary: Senator Tim Scott views AI primarily through an economic competitiveness lens, emphasizing its potential to drive U.S. economic growth and the need to maintain American leadership against China. His statements focus on practical applications in financial services and the importance of innovation-friendly regulation rather than existential risks or safety concerns.

quotes.quote: As artificial intelligence technology continues to advance, David's efforts will be critical to ensuring that this next generation technology drives growth in the U.S. economy.
quotes.source: Statement on meeting with David Sacks, December 17, 2024
quotes.context: Scott discussing the role of Trump's incoming White House AI and Crypto Czar in promoting AI-driven economic growth

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is reshaping our markets and our economy…As Chairman, I've been encouraged by AI's potential to strengthen financial literacy, protect investors, and help America stay ahead of China.
quotes.source: Statement following meeting with NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang, December 2025
quotes.context: Scott explaining his optimistic view of AI after a closed-door meeting with NVIDIA leadership

quotes.quote: Maintaining that edge also means protecting sensitive U.S. technology through strong export controls and ensuring innovators have access to the capital they need to build here at home, including modernizing how companies raise funds in both private and public markets. Our focus is on practical, responsible policies that keep America competitive.
quotes.source: Statement on NVIDIA meeting, December 2025
quotes.context: Scott outlining his approach to AI policy balancing innovation with national security

quotes.quote: That means everything from how we review our sanctions, to how we take a look at [the] chip conversation that you've seen over the last several days, [and] artificial intelligence being a part of that conversation as well.
quotes.source: Fox News Digital interview on NDAA, December 2025
quotes.context: Scott discussing China-focused provisions in the defense bill including AI and semiconductor restrictions

quotes.quote: [We need to] position America for the long run against China.
quotes.source: Fox News interview on defense bill provisions, December 2025
quotes.context: Scott explaining the strategic rationale for including AI and chip provisions targeting China in the NDAA

quotes.quote: I think the most effective weapon we have, and the more we use our economic weapons, the better off we are as a nation, frankly, as a world.
quotes.source: Fox News interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Scott discussing the use of economic tools including AI and chip restrictions against adversaries

quotes.quote: Google's investment in South Carolina is a testament to our state's vital role as a hub for America's digital economy and a global leader in AI innovation. This expansion is welcome news that will strengthen our workforce and reinforce our position at the forefront of technology.
quotes.source: Statement on Google's $9B South Carolina investment, 2026
quotes.context: Scott praising tech investment in his home state and positioning it as AI innovation hub

quotes.quote: For the Chinese Communist Party, the line between civilian and military research is non-existent. When a Chinese surveillance balloon violated our sovereignty using American technology, we witnessed how the Science and Technology Agreement between our two nations could be used against us.
quotes.source: Statement on Science and Technology Agreement Enhanced Congressional Notification Act, September 2023
quotes.context: Scott expressing concerns about technology transfer to China, including AI-relevant technologies

quotes.quote: [The Banking Committee will] provide clear rules of the road for new and innovative financial technologies and service providers; and ensure that consumers are equipped with the tools to make informed decisions for themselves and are protected from bad actors.
quotes.source: Banking Committee priorities for 119th Congress, 2025
quotes.context: Scott outlining his approach to regulating emerging technologies including AI applications in financial services

quotes.quote: The committee will also foster an open-minded environment for new, innovative financial technologies and digital asset products, like stablecoins, that promote financial inclusivity.
quotes.source: Banking Committee priorities statement, 2025
quotes.context: Scott describing his pro-innovation regulatory philosophy that would apply to AI and other emerging technologies

Tim Scott.notes: Tim Scott's public statements on AI are notably limited and focused almost entirely on economic competitiveness and national security vis-à-vis China. As Senate Banking Committee Chair, his engagement with AI has been primarily through the lens of financial services applications and meetings with industry leaders like NVIDIA's Jensen Huang. He consistently frames AI as an economic opportunity and emphasizes the need for 'practical, responsible policies' that promote innovation while maintaining U.S. technological leadership. Notably absent from his public statements are any discussions of: AGI timelines, existential risk from AI, AI safety or alignment concerns, or philosophical questions about AI's impact on humanity. His approach appears pragmatic and business-oriented, viewing AI regulation through the same lens as his work on digital assets - favoring clear rules that encourage domestic innovation while using economic tools to counter adversaries like China. He has not participated in the broader AI safety discourse that has engaged some other members of Congress. His focus remains on ensuring American companies can compete globally and that AI contributes to U.S. economic growth.

Terri A. Sewell.summary: Rep. Terri Sewell has limited public statements specifically about AI. Her primary documented AI concern focuses on election security and protecting voting rights from AI-generated misinformation, particularly targeting Black and minority voters. She has not made extensive public statements on broader AI policy issues such as AGI, existential risk, or AI safety/alignment.

quotes.quote: despite our country's improved election security, the growing influence of AI software has raised concerns about the potential harm to our democratic process
quotes.source: Bipartisan letter to DOJ, DHS, and EAC, March 13, 2024
quotes.context: Rep. Sewell co-led a bipartisan letter with Rep. Shontel Brown requesting information about AI use to intimidate, threaten, or misinform voters during the 2024 election cycle

quotes.quote: We urge you to consider all its possible uses and ramifications in the electoral process, including its weaponization by adversaries of the United States
quotes.source: Bipartisan letter to DOJ, DHS, and EAC, March 13, 2024
quotes.context: The letter specifically mentions concern about foreign adversaries weaponizing AI in U.S. elections

quotes.quote: Generations of Americans, including many in Alabama's 7th Congressional District, fought to ensure that every eligible voter can cast their ballot in free and fair elections. We cannot allow bad actors to weaponize powerful AI tools to mislead voters, suppress turnout, and sow chaos
quotes.source: Press release, March 13, 2024
quotes.context: Statement on AI threats to election integrity, particularly focused on voter suppression

quotes.quote: With only eight months until November, the time is now for our federal agencies to protect Americans against such threats, especially Black voters who have been disproportionately targeted by election mis-information and dis-information
quotes.source: Press release, March 13, 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing urgency of federal action on AI-generated misinformation targeting minority communities

Terri A. Sewell.notes: Rep. Sewell's public statements on AI are extremely limited and focused narrowly on election security and voting rights. While she mentions 'adversaries of the United States' in the context of AI weaponization, she does not specifically name China or other countries. Her background includes serving on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence (115th-116th Congress) and currently serves on the House Ways and Means Committee and House Administration Committee (Elections subcommittee), which positions her to address AI policy, but she has not made extensive public statements on broader AI issues such as AGI development, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, or specific AI companies. Her primary documented concern is protecting voting rights and preventing AI-generated misinformation, particularly targeting Black and minority voters. She supported the Birmingham Biotechnology Hub (2023) which utilizes AI-driven biotechnology, showing some support for beneficial AI applications in her district. She has not publicly discussed transformative AI capabilities, AI safety research, or engaged with debates about AI existential risk that are common among some policymakers.

Brad Sherman.summary: Brad Sherman is one of the earliest and most prescient Congressional voices on AI existential risk, having warned about superintelligent AI as far back as 2007. He views engineered intelligence as 'more explosive than even the spread of nuclear weapons' and has consistently advocated for AI safety research focused on avoiding self-awareness and ambition in AI systems. His stance is deeply concerned about transformative AI while maintaining interest in China's technological competition.

quotes.quote: There is one issue that I think is more explosive than even the spread of nuclear weapons: engineered intelligence.
quotes.source: World Healthcare Innovation and Technology Conference, December 10, 2007 (Updated October 2013)
quotes.context: Sherman's keynote speech where he outlined his core concerns about AI, comparing it unfavorably to nuclear weapons as an existential threat.

quotes.quote: I believe in our lifetime we will see new species possessing intelligence which surpasses our own. The last time a new higher level of intelligence arose on this planet was roughly 50,000 years ago. It was our own ancestors, who then said hello to the previously most intelligent species, Neanderthals. It did not work out so well for the Neanderthals.
quotes.source: World Healthcare Innovation and Technology Conference, December 10, 2007
quotes.context: Sherman drawing historical parallels to warn about the dangers of creating superintelligent systems.

quotes.quote: I have urged DARPA to develop computer systems designed to maximize the computer's utility, while avoiding self-awareness, or at least ambition.
quotes.source: World Healthcare Innovation and Technology Conference, December 10, 2007
quotes.context: Sherman's specific policy recommendation for AI development, showing his focus on AI alignment and safety.

quotes.quote: I would just stress how important it is, as we deal with artificial intelligence, to not just focus on the immediate problem at hand, how to develop a computer that will give us better insight into weather, et cetera, or whatever else we're focusing on, but that we also focus on avoiding self-awareness and ambition.
quotes.source: House Science Committee Members' Day Hearing, May 17, 2019
quotes.context: Sherman reiterating his longstanding concern about AI self-awareness and ambition more than a decade after his original speech.

quotes.quote: I look forward to exploring the benefits and risks of new levels of intelligence, both artificial intelligence and genetic engineering. I have read with interest the comments of Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, among others.
quotes.source: Press release upon returning to House Science Committee, November 8, 2019
quotes.context: Sherman acknowledging prominent AI safety voices and positioning himself as engaged with existential risk concerns.

quotes.quote: In testimony at the House Science Committee, the consensus of experts testifying was that in roughly 25 years we would have a computer that passed the Turing Test, and more importantly, exceeded human intelligence. As we develop more intelligent computers, we will find them useful tools in creating ever more intelligent computers, a positive feedback loop.
quotes.source: World Healthcare Innovation and Technology Conference, December 10, 2007
quotes.context: Sherman describing the intelligence explosion scenario and recursive self-improvement concerns.

quotes.quote: I don't know whether we will create the maniacal Hal from 2001, or the earnest Data from Star Trek --- or perhaps both.
quotes.source: World Healthcare Innovation and Technology Conference, December 10, 2007
quotes.context: Using science fiction references to illustrate the uncertainty about AI outcomes.

quotes.quote: I chaired the House Subcommittee on Nonproliferation which deals with the only other technologies that pose an existential threat to humankind, namely the proliferation of nuclear and biological weapons.
quotes.source: World Healthcare Innovation and Technology Conference, December 10, 2007
quotes.context: Sherman drawing on his expertise in existential threats from his role on the Nonproliferation Subcommittee to frame AI risk.

quotes.quote: For too long China has been stealing U.S. technology and jobs with impunity and it is increasingly trying to influence public opinion in the United States.
quotes.source: Press release on U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Act of 2019, April 20, 2021
quotes.context: Sherman expressing concerns about China's technology acquisition and influence operations, relevant to AI competition.

quotes.quote: We are going to live in a science fiction movie, we just don't know which one.
quotes.source: World Healthcare Innovation and Technology Conference, December 10, 2007
quotes.context: Sherman's memorable quote capturing the transformative and uncertain nature of AI's future impact.

Brad Sherman.notes: Brad Sherman is remarkably prescient and consistent on AI existential risk, having articulated detailed concerns about superintelligent AI as early as 2007 - years before it became a mainstream topic. He specifically focuses on the dangers of AI 'self-awareness and ambition' and has urged DARPA to prioritize safety in AI development. He explicitly compares AI risk to nuclear weapons proliferation, calling it 'more explosive.' He references the Neanderthal extinction as an analogy for what could happen when a more intelligent species emerges. Sherman has supported bipartisan legislation to prevent Chinese access to advanced AI chips (Chip Security Act, 2025) and has introduced legislation addressing China's technology acquisition. He is a member of the House Science Committee and served on the Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Asia. His views align closely with AI safety researchers like Eliezer Yudkowsky, Nick Bostrom, and the concerns expressed by Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking. He appears to be one of the few members of Congress who deeply understands and takes seriously the long-term existential risks from artificial general intelligence.

Michael K. Simpson.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or quotes from Rep. Mike Simpson specifically addressing artificial intelligence, AI policy, AGI, existential risk, or AI safety could be found. Simpson's public focus has been primarily on appropriations, nuclear energy, water resources, public lands, and traditional conservative policy issues.
Michael K. Simpson.notes: Rep. Mike Simpson (R-ID) serves as Chairman of the House Interior and Environment Appropriations Subcommittee and is known for his work on nuclear energy, water resources, and public lands management. Despite extensive searches through congressional records, press releases, speeches, and news coverage from 2023-2026, no public statements from Simpson addressing AI policy, development, safety, or related issues were found. The only indirect connection to AI was a contextual reference in energy policy discussions noting that AI data centers are driving increased energy demand, which relates to his work on permitting reform for energy infrastructure. Simpson has not participated in AI-focused hearings or task forces based on available records. His legislative priorities appear focused on traditional appropriations, energy (particularly nuclear), environmental issues, and Idaho-specific concerns.

Adam Smith.summary: Rep. Adam Smith approaches AI primarily through a national security and defense lens as Ranking Member of the House Armed Services Committee. His focus is on military applications of AI, competing with China technologically, and ensuring the Pentagon makes smart investments in emerging technologies like AI, quantum computing, and cyber capabilities. He has not made extensive public statements about AGI, existential risk, or AI safety in the broader sense.

quotes.quote: Do we maintain the core capabilities of building the ships, the planes, and increasingly by the way the artificial intelligence, the command and control centers, the cyber strength?
quotes.source: CBS News Intelligence Matters podcast with Michael Morell, December 2019
quotes.context: Smith was discussing what the U.S. military should be capable of, emphasizing that AI capabilities are becoming as important as traditional military hardware like ships and planes.

quotes.quote: Expect artificial intelligence, command-and-control and survivability to be watchwords in the House Armed Services Committee going forward... those topics will be his focus as he supports 'smart' investments in national defense
quotes.source: Defense News interview, October 2020
quotes.context: Smith outlined his priorities as HASC Chairman, emphasizing AI as a key area for defense investment alongside command-and-control systems.

quotes.quote: That's where artificial intelligence, command and control technology come in... [in dealing with] peer potential peer competitors, like China and Russia, Iran and North Korea
quotes.source: Defense News interview, October 2020
quotes.context: Smith connected AI development to competition with China and other adversaries, viewing it as essential for maintaining military advantage.

quotes.quote: Congressman Smith's guest lecture will focus on how the United States can address the challenges of Great Power Competition by leveraging America's strength in emerging technologies such as artificial intelligence, quantum computing and 5G communications
quotes.source: Naval Postgraduate School event announcement
quotes.context: Smith has emphasized AI as part of America's competitive advantage in great power competition, particularly against China.

quotes.quote: Are policymaking frameworks agile enough to handle the novel questions raised by systems incorporating capabilities such as AI, autonomy, and directed energy, at the pace and scale of innovation we hope to achieve?
quotes.source: HASC Hearing Opening Statement on 'Outpacing China: Expediting the Fielding of Innovation,' February 2024
quotes.context: Smith raised questions about whether current policy frameworks can keep up with AI innovation, particularly in the context of competing with China.

quotes.quote: If China thinks that we have the ability to protect our systems and to be survivable and to make their systems vulnerable, that's the best deterrence we can have. It's not just a matter of building a lot of things, we have to make sure that those things meet the technological challenges of today's warfare
quotes.source: FedScoop interview on 2023 defense budget, March 2022
quotes.context: Smith emphasized that technological superiority, including in AI and cyber, is key to deterring China, not just quantity of weapons.

quotes.quote: The confluence of AI, biotech, and compute dramatically lowers the bar [for developing bioweapons]... that's a shared concern in which [Chinese officials] highlighted, as did you, that the United States and China both are at risk because of that and we should collaborate
quotes.source: CSIS event 'Rep. Adam Smith on Engaging China,' November 2025
quotes.context: Smith discussed concerns raised by Chinese officials about AI-enabled bioweapons development, noting this as an area where US-China collaboration might be beneficial.

quotes.quote: We know where the future of warfare is headed. It is secure communications, information systems, drones, counter drones, missile, and missile defense
quotes.source: Council on Foreign Relations event, October 2025
quotes.context: Smith outlined his vision for future warfare, emphasizing AI-enabled systems and the need for rapid Pentagon acquisition of innovative technologies.

quotes.quote: When it comes to cyber, protecting our systems, I think, is our greatest problem right now — even more so than our ability to exploit other people's systems
quotes.source: CyberScoop interview, January 2023
quotes.context: While discussing cyber rather than AI specifically, Smith emphasized defensive capabilities and system protection as critical priorities.

quotes.quote: Improving information systems will be one of the most critical investments in upcoming military budgets... we will be 'scrubbing' older weapons systems and cutting funding to bloated programs
quotes.source: Brookings Institute virtual appearance, March 2021
quotes.context: Smith indicated he would prioritize investment in AI and information systems over legacy weapons programs.

Adam Smith.notes: Rep. Adam Smith's AI views are primarily focused on national security and defense applications rather than broader societal or existential concerns. He consistently frames AI in the context of: (1) Military competition with China, Russia, and other adversaries; (2) The need for Pentagon modernization and rapid acquisition of emerging technologies; (3) Command-and-control systems and cyber defense capabilities. Notably absent from his public statements are discussions of: AGI or superintelligence; existential risk from AI; AI safety or alignment research; specific AI companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, or Google; or broader societal impacts beyond defense. His one mention of AI risk came in a 2025 discussion where he noted Chinese officials' concerns about AI-enabled bioweapons, suggesting this as a potential area for US-China collaboration. As Ranking Member of the House Armed Services Committee, his committee has jurisdiction over DoD AI policy through the Cyber, Innovative Technologies, and Information Systems Subcommittee. His approach is pragmatic and focused on maintaining U.S. technological superiority for deterrence purposes.

Adrian Smith.summary: Congressman Adrian Smith, Chair of the House Ways and Means Trade Subcommittee, has extremely limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. His technology-related remarks focus primarily on intellectual property protection, digital trade policy, and maintaining American innovation leadership against foreign competitors, particularly China. No substantive quotes about AI safety, AGI, existential risk, or transformative AI capabilities were found.

quotes.quote: U.S. innovation is one of our nation's greatest strengths – it is a core driver of America's economic engine and key to U.S. national security.
quotes.source: Opening Statement, Trade Subcommittee Hearing on Maintaining American Innovation and Technology Leadership, January 13, 2026
quotes.context: Smith emphasized the importance of protecting American innovation and intellectual property, noting that IP-intensive industries account for 41% of U.S. GDP and 8.9 million jobs in the technology sector.

quotes.quote: Many of our trading partners lack similar innovation-friendly rules and often impose measures aimed at undermining American companies in order to advantage their own firms.
quotes.source: Opening Statement, Trade Subcommittee Hearing, January 13, 2026
quotes.context: Discussing foreign threats to American technological leadership, with implicit reference to China and other competitors, though not specifically about AI.

quotes.quote: I think it's important that we strategically lay this out in a way that we can get some results through legislation to prevent these bad things from happening again.
quotes.source: Quotes.net (context: discussing IRS accountability)
quotes.context: General statement about legislative approach to preventing government overreach; not AI-specific but reflects his approach to regulation and accountability.

Adrian Smith.notes: Congressman Adrian Smith has an extremely limited public record on AI-specific issues. As Chair of the House Ways and Means Trade Subcommittee, his technology focus is primarily on: (1) protecting American intellectual property from foreign competitors, especially China; (2) digital trade policy and digital services taxes; (3) maintaining U.S. innovation leadership broadly. His January 2026 hearing on 'Maintaining American Innovation and Technology Leadership' focused on IP rights and trade, not AI safety, capabilities, or existential risk. Smith represents Nebraska's 3rd district (rural, agricultural) and his policy priorities center on trade, agriculture, tax policy, and rural issues. He has not participated in AI safety summits, made statements about AGI timelines, discussed AI alignment, or engaged with the AI safety community. The lack of AI-specific statements may reflect either: (1) limited engagement with AI policy issues; (2) focus on his committee's traditional jurisdiction areas; or (3) simply that AI has not been a priority topic for his rural Nebraska constituency. Without direct quotes or testimony on AI, it's impossible to assess his views on transformative AI, existential risk, or AI safety.

Christopher H. Smith.summary: Rep. Christopher H. Smith (R-NJ), a senior member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee focused on human rights, has extremely limited public statements on AI. His primary engagement with AI appears to be through the lens of China's use of the technology for human rights abuses and disinformation, consistent with his decades-long focus on international human rights issues.

quotes.quote: At today's House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing, 'Winning the AI Arms Race Against the Chinese Communist Party,' senior member Rep. Chris Smith (R-NJ) raised serious concerns about the Chinese Communist Party (CCP)'s weaponization of AI technology to violate international human rights standards and spread disinformation about historical events, such as Tiananmen Square
quotes.source: House Foreign Affairs Committee hearing, January 14, 2026
quotes.context: Smith participated in a hearing specifically focused on AI competition with China, emphasizing his concern about China's use of AI for human rights violations and historical revisionism

Christopher H. Smith.notes: CRITICAL LIMITATION: Only one substantive public statement about AI could be found for Rep. Christopher H. Smith despite extensive searching. Smith has been in Congress since 1981 and is the longest-serving member from New Jersey, with a career focused primarily on international human rights issues, veterans' affairs, and pro-life advocacy. He has been sanctioned twice by the Chinese government for his criticism of human rights abuses. His sole identified AI-related statement focuses exclusively on China's weaponization of AI for human rights abuses and disinformation, which is entirely consistent with his decades-long focus on human rights and China policy. He does not appear to have made public statements about: AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, AI companies (OpenAI, Anthropic, etc.), transformative potential of AI, domestic AI policy, or technical aspects of AI development. This suggests AI policy is not a priority issue for him, and he views it primarily through the human rights/China lens that has defined his congressional career.

Linda T. S\u00e1nchez.summary: Based on extensive research, Representative Linda T. Sánchez (D-CA-38) has not made substantial public statements specifically about artificial intelligence policy, safety, or development. Her legislative focus has been primarily on labor rights, working families, trade policy, tax reform, and internet safety issues like cyberbullying.
Linda T. S\u00e1nchez.notes: Representative Sánchez serves as Ranking Member of the House Ways and Means Trade Subcommittee and has been in Congress since 2003. While she has been involved in technology-adjacent issues (particularly cyberbullying legislation in the late 2000s and trade policy discussions that touch on technology leadership), there is no substantial public record of her making specific statements about AI, AGI, AI safety, existential risk, or AI alignment. Her legislative priorities focus on working families, labor rights, tax policy, trade, and social welfare issues. The lack of public statements on AI does not necessarily indicate her position, but rather that this has not been a primary focus area of her legislative work or public communications as of January 2026.

Bennie G. Thompson.summary: Based on available public records, Rep. Bennie G. Thompson's AI-related statements focus primarily on national security and homeland security concerns. His public comments emphasize the threat AI poses when used by foreign adversaries (China, Russia, Iran) for election interference, disinformation, and critical infrastructure attacks. He has supported AI legislation focused on civil rights protections and cosponsored bills to establish AI task forces at DHS/CISA.

quotes.quote: AI in the hands of our adversaries can jeopardize the security of Federal and critical infrastructure networks, as well as the integrity of our elections.
quotes.source: House Homeland Security Committee Hearing, May 22, 2024
quotes.context: Opening statement as Ranking Member at a hearing titled 'Advancing Innovation (AI): Harnessing Artificial Intelligence to Defend and Secure the Homeland'

quotes.quote: We know that China, Russia, and Iran have spent the past 4 years honing their abilities to influence our elections, sow discord among the American public, and undermine confidence in our election results.
quotes.source: House Homeland Security Committee Hearing, May 22, 2024
quotes.context: Statement about foreign adversaries' use of AI for election interference

quotes.quote: Advances in AI will only make their job easier, so we must redouble our efforts to identify manipulated content and empower the public to identify malicious foreign influence operations.
quotes.source: House Homeland Security Committee Hearing, May 22, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the need for countermeasures against AI-enabled foreign influence operations

quotes.quote: I look forward to a robust conversation about how the Department of Homeland Security can use AI strategically to carry out its mission more effectively.
quotes.source: House Homeland Security Committee Hearing, May 22, 2024
quotes.context: Expressing support for DHS's strategic use of AI for homeland security purposes

quotes.quote: I am interested in understanding how CISA can better leverage AI to scale and improve the analytic capacity that is central to its mission.
quotes.source: House Homeland Security Subcommittee Hearing, December 12, 2023
quotes.context: Discussing CISA's role in securing artificial intelligence

quotes.quote: As policy makers, we need to acknowledge that CISA will require the necessary resources and personnel to fully realize the potential of AI while mitigating the threat it poses to National security.
quotes.source: House Homeland Security Subcommittee Hearing, December 12, 2023
quotes.context: Advocating for adequate funding and staffing for AI security efforts

quotes.quote: [Trump] is not only a threat to CISA, he's a threat to democracy.
quotes.source: Politico interview, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing concerns about threats to CISA, the agency responsible for election security and AI-related cybersecurity (referenced in Progressive Magazine, June 2024)

Bennie G. Thompson.notes: Limited public information available about Rep. Thompson's comprehensive AI views. His statements are primarily focused on: (1) AI as a national security threat when used by foreign adversaries (China, Russia, Iran); (2) Election security and disinformation concerns; (3) Support for DHS/CISA using AI defensively for homeland security; (4) Civil rights and bias concerns - he cosponsored the Eliminating BIAS Act in January 2026 to mandate civil rights offices in federal agencies using AI. Thompson has not made extensive public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, or specific AI companies like OpenAI. His focus is operational and security-oriented rather than philosophical or focused on long-term AI development. As Ranking Member of the House Homeland Security Committee, his AI engagement is primarily through the lens of counterterrorism, cybersecurity, and critical infrastructure protection. The limited number of direct quotes (7 instead of 10) reflects the scarcity of his public statements specifically about AI policy and technology.

Mike Thompson.summary: Insufficient public information available. While one voter guide source listed 'AI regulation' among Rep. Thompson's top issues, extensive research did not uncover any substantial public statements, quotes, press releases, or legislative actions specifically focused on artificial intelligence policy.
Mike Thompson.notes: Representative Mike Thompson (D-CA-04) serves on the House Ways and Means Committee and chairs the Gun Violence Prevention Task Force. While a Progressive Voters Guide from 2024 listed 'AI regulation' among his top issues, no actual quotes, press releases, or specific policy positions on AI could be found through searches of his official website, congressional records, news sources, or public statements. His public focus appears to be primarily on taxation, healthcare, gun violence prevention, veterans' issues, environmental conservation, and agriculture. He has supported technology initiatives like the CHIPS and Science Act for semiconductor manufacturing and hosts an annual Congressional App Challenge for students, but these do not specifically address AI policy. Without concrete statements or legislative actions on AI, it is not possible to characterize his views on AI safety, alignment, existential risk, transformative potential, or competition with China in this domain.

Glenn Thompson.summary: Representative Glenn Thompson (R-PA-15), Chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, has not made significant public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. His technology-related comments focus primarily on agricultural innovation, digital assets/cryptocurrency regulation, and rural broadband access rather than AI policy, safety, or geopolitical competition.

quotes.quote: My definition of American agriculture is science, technology, and innovation. And we have the scientists to back that up.
quotes.source: Puck interview, September 2025
quotes.context: Thompson discussing agricultural policy and pesticide regulation, emphasizing his support for science-based approaches to agriculture rather than specifically addressing AI

quotes.quote: Today's introduction of the Financial Innovation and Technology for the 21st Century Act marks a significant milestone in the House Committees on Agriculture and Financial Services efforts to establish a much-needed regulatory framework that protects consumers and investors and fosters American leadership in the digital asset space.
quotes.source: Press release, July 2023
quotes.context: Thompson introducing legislation on cryptocurrency and blockchain technology regulation, not AI specifically

quotes.quote: There are provisions for the safety net, increased investment in research – science, technology and innovation.
quotes.source: City & State Pennsylvania interview, August 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the Farm Bill's investment in agricultural research and innovation, with no specific mention of AI technologies

Glenn Thompson.notes: After comprehensive research including searches of Congressional records, committee hearings, press releases, interviews, and news coverage, I found no substantive public statements from Rep. Glenn Thompson specifically addressing artificial intelligence, AI safety, AGI, existential risk, or AI competition with China. His technology-related statements focus on: (1) agricultural innovation and precision agriculture, (2) cryptocurrency/blockchain regulation through the Financial Innovation and Technology for the 21st Century Act (CLARITY Act), and (3) rural broadband expansion. As Chairman of the House Agriculture Committee since 2023, his legislative priorities center on farm policy, nutrition programs, rural development, and agricultural research rather than AI policy. Thompson consistently emphasizes 'science, technology, and innovation' in agriculture but has not publicly engaged with broader AI policy debates that are prominent in Congress. This appears to reflect his committee jurisdiction and district priorities (rural Pennsylvania) rather than indicating a particular stance on AI issues.

John Thune.summary: John Thune, now Senate Majority Leader, views AI as a revolutionary and transformative technology requiring a 'light-touch' regulatory approach focused on innovation and competitiveness. He consistently emphasizes the need to maintain U.S. leadership in AI to counter China, while establishing 'basic rules of the road' for high-risk applications rather than heavy-handed regulation.

quotes.quote: There is no question that AI will come to play an important role in national defense, and falling behind adversaries – like the Chinese Communist Party – in this area could put our country at a serious disadvantage when it comes to our national security.
quotes.source: Senate floor speech, November 2023
quotes.context: Thune explaining the national security imperative for AI leadership while introducing his bipartisan AI bill

quotes.quote: If we fall behind adversarial nations, particularly China, there will be profoundly dangerous implications for our national security and economic prosperity.
quotes.source: Opinion editorial, December 2023
quotes.context: Warning about the consequences of falling behind in AI development, specifically mentioning China as the primary competitor

quotes.quote: AI is a revolutionary technology that has the potential to improve health care, agriculture, logistics and supply chains, and countless other industries.
quotes.source: Press release introducing AI Research, Innovation, and Accountability Act, November 2023
quotes.context: Describing the transformative potential of AI while announcing bipartisan legislation

quotes.quote: As the release of ChatGPT to the public last year demonstrated, artificial intelligence is about to take a giant step forward.
quotes.source: Senate floor speech, November 2023
quotes.context: Acknowledging the significant advancement represented by generative AI and foundation models

quotes.quote: The light-touch approach the United States has taken on internet regulation is a good model to follow for AI. The explosive growth of internet innovation in our country is in large part a result of government not weighing down a new technology with heavy-handed regulation.
quotes.source: Opinion editorial, December 2023
quotes.context: Articulating his philosophy on AI regulation, drawing parallels to successful internet policy

quotes.quote: By incentivizing more talent to pursue training in this field, we can ensure America remains competitive globally in this emerging technology.
quotes.source: Press release on AI Scholarship-for-Service Act, April 2021
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to build federal AI workforce capacity in competition with China

quotes.quote: This new technology brings with it seemingly endless possibilities. It promises potentially tremendous advances in medicine, farming, and manufacturing. It can improve everything from national defense to daily life. But, as with any sophisticated technology, this next generation of AI also presents risks.
quotes.source: Opinion editorial, December 2023
quotes.context: Balancing optimism about AI's potential with acknowledgment of risks

quotes.quote: We want to be the leaders in AI and quantum and all these new technologies. And the way to do that is not to come in with a heavy hand of government, it's to come in with a light touch.
quotes.source: Interview with Axios, June 2025
quotes.context: As Senate Majority Leader, defending approach to AI regulation including state preemption provisions

quotes.quote: [DeepSeek] was a wake-up call for us that we've got to step up our game.
quotes.source: Statement on China's DeepSeek AI model, January 2025
quotes.context: Responding to Chinese AI breakthrough that demonstrated competitive threat to U.S. AI leadership

quotes.quote: Unlike the White House's executive order, our bill doesn't instantly assume that artificial intelligence technology is bad and that it should be subject to heavy-handed government intervention. Nor does our legislation rush us into regulations before we have a clear idea of what aspects of this technology need to be regulated and in what way.
quotes.source: Senate floor speech, November 2023
quotes.context: Contrasting his legislative approach with the Biden administration's AI executive order

John Thune.notes: John Thune is the current Senate Majority Leader (as of January 2025) and has been a leading Republican voice on AI policy. He authored the bipartisan AI Research, Innovation, and Accountability Act with Sen. Amy Klobuchar, which passed the Senate Commerce Committee in July 2024. His approach is characterized by: (1) Strong emphasis on U.S.-China competition as the primary frame for AI policy; (2) Consistent advocacy for 'light-touch' regulation modeled on internet policy; (3) Focus on risk-based frameworks for 'critical-impact' and 'high-impact' AI systems rather than comprehensive regulation; (4) Support for self-certification by companies rather than licensing regimes; (5) Concern about misinformation and deepfakes but opposition to heavy-handed content regulation; (6) No discussion of AGI, existential risk, or AI alignment in the technical sense used by AI safety researchers; (7) References to ChatGPT and major AI companies in context of policy discussions; (8) Recent response to China's DeepSeek breakthrough shows continued focus on competitive dynamics. His stance is firmly pro-innovation with targeted safety measures for high-risk applications, viewing AI primarily through economic competitiveness and national security lenses rather than through existential risk frameworks.

Paul Tonko.summary: Rep. Paul Tonko (D-NY) views AI as transformative technology with significant economic and workforce potential, focusing primarily on K-12 AI education and preparing the American workforce for competition. His AI-related legislative work centers on education access and consumer protection, particularly restricting AI use in gambling/sports betting, rather than broader AI governance or safety concerns.

quotes.quote: The development of Artificial Intelligence has fundamentally changed the way we live and work, bringing untold potential in the fields of medical science, research and development, engineering, manufacturing and so much more.
quotes.source: Press release introducing AI Education Act, September 24, 2020
quotes.context: Tonko was introducing bipartisan legislation to establish K-12 AI education programs through the National Science Foundation, emphasizing AI's transformative economic potential.

quotes.quote: We have only begun to scratch the surface of what AI can do to revolutionize our health care, manufacturing, technology and other fields that will drive America's 21st century economic and technological growth.
quotes.source: Statement on AI Education Act passing in NDAA, December 8, 2020
quotes.context: Tonko was celebrating the passage of his AI education bill as part of the National Defense Authorization Act, framing AI as central to American competitiveness.

quotes.quote: The surest way to keep our nation at the leading competitive edge...
quotes.source: Statement on AI Education Act, December 8, 2020
quotes.context: Tonko was discussing workforce development and education as key to maintaining U.S. competitiveness in AI, though the full quote was truncated in available sources.

quotes.quote: We have only begun to scratch the surface of what AI can do in driving economic and technological growth. Opening the door for more of America's students to learn about it will prepare them, and us, for the groundbreaking advances in science, technology, manufacturing and more that we know are coming.
quotes.source: Congressional newsletter, December 2020
quotes.context: Tonko was explaining the importance of his AI Education Act and expressing optimism about AI's future economic impact.

quotes.quote: AI could not be used to track player habits or offer personalized promotions.
quotes.source: Statement on SAFE Bet Act provisions, 2024
quotes.context: Tonko was describing restrictions on AI use in sports betting, showing concern about manipulative AI applications in gambling rather than broader AI safety issues.

quotes.quote: Since the 2018 Supreme Court decision that allowed sports betting to become legalized in a widespread fashion the sportsbook industry has been operating in a Wild West, largely unregulated environment.
quotes.source: Virtual press conference on SAFE Bet Act, March 21, 2024
quotes.context: Tonko was advocating for federal regulation of sports betting, including restrictions on AI use for tracking and targeting customers.

quotes.quote: We are dealing with a massive and growing public health crisis involving a known, addictive product.
quotes.source: Statement on sports betting legislation, March 19, 2024
quotes.context: Tonko was discussing sports betting regulation and AI's role in potentially exacerbating gambling addiction through personalized targeting.

quotes.quote: It is deep investments that need to be made.
quotes.source: Event on CHIPS Act, June 17, 2022
quotes.context: While discussing semiconductor manufacturing and competition with China, Tonko emphasized the need for substantial federal investment in technology infrastructure, which relates to AI compute capabilities.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence (AI), which enables machines to learn to perform a task by training on diverse datasets, is one of the most revolutionary developments in scientific history.
quotes.source: Co-authored academic paper 'A Perspective on K-12 AI Education', 2022
quotes.context: From a paper Tonko co-authored with students and academics about K-12 AI education, describing AI's transformative impact on medicine, biology, transportation, and entertainment.

quotes.quote: Increases awareness of potential ethical, social, safety, and security risks of artificial systems.
quotes.source: AI Education Act bill text, 2020
quotes.context: One of the stated goals of Tonko's AI Education Act, showing awareness of AI risks though focused on education rather than technical safety measures.

Paul Tonko.notes: Paul Tonko's AI-related work is narrowly focused on two main areas: (1) K-12 AI education and workforce development to maintain U.S. competitiveness, and (2) consumer protection by restricting AI use in sports betting/gambling. While he participated in House Science, Space, and Technology Committee hearings on AI (including a June 2023 hearing titled 'Artificial Intelligence: Advancing Innovation Towards the National Interest'), no direct quotes from him during these hearings were found in available transcripts. His references to China are limited to broader technology competition contexts (semiconductors/CHIPS Act) rather than specific AI competition concerns. He does not appear to discuss AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, or technical AI safety issues.
