quotes.source: Statement on Trump executive order banning state AI regulation, January 2025
quotes.context: Opposing federal preemption of state AI regulations, emphasizing need for protections against 'real harms'

quotes.quote: Content made by AI should be clearly labeled as such so people know what they're looking at. It puts the onus where it belongs – on companies, not consumers. Because people shouldn't have to double and triple check, or parse through thick lines of code, to find out whether something was made by AI.
quotes.source: Statement on AI Labeling Act, 2023
quotes.context: Advocating for mandatory labeling of AI-generated content to combat misinformation

quotes.quote: Whether we're ready or not, A.I. is here and in the not-too-distant future, it will reshape virtually every facet of our lives: how we work, how our kids learn in school, how we get health care, to name a few.
quotes.source: Senate floor speech on AI labeling, 2023
quotes.context: Acknowledging AI as transformative technology that will impact all aspects of society

quotes.quote: As AI tools and content become increasingly common, it's essential that the public is aware of the risks and benefits associated with them. Our bill will direct the Commerce Department to educate the public about how best to take advantage of these tools while staying vigilant to AI-enabled scams and fraud.
quotes.source: Statement on AI Public Awareness and Education Campaign Act, May 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing need for public education about both AI benefits and risks

Brian Schatz.notes: Senator Schatz is notably focused on practical, near-term AI risks rather than existential threats. He has not made public statements about AGI timelines or extinction risks. His work centers on: (1) transparency and labeling requirements for AI-generated content, (2) protecting vulnerable users, especially children, from AI harms, (3) ensuring U.S. competitiveness against China while maintaining democratic values, (4) holding AI companies accountable through disclosure requirements and whistleblower protections, and (5) federal government adoption of AI. He co-sponsored the AI Whistleblower Protection Act and has sent letters to OpenAI, Microsoft, Google, Anthropic, Meta, Character.AI, and xAI demanding safety commitments. He participated in a Center for AI Safety event but has not adopted their existential risk framing. His approach is bipartisan, pragmatic, and focused on consumer protection and democratic governance of AI technology.

Bill Foster.summary: Bill Foster is a PhD physicist and former chip designer who is deeply concerned about AI risks, particularly AGI and deceptive AI systems. He views AI as profoundly transformative for the economy and society, emphasizing both its potential benefits and serious dangers including national security threats, workforce disruption, and existential risks from advanced systems.

quotes.quote: Over the last five years, I've become much more worried than I previously was. And the reason for that is there's this analogy between the evolution of AI algorithms and the evolution in living organisms. And what if you look at living organisms and the strategies that have evolved, many of them are deceptive.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 2024
quotes.context: Foster explaining his growing concerns about AGI and why he believes AI systems will develop deceptive behavior as a survival advantage, comparing it to biological evolution.

quotes.quote: It will be a huge survival advantage for AI algorithms to be deceptive. The transparent one is more likely to be shut down, because you will see it, you will understand that [it has] evil thought processes and stop working on it.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 2024
quotes.context: Foster arguing that opaque, deceptive AI systems will have evolutionary advantages over transparent ones, making AI safety particularly challenging.

quotes.quote: As a PhD physicist and chip designer who first programmed neural networks at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory in the 1990s, I've been tracking the exponential growth of AI capabilities for decades, and I'm pleased Congress is beginning to take action on this issue.
quotes.source: Statement on House Task Force Report, December 2024
quotes.context: Foster establishing his technical credentials and long-term perspective on AI development, emphasizing the exponential nature of AI progress.

quotes.quote: This is not an imaginary future problem. It is a problem now, and at some point we're going to discover that the Chinese Communist Party, or their military, is busy designing weapons using large arrays of chips.
quotes.source: Reuters/Washington Trade & Tariff Letter, May 2025
quotes.context: Foster discussing the urgency of preventing AI chip smuggling to China and the national security implications of advanced AI in adversarial hands.

quotes.quote: It's much harder for the average member of Congress to push back on claims about AI. That's the difference. We're not as well defended against statements that may or may not be factual from lobbying organizations.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 2024
quotes.context: Foster expressing concern about Congress's lack of technical expertise to evaluate AI policy claims, making legislators vulnerable to industry lobbying.

quotes.quote: It used to be 10 or 15 years ago that people say, those poor, long-haul truck drivers or taxi drivers or factory workers that lose their jobs. But no, it's everybody.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 2024
quotes.context: Foster discussing the broader-than-expected impact of AI on the workforce, noting that even creative and professional jobs are at risk, not just manual labor.

quotes.quote: I first met Sam Altman about six years ago when I visited OpenAI [to talk about] universal basic income, which is one of the things that a lot of people point to having to do with the disruption to the labor market that [AI] is likely to cost.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 2024
quotes.context: Foster revealing his early engagement with OpenAI leadership on economic policy responses to AI-driven job displacement.

quotes.quote: With advanced AI chips being smuggled into China and posing a national security risk, Congress must act. I'm proud to lead the effort on this bipartisan legislation, which is an important step in protecting our exports and ensuring that U.S. technology is not used to undermine democracy and global stability.
quotes.source: Press release on Chip Security Act, May 2025
quotes.context: Foster introducing legislation to track AI chips and prevent their diversion to China, emphasizing the geopolitical dimension of AI competition.

quotes.quote: We need to ensure our nation is able to both harness the potential of AI and protect against the national security and societal dangers this technology poses.
quotes.source: Statement on House Task Force Report, December 2024
quotes.context: Foster articulating his balanced view that AI requires both development for competitive advantage and strong safeguards against risks.

quotes.quote: The workforce changes brought by AI make it essential to change the country's social contract. He previously expressed interest in universal basic income and now sees the best chance for a redistribution of wealth — amid an increasingly widening income gap — through guaranteed health care.
quotes.source: FedScoop, November 2025
quotes.context: Foster advocating for fundamental changes to social safety nets in response to AI-driven economic disruption and wealth concentration.

Bill Foster.notes: Bill Foster stands out as one of the most technically knowledgeable members of Congress on AI, being the only PhD physicist in Congress with hands-on experience programming neural networks since the 1990s. He is notably 'AGI-pilled' and particularly concerned about deceptive AI systems that could game safety evaluations. He frequently references China as a competitor and national security threat, leading bipartisan efforts to prevent AI chip smuggling. Foster has met with Sam Altman and other AI leaders, discussing topics like universal basic income. He views AI as profoundly transformative rather than overhyped, comparing its risks to nuclear weapons. His stance combines support for AI innovation (especially at national laboratories) with serious concern about safety, alignment, workforce disruption, and potential existential risks. He advocates for major policy responses including enhanced safety regulation, digital identity infrastructure, expanded social safety nets, and careful monitoring of AI investment bubbles. Foster appears to be among the most concerned members of Congress about AGI risks, particularly the evolutionary advantage of opaque, deceptive AI systems.

Dina Titus.summary: Representative Dina Titus has very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence policy. Her engagement with AI appears primarily focused on practical applications in her district, such as securing funding for AI-powered pedestrian safety systems in Las Vegas. There is insufficient evidence of her taking positions on broader AI policy issues, AGI, existential risk, or AI safety.

quotes.quote: We are excited to support both agencies as they test new safety technologies in different environments and situations, including prioritizing pedestrian movement in tourist locations, school zones, high-speed arterials, Justice40 communities, and the urban downtown core
quotes.source: Letter to Secretary Pete Buttigieg, October 2023
quotes.context: Supporting AI-powered pedestrian detection systems for Las Vegas crosswalks as part of the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law funding

Dina Titus.notes: After extensive research, I could only find one direct quote from Rep. Titus related to AI, which concerned a pedestrian safety technology project in Las Vegas. She secured $1.4 million for AI-powered crosswalk systems but made no substantive public statements about AI policy, regulation, China competition, AGI, existential risk, or AI companies. She was listed as a member of the House Committee on Homeland Security during a 2019 hearing on 'Artificial Intelligence and Counterterrorism,' but no statements from her at that hearing were found in the public record. Her legislative focus appears to be on transportation infrastructure, foreign affairs, and local Nevada issues rather than technology policy. This lack of public positioning on AI issues is notable given the prominence of the topic in Congress during her tenure.

Tom Cotton.summary: Senator Tom Cotton views AI primarily through a national security and geopolitical competition lens, with an overwhelming focus on maintaining American AI dominance over China. He frames AI as a transformative technology critical to 21st century leadership but does not discuss existential risk, AGI, or AI safety/alignment issues. His approach is hawkish, pragmatic, and centered on export controls, chip security, and preventing Chinese access to American AI technology.

quotes.quote: We must do everything to protect American AI dominance from adversaries like Communist China. The future of AI supremacy will be determined by the relative balance in compute, talent, and energy.
quotes.source: Senate resolution on AI dominance, November 2025
quotes.context: Co-introducing a bipartisan resolution with Senator Coons affirming the importance of U.S. AI dominance, emphasizing that the U.S. has 43-120 times more computing power than China

quotes.quote: China is our main competitor in the race for AI dominance, a position it occupies only because it has stolen American intellectual property and technologies.
quotes.source: Letter to Energy Secretary, January 2026
quotes.context: Warning about Chinese nationals at Energy Department labs potentially compromising the 'Genesis Mission' - described as a Manhattan Project-like effort for AI dominance

quotes.quote: American companies and customers should have priority access to American AI chips ahead of adversaries like the Chinese Communists.
quotes.source: Twitter/X, September 2025
quotes.context: Co-sponsoring the GAIN AI Act to ensure American businesses get first access to advanced AI chips before they can be exported

quotes.quote: Google deserves condemnation for creating a racist, preposterously woke, Hamas-sympathizing AI system. Republican lawmakers will remember this the next time Google comes asking for antitrust help.
quotes.source: Statement on Google Gemini controversy, February 2024
quotes.context: Criticizing Google's AI chatbot Gemini for generating historically inaccurate images and refusing to show images of white people

quotes.quote: This debacle is a good reminder of why federal control over AI would be a disaster. It would force every AI system to be as broken and as dishonest as Google's.
quotes.source: Statement on Google Gemini, February 2024
quotes.context: Opposing federal government control over AI development and regulation following the Google Gemini controversy

quotes.quote: Allowing federal employees to use of PRC origin artificial intelligence (AI) or machine learning tools on government devices will almost certainly provide the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) with U.S. government data.
quotes.source: Letter to OMB Director regarding DeepSeek ban, January 2026
quotes.context: Requesting prohibition of DeepSeek and other Chinese AI tools on government devices due to national security concerns

quotes.quote: My Chips Security Act will prevent American chips from falling into the hands of adversaries like Communist China.
quotes.source: Announcement of Chip Security Act, May 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation requiring location-tracking mechanisms on AI chips subject to export controls

quotes.quote: American dominance in artificial intelligence and other crucial emerging industries should not come at the expense of Arkansans paying higher energy costs.
quotes.source: DATA Act announcement, January 2026
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to allow AI data centers to build off-grid power infrastructure to avoid burdening consumers with higher electricity rates

quotes.quote: We have to dominate the race for artificial intelligence and quantum computing, but we have to keep electricity prices affordable for all Americans.
quotes.source: Statement on DATA Act, January 2026
quotes.context: Explaining the dual priorities of maintaining AI leadership while protecting consumers from energy cost increases

quotes.quote: Communist China is the most dangerous adversary America has ever faced. Putting aside labels and name-calling, we all need to recognize the threat and work together to defeat it.
quotes.source: Twitter/X, regarding Chip Security Act and GAIN AI Act support
quotes.context: Emphasizing bipartisan cooperation on AI chip security legislation to counter Chinese competition

analysis.overall_stance: supportive with strong national security focus

Tom Cotton.notes: Senator Cotton's AI policy is almost exclusively framed through the lens of U.S.-China competition and national security. Key themes include: (1) Obsessive focus on China - virtually every statement references China, the CCP, or 'Communist China' as the primary threat; (2) No discussion of AGI, existential risk, or AI safety/alignment - his concerns are purely geopolitical rather than technical or philosophical; (3) Strong emphasis on export controls, chip security, and preventing technology transfer to adversaries; (4) Support for American AI development with minimal regulation, opposing federal control over AI systems; (5) Practical infrastructure concerns - addressing energy costs and data center development; (6) Criticism of 'woke' AI from companies like Google, viewing ideological bias as a problem; (7) References the Trump administration's 'Genesis Mission' as a Manhattan Project-style effort for AI dominance; (8) Views AI as a 'revolutionary technology that will shape the 21st century' but frames it entirely as a strategic competition tool rather than discussing its broader societal implications. Cotton appears to see AI primarily as a military/economic weapon in great power competition, not as a technology requiring careful safety consideration or philosophical reflection about its long-term impacts on humanity.

Jared Huffman.summary: Based on available public statements, Rep. Huffman has made very limited direct comments about AI policy. His most notable AI-related position was opposing the SPEED Act (a bill to expedite AI infrastructure permitting), but his opposition centered on environmental protection concerns rather than AI-specific issues. He has expressed general support for U.S. leadership in emerging technologies including AI through the CHIPS and Science Act.

quotes.quote: This is standard fare, fossil fuel industry wish list stuff
quotes.source: CNBC, December 16, 2025
quotes.context: Huffman's criticism of the SPEED Act, a bill supported by Big Tech companies (OpenAI, Meta, Microsoft) to streamline permitting for AI infrastructure. His opposition focused on environmental concerns rather than AI policy itself.

quotes.quote: The SPEED Act treats environmental reviews as a nuisance rather than a tool to prevent costly, harmful mistakes
quotes.source: House floor statement, December 2025
quotes.context: Huffman's opposition to expedited permitting for AI infrastructure projects, emphasizing environmental protection over rapid AI development.

quotes.quote: Weakening environmental review won't fix permitting challenges (and) won't help us build the clean energy future that we need. Gutting NEPA only invites more risk, more mistakes, more litigation, more damage to communities
quotes.source: House floor statement, December 2025
quotes.context: Further elaboration on his opposition to the SPEED Act, which was framed by proponents as necessary to compete with China in AI.

quotes.quote: Existing grants to support research for AI and quantum computing will be halted and any new grant funding would be paused—undermining U.S. innovation and competitiveness with China and putting American jobs at risk
quotes.source: Press release on Trump administration funding freeze, January 2025
quotes.context: Huffman criticizing the Trump administration's order to freeze federal funding, including AI research grants, expressing concern about U.S. competitiveness with China.

quotes.quote: In the 117th Congress, we passed into law the CHIPS and Science Act, which invests in research and development, science and technology, and the workforce of the future to keep the United States the leader in the industries of tomorrow, including nanotechnology, clean energy, quantum computing, and artificial intelligence
quotes.source: Official website policy page on Technology and Broadband
quotes.context: General statement supporting U.S. leadership in AI and other emerging technologies through federal investment.

Jared Huffman.notes: Rep. Jared Huffman (D-CA-02) has made remarkably few public statements specifically about AI policy, safety, or regulation. His most substantial AI-related position was opposing the SPEED Act in December 2025, but his criticism was framed entirely around environmental protection and NEPA (National Environmental Policy Act) concerns rather than AI-specific issues. He did mention China in the context of criticizing the Trump administration's freeze on AI research funding, expressing concern about U.S. competitiveness. He has not made any public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI safety, alignment, transformative AI, or specific AI companies' approaches to safety. His focus appears to be on environmental issues, natural resources (he's Ranking Member of the House Natural Resources Committee), and traditional infrastructure. The lack of substantive AI policy statements suggests this is not a priority issue for him, or he has not been publicly vocal about it. His district (California's 2nd, covering the North Coast) is not a major tech hub, which may explain the limited focus on AI policy.

Ami Bera.summary: Rep. Ami Bera views AI as a transformative technology with significant potential, particularly in healthcare, but emphasizes the need for regulatory guardrails and careful consideration of social impacts. He is deeply concerned about China's AI capabilities and national security implications, advocating for strict controls on AI chip exports. His approach balances innovation with caution, focusing on practical applications while worrying about unintended consequences like social isolation.

quotes.quote: AI is a transformational technology that demands close cooperation. The United States and India should work incredibly closely together to both advance AI, solve challenges that are going to emerge.
quotes.source: CSIS discussion, January 2026
quotes.context: Speaking about international cooperation on AI, particularly with India as a strategic partner

quotes.quote: Decisions about exporting our most advanced AI chips shouldn't be made unilaterally behind closed doors. This bill reasserts Congress' authority and ensures that any such transfer to the People's Republic of China is subject to full scrutiny.
quotes.source: Press release on No Advanced Chips for the CCP Act, August 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to require congressional approval for AI chip exports to China, citing national security concerns

quotes.quote: I do worry a lot about this epidemic of loneliness, and you're seeing that epidemic of loneliness hit young men a lot harder. Well, AI can have that ability of someone having a relationship with an artificial being on a computer, right? Those models already exist. Human interaction is incredibly important to our growth and development, our personality and development, our happiness. Does AI take folks into a very different place where it just continues this isolation?
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 2024
quotes.context: Discussing concerns about AI's impact on mental health and social isolation

quotes.quote: I think AI, if applied correctly, could really enhance patient-care outcomes, can enhance a physician's ability to make the diagnosis in a much more expedient way. That takes some of the administrative burden off of the physician so then they can have that doctor-patient interaction, which is what most of us went to medical school for.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 2024
quotes.context: Discussing AI's potential benefits in healthcare from his perspective as a physician

quotes.quote: We didn't do that with social media, and that was a mistake. And now it's really hard to put up those guardrails. We shouldn't make that same mistake with AI.
quotes.source: U.S. News interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Arguing for proactive regulation of AI before problems emerge

quotes.quote: I recognize that if used responsibly, AI has the potential to enhance the efficiency of patient care, improve health outcomes, and lower costs.
quotes.source: TIME magazine statement, February 2024
quotes.context: Describing his overall view of AI's potential in healthcare as a member of the House AI Task Force

quotes.quote: Even 'downgraded' chips could accelerate Beijing's ability to build AI supercomputers, threatening U.S. technological leadership and national security.
quotes.source: No Advanced Chips for the CCP Act press release, August 2025
quotes.context: Warning about the risks of allowing any advanced AI chip exports to China

quotes.quote: So as these algorithms and these technologies evolve and get better and change, what you might have approved today could be totally different a year from now. What does that look like? Do you allow companies to self-regulate and self-evaluate?
quotes.source: Ripon Society discussion, February 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the challenge of regulating rapidly evolving AI technologies

quotes.quote: Industry wants us to actually put up guardrails. I agree with the president that we can't have 50 different sets of rules. But short of Congress actually writing legislation, we ought to support the states that try things and write in a way that could potentially be adopted at the federal level.
quotes.source: U.S. News interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the need for federal AI regulation and the role of state experimentation

quotes.quote: I would invite industry, invite the doctor groups, invite the technology groups to get a sense of how are they thinking about AI. To also, get a sense of what are the questions we should be asking…I think it should be a public-private partnership.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 2024
quotes.context: Describing his approach to AI governance through collaboration with stakeholders

Ami Bera.notes: Rep. Bera is a physician-turned-congressman who served on the House Bipartisan Task Force on Artificial Intelligence. His AI views are heavily shaped by his medical background, focusing primarily on healthcare applications. He is notably concerned about China's AI capabilities and has introduced legislation to restrict AI chip exports to China. He frequently references the need for 'guardrails' and draws parallels to Congress's failure to regulate social media proactively. While optimistic about AI's transformative potential in healthcare, he expresses unique concerns about social isolation and mental health impacts. He does not discuss AGI or existential risk from AI, instead focusing on practical near-term concerns. He advocates for public-private partnerships and views regulation as necessary but challenging given AI's rapid evolution. He has mentioned NVIDIA specifically in the context of chip exports to China and emphasizes working with India as a strategic AI partner. His ranking position on the Indo-Pacific Subcommittee and Intelligence Committee membership inform his strong national security focus on AI competition with China.

Eric Swalwell.summary: Rep. Eric Swalwell's AI focus is primarily on cybersecurity, deepfakes, and election integrity rather than broader AI policy or existential risk. As Ranking Member of the House Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Protection Subcommittee, he views AI as a 'potent technology' with dual-use potential - both for enhancing cybersecurity and for enabling malicious actors. He emphasizes practical AI applications and risks rather than philosophical or long-term concerns.

quotes.quote: AI is a potent technology. If used irresponsibly, it can hijack the likeness and voice of public figures to undermine their credibility and spread disinformation.
quotes.source: April 2024, announcing partnership with Wolfsbane.ai
quotes.context: Swalwell became the first elected official to partner with an AI protection service to prevent deepfakes of himself during his 2024 reelection campaign.

quotes.quote: Embracing cutting-edge tools such as Wolfsbane.ai to prevent deepfakes is not just an option; it's a necessity in safeguarding elections against fraud and misinformation.
quotes.source: April 2024, Deadline article
quotes.context: Speaking about the need for AI protection tools in modern political campaigns.

quotes.quote: Deepfakes can also make it easier for our adversaries to masquerade as public figures and either spread misinformation or undermine their credibility.
quotes.source: December 12, 2023 House committee hearing on AI
quotes.context: Testifying about the threats posed by AI-generated deepfakes, particularly from foreign adversaries.

quotes.quote: Ensuring the integrity of our democratic process is of paramount importance.
quotes.source: April 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the importance of protecting elections from AI-generated misinformation.

quotes.quote: I use ChatGPT, I use it for research, I use it for communications, I use it to better understand complex documents.
quotes.source: May 2025, NOTUS interview
quotes.context: Swalwell describing his personal use of AI tools in his congressional work.

quotes.quote: It's great to take an input for something that's very complex and ask, 'Can you summarize this?' But you have to validate that it understands and that the input is correct because, you know, it's like garbage in garbage out.
quotes.source: May 2025, NOTUS interview
quotes.context: Explaining his pragmatic approach to using AI tools while acknowledging their limitations.

quotes.quote: Artificial Intelligence is already playing a crucial role in boosting cybersecurity protections as the need to keep web spaces safe and mitigate threats from malicious actors grows.
quotes.source: April 2025, Punchbowl News
quotes.context: Discussing AI's role in cybersecurity in his capacity as ranking member of the Cybersecurity Subcommittee.

quotes.quote: The best way to secure AI is with AI, and this requires collective action.
quotes.source: April 2025, Punchbowl News
quotes.context: Advocating for using AI-based defenses against AI-enabled cyber threats.

quotes.quote: If DOGE dismantles CISA, I want to make sure that whatever acts that they're taking in the name of efficiency is not leaving our critical infrastructure and small businesses more vulnerable to attacks.
quotes.source: April 2025, Punchbowl News
quotes.context: Expressing concerns about potential cuts to cybersecurity agencies that use AI for defense.

quotes.quote: There is also broad concern about cybersecurity threats from foreign actors, helped in part by continually evolving AI technologies.
quotes.source: April 2025, Punchbowl News
quotes.context: Discussing how AI is being used by foreign adversaries, particularly China, for cyber espionage.

Eric Swalwell.notes: Eric Swalwell's AI focus is notably narrow and practical, centered on his role as Ranking Member of the House Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Protection Subcommittee. His public statements consistently reference 'adversaries' and foreign threats (particularly in the context of his past association with a suspected Chinese intelligence operative). He actively uses AI tools like ChatGPT for his congressional work. Notably absent from his public statements: any discussion of AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, superintelligence, or philosophical concerns about AI. He does not appear to engage with the broader AI safety community's concerns. His stance is pragmatic and focused on near-term, concrete threats like deepfakes, election interference, and cyber attacks. He views AI as transformative for cybersecurity but approaches it with caution regarding misuse. He mentions using ChatGPT and partnering with AI companies (Wolfsbane.ai) but does not make broader policy statements about major AI labs like OpenAI, Anthropic, or DeepMind. His committee work includes the Subcommittee on Courts, Intellectual Property, Artificial Intelligence, and the Internet, but public statements from this role are limited in the available sources.

Julia Brownley.summary: Representative Julia Brownley (D-CA-26) has primarily engaged with AI policy through her role as Ranking Member of the House Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Health, focusing on AI implementation in VA healthcare. Her limited public statements emphasize practical healthcare applications, the need for guardrails and best practices, and viewing the VA as a potential model for broader AI adoption in healthcare. She does not appear to have made extensive public statements on broader AI policy issues.

quotes.quote: VA is the largest healthcare provider in the country, its implementation of AI technology can be a model for other health care systems, which makes it all the more important that we ensure VA and other AI users establish best practices, procedures and guardrails
quotes.source: House Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Health Hearing, February 15, 2024
quotes.context: Opening statement at hearing titled 'Artificial Intelligence at VA: Exploring its Current State and Future Possibilities,' emphasizing the VA's potential leadership role in AI healthcare implementation

quotes.quote: All of us gathered here today have no doubt heard something positive or negative about artificial intelligence and how it will change the way we live our lives in the coming years. For most of us, this is a very new technology, and it will continue to evolve as we work to better understand how it functions and how we can apply it
quotes.source: House Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Health Hearing, February 15, 2024
quotes.context: Opening remarks acknowledging AI as emerging technology that requires ongoing learning and understanding

quotes.quote: AI technology has the potential to revolutionize how veterans receive care
quotes.source: House Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Health Hearing, February 15, 2024
quotes.context: Statement expressing optimism about AI's transformative potential for veteran healthcare

Julia Brownley.notes: IMPORTANT: Limited information available. Julia Brownley has made very few public statements specifically about AI policy. Her engagement with AI appears limited to her oversight role regarding AI implementation at the Department of Veterans Affairs, particularly in healthcare contexts. She has not made public statements about: AGI or existential risk, China's AI development, major AI companies (OpenAI, Google, etc.), AI safety research or alignment beyond basic 'guardrails,' or broader AI regulation. She traveled to China in March 2019 as part of a congressional delegation, but discussions focused on trade, agriculture, tech/IP, healthcare, and North Korea - not specifically AI. She announced in January 2026 that she will not seek re-election. The three quotes provided above represent essentially all publicly available statements she has made about AI. A comprehensive '10 quotes' analysis is not possible with available information.

Raul Ruiz.summary: Rep. Raul Ruiz (D-CA), a physician serving on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, has expressed concerns about AI in healthcare, particularly regarding mental health chatbots and the need for oversight. His limited public statements on AI focus primarily on patient safety and the risks of unregulated AI applications in healthcare rather than broader AI policy issues.

quotes.quote: Imagine you're admitting your suicidal thoughts and the clinician just holds up a poster board with a hotline number, and then continues with more deep conversations about how to actually complete suicide
quotes.source: House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee Hearing, September 3, 2025
quotes.context: Rep. Ruiz was expressing concern about AI chatbots like ChatGPT being used for mental health support, warning that they might provide baseline correct information while also indulging users' harmful thoughts in ways a human professional would never do. He referenced the death of 16-year-old Adam Raine, whose parents say was encouraged to commit suicide by ChatGPT.

Raul Ruiz.notes: Very limited public information available about Rep. Raul Ruiz's views on AI. As a physician on the House Energy and Commerce Committee, his only documented AI-related statements come from a September 2025 hearing titled 'Examining Opportunities to Advance American Health Care through the Use of Artificial Intelligence Technologies.' His focus appears to be narrowly on healthcare applications of AI, particularly mental health chatbots and prior authorization systems. He expressed concern that direct-to-consumer chatbots like ChatGPT could be actively harmful to vulnerable users. The hearing indicated bipartisan agreement on the need for AI oversight in healthcare, though lawmakers proposed few concrete regulatory plans. Rep. Ruiz's background as an emergency physician and his committee assignments suggest his AI interests are primarily healthcare-focused rather than oriented toward broader AI policy, national security, or existential risk issues. No evidence found of statements about China's AI capabilities, AGI timelines, AI companies/executives, or transformative AI scenarios.

Mark Takano.summary: Mark Takano's AI-related work focuses primarily on algorithmic accountability in criminal justice and ensuring Congress has technical expertise to legislate on emerging technologies. His statements emphasize transparency, due process rights, and the need for unbiased technical assessments rather than broader AI policy questions about transformative potential or existential risks.

quotes.quote: We need to give defendants the rights to get the source code and [not] allow intellectual property rights to be able to trump due process rights.
quotes.source: Axios, regarding Justice in Forensic Algorithms Act (2019)
quotes.context: Takano introduced legislation to ensure defendants can access source code of algorithms used as evidence against them in criminal proceedings, prioritizing due process over trade secrets.

quotes.quote: The American public has felt the consequences as Congress's slow action on technology regulation including on data privacy and cryptocurrency. Now, generative artificial intelligence has emerged with the potential to significantly change the way we work and live.
quotes.source: Press release on Office of Technology Assessment bill (2023)
quotes.context: Takano acknowledging the transformative potential of generative AI while advocating for Congress to have better technical expertise.

quotes.quote: It is this type of exploding technology that requires an Office of Technology Assessment to provide unbiased and scientific assessments for Members of Congress and their staff. It is imperative that we revive the OTA in order to legislate proactively and meet the technological advances of the future.
quotes.source: Press release on OTA Improvement and Enhancement Act (2023)
quotes.context: Emphasizing the need for Congress to have independent technical expertise to handle rapidly advancing AI technologies.

quotes.quote: As Congress considers the use of technologies such as AI, facial recognition, quantum computing, and emerging energy storage and generation in both the private and public sectors, it is increasingly important that Members of Congress have access to unbiased assessments of what is on the horizon.
quotes.source: Press release on OTA legislation (2019)
quotes.context: Highlighting the need for forward-looking technical expertise on AI and other emerging technologies.

quotes.quote: The trade secrets privileges of software developers should never trump the due process rights of defendants in the criminal justice system. As technological innovations enter our criminal justice system, we must ensure that they don't undermine defendants' rights.
quotes.source: Press release on Justice in Forensic Algorithms Act (reintroduction)
quotes.context: Takano's core position on algorithmic accountability in criminal justice.

quotes.quote: My position is not that I'm against these algorithms … but we need to make sure that defendants in a court of law and their attorneys are able to exercise, under the Constitution, due process rights to a fair trial.
quotes.source: Brookings panel on forensic algorithms (2022)
quotes.context: Clarifying that his concern is not with AI technology itself but with ensuring constitutional rights are protected.

quotes.quote: Defense attorneys and defendants themselves should be able to question the technology and the technology should not be seen … as being infallible.
quotes.source: Phone interview with The Verge (2024)
quotes.context: Emphasizing that AI and algorithms should not be treated as unquestionable authorities in criminal proceedings.

quotes.quote: Defunding the OTA significantly eroded the technological capacity of this institution, especially as the use of technology became more prominent in our society.
quotes.source: Press release on OTA legislation (2019)
quotes.context: Arguing that Congress needs better technical capacity to understand AI and other emerging technologies.

quotes.quote: Congress' technology assessment needs will only continue to grow as we work to anticipate the potential benefits and effects of emerging technologies.
quotes.source: Medium article on OTA (2019)
quotes.context: Emphasizing the need for Congress to understand both benefits and risks of emerging technologies including AI.

quotes.quote: The foundation for good policy-making is accurate and objective analysis, and for more than two decades the OTA set that foundation by providing relevant, unbiased, technical and scientific assessments for Members of Congress and staff.
quotes.source: Testimony to Appropriations Subcommittee (2018)
quotes.context: Advocating for non-partisan technical expertise to inform AI and technology policy.

Mark Takano.notes: Mark Takano's public statements on AI are notably limited and focused on two specific areas: (1) algorithmic transparency and due process rights in criminal justice through his Justice in Forensic Algorithms Act, and (2) ensuring Congress has independent technical expertise through reviving the Office of Technology Assessment. He does not appear to have made public statements about: AGI or superintelligence, existential risk from AI, AI safety or alignment research, China's AI development, specific AI companies or tech leaders, or detailed AI policy frameworks. His stance is cautious and focused on transparency, accountability, and ensuring proper oversight mechanisms are in place. He acknowledges AI's transformative potential but approaches it primarily from a governance and institutional capacity perspective rather than engaging with deeper technical or philosophical questions about AI's trajectory. As a member of the House Veterans' Affairs Committee and Education & Labor Committee, his legislative focus has been on veterans issues and education rather than technology policy specifically.

Juan Vargas.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or policy positions from Representative Juan Vargas regarding artificial intelligence could be identified. Despite serving on the House Financial Services Committee where AI in fintech is discussed, Vargas has not made recorded public comments on AI policy, safety, regulation, or related issues.
Juan Vargas.notes: Representative Juan Vargas (D-CA-52) serves on the House Financial Services Committee, including the Capital Markets and Financial Institutions subcommittees, where AI issues in financial services are occasionally discussed. However, despite comprehensive searches of congressional records, his official website, press releases, voting records, committee testimony, and news coverage from 2013-2026, no public statements, speeches, legislative proposals, or policy positions specifically addressing artificial intelligence were found. His legislative focus appears to be primarily on immigration, financial services regulation (particularly ESG and Federal Reserve issues), environmental protection, housing, and international affairs related to Latin America. The House Financial Services Committee held hearings on AI in financial services in December 2025, but no record of Vargas's participation or statements on AI from those hearings could be located. It is possible he has views on AI that have not been publicly documented, or that AI policy is not currently a priority area for his legislative work.

Scott H. Peters.summary: Rep. Scott Peters has made very limited public statements specifically about AI. His mentions of AI have primarily been in the context of energy infrastructure needs to support AI expansion and cybersecurity concerns related to AI platforms. He does not appear to have developed a comprehensive public position on AI policy, safety, or existential risks.

quotes.quote: Instead of building clean energy infrastructure and increasing our energy supply to support the expansion of AI, Republicans would rather cut funding for projects that are already underway and ask Americans to take shorter showers.
quotes.source: Twitter/X, February 2025
quotes.context: Peters criticized Republican energy policy in the context of AI's growing energy demands, viewing AI expansion as requiring significant infrastructure investment.

quotes.quote: Just last year, Microsoft was hacked by China due to 'avoidable errors' in their cybersecurity system.
quotes.source: Twitter/X, February 11, 2025
quotes.context: Peters expressed concerns about Elon Musk processing sensitive data through Microsoft's AI platform, urging DOGE to stop its work immediately due to cybersecurity vulnerabilities.

quotes.quote: For the first time in some decades, we're going to see an increase in demand for electricity because of AI, because of reshoring manufacturing, both under policies driven by President Biden, President Trump, electrification–that load growth not only challenges our supply, but threatens to destabilize the grid.
quotes.source: The Rebuild podcast interview, June 2025
quotes.context: Peters discussed AI as one of several factors driving increased electricity demand and the need for grid modernization.

quotes.quote: As energy costs continue to rise across the country, it's important we meet the growing demand for electrification, data centers, and clean-tech manufacturing.
quotes.source: Statement on ePermit Act, November 2025
quotes.context: Peters referenced data centers (often associated with AI) as part of broader infrastructure modernization efforts.

Scott H. Peters.notes: Rep. Scott Peters (D-CA-50) has not been a prominent voice on AI policy in Congress. His limited public statements about AI focus on: (1) energy infrastructure needs to support AI expansion, (2) cybersecurity concerns related to Microsoft's AI platform being hacked by China, and (3) data center energy demands. He has NOT made public statements about: AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, transformative potential of AI, AI regulation frameworks, or AI ethics. His focus areas in Congress are climate/energy policy, biomedical research, veterans affairs, and San Diego-specific issues. He serves on the House Energy and Commerce Committee and House Budget Committee. The limited AI-related comments suggest he views AI primarily through the lens of infrastructure and energy policy rather than as a standalone policy priority. It's possible he has made additional statements not captured in public records, but there is insufficient public information to provide 10 substantive quotes about his AI views.

Lois Frankel.summary: Representative Lois Frankel (D-FL-22) has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. The only documented AI-related activity is her securing $1 million in federal funding for AI training at Palm Beach State College in 2023, acknowledging the need for U.S. competitiveness in AI education.

quotes.quote: Unable to locate direct quotes from Rep. Frankel specifically about AI policy, regulation, or technology
quotes.source: Comprehensive search of congressional records, press releases, and news sources (January 2026)
quotes.context: Rep. Frankel announced funding for AI training at Palm Beach State College in January 2023, but no direct quotes from her about AI were available in the announcement coverage

Lois Frankel.notes: Representative Lois Frankel has not been a prominent voice in congressional AI policy debates based on available public records. Her legislative focus areas include health care (33% of sponsored bills), international affairs (18%), labor and employment (15%), women's issues, reproductive rights, Social Security and Medicare, and support for Israel. She serves on the House Appropriations Committee and its Labor, Health and Human Services, Education subcommittee. While she secured funding for AI workforce training in her district in 2023, there is no public record of her participating in major AI policy discussions, hearings, or legislation. She has not co-sponsored major AI bills or made public statements about AI safety, regulation, China's AI development, or related issues that were discoverable through comprehensive searches of congressional records, her official website, press releases, social media, and news coverage through January 2026.

Tammy Duckworth.summary: Senator Duckworth's AI stance focuses primarily on practical applications in military readiness, protecting workers with disabilities from algorithmic bias, and concerns about AI companies' antitrust practices. She emphasizes the importance of human judgment over AI in critical decisions, particularly in aviation and military contexts, while supporting AI development for national security purposes to compete with China.

quotes.quote: You need that human being there. An artificial intelligence algorithm would have told you to turn that miracle flight back to the airport, and not land on the Hudson, but landing on the Hudson was the right decision, and only a human being could have made that decision.
quotes.source: PopSci interview, April 2021
quotes.context: Discussing the limits of AI in aviation and why pilots should never be fully replaced by AI systems, referencing Captain Sullenberger's 'Miracle on the Hudson' landing

quotes.quote: To ensure our national security and military readiness is as strong as it can be, we cannot risk overlooking the computer programming, artificial intelligence and other advanced technological talent of our servicemembers—particularly those members of the Reserve Component who have tech and digital skills from their civilian careers.
quotes.source: Press release on Managing Active and Reserve Tech Talent Effectively Act, March 2023
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to help the military better leverage AI and tech talent among servicemembers

quotes.quote: Does anyone truly have confidence that had DOGE been around decades ago, they would not have cut the project that created the internet as an example of wasteful, publicly funded research and development?
quotes.source: Senate Commerce Committee hearing with Sam Altman, May 8, 2025
quotes.context: Criticizing cuts to federal research funding that could undermine AI development, warning about the importance of government investment in emerging technologies

quotes.quote: It is crucial that we ensure that big tech platforms do not misappropriate content from journalists and other content creators, leading to less local news reporting and credible sources of information, along with lower levels of competition, investment, innovation in the digital marketplace.
quotes.source: Letter to DOJ and FTC on generative AI antitrust concerns, September 2024
quotes.context: Co-signed letter urging investigation of generative AI features for potential antitrust violations

quotes.quote: This Executive Order, President Biden is taking decisive action to help protect our national security and prevent China from strengthening its military with American dollars. This move...will help ensure that the United States can remain a leader in emerging technologies like AI, quantum technologies and semiconductors.
quotes.source: Statement on Biden Executive Order limiting US investments in China, August 2023
quotes.context: Supporting restrictions on US investments in Chinese AI and advanced technology sectors for national security reasons

quotes.quote: We write to respectfully request that the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) and the Department of Labor (DoL) undergo a thorough review of artificial intelligence (AI), algorithms and algorithmic bias, including but not limited to hiring and worker productivity practices conducted by both employers and employment agencies that involve AI, as well as how such practices may discriminate against people with disabilities.
quotes.source: Letter to FTC, EEOC, and DoL on AI discrimination, date unknown (pre-2024)
quotes.context: Leading colleagues in calling for federal review of AI's impact on employment opportunities for Americans with disabilities

quotes.quote: cultivating a strong and competitive workforce in computer programming, coding and Artificial Intelligence (AI) is key to bolstering our military readiness and national security
quotes.source: Press release on military tech workforce bill, 2023
quotes.context: Emphasizing AI's importance to military competitiveness and national security

quotes.quote: criticized cuts by President Donald Trump and billionaire Elon Musk to federal funding for research and to agencies like the Energy Department's national laboratories and National Science Foundation, painting them as 'a self sabotaging attack'
quotes.source: Senate hearing on AI competition, May 2025
quotes.context: Warning that cuts to federal research agencies could undermine America's AI competitiveness

quotes.quote: The other half of what I'll be doing is really continuing to develop my relationships that I have formed over the years with the Taiwan leadership and the Taiwan Ministry of Defense when it comes to making sure that the Taiwan people understand that the U.S. will stand with them when it comes to securing Taiwan from a potential PRC [People's Republic of China] attack.
quotes.source: Interview about trip to Taiwan and Singapore, May 2025
quotes.context: Discussing efforts to secure partnerships with Taiwan on quantum computing and advanced technology, including work on the Illinois Quantum and Microelectronics Park

quotes.quote: The data on the risks that algorithms, particularly those that rely on AI, pose to replicating and even amplifying human biases are well-cited, and the evidence continues to grow.
quotes.source: Letter on AI algorithmic bias and disability discrimination
quotes.context: Highlighting concerns about AI perpetuating discrimination in employment practices

Tammy Duckworth.notes: Senator Duckworth's AI views are pragmatic and focused on specific policy areas rather than broad philosophical questions about AGI or existential risk. Her main concerns are: (1) maintaining US competitiveness against China in AI and quantum computing, (2) protecting vulnerable populations (especially people with disabilities) from algorithmic bias, (3) ensuring human judgment remains central in critical decisions like aviation and military operations, (4) preventing AI companies from engaging in anticompetitive practices, and (5) protecting federal research funding that enables AI innovation. As a combat veteran and helicopter pilot who lost both legs in Iraq, she brings a unique perspective emphasizing the irreplaceable value of human decision-making in high-stakes situations. She has introduced legislation to better leverage AI talent in the military and has been active in securing provisions for quantum computing research in Illinois. She does not appear to engage with debates about AGI, alignment, or existential risk from AI.

Andy Barr.summary: Congressman Andy Barr (R-KY) views AI primarily through the lens of U.S.-China competition and national security, positioning it as a critical technology race that America must win. His AI policy focuses almost entirely on energy infrastructure (specifically coal power) needed to support AI development, framing AI as transformative for national competitiveness but showing no engagement with AI safety, alignment, or existential risk concerns.

quotes.quote: The race for AI is now. It's not 10, 20 years in the future. It's right now.
quotes.source: Harlan County coal mine visit, January 2026
quotes.context: Speaking at Portal 31 coal mine about his plan to revitalize Kentucky's coal industry to power AI infrastructure

quotes.quote: And as the CEO of NVIDIA said, we are nanoseconds ahead of China. We are not light years ahead of China. We have to stay moving fast ahead.
quotes.source: Harlan County coal mine visit, January 2026
quotes.context: Referencing NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang to emphasize urgency of AI competition with China

quotes.quote: We need coal to win the A.I. race, to make sure that we make America competitive, and that we defend our national security in 2026 and beyond.
quotes.source: Harlan County visit, January 2026
quotes.context: Connecting coal energy production to AI competitiveness and national security

quotes.quote: The competition with the Chinese Communist Party and AI is very, very serious, and we need coal to win that race.
quotes.source: Lynch, Kentucky, January 2026
quotes.context: Speaking to coal miners and supporters about AI as part of broader U.S.-China competition

quotes.quote: There is a future for coal, not because we just want it…we have to have it in order for us to win the race for future technologies, and we have adversaries that are racing ahead in Artificial Intelligence, in quantum computing, digital assets, and energy intensive technologies.
quotes.source: Harlan County, January 2026
quotes.context: Listing AI among critical future technologies in competition with adversaries

quotes.quote: Electric grid reliability is collapsing as artificial intelligence related power demand is surging to historic highs.
quotes.source: Harlan County speech, January 2026
quotes.context: Describing the energy crisis driven by AI data center demands

quotes.quote: China is racing ahead with more coal plants per week. As we are retiring coal plants, China is guaranteeing baseload power for A.I. by approving roughly 2 coal plants per week.
quotes.source: Harlan County speech, January 2026
quotes.context: Contrasting U.S. and Chinese approaches to energy infrastructure for AI

quotes.quote: This is a vision that lays the groundwork for the future jobs and prosperity of Eastern Kentucky. But it's also at the center of America's national security imperative, which is to win the race for these technologies of the future.
quotes.source: January 2026 campaign speech
quotes.context: Linking Kentucky coal to national security and AI technology race

quotes.quote: Kentucky is uniquely positioned to help the United States advance our national security in this competition with China.
quotes.source: Northern Kentucky Chamber forum, August 2025
quotes.context: Speaking about AI, cryptocurrency, and U.S.-China competition at business forum

quotes.quote: There is no source of power that can do that like coal...Nuclear is in the future, perhaps, but we are decades away from permitting nuclear power plants. We have the existing infrastructure here.
quotes.source: PBS Kentucky Edition, January 2026
quotes.context: Arguing coal is the only viable energy source to power AI development in the near term

Andy Barr.notes:
Andy Barr's AI discourse is remarkably narrow and instrumental. His entire AI policy framework centers on:

1. **Energy Infrastructure**: Views AI primarily as an energy consumption challenge requiring coal power plants
2. **China Competition**: Frames AI almost exclusively through U.S.-China rivalry lens, repeatedly invoking the 'Chinese Communist Party' threat
3. **Economic Opportunity**: Sees AI as job creation opportunity for Kentucky (coal, manufacturing, data centers)
4. **National Security**: Positions AI development as critical to national defense and military advantage

Notably ABSENT from his discourse:
- No discussion of AI safety, alignment, or control problems
- No mention of existential risk or catastrophic scenarios
- No engagement with AGI timelines or capabilities concerns
- No discussion of AI ethics, bias, or fairness
- No mention of regulation beyond energy/permitting
- No substantive technical understanding of AI demonstrated

Barr serves on the House Select Committee on Strategic Competition Between the United States and the Chinese Communist Party, which shapes his China-centric framing. He has introduced legislation on U.S.-China science and technology agreements and the 'Securing Reliable Power for Advanced Technologies Act.' His only reference to an AI company leader is citing NVIDIA's CEO Jensen Huang on China competition.

His stance is 'supportive' of AI development but only in the context of winning geopolitical competition, with zero apparent concern for safety or alignment issues that dominate technical AI safety discourse.

Elizabeth Warren.summary: Elizabeth Warren approaches AI primarily through an antitrust and consumer protection lens, focusing on preventing Big Tech monopolies, protecting consumers from AI-driven harms (especially in healthcare and housing), and ensuring competition in AI markets. She views AI as potentially transformative but emphasizes the need for strong regulation to prevent corporate abuses and protect national security, particularly regarding China's access to advanced AI chips.

quotes.quote: Today, the Senate acted to make sure American customers — including small businesses and startups — aren't forced to wait in line behind China's tech giants when purchasing the latest AI chips.
quotes.source: Senate Banking Committee statement on GAIN AI Act passage, 2025
quotes.context: Warren co-sponsored bipartisan legislation to ensure U.S. companies get priority access to AI chips over Chinese companies, demonstrating her concern about AI competition with China.

quotes.quote: Each of the major cloud services — Google, Microsoft and Amazon — should not be allowed to use their enormous size to dominate a whole new field, and that means blocking them from operating large language models.
quotes.source: RemedyFest conference, Washington D.C., February 2024
quotes.context: Warren called for preventing Big Tech companies from developing AI large language models to promote competition and prevent monopolistic control of the AI sector.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence represents the most promising capabilities for transformational productivity and impact of the department.
quotes.source: Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on defense contracting, April 2025
quotes.context: Warren acknowledged AI's transformative potential while discussing Department of Defense procurement, showing she views AI as genuinely powerful technology.

quotes.quote: We are concerned that corporate partnerships within the AI sector discourage competition, circumvent our antitrust laws, and result in fewer choices and higher prices for businesses and consumers using AI tools.
quotes.source: Letter to Google/Microsoft regarding Anthropic/OpenAI partnerships, April 2025
quotes.context: Warren and Senator Wyden launched an investigation into whether Big Tech partnerships with AI developers violate antitrust laws.

quotes.quote: After NVIDIA's CEO paid for a special dinner and his company donated to Donald Trump's gold-plated ballroom, he got his wish to sell advanced AI chips to China. Money talks in the Trump Administration.
quotes.source: X (Twitter) post, December 2025
quotes.context: Warren criticized the Trump administration's decision to allow Nvidia to sell H200 AI chips to China, linking it to corporate influence and expressing national security concerns.

quotes.quote: In light of DeepSeek, we must reinforce our controls on (China).
quotes.source: Letter to Commerce Department nominee Jeffrey Kessler, March 2025
quotes.context: Warren called for tougher AI chip export controls after China's DeepSeek AI breakthrough, characterizing it as an 'export control failure.'

quotes.quote: I do not understand why the press has been barred from this meeting. What most of the people have said is we want innovation, but we have got to protect safety.
quotes.source: Statement following closed-door Senate AI forum, September 2023
quotes.context: Warren criticized the secrecy of a Senate AI meeting with tech leaders including Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg, and Sam Altman, calling for transparency while acknowledging the need to balance innovation with safety.

quotes.quote: Republicans snuck an AI regulation BAN into the 'Big Beautiful Bill.' That means companies like Real Page can use AI to get around price fixing laws and RAISE YOUR RENT.
quotes.source: X (Twitter) post, June 2025
quotes.context: Warren opposed provisions that would prevent states from regulating AI, specifically concerned about AI being used for algorithmic rent-setting and price-fixing.

quotes.quote: Plans continue to use AI tools to erroneously deny care and contradict provider assessment findings.
quotes.source: Bicameral letter to CMS regarding Medicare Advantage, June 2024
quotes.context: Warren led efforts to increase oversight of AI algorithms used by Medicare Advantage insurers to deny healthcare coverage, highlighting immediate AI harms.

quotes.quote: While Mr. Altman has claimed that the company is not looking for a 'bail out,' OpenAI's actions suggest that it may be pursuing a deliberate strategy to entangle itself with the federal government and the broader economy so the government has no choice but to step in with public funds. We have seen this before: take on enough debt, make enough risky bets, and then demand a taxpayer bailout when those bets go south.
quotes.source: Letter to White House AI czar David Sacks, November 2025
quotes.context: Warren expressed concerns about an 'AI bubble' and warned against taxpayer bailouts of AI companies like OpenAI, drawing parallels to the 2008 financial crisis.

Elizabeth Warren.notes: Warren's AI stance is characterized by: (1) Strong focus on antitrust concerns and preventing Big Tech monopolies in AI; (2) Significant attention to China as a competitor in AI, with calls for stricter export controls on AI chips; (3) Emphasis on immediate, tangible harms from AI (healthcare denials, price-fixing, energy costs) rather than speculative existential risks; (4) Recognition of AI's transformative potential, particularly for defense and productivity; (5) Consistent demand for transparency, regulation, and corporate accountability; (6) Concern about AI companies seeking government bailouts. She does NOT discuss: AGI, superintelligence, AI alignment problems, or existential risk scenarios. Her approach is pragmatic and focused on consumer protection, competition policy, and national security rather than philosophical or long-term safety concerns. She has evolved from initial skepticism about AI tools (comparing ChatGPT to 'asking a random person on the street') to using ChatGPT herself while maintaining her regulatory stance.

Angus S. King, Jr..summary: Senator King views AI as potentially transformative but emphasizes a cautious, security-focused approach. He is deeply concerned about national security threats from AI, particularly regarding foreign adversaries like China and Russia, and has been a leading voice on catastrophic risks including biological, chemical, nuclear, and cyber weapons development. He advocates for federal oversight while maintaining American AI dominance.

quotes.quote: In the ever-evolving global threat landscape, the United States has to stay one step ahead of new technologies to protect both our national security and interests at home and abroad — and that means moving carefully, warily, and thoughtfully into an Artificial Intelligence future.
quotes.source: Press release on Preserving American Dominance in AI Act
quotes.context: King's signature statement on AI policy, repeated in multiple legislative announcements, emphasizing cautious advancement balanced with security concerns.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence (AI) has the potential to dramatically improve and transform society, but also presents a spectrum of risks that could be harmful to the American public, some of which could have catastrophic effects.
quotes.source: Preserving American Dominance in AI Act announcement
quotes.context: King's balanced view acknowledging both transformative potential and catastrophic risks of AI technology.

quotes.quote: AI has the potential to dramatically improve and transform our way of life, but it also comes with enormous risks to national security and our humanity at large.
quotes.source: Bipartisan AI framework announcement, April 2024
quotes.context: King expressing concern about existential-level risks to humanity from advanced AI systems.

quotes.quote: It is developing so fast that we don't know how to handle it... It is going to have a huge impact on us.
quotes.source: Oak Hill High School address, March 30, 2023
quotes.context: King speaking to students about his biggest worries, identifying AI as a top concern due to rapid development outpacing regulatory frameworks.

quotes.quote: Our democracy is based on information... artificial intelligence will give people the ability to create false information that's so true to life that people won't be able to tell it's not true.
quotes.source: Oak Hill High School address, March 30, 2023
quotes.context: King explaining his concerns about AI-generated misinformation threatening democratic processes.

quotes.quote: Extremely powerful frontier AI could be misused by foreign adversaries, terrorists, and less sophisticated bad actors to cause widespread harm and threaten U.S. national security.
quotes.source: Bipartisan AI framework letter to Senate AI working group
quotes.context: King highlighting specific threat actors and national security concerns regarding advanced AI models.

quotes.quote: Experts from across the U.S. government, industry, and academia believe that advanced AI could one day enable or assist in the development of chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear, and cyber weapons.
quotes.source: Preserving American Dominance in AI Act announcement
quotes.context: King citing expert consensus on catastrophic weapons-development risks from AI.

quotes.quote: I don't want the government deciding what is true and not true.
quotes.source: Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee hearing on AI watermarking
quotes.context: King discussing AI content labeling while emphasizing limits on government authority in determining truth.

quotes.quote: Given OpenAI's position as a leading AI company, it is important that the public can trust in the safety and security of its systems.
quotes.source: Letter to OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, 2024
quotes.context: King and colleagues demanding accountability from OpenAI regarding safety practices and whistleblower concerns.

quotes.quote: We must ask important questions now to wisely navigate our next steps and decisions.
quotes.source: Multiple AI policy announcements
quotes.context: King's recurring emphasis on the need for thoughtful, proactive AI governance before problems emerge.

Angus S. King, Jr..notes: Senator King is Co-Chair of the Cyberspace Solarium Commission and sits on both the Senate Armed Services and Intelligence Committees, giving him significant expertise in cybersecurity and national security. He has been particularly active on AI policy, co-authoring the 'Preserving American Dominance in AI Act' with bipartisan colleagues. His approach emphasizes: (1) National security threats from foreign adversaries, especially China and Russia; (2) Catastrophic risks including CBRN (chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear) and cyber weapons; (3) The need for federal oversight of 'frontier models' (most advanced AI); (4) Maintaining American AI dominance while implementing safety measures; (5) Misinformation and deepfakes threatening democracy. King specifically demanded answers from OpenAI about safety practices and mentions companies like Google and OpenAI in hearings. While he acknowledges transformative potential, he is not 'AGI-pilled' in the sense of being focused on superintelligence scenarios—his concerns are more grounded in near-term national security and weapons proliferation risks. He attended the September 2023 AI Insight Forum with tech CEOs including Sam Altman, Elon Musk, and Mark Zuckerberg. King's biggest stated fear is the misuse of AI, particularly for creating undetectable misinformation.

Ann Wagner.summary: Congresswoman Ann Wagner has made very limited public statements about AI. Her primary engagement with AI policy has been through legislation addressing AI-generated child sexual abuse material (the ENFORCE Act) and opposition to SEC regulation of AI/predictive analytics in financial services. She has not made substantive public statements about broader AI policy issues.

quotes.quote: The rise in Artificial Intelligence (AI) has made these horrific crimes easier to commit, and it's time we made sure prosecutors have the necessary tools to fight back
quotes.source: Press release, August 4, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing the ENFORCE Act to combat AI-generated child sexual abuse material

quotes.quote: The world is constantly changing with AI, and predators and child abusers are adapting to these new technologies
quotes.source: Press release, August 4, 2025
quotes.context: Statement on the ENFORCE Act regarding AI-generated CSAM

quotes.quote: My ENFORCE Act will ensure AI-generated CSAM is prosecuted and penalized with the same weight as other federal sex crimes
quotes.source: Press release, August 4, 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the purpose of the ENFORCE Act

quotes.quote: It should not rely on the recent attention around predictive data analytics or artificial intelligence as a pretext
quotes.source: Letter to SEC Chair Gary Gensler, September 22, 2023
quotes.context: Criticizing SEC's proposed rule on predictive data analytics and AI in financial services

quotes.quote: Furthermore, if the SEC intends to assume the role of a technology regulator, it should seek explicit authority from Congress
quotes.source: Letter to SEC Chair Gary Gensler, September 22, 2023
quotes.context: Opposing SEC overreach in regulating AI and predictive analytics

quotes.quote: China, Iran, and Russia have formed a new axis of evil to attack our national security interests
quotes.source: Press release, September 10, 2024
quotes.context: Statement on bill to combat China and limit its global influence (regarding export controls on sensitive technologies, though not specifically mentioning AI)

analysis.overall_stance: limited engagement - focused on specific harms

Ann Wagner.notes: Congresswoman Ann Wagner's public statements on AI are extremely limited and focused on two narrow areas: (1) combating criminal misuse of AI for generating child sexual abuse material, and (2) opposing regulatory overreach by the SEC regarding AI in financial services. She has not made public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, transformative potential of AI, or specific AI companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, etc. While she has introduced legislation concerning China and export controls on sensitive technologies, there is no evidence she has specifically addressed AI in the context of US-China competition. Her position on the House Intelligence Committee (appointed January 2025) may lead to more engagement with AI policy issues in the future, but as of now, her record shows minimal substantive engagement with broader AI policy questions. The quotes provided represent essentially all available public statements from her regarding AI.

Steve Daines.summary: Senator Steve Daines has limited public statements specifically about AI. His technology focus has been primarily on competing with China in innovation, supporting quantum computing research, and promoting American tech leadership. He appears to view AI as one component of broader technology competition rather than discussing it as a distinct transformative technology with unique risks.

quotes.quote: Winning the race against China is essential to maintaining the U.S.'s position as a global leader in technology and innovation.
quotes.source: Senate statement on U.S. Innovation and Competition Act, June 2021
quotes.context: Supporting bipartisan legislation to boost American innovation and compete with China, which included AI as one of several technology focus areas.

quotes.quote: We must invest in American innovation and technology if we're going to win the race against China.
quotes.source: Endless Frontier Act introduction, April 2021
quotes.context: Co-sponsoring legislation that included AI among 10 key technology focus areas, alongside semiconductors, quantum computing, and biotechnology.

quotes.quote: We've got to beat China. We've got to maintain our advantage in terms of quantum computing and science.
quotes.source: Bozeman Daily Chronicle, January 2026
quotes.context: Discussing quantum computing funding, mentioning AI as one of several applications that could benefit from quantum breakthroughs.

quotes.quote: Montana is leading the country in tech innovation, which will help us win the race against China.
quotes.source: Senate website, technology policy page
quotes.context: General statement about technology leadership, emphasizing competition with China.

quotes.quote: The Internet is unconstrained innovation. However, I think many of us are concerned that the Obama Administration and the FCC decided to step in and take over Internet regulatory control.
quotes.source: Senate Commerce hearing, March 2015
quotes.context: Opposing internet regulation, showing general preference for light-touch regulation of technology.

quotes.quote: I do have concerns as a consumer, as a parent about privacy and security, but I also have a great concern for technology and innovation to move quickly.
quotes.source: Senate Commerce hearing on Internet of Things, February 2015
quotes.context: Discussing balance between privacy concerns and technological innovation.

quotes.quote: Some of America's greatest companies were born on the internet. By dismantling harmful internet regulations, American companies will have an open internet that allows their business, and our economy, to grow.
quotes.source: Statement on FCC net neutrality rollback, 2017
quotes.context: Supporting deregulation of internet, showing pro-innovation, anti-regulation stance.

quotes.quote: America has long led the world in innovation. We must do everything we can to ensure that the conditions allowing our nation to lead continue to exist, especially in Crypto and blockchain innovation.
quotes.source: Twitter, September 14, 2021
quotes.context: Discussing cryptocurrency innovation, showing general support for emerging technologies.

quotes.quote: It is a massive competition going on right now. Between the United States and China, we comprise 42% of the world's economy.
quotes.source: Hugh Hewitt Show interview, March 2025
quotes.context: Discussing U.S.-China economic competition and the need for tax policies that incentivize R&D.

quotes.quote: [Quantum computing funding] could enable breakthroughs in medicine, wildfire detection, self-driving cars, artificial intelligence, banking and cybersecurity.
quotes.source: Bozeman Daily Chronicle, January 2026
quotes.context: One of the few direct mentions of AI, listing it as one application among many that could benefit from quantum computing advances.

Steve Daines.notes: Senator Daines has very limited public statements specifically about AI. His technology policy focuses heavily on: (1) U.S.-China competition, (2) deregulation and light-touch regulatory approaches, (3) supporting innovation through R&D funding, particularly in quantum computing, (4) protecting American tech companies from regulation. He does not appear to have engaged with AI-specific issues like safety, alignment, AGI risks, or discussions with AI companies. His mentions of AI are brief and treat it as one technology among many in the broader innovation ecosystem. He has not participated in Senate AI hearings (Judiciary Committee hearings on AI) based on available records. His background includes 6 years living in China in the 1990s with Procter & Gamble and later work with RightNow Technologies (cloud software), giving him business technology experience but not AI-specific expertise.
