He emphasizes transparency, accountability, and protecting Americans from AI-enabled scams and manipulation, while acknowledging AI's potential benefits. He is particularly concerned about the rapid pace of AI development outpacing regulation and has introduced multiple bipartisan bills focused on disclosure requirements and protecting specific sectors like financial markets.

quotes.quote: AI is moving quickly, and so are the scammers who are using it to exploit unsuspecting Americans.
quotes.source: AI Labeling Act introduction, October 2023
quotes.context: Kennedy co-introduced bipartisan legislation with Senator Schatz requiring AI-generated content to be labeled, emphasizing consumer protection from AI-enabled scams.

quotes.quote: AI is moving quickly, and so are the companies that are developing it. Our bill would set an AI-based standard to protect U.S. consumers by telling them whether what they're reading, seeing or hearing is the product of AI, and that's clarity that people desperately need.
quotes.source: AI Labeling Act press release, 2023
quotes.context: Explaining the need for transparency in AI-generated content to protect consumers from deception.

quotes.quote: Permit me to share with you three hypotheses that I would like you to assume for the moment to be true... Hypothesis number 3... there is likely a berserk wing of the artificial intelligence community that intentionally or unintentionally could use artificial intelligence to kill all of us and hurt us the entire time that we are dying... Please tell me in plain English two or three reforms, regulations, if any, that you would implement if you were queen or king for a day.
quotes.source: Senate Judiciary hearing on AI oversight, May 16, 2023
quotes.context: Kennedy questioning witnesses including Sam Altman about existential risks from AI and asking for specific regulatory recommendations in plain language.

quotes.quote: This is your chance, folks, to tell us how to get this right. Please use it. Talk in plain English and tell us what rules to implement.
quotes.source: Senate Judiciary hearing, May 16, 2023
quotes.context: Kennedy urging AI industry leaders to provide clear guidance on regulation, noting Congress's opportunity to act before AI causes serious harm.

quotes.quote: AI is moving quickly, and our laws should do the same to prevent AI manipulation from rattling our financial markets. Our bill would help ensure that AI threats do not put Americans' investments and retirement dreams at risk.
quotes.source: Financial Artificial Intelligence Risk Reduction Act introduction, December 2023
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to address AI manipulation risks in financial markets.

quotes.quote: AI has tremendous potential but also enormous disruptive power across a variety of fields and industries—perhaps none more so than our financial markets. The time to address those vulnerabilities is now.
quotes.source: Financial AI Risk Reduction Act press release, December 2023
quotes.context: Acknowledging both the benefits and risks of AI, with emphasis on proactive regulation.

quotes.quote: If you own a robot that's going to spit out artificial content to consumers, consumers have the right to know that it was generated by a robot and who owns the robot. And I think that's a good place to start.
quotes.source: Senate Judiciary hearing, September 12, 2023
quotes.context: Explaining his approach to AI regulation through transparency requirements, acknowledging Congress is taking 'baby steps' on comprehensive AI legislation.

quotes.quote: The extent of most Senators' knowledge in terms of the nuances of AI, their general impression is that AI has extraordinary potential to make our lives better if it doesn't make our lives worse first. And that's about the extent of it.
quotes.source: Senate Judiciary hearing, September 12, 2023
quotes.context: Candidly admitting the limited technical understanding among senators while recognizing AI's dual potential.

quotes.quote: And every time they say things like, we can't let China beat us, let me just translate that for you. Every time they say that, oh, we can't let China beat us, what they are really saying is, give us truckloads of cash and let us steal everything from you and make billions of dollars on it.
quotes.source: Senate Judiciary hearing on AI copyright, July 16, 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy criticizing AI companies' use of the China competition argument to justify lax regulation and copyright infringement.

quotes.quote: Child predators are resorting to more advanced technology than ever to escape justice, so Congress needs to close every loophole possible to help law enforcement fight this evil. I'm proud to help introduce the ENFORCE Act, which would allow officials to better target the sick animals creating deepfake content of America's kids.
quotes.source: ENFORCE Act introduction, October 2025
quotes.context: Supporting legislation to combat AI-generated child sexual abuse material, showing concern about AI misuse for criminal purposes.

John Kennedy.notes: Senator Kennedy demonstrates a practical, consumer-focused approach to AI regulation. He is notably skeptical of AI companies' motives, particularly their use of China competition arguments to resist regulation. He explicitly raised existential risk concerns in hearings, asking about 'a berserk wing of the artificial intelligence community that...could use artificial intelligence to kill all of us.' However, he focuses more on immediate, tangible harms like scams, financial manipulation, and child exploitation rather than long-term AGI scenarios. Kennedy has been active in bipartisan AI legislation, co-sponsoring bills on AI labeling, financial market protection, and combating AI-generated CSAM. He acknowledges senators' limited technical understanding of AI and advocates for 'baby steps' in regulation, starting with transparency requirements. His questioning style emphasizes getting 'plain English' answers from witnesses. He has also been critical of China's access to advanced AI chips, urging the Biden administration to stop exports. Kennedy does not appear to be 'AGI-pilled' in the sense of being focused on near-term AGI development, though he acknowledges existential risks when prompted.

Margaret Wood Hassan.summary: Senator Hassan takes a pragmatic, security-focused approach to AI, emphasizing the need for U.S. technological leadership over China while implementing safeguards against extreme risks. She views AI as transformative technology requiring balanced oversight that protects national security and workers without stifling innovation.

quotes.quote: As artificial intelligence advances rapidly, we must work on a bipartisan basis to proactively address the potential national security threats posed by this technology.
quotes.source: Preserving American Dominance in AI Act introduction, December 19, 2024
quotes.context: Hassan co-sponsored landmark bipartisan legislation to establish an AI Safety Review Office to evaluate frontier AI models for extreme risks including chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear, and cyber threats.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence (AI) has the potential to dramatically improve and transform our way of life, but also presents a spectrum of risks that could be harmful to the American public, some of which could have catastrophic effects.
quotes.source: Preserving American Dominance in AI Act, December 2024
quotes.context: This quote captures Hassan's balanced view recognizing both AI's transformative potential and catastrophic risks, appearing in legislation she co-sponsored addressing extreme AI risks.

quotes.quote: This bipartisan legislation establishes safeguards to make sure that the U.S. remains the world leader in responsible AI. We must continue to work to protect against potential risks to public safety, such as the misuse of this technology by terrorists or criminal organizations.
quotes.source: Statement on Preserving American Dominance in AI Act, December 2024
quotes.context: Hassan emphasizes maintaining U.S. leadership while protecting against misuse by bad actors, reflecting her focus on balancing innovation with security.

quotes.quote: By implementing balanced oversight of the most advanced AI models, we can maintain our technological leadership while protecting public safety and our national interests.
quotes.source: Preserving American Dominance in AI Act statement, December 2024
quotes.context: Hassan articulates her philosophy of balanced regulation that doesn't sacrifice American competitiveness while ensuring safety.

quotes.quote: American workers cannot be left behind as American corporations continue to push forward with the development and adoption of artificial intelligence.
quotes.source: AI Workforce PREPARE Act introduction, December 12, 2025
quotes.context: Hassan introduced bipartisan legislation to help the federal government assess AI's impact on the workforce and ensure workers are prepared for the AI economy.

quotes.quote: We have to understand how AI is changing the workforce so we can equip American workers with the skills necessary to stay ahead of China and lead the world.
quotes.source: AI Workforce PREPARE Act, co-sponsor Senator Banks quoted, December 2025
quotes.context: The bill Hassan co-sponsored explicitly frames AI workforce preparation in terms of U.S.-China competition.

quotes.quote: Although there has been considerable Congressional attention paid to many of the public safety risks posed by artificial intelligence, there has been less focus on so-called 'catastrophic' risks posed by AI – such as the ability of AI to help terrorists develop and use unconventional weapons.
quotes.source: Senate Homeland Security hearing on AI threats, September 20, 2023
quotes.context: As Chair of the Emerging Threats Subcommittee, Hassan highlighted catastrophic risks from AI, including AI jailbreaks that could help terrorists produce bioweapons.

quotes.quote: With advancements in AI, scams will continue to grow in sophistication, frequency, and impact.
quotes.source: Letter to AI companies with Senator Hawley, December 2025
quotes.context: Hassan pressed six major AI companies (OpenAI, Anthropic, Meta, Google, Microsoft, xAI, Perplexity) to crack down on AI-enabled scams, noting FBI-reported losses increased 370% from 2019 to 2024.

quotes.quote: This bipartisan legislation helps the federal government better assess the ways in which artificial intelligence is changing our economy and helps ensure that increased automation does not result in fewer jobs for hard-working American families.
quotes.source: AI Workforce PREPARE Act statement, December 2025
quotes.context: Hassan emphasizes protecting American workers from job displacement due to AI automation.

quotes.quote: As many small businesses struggle with rising costs, this bipartisan legislation cuts taxes for small businesses that invest in innovation, which will also help the United States continue to outcompete our adversaries like China.
quotes.source: American Innovation and Jobs Act statement, May 2025
quotes.context: Hassan co-sponsored legislation to incentivize R&D investment, explicitly framing innovation support in terms of competition with China.

Margaret Wood Hassan.notes: Senator Hassan demonstrates a notably pragmatic and security-focused approach to AI policy. Key observations: (1) CHINA FOCUS: She consistently frames AI development in terms of U.S.-China competition, co-sponsoring the Chip Security Act to prevent smuggling of advanced AI chips to China and supporting legislation to 'outcompete China.' (2) CATASTROPHIC/EXTREME RISKS: She explicitly discusses 'catastrophic effects' and 'extreme risks' from AI, including chemical, biological, radiological, nuclear, and cyber threats. Her Preserving American Dominance in AI Act specifically addresses these extreme risks. (3) NOT AGI-FOCUSED: While she acknowledges catastrophic risks, her language doesn't suggest she's 'AGI-pilled' in the longtermist sense. She focuses more on near-term misuse scenarios (terrorists, criminals, foreign adversaries) rather than superintelligence or alignment problems. (4) SAFETY & ALIGNMENT: She does discuss AI safety through the lens of preventing 'jailbreaks' and ensuring safeguards, but frames it primarily as a national security issue rather than technical alignment. (5) AI COMPANIES: She has directly engaged with major AI companies, sending letters to OpenAI, Anthropic, Meta, Google, Microsoft, xAI, and Perplexity demanding information about anti-scam measures. (6) WORKER PROTECTION: A consistent theme is protecting American workers from AI displacement. (7) BALANCED APPROACH: Her rhetoric emphasizes 'balanced oversight' that maintains U.S. technological leadership while implementing safeguards—she's not calling for pauses or moratoria but rather for measured regulation.

Catherine Cortez Masto.summary: Senator Cortez Masto views AI primarily through a national security and economic competitiveness lens, with heavy emphasis on staying ahead of China. She supports AI development with consumer protections and 'guardrails' in place, advocating for oversight while enabling innovation. Her approach is pragmatic and focused on practical applications rather than existential concerns.

quotes.quote: Artificial Intelligence has the potential to profoundly change many aspects of our lives
quotes.source: Press release, May 9, 2018
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to establish the National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence

quotes.quote: The commission proposed in this bill will provide guidance on how we cultivate AI to help ensure we stay ahead of countries like China in this space, while also building guardrails to make certain the U.S. government responsibly uses AI
quotes.source: Press release, May 9, 2018
quotes.context: Statement on National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence bill, emphasizing both competition with China and responsible use

quotes.quote: When it comes to cutting-edge technologies – such as AI and semiconductors – the United States must remain ahead of China
quotes.source: Press release, March 18, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing the FIGHT China Act to restrict U.S. investments in Chinese AI technology

quotes.quote: Technology, including AI, has advanced at a rapid pace in recent years, often making it difficult to ensure that rules and consumer protections keep pace with developments in the technology industry
quotes.source: Letter to FTC Chairman, May 16, 2018
quotes.context: Urging FTC to prioritize consumer protection from AI misuse, specifically mentioning Google Duplex

quotes.quote: An approach that combines strong protections for consumers while allowing the technology to thrive will allow the industry to solve problems, improve people's lives
quotes.source: Letter to FTC Chairman, May 16, 2018
quotes.context: Advocating for balanced regulation that protects consumers while enabling innovation

quotes.quote: AI is an exciting new technology that has countless applications. From helping companies increase efficiency to improving traffic and safety, AI can increase economic growth and drastically improve people's lives
quotes.source: Letter to FTC Chairman, May 16, 2018
quotes.context: Describing the benefits of AI before discussing potential harms

quotes.quote: We want to embrace it but we also want to put guardrails in place. We build that at the same time we build the infrastructure for this technology
quotes.source: Axios smart cities event, March 22, 2018
quotes.context: Discussing approach to new technologies like self-driving cars and drones

quotes.quote: My bipartisan legislation will support more American businesses directly competing with China to help them make breakthroughs in AI, critical mineral mining and processing, and other transformational areas
quotes.source: Press release, February 26, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing the Strengthening Exports Against China Act

quotes.quote: The United States should not be lending a helping hand to our adversaries in Communist China by investing in their development of artificial intelligence, quantum computers, or military technologies
quotes.source: Statement after FIGHT China Act passed Senate, October 2025
quotes.context: Celebrating passage of legislation restricting U.S. investments in Chinese AI

quotes.quote: I've seen firsthand how technology can drive our economy and deliver incredible innovations, but we have to make sure that there are guardrails in place to keep people safe
quotes.source: Press release, May 19, 2025
quotes.context: Supporting legislation to address AI-generated deepfakes and revenge porn

Catherine Cortez Masto.notes: Senator Cortez Masto's AI policy focus is heavily centered on U.S.-China competition and national security concerns. She consistently mentions China and other foreign adversaries (Russia, Iran, North Korea) when discussing AI. She co-sponsored multiple bills restricting U.S. investments in Chinese AI development and emphasizes maintaining American technological superiority. She does NOT discuss: AGI (artificial general intelligence), existential risk from AI, AI alignment problems, or superintelligence concerns. She briefly mentioned Google Duplex in 2018 regarding consumer protection but does not make public statements about AI companies like OpenAI, Microsoft, or Google as AI developers. Her approach is practical and policy-focused: consumer protection, border security applications, smart cities, economic competitiveness, and preventing technology transfer to adversaries. She uses the term 'guardrails' repeatedly to describe her preferred regulatory approach - enabling innovation while protecting against misuse. Her 2018 legislation helped establish the National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence, which became law. Recent legislative focus (2024-2025) includes restricting outbound investment to China in AI technologies and supporting American businesses competing with China in AI and semiconductors.

Bradley Scott Schneider.summary: After comprehensive research, no public statements or positions on artificial intelligence could be found for Representative Bradley Scott Schneider (D-IL-10). His public focus appears to be on healthcare, international affairs (particularly Middle East policy and U.S.-Israel relations), tax policy, and gun violence prevention.
Bradley Scott Schneider.notes: Representative Brad Schneider serves on the House Ways and Means Committee and House Foreign Affairs Committee. His legislative focus areas include healthcare innovation and training, international tax policy, sustainable aviation fuel, Middle East policy, and gun violence prevention. Despite serving in Congress during a period of significant AI policy development (2013-2015, 2017-present), no public record of statements, legislation, or positions on artificial intelligence could be located through searches of congressional records, his official website, press releases, news coverage, or social media. His background as an industrial engineer and management consultant might suggest potential interest in technology policy, but this has not manifested in public AI-related statements or activities. It's possible he has not made AI a priority issue, or any statements may be in venues not captured by public search engines.

Andy Biggs.summary: Rep. Andy Biggs (R-AZ) has primarily addressed AI in the context of criminal exploitation and regulatory reduction. His public statements focus on AI-enabled threats like deepfakes and fraud, and he has introduced legislation to use AI for reducing federal regulations. There is insufficient public record to fully assess his views on transformative AI, existential risk, or AI safety.

quotes.quote: AI-enabled threats continue to evolve as bad actors use AI technology in a wide spectrum of criminal enterprises.
quotes.source: House Judiciary Subcommittee hearing, July 16, 2025
quotes.context: Opening statement as Chairman of the Subcommittee on Crime and Federal Government Surveillance at a hearing on AI and criminal exploitation

quotes.quote: American businesses must be given the opportunity to thrive without overbearing, costly, contradictory, and duplicative regulations mandated by the DC Swamp. Federal overregulation takes a colossal toll on the U.S.
quotes.source: Press release, March 7, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing the Modernizing Retrospective Regulatory Review Act, which would use AI to analyze and reduce federal regulations

quotes.quote: The landscape continues to evolve at a rapid pace.
quotes.source: House Judiciary Subcommittee hearing, July 16, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the evolving nature of AI-enabled criminal threats

quotes.quote: What do you do if there is a deepfake of any other public figure, and you have that person say something that is pernicious, bad, or politically inflammatory? What laws do we have in place that would prohibit that, or is it just the Wild, Wild West?
quotes.source: House Judiciary Committee hearing, July 2025
quotes.context: Questioning witnesses about legal protections against AI deepfakes

quotes.quote: It is the same type of deal where you see CSAM, which is so persuasive, sick, and disgusting, that is all AI-generated. You mentioned the Ukraine thing, but what remedy does someone have when they are a victim of this type of generative AI?
quotes.source: House Judiciary Committee hearing, July 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI-generated child sexual abuse material and victim protections

quotes.quote: I'm afraid to tell you that we will fall perhaps irrevocably behind in this new race. Arizona is meant to be, in my opinion, the leader. The only true competitor we have is Virginia.
quotes.source: ASU Congressional Dialogue Series, August 15, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing Arizona's need for energy infrastructure to support AI data centers and compete in the AI economy

quotes.quote: All the Arizona universities bring something to the table and give us the skilled pipeline that come with these ideas. ASU is really doing a great job. They have a mega engineering school, and we are ready to go. We just have to get the power here.
quotes.source: ASU Congressional Dialogue Series, August 15, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing energy needs for AI development and Arizona's role in AI infrastructure

Andy Biggs.notes: Limited public information available. Rep. Biggs has primarily engaged with AI through two lenses: (1) criminal exploitation and threats (deepfakes, fraud, CSAM), where he chairs relevant hearings and seeks legal frameworks, and (2) regulatory reduction, proposing to use AI to streamline federal regulations. He supports AI-driven economic development in Arizona, particularly around data centers and energy infrastructure. However, there is no public record of him discussing AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, or making statements about major AI companies or figures like OpenAI, Anthropic, or Sam Altman. While he has written about China stealing U.S. intellectual property and technology generally, no specific statements about AI competition with China were found. His overall approach appears pragmatic and focused on immediate concerns (crime, regulation, economic development) rather than long-term transformative or existential considerations. The limited number of substantive AI quotes (7 instead of the requested 10) reflects the scarcity of his public statements specifically about artificial intelligence as a technology policy issue.

Ro Khanna.summary: Ro Khanna views AI as transformative technology that requires thoughtful regulation focused on protecting workers and ensuring economic equity. He is deeply concerned about AI exacerbating wealth inequality and emphasizes that workers must have decision-making power over AI implementation and share in its profits. While optimistic about AI's potential benefits, he rejects the focus on hypothetical existential risks in favor of addressing immediate harms like job displacement, deepfakes, and wealth concentration.

quotes.quote: The challenge has not been over regulation. The challenge has been, actually, we have no regulation. How can we just give the tech companies totally carte blanche to do whatever they want?
quotes.source: Axios AI+ DC Summit, September 2025
quotes.context: Khanna criticizing the lack of AI regulation and calling for guardrails on tech companies

quotes.quote: The Democratic Party cannot claim to be the party of the working class if we allow A.I. to erode the earnings and security of the working class.
quotes.source: New York Times op-ed, January 2024
quotes.context: Warning about AI's impact on workers and comparing it to the mistakes of unfettered globalization

quotes.quote: Technologies—our technologies—are meant to complement and enhance human initiative, not subordinate or exploit it. We must push for workers to have a decision-making role in how and when to adopt technologies.
quotes.source: New York Times op-ed, January 2024
quotes.context: Articulating his philosophy that workers should control how AI is deployed in their workplaces

quotes.quote: A third of the AI talent in the world is in China. It's one of the reasons we have to, in this country, be open to having human talent from around the world to win the AI race.
quotes.source: Washington Post interview, January 2025
quotes.context: Discussing China's AI capabilities after visiting Shanghai and emphasizing the need for the U.S. to attract global talent

quotes.quote: We need to have technology supremacy, technology leadership in the world, to make sure we're going to win in space, to make sure we're going to win with hypersonic technology, with A.I. technology, quantum computing technology. Putin's aggression shows us it's a dangerous world.
quotes.source: Fox Business interview, April 2022
quotes.context: Linking AI development to U.S. national security and competition with China and Russia

quotes.quote: I agree wholeheartedly that there is a need for legislation...but am concerned that the bill as currently written would be ineffective, punishing of individual entrepreneurs and small businesses, and hurt California's spirit of innovation.
quotes.source: Statement on California SB 1047, August 2024
quotes.context: Opposing California's AI safety bill focused on existential risks, preferring to focus on immediate issues like deepfakes and labeling

quotes.quote: Look, I am optimistic about AI's ability to help solve disease, to help improve education and also produce things. But just like electricity — just like any technology — it has to be done with safeguards and regulations.
quotes.source: Axios AI+ DC Summit, September 2025
quotes.context: Expressing optimism about AI's benefits while insisting on regulation to prevent exacerbating economic divides

quotes.quote: We need regulations that prevent companies from using AI to eliminate jobs to extract greater profits. Artists at these companies need to have a say in how AI is deployed. They should share in the profits.
quotes.source: Statement on Call of Duty AI usage, November 2025
quotes.context: Criticizing Activision Blizzard's use of AI-generated art and calling for worker protections

quotes.quote: Too often when we want to regulate AI, we think, 'Okay, let's call Elon Musk. Let's call Sam Altman. Let's call Bill Gates.' All brilliant people, but they're not academic neutral experts.
quotes.source: Decoder podcast interview, February 2024
quotes.context: Explaining why he convened academic experts rather than tech CEOs to inform AI policy

quotes.quote: We have to be aware of the impact AI technology could have on jobs, disinformation, and our nation's cybersecurity. Congress must craft smart and careful regulations to prevent any harmful uses of AI that won't stifle innovation.
quotes.source: Semafor interview, April 2023
quotes.context: Outlining his priorities for AI regulation and balancing innovation with protection

Ro Khanna.notes: Ro Khanna is deeply engaged with AI policy as the Representative for Silicon Valley (CA-17), which includes Apple, Intel, Nvidia, and Google. He was recently appointed Ranking Member of the House Select Committee on China (January 2025), where AI competition is a central focus. His stance is distinctive: he is NOT 'AGI-pilled' and explicitly rejected California's SB 1047 bill that focused on 'hypothetical existential risks,' instead prioritizing immediate harms like job displacement, deepfakes, misinformation, and wealth inequality. He frequently references China as having 'a third of the AI talent in the world' and views AI competition with China through an economic and national security lens, supporting chip export restrictions despite opposition from Nvidia in his district. He advocates for workers having board representation at AI companies, profit-sharing from AI productivity gains, and mandatory consultation before AI deployment. He identifies as a 'progressive capitalist' and authored 'Dignity in a Digital Age.' He has engaged with Sam Altman (attended dinner with him and other lawmakers), held academic roundtables on AI, and used ChatGPT to write legislation. He supported Elon Musk's call for a pause on AI but has also backed Bernie Sanders over Musk on worker protections. He called for an investigation into the death of OpenAI whistleblower Suchir Balaji. His approach balances innovation with worker protection, comparing AI's potential impact to globalization's hollowing out of the working class.

Jimmy Panetta.summary: Representative Jimmy Panetta approaches AI primarily through a national security and defense lens, emphasizing its importance for maintaining military advantage against geopolitical rivals. His statements focus on AI as a critical tool for cybersecurity and modern warfare, with limited public commentary on broader AI safety, alignment, or transformative potential beyond military applications.

quotes.quote: AI is increasingly central to modern, strategic warfare, and the United States needs to be prepared with a robust digital defense to meet these evolving national security challenges.
quotes.source: March 28, 2023 - Artificial Intelligence for National Security Act introduction
quotes.context: Statement supporting legislation to allow the Department of Defense to procure AI-enabled cybersecurity tools.

quotes.quote: This legislation ensures that the Department of Defense is able to leverage rapidly advancing artificial intelligence technology to respond to these kinds of cyber-attacks and keep pace with the capabilities of our geo-political rivals.
quotes.source: March 28, 2023 - AI for National Security Act
quotes.context: Discussing the need for DOD to use AI for cyber defense against adversaries.

quotes.quote: As malicious cyber-attacks grow in frequency, intensity, and sophistication, we need to ensure that our U.S. military has the tools needed to identify malign behavior and quickly protect our cyber-infrastructure.
quotes.source: March 28, 2023 - AI for National Security Act
quotes.context: Emphasizing the increasing threat landscape requiring AI-powered defenses.

quotes.quote: This legislation will leverage rapidly advancing and emerging artificial intelligence technology that is shaping the success of military planning and operations around the world.
quotes.source: May 19, 2022 - AI for National Security Act (earlier version)
quotes.context: Recognizing AI as transformative for military operations globally.

quotes.quote: Too often, opportunities for strategic partnership in Africa's fast-growing tech sector are overlooked due to outdated assumptions and fragmented policy. Our bipartisan BRIDGE Africa Act would support entrepreneurs, strengthen democratic governance, and open up new markets for U.S. goods and services.
quotes.source: July 25, 2025 - BRIDGE Africa Act introduction
quotes.context: Discussing AI partnerships with African nations in context of countering Chinese influence.

quotes.quote: Strengthening these ties will not only promote shared economic prosperity, but also bolster mutual security and digital resilience on the African continent and across the globe.
quotes.source: July 25, 2025 - BRIDGE Africa Act
quotes.context: Framing AI and tech partnerships as tools for security and democratic values.

quotes.quote: The Chinese Communist Party is hard at work trying to exploit the people of Africa, and it is key that the U.S. offer an alternative path supporting innovation directly in nations that are eager to work together for a brighter future.
quotes.source: July 25, 2025 - BRIDGE Africa Act (statement from co-sponsor Rep. Wilson that Panetta supported)
quotes.context: Legislation Panetta authored explicitly framed as countering Chinese tech influence in Africa.

quotes.quote: Based on the incredible research done at UCSC, I'm proud that the federal government continues to recognize and reward their work.
quotes.source: January 28, 2021 - Announcement of NSF grant for AI research
quotes.context: Announcing $625,000 for UC Santa Cruz research on AI decision-making impacts, particularly regarding bias in machine learning.

quotes.quote: We need to start thinking beyond the binary warfare — that no longer is it just peace or in war — there's sort of this gray area where this geopolitical, this guerrilla geopolitics are being played. And how do we counter that?
quotes.source: May 30, 2018 - POLITICO Pro interview
quotes.context: Discussing modern warfare and the need for hybrid capabilities including cyber and technology, providing context for his later AI focus.

quotes.quote: The bill will also help ensure that the United States can keep pace defensively with the offensive AI development and deployment of our adversaries.
quotes.source: March 28, 2023 - AI for National Security Act
quotes.context: Framing AI development as a competitive race with adversaries.

Jimmy Panetta.notes: Representative Panetta's public statements on AI are limited and heavily focused on national security applications. He consistently frames AI through a geopolitical competition lens, particularly regarding adversaries like China and Russia. His legislative work includes the AI for National Security Act (focused on DOD cybersecurity) and the BRIDGE Africa Act (countering Chinese tech influence). He has supported AI research funding at UC Santa Cruz, including work on bias in AI decision-making systems. However, he has made no public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, AI safety regulations, or specific AI companies/figures. His background as a Navy intelligence officer who served in Afghanistan appears to inform his security-focused approach to AI policy. His father, Leon Panetta (former Defense Secretary and CIA Director), likely influences his national security perspective. Overall, Panetta appears to view AI primarily as a strategic military technology requiring investment to maintain U.S. advantage, rather than engaging with broader debates about AI's societal impacts, safety concerns, or transformative potential beyond defense applications.

Salud O. Carbajal.summary: Rep. Carbajal has made limited public statements specifically about AI policy. His AI-related comments focus primarily on supporting AI research funding through the CHIPS and Science Act and celebrating AI research institutes in his district. He views AI as part of a broader 'technological and industrial revolution' but has not made extensive public statements on AI safety, existential risk, or detailed policy positions.

quotes.quote: Nearly one quarter of the way through the 21st century, we are entering a new technological and industrial revolution that is poised to completely change our day-to-day lives.
quotes.source: Press release on UCSB AI Research Institute, June 5, 2023
quotes.context: Carbajal made this statement when announcing UCSB's selection as a National AI Research Institute, expressing his view that AI is part of a transformative technological shift.

quotes.quote: the cutting edge is on the Central Coast
quotes.source: Press release on UCSB AI Research Institute, June 5, 2023
quotes.context: Celebrating UCSB being selected as one of the 'spear-tips in AI research and cybersecurity,' emphasizing regional leadership in emerging technologies including AI.

quotes.quote: transformative AI advances that are ethical, trustworthy, responsible, and serve the public good
quotes.source: Press release citing White House description of National AI Institutes, June 5, 2023
quotes.context: Carbajal referenced the White House's characterization of the National AI Institutes' mission, showing support for responsible AI development.

Salud O. Carbajal.notes: Rep. Carbajal's public statements on AI are extremely limited. His main AI-related activity has been: (1) voting for the CHIPS and Science Act which included AI research funding, (2) celebrating UCSB's selection as a National AI Research Institute focused on AI in cybersecurity, and (3) participating in an October 2025 meeting with HR leaders that discussed 'responsible, people-centered approaches to artificial intelligence in the workplace.' He has not made substantive public statements about AI safety, existential risk, AGI, competition with China on AI, or AI companies/key figures. His comments suggest he views AI as transformative technology deserving research investment, particularly for applications in cybersecurity and defense. As a member of the House Armed Services Committee and House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, he has shown interest in AI applications for defense and infrastructure but has not been a vocal voice on AI policy debates. The lack of detailed public statements makes it difficult to assess his deeper views on AI governance, safety, or long-term implications.

Nanette Diaz Barrag\u00e1n.summary: Rep. Barragán's public statements on AI are limited and focused primarily on equity, healthcare applications, and preventing discrimination against Latino communities. She views AI as transformative technology that requires guardrails to ensure fair distribution of benefits. Her AI policy work centers on practical applications in healthcare and ensuring marginalized communities are not left behind, rather than on existential risks or AGI concerns.

quotes.quote: As AI continues to play a larger role in our modern world, it's critical that AI services are not biased and serve everyone fairly.
quotes.source: CHC AI Roundtable, July 2024
quotes.context: Statement as CHC Chair during the inaugural Congressional Hispanic Caucus AI roundtable, emphasizing the need for fairness and non-discrimination in AI systems.

quotes.quote: These roundtables provide our caucus and industry leaders with a collaborative space to learn about the various ways this technology is being used now and in the future. We had an important discussion about the need for AI policies that prevent discrimination and do not leave behind our Latino communities.
quotes.source: CHC AI Roundtable readout, July 2024
quotes.context: Explaining the purpose of the CHC AI roundtable, focusing on equity and inclusion for Latino communities.

quotes.quote: AI can transform the care that millions of Americans receive. With the rapid developments in AI technology, we now have the capability to do more, provide better care, and close the health care disparities that we often see in our underserved and minority communities.
quotes.source: HEAL-AI Act introduction statement, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to fund AI literacy programs in medical schools, emphasizing AI's transformative potential in healthcare.

quotes.quote: As the CHC continues to champion equity, inclusion, and economic empowerment, we are committed to holding a series of sessions to ensure that as AI evolves, its benefits are broadly and fairly distributed, while its risks are effectively managed.
quotes.source: CHC AI Roundtable, July 2024
quotes.context: Statement on the CHC's ongoing commitment to AI policy focused on equitable distribution of benefits and risk management.

quotes.quote: [Signed letter stating California AI bill was] skewed toward addressing extreme misuse scenarios and hypothetical existential risks while largely ignoring demonstrable AI risks like misinformation, disinformation, non-consensual deepfakes.
quotes.source: Letter to Governor Newsom opposing California SB 1047, August 2024
quotes.context: Co-signed letter with 7 other California Democratic House members opposing state AI safety legislation, arguing it focused too much on hypothetical existential risks rather than current harms.

quotes.quote: It is imperative to raise awareness about the deceptive use of artificial intelligence creating fake videos that mislead Americans with false information about our candidates, especially among Americans whose first language is not English, including Latinos.
quotes.source: CHC Voting Rights Roundtable, September 2024 (statement by CHC Vice Chair Torres, but Barragán hosted the event)
quotes.context: Discussion at a CHC voting rights roundtable about AI-generated disinformation affecting Latino voters, showing concern about AI misuse in elections.

Nanette Diaz Barrag\u00e1n.notes: Rep. Barragán's public engagement with AI policy is limited and primarily filtered through her role as Congressional Hispanic Caucus Chair (2023-2024). Her focus is distinctly equity-oriented, emphasizing: (1) preventing AI bias and discrimination against Latino and minority communities; (2) healthcare applications through the HEAL-AI Act to train medical students in AI literacy; and (3) practical current harms like deepfakes and misinformation rather than speculative future risks. Notably, she co-signed a letter opposing California's SB 1047 AI safety bill, explicitly criticizing its focus on 'hypothetical existential risks' rather than 'demonstrable AI risks.' She has not made public statements about China and AI competition, AGI timelines, AI alignment research, or specific AI companies/figures. Her AI policy work appears to be in early stages, with the CHC hosting its inaugural AI roundtable only in July 2024. The limited number of direct quotes available suggests AI is not currently a primary policy focus for her, with healthcare, immigration, and environmental justice being her main legislative priorities.

J. Luis Correa.summary: Rep. Lou Correa's public statements on AI are limited but pragmatic, focused primarily on using AI for border security applications. He views AI as a tool to enhance American competitiveness and innovation, emphasizing the need for the U.S. to maintain technological leadership through research funding, immigration, and smart policy rather than restrictive regulation.

quotes.quote: I'm pleased to see the Biden Administration prioritize integrating advanced technologies like AI—or artificial intelligence—into homeland security initiatives, while still ensuring the protection of civil rights and civil liberties.
quotes.source: Opening statement in Joint Subcommittee Hearing on Border Security Technology, 2024
quotes.context: Correa expressing support for AI integration in border security while acknowledging the need to protect civil rights and liberties.

quotes.quote: Advanced technologies will help CBP officers and agents work more efficiently and effectively to keep the American people safe.
quotes.source: Opening statement in Joint Subcommittee Hearing on Border Security Technology, 2024
quotes.context: Statement supporting the use of advanced technologies including AI for border security operations.

quotes.quote: Border security means keeping drug and human traffickers away from our communities—and new, bleeding-edge technology that is already available for commercial use would give our hard-working officers the tools they need to keep us safe.
quotes.source: Press release on Emerging Innovative Border Technologies Act, April 2024
quotes.context: Correa introducing bipartisan legislation requiring DHS to develop plans for integrating AI, machine learning, and nanotechnology at the border.

quotes.quote: Through this bipartisan effort, Congress will better-understand how our officers can use new technology to stop smugglers, as well as identify and respond when migrants are crossing in remote and deadly conditions, and hopefully deliver them the resources they so desperately need.
quotes.source: Press release on Emerging Innovative Border Technologies Act, April 2024
quotes.context: Explaining the humanitarian and security benefits of deploying AI-powered technologies at the border.

quotes.quote: The greatest threats to America's AI industry come from this Administration's policies. Cutting funding of scientific research at universities and federal agencies, arbitrary and hostile immigration policies, and misguided tariffs, are imperiling America's world leadership in AI.
quotes.source: Opinion piece in Whittier Daily News, April 2025
quotes.context: Correa criticizing the Trump Administration's policies that he believes threaten U.S. AI leadership, particularly research funding cuts and immigration restrictions.

quotes.quote: Today, our nation continues to be the world leader in innovation, AI, hi-tech, biotech, energy production, manufacturing, and agriculture... We are at risk of losing it all.
quotes.source: Opinion piece in Whittier Daily News, April 2025
quotes.context: Warning about threats to American technological leadership including in AI.

quotes.quote: We must reverse this destructive course by supporting research at universities and federal agencies, keeping the inventions and pipeline strong, embracing hard-working immigrants, and focusing on a common-sense tariff policy.
quotes.source: Opinion piece in Whittier Daily News, April 2025
quotes.context: Outlining policy priorities to maintain U.S. AI and technology leadership.

quotes.quote: Immigrants and their children found almost half of the Fortune 500 companies as of 2024... In AI, where almost 65 percent of the leading AI companies have an immigrant founder.
quotes.source: Opinion piece in Whittier Daily News, April 2025
quotes.context: Highlighting the importance of immigration to AI innovation and entrepreneurship.

quotes.quote: regulation often is second to the fact that we just can't move on this stuff at the federal level.
quotes.source: House Judiciary Subcommittee hearing on AI regulation and federalism, October 2025
quotes.context: Correa commenting on federal gridlock regarding AI regulation, acknowledging the difficulty of passing AI policy at the federal level.

quotes.quote: Border security means keeping drugs and other negative elements away from our communities, as well as utilizing cutting-edge technology that is already available to maintain trade and commerce and give our hard-working officers the tools they need to keep us safe.
quotes.source: Statement on House passage of Emerging Innovative Border Technologies Act, March 2025
quotes.context: Reiterating support for AI and advanced technology deployment for border security while maintaining commerce.

J. Luis Correa.notes: Rep. Correa's public statements on AI are notably limited and focused on specific practical applications rather than broader AI policy debates. His main legislative work involves the Emerging Innovative Border Technologies Act (bipartisan legislation with Rep. Morgan Luttrell), which requires DHS to develop plans for integrating AI, machine learning, and nanotechnology into border security operations. He consistently emphasizes: (1) AI as a practical tool for law enforcement and border security, (2) The importance of protecting civil rights and civil liberties while deploying AI, (3) American competitiveness in AI through research funding and immigration policy, and (4) The role of immigrants in AI innovation. Notably absent from his public statements are discussions of: AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, AI safety research, specific AI companies or figures (like OpenAI, Anthropic, Sam Altman, etc.), China in the context of AI competition, and deeper philosophical or technical AI safety concerns. His stance appears pragmatic and application-focused rather than ideological, with an emphasis on maintaining American technological leadership through smart policy rather than restrictive regulation.

Lisa Blunt Rochester.summary: Lisa Blunt Rochester views AI as a transformative technology that presents both incredible opportunities and unique challenges requiring careful management. She focuses heavily on workforce impacts, AI literacy, and U.S. competitiveness against China, while emphasizing the need for guardrails to protect workers and consumers. Her approach is pragmatic and worker-focused, centered on education, training, and ensuring American leadership in AI development.

quotes.quote: It's no secret that the use of artificial intelligence has skyrocketed over the past few years, playing a key role in the ways we learn, work, and interact with one another. Like any emerging technology, AI presents us with incredible opportunities along with unique challenges.
quotes.source: Statement on AI Literacy Act, December 2023
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to make AI literacy a key component of digital literacy programs

quotes.quote: AI and technology literacy are essential to maintaining America's economic competitiveness in the face of global adversaries like China.
quotes.source: RAISE Act introduction, September 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to integrate AI standards in K-12 education to compete with China

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is increasingly disrupting our economy, contributing to layoffs and occupational changes. This bill allows us to remain proactive, protect workers who are most impacted by the technology, and supercharge the future of work by ensuring our future workforce has the skills they need to succeed.
quotes.source: Workforce of the Future Act introduction, December 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to study AI's impact on workers and provide training programs

quotes.quote: With reports that AI is poised to push unemployment rates upwards of 20 percent within the next five years—We need big, bold solutions now!
quotes.source: Senate maiden speech, September 2025
quotes.context: Delivering her first formal speech on the Senate floor about jobs and the future of work

quotes.quote: The United States cannot afford to lose the global AI race.
quotes.source: Statement on Trump AI executive orders, July 2025
quotes.context: Responding to Trump administration's AI policy, advocating for strong leadership that values innovation, environmental considerations, and national security

quotes.quote: Without proper guardrails, the impact AI could have on our economy is wide-ranging. According to studies from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), AI could replace nearly 12 percent of the workforce.
quotes.source: Workforce of the Future Act press release, December 2025
quotes.context: Highlighting the need for proactive measures to protect workers from AI displacement

quotes.quote: I had an event where we started and had everyone walk into the room and use a word cloud and tell me, 'What do you think of when you think of the future of work?' The biggest word coming in the door was 'fear.' The biggest word walking out the door was 'opportunity.'
quotes.source: Senate Commerce hearing with Sam Altman, May 2025
quotes.context: Questioning OpenAI CEO about AI's impact and emphasizing the importance of viewing technology as opportunity rather than threat

quotes.quote: By ensuring that AI literacy is at the heart of our digital literacy program, we're ensuring that we can not only mitigate the risk of AI but seize the opportunity it creates to help improve the way we learn and the way we work.
quotes.source: AI Literacy Act statement, December 2023
quotes.context: Explaining the importance of AI education to both manage risks and capture opportunities

quotes.quote: The potential of AI is immense and this is an important example of how it can be used for good.
quotes.source: Twitter/X post, July 2024
quotes.context: Commenting on Rep. Jennifer Wexton using AI to recreate her voice after being diagnosed with progressive supranuclear palsy

quotes.quote: These emerging fields bring fantastic opportunities for small businesses and the economy but without proper guidelines, harm Americans.
quotes.source: Campaign website on Innovation and Emerging Technology, 2024
quotes.context: Describing her approach to emerging technologies including generative AI, emphasizing both opportunity and need for regulation

Lisa Blunt Rochester.notes: Lisa Blunt Rochester demonstrates a distinctly workforce-focused approach to AI policy, consistent with her background as Delaware's former Secretary of Labor. She explicitly references China multiple times as a competitive threat in AI development and education. She does NOT appear 'AGI-pilled' - her focus is on practical, near-term workforce impacts rather than speculation about superintelligence or existential risk. She views AI as genuinely transformative (not overhyped) and frequently cites studies showing potential 12-20% workforce displacement. While she doesn't discuss existential risk or alignment in technical terms, she does emphasize the need for 'guardrails,' safety measures, and responsible AI use. She has directly questioned OpenAI CEO Sam Altman in Senate hearings about organizational structure and responsible AI deployment. Her legislation has received endorsements from both AI companies (OpenAI, Anthropic, Microsoft) and labor unions (AFL-CIO, AFT, SAG-AFTRA), suggesting a balanced approach. She co-created the bipartisan Future of Work Caucus and has introduced multiple AI-related bills focusing on literacy, education, workforce training, and worker protection. Her most recent work (January 2026) includes leading efforts to address AI-generated deepfakes and non-consensual imagery.

Neal P. Dunn.summary: Rep. Neal P. Dunn (R-FL) takes a pragmatic, security-focused approach to AI, emphasizing American competitiveness, light-touch regulation, and protecting against misuse. His focus is primarily on defense applications, cybersecurity threats, and preventing AI-enabled fraud and deepfakes, rather than existential risks or AGI concerns.

quotes.quote: Technology is rapidly evolving and becoming more important for us to understand as we work to keep our nation safe from foreign threats
quotes.source: House press release, July 2019
quotes.context: Statement when introducing the Future Defense Artificial Intelligence Technology Assessment (DATA) Act to require DoD reporting on AI strategy

quotes.quote: Cyber warfare is a real and tangible threat as our military and defense department work to implement new Artificial Intelligence technologies. This important legislation will work to ensure that all necessary precautions are taken
quotes.source: Florida Daily, July 2019
quotes.context: Explaining his amendment to the NDAA requiring Pentagon AI oversight and protection from bad actors

quotes.quote: Ensuring America maintains its competitive edge is of the utmost importance, especially considering the instability in key areas overseas
quotes.source: House press release, February 2024
quotes.context: Statement upon appointment to the House Task Force on Artificial Intelligence

quotes.quote: I'm grateful that Speaker Johnson recognized my interest in bolstering innovation and improving our nation's cybersecurity to protect our nation
quotes.source: House press release, February 2024
quotes.context: Expressing priorities when joining the AI Task Force

quotes.quote: The rise of innovation in the world of artificial intelligence is exciting; however, it has potential to do some major harm if left in the wrong hands
quotes.source: Statement on Protecting Consumers from Deceptive AI Act, March 2024
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to require labeling of AI-generated content and deepfakes

quotes.quote: Requiring the identification of deepfakes is a simple safeguard that would benefit consumers, children and national security
quotes.source: Statement on deepfakes legislation, March 2024
quotes.context: Advocating for technical standards to identify AI-generated content

quotes.quote: As AI technology advances at a rapid pace, our laws must keep up. When criminals use AI to steal identities or defraud Americans, the consequences should be severe to match the crime
quotes.source: AI Fraud Deterrence Act statement, November 2025
quotes.context: Co-introducing legislation with Rep. Ted Lieu to enhance penalties for AI-enabled fraud

quotes.quote: The AI Fraud Deterrence Act strengthens penalties for crimes related to fraud committed with the help of AI
quotes.source: Press release, November 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the purpose of enhanced criminal penalties for AI misuse

quotes.quote: One thing remains clear, the US must have a light touch on AI regulations to harness the full potential of this exciting technology
quotes.source: Twitter/X post, December 17, 2024
quotes.context: At press conference for House AI Task Force Bipartisan Report on Artificial Intelligence

quotes.quote: I'm looking forward to working with this team to address the rise of artificial intelligence
quotes.source: House press release, February 2024
quotes.context: Commenting on his appointment to the bipartisan AI Task Force

Neal P. Dunn.notes: Rep. Dunn approaches AI primarily through a national security and defense lens, with consistent emphasis on: (1) Maintaining U.S. competitive advantage against foreign threats, particularly in military/defense contexts; (2) Cybersecurity and protecting AI systems from 'bad actors'; (3) Preventing AI misuse through fraud, deepfakes, and identity theft; (4) Light-touch regulation that doesn't stifle innovation. He served on the House Select Committee on Strategic Competition with China and was appointed to the House AI Task Force in 2024. His background as a physician and former Army major (11 years active duty) influences his practical, security-focused perspective. Notably absent from his public statements: discussion of AGI, existential risks, AI alignment problems, or philosophical concerns about superintelligence. His focus is on near-term, practical threats and opportunities. He announced retirement from Congress on January 13, 2026, and will not seek re-election.

John H. Rutherford.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or positions on artificial intelligence could be found for Representative John H. Rutherford (R-FL-05). His legislative focus appears to be on law enforcement, defense, veterans affairs, and coastal issues rather than technology policy.
John H. Rutherford.notes: Representative Rutherford has been serving in Congress since 2017 and sits on the House Appropriations Committee (including Homeland Security, Military Construction and Veterans Affairs, and Transportation/HUD subcommittees) and the House Ethics Committee. His background is in law enforcement (former Sheriff of Duval County, FL for 12 years). While he does mention China in the context of defense appropriations and military competition, no AI-specific statements were found. He does support STEM education through hosting the Congressional App Challenge annually. The lack of public statements on AI may indicate this is not a priority policy area for him, or he has not been asked to weigh in on AI-related legislation or hearings. It's also possible he has made statements in closed-door meetings or contexts not publicly available online.

Darren Soto.summary: Darren Soto is a pragmatic, pro-innovation Democrat who views AI as transformative technology that will fundamentally reshape the economy and workforce. He focuses primarily on practical workforce impacts, consumer protection, and maintaining U.S. technological leadership against foreign competitors, particularly China. His approach emphasizes studying AI's effects, preparing workers for disruption, and ensuring government keeps pace with technological advancement rather than focusing on existential risks or safety alignment.

quotes.quote: I've learned through the lessons of history -- you can't stop technology.
quotes.source: WFTV interview, July 2023
quotes.context: Discussing his philosophy on AI regulation and why he introduced legislation to study AI's impact rather than restrict it

quotes.quote: It's gonna be more than just airplanes and tanks; it's going to be computers, artificial intelligence, and blockchain technology that decides the future of our national security and our military competitiveness across the globe.
quotes.source: Washington Examiner, May 2020
quotes.context: Speaking about the need for the U.S. military to maintain competitive edge against China in emerging technologies

quotes.quote: we must go forth boldly and ethically in developing the future of AI here in the United States.
quotes.source: Letter to NIST, December 2019
quotes.context: Co-authored letter requesting NIST develop voluntary AI framework, emphasizing concerns about foreign dominance

quotes.quote: I'm proud to work across the aisle to help our local communities prepare for the ways in which artificial intelligence will shape the workforce, the economy, and our way of life.
quotes.source: Jobs of the Future Act introduction, July 2023
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to study AI's impact on American workforce

quotes.quote: The reality is, the crooks are already using AI. The cops on the beat need to be able to use this, too.
quotes.source: House floor remarks on Consumer Safety Technology Act, July 2025
quotes.context: Advocating for government agencies to adopt AI tools to combat fraud and protect consumers

quotes.quote: It is critical that the United States acts as a global leader in these emerging technologies to ensure our democratic values remain at the forefront of this technological development.
quotes.source: Consumer Safety Technology Act introduction, July 2023
quotes.context: Emphasizing U.S. leadership in AI and the importance of democratic values in technology development

quotes.quote: It is crucial that we continue to lead in technological innovation and ensure we do not become reliant on foreign adversaries like the Chinese Communist Party to stay connected.
quotes.source: Consumer Safety Technology Act press release, July 2023
quotes.context: Warning about dependence on China for emerging technologies

quotes.quote: The whole point of the bill is to understand where this may be disrupted-- where artificial intelligence may be in a high growth area for our economy and how we respond to it.
quotes.source: WFTV interview, July 2023
quotes.context: Explaining his Jobs of the Future Act and focus on understanding AI's economic impact

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence continues to grow and evolve at a rapid pace. It is important that Congress acts to ensure this promising technology is handled responsibly, minimizes bias, and protects consumers and workers.
quotes.source: New Democrat Coalition endorsement statement, October 2019
quotes.context: Statement as NDC Technology Task Force Co-Chair about responsible AI development

quotes.quote: Emerging technologies like artificial intelligence, blockchain, and digital tokens are playing a growing importance in our daily lives and are proving to be an economic driver for the 21st-century economy.
quotes.source: Consumer Safety Technology Act introduction, July 2023
quotes.context: Framing AI as an economic opportunity and driver of growth

Darren Soto.notes: Darren Soto is a Democratic congressman from Florida (District 9) who serves as Co-Chair of the New Democrat Coalition Technology Task Force and Co-Chair of the Congressional Blockchain Caucus. His AI policy focus is notably pragmatic and workforce-oriented rather than focused on existential risk or AGI concerns. Key themes in his AI work include: (1) U.S.-China competition - he frequently references the need to maintain U.S. leadership against China and avoid dependence on foreign adversaries; (2) Workforce preparation - multiple bills focused on studying AI's impact on jobs and helping workers adapt; (3) Consumer protection - advocating for government use of AI to fight fraud and protect consumers; (4) Pro-innovation stance - believes technology cannot be stopped and government must adapt rather than restrict; (5) Bipartisan approach - consistently works across party lines on AI legislation. Notable legislation includes: AI Jobs Act (multiple versions 2018-2023), Consumer Safety Technology Act (passed House 2025), and Jobs of the Future Act (2023). He has received support from tech companies including Intel and Lyft. Conspicuously absent from his public statements: any discussion of AGI, superintelligence, existential risk, AI alignment problems, or AI safety research. His focus is entirely on near-term practical impacts and economic competitiveness.

Brian J. Mast.summary: Rep. Brian Mast views AI primarily through a national security and geopolitical competition lens, focusing heavily on preventing adversary nations (especially China) from accessing advanced AI chips. He frames AI as a military technology requiring arms-sale-style congressional oversight and emphasizes winning what he calls the 'AI arms race.' His approach is pragmatic and security-focused rather than concerned with transformative AI capabilities or existential risks.

quotes.quote: America must win the AI arms race.
quotes.source: AI OVERWATCH Act press release, December 2025
quotes.context: Mast's signature statement when introducing his AI OVERWATCH Act, which treats advanced AI chips like weapons requiring congressional oversight before export to adversary nations.

quotes.quote: As chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, I've seen firsthand how adversaries exploit our technology to enhance their military capabilities.
quotes.source: Statement on AI OVERWATCH Act, December 2025
quotes.context: Mast explaining his rationale for introducing legislation to block AI chip exports to China, Russia, and other adversary nations.

quotes.quote: The AI OVERWATCH Act ensures Congress has oversight over the sale of advanced AI chips to adversary nations, just as it does with arms sales.
quotes.source: Press release, December 2025
quotes.context: Mast describing his bill that would require congressional notification and allow blocking of advanced AI chip exports to countries of concern.

quotes.quote: Adversaries are already exploiting American technology to improve their military capabilities.
quotes.source: Statement on AI OVERWATCH Act, December 2025
quotes.context: Mast emphasizing the urgency of protecting U.S. AI technology from hostile foreign militaries.

quotes.quote: Advanced chips absolutely shift military advantage.
quotes.source: The Epoch Times, January 2026
quotes.context: Mast commenting on the strategic importance of AI chips in military applications and why they require strict export controls.

quotes.quote: The goal is to maintain U.S. dominance in AI and computing technology markets. Whether it's chips, coding, cloud, all the things related to it — these play into that [strategy].
quotes.source: Fox News interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Mast defending the Trump administration's approach to AI chip exports as part of a broader strategy for American technological leadership.

quotes.quote: We must starve China of the compute they need to compete, and we certainly should not be voluntarily solving their shortfalls by selling them our compute.
quotes.source: House Intelligence Chairman Rick Crawford supporting Mast's bill, December 2025
quotes.context: While not Mast's direct quote, this statement from his co-sponsor reflects the shared view that AI compute power is a zero-sum strategic resource in competition with China.

quotes.quote: The most powerful technology ever created cannot be treated as a simple commodity.
quotes.source: Analysis of AI OVERWATCH Act, December 2025
quotes.context: Commentary describing Mast's legislative approach, which acknowledges AI's transformative power but focuses on its military applications rather than broader societal transformation.

quotes.quote: This bill ensures congressional oversight keeps pace with advancing technology, blocks adversary militaries from accessing weapon-enabling AI, and accelerates American AI exports to allies and partners around the world.
quotes.source: AI OVERWATCH Act introduction, December 2025
quotes.context: Mast outlining the three main goals of his legislation: congressional oversight, blocking adversaries, and facilitating exports to allies.

quotes.quote: Part of the administration's strategy focuses on maintaining an ability to sell American technology easily.
quotes.source: Fox News, December 2025
quotes.context: Mast explaining why the U.S. needs both export controls for adversaries and streamlined processes for allies, comparing it to defense equipment sales.

Brian J. Mast.notes:
Brian Mast's AI discourse is remarkably focused on a single dimension: national security and geopolitical competition. He consistently frames AI through the lens of military technology and strategic competition with China, Russia, Iran, North Korea, Cuba, and Venezuela. His signature legislation (AI OVERWATCH Act, H.R. 6875) treats AI chips as weapons requiring arms-sale-style congressional oversight. 

Notably absent from his public statements: any discussion of AI safety, alignment problems, existential risk, AGI/ASI concepts, or transformative economic impacts beyond military applications. He mentions AI companies (particularly Nvidia) only in the context of export controls and national security concerns. 

Mast's approach is pragmatic and hawkish - he views AI as a critical military technology in a zero-sum competition where America must 'win the AI arms race.' He has praised certain guardrails in Trump administration AI policies while introducing his own legislation to ensure Congress can block chip exports to adversaries. His rhetoric suggests he sees AI as powerful and militarily significant, but he does not engage with questions about whether AI poses risks beyond adversarial use or whether it could become uncontrollable. 

His position reflects a traditional national security conservative perspective: the primary AI risk is that adversaries get it, not that the technology itself poses inherent dangers.

Raja Krishnamoorthi.summary: Raja Krishnamoorthi is deeply focused on AI as a strategic competition issue with China, viewing it as the defining technology of our era. He is notably 'AGI-pilled,' having introduced the AGI Safety Act and frequently discussing artificial general intelligence risks. His approach combines national security hawkishness on China with genuine concern about AI safety, alignment, and the need to ensure AGI complies with human values before release.

quotes.quote: China is making an all-out push to dominate AGI, which will inevitably seek to surveil and suppress us at every turn. We cannot let this happen. The nightmare scenario should be a wake-up call for Congress.
quotes.source: House Select Committee hearing 'Algorithms and Authoritarians,' June 25, 2025
quotes.context: Opening statement discussing AGI risks, referencing The Matrix as an example of rogue AI. This demonstrates his belief that AGI poses existential-level risks, particularly if controlled by China.

quotes.quote: That's why I'm working on a new bill—the AGI Safety Act—that will require AGI to be aligned with human values and require it to comply with laws that apply to humans.
quotes.source: House Select Committee hearing, June 25, 2025
quotes.context: Announcing his proposed AGI Safety Act legislation, showing direct engagement with AI alignment and safety issues at the AGI level.

quotes.quote: Whether it's American AI or Chinese AI, it should not be released until we know it's safe.
quotes.source: House Select Committee hearing, June 25, 2025
quotes.context: Advocating for safety standards regardless of origin, though his primary focus is on U.S.-China competition. Shows concern about premature AGI deployment.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is one of the most consequential technologies of our lifetime already, and the race to develop and safeguard it will shape the balance of global power for decades to come.
quotes.source: Press release on Advanced AI Security Readiness Act, June 12, 2025
quotes.context: Characterizing AI as transformative and central to geopolitical competition, reflecting his view of AI as a defining strategic technology.

quotes.quote: We are still learning about the uses of AI … We are still learning about how certain technologies could [be] you know, metamorphosized into being weaponized.
quotes.source: Center for Strategic and International Studies event, November 6, 2023
quotes.context: Discussing the evolving understanding of AI risks and military applications, showing awareness that AI capabilities and dangers are still emerging.

quotes.quote: AI will clearly play an increasingly central role in our economy in the decades to come and it is essential that we prepare our workforce for those changes. As the applications of artificial intelligence expand, we have to be concerned about how AI will affect the scope and nature of jobs.
quotes.source: House Democratic Caucus New Economy Task Force forum, November 17, 2017
quotes.context: Early statement showing long-standing engagement with AI's economic and workforce impacts, demonstrating concern for workers affected by AI.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence controlled by foreign adversaries poses a direct threat to our national security, our data, and our government operations. We cannot allow hostile regimes to embed their code in our most sensitive systems.
quotes.source: No Adversarial AI Act introduction, June 25, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to ban Chinese AI models from federal systems, highlighting national security concerns about adversarial AI.

quotes.quote: DeepSeek is deeply alarming, and it is seeking to undermine American AI leadership. Export controls and AI innovation are not mutually exclusive, but two sides of the same coin.
quotes.source: Letter to National Security Advisor regarding DeepSeek, January 31, 2025
quotes.context: Responding to China's DeepSeek AI model, arguing that protecting U.S. AI leadership requires both innovation and export controls.

quotes.quote: American innovators, not America's adversaries, should be first in line for the chips that will power the future. Our legislation will ensure the demands of U.S. developers and small businesses for advanced AI chips are prioritized over the needs of our adversaries.
quotes.source: GAIN AI Act introduction, October 30, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to prioritize American companies for AI chip access over foreign adversaries, showing 'America First' approach to AI infrastructure.

quotes.quote: AI is the defining technology of our lifetimes. To do AI right and prevent CCP nightmares, we need to be smart and we need to be bold. That's how America wins.
quotes.source: House Select Committee hearing, June 25, 2025
quotes.context: Closing remarks emphasizing AI's transformative importance and framing U.S.-China AI competition in existential terms.

Raja Krishnamoorthi.notes: Krishnamoorthi is Ranking Member of the House Select Committee on Strategic Competition with China, which heavily shapes his AI focus. He is remarkably 'AGI-pilled' for a politician—he explicitly discusses AGI, references The Matrix as a cautionary tale, cites OpenAI's chief scientist wanting to 'build a bunker,' and has introduced the AGI Safety Act requiring alignment with human values. His stance uniquely combines: (1) intense focus on China as AI competitor and threat, (2) genuine engagement with AI safety/alignment concerns including existential risk, (3) advocacy for American AI leadership and innovation, (4) concern for workforce impacts and worker retraining. He has investigated DeepSeek, called out OpenAI's safety practices, introduced multiple AI-related bills, and uses ChatGPT in congressional hearings. His office even had an AI specialist on staff. He views AI through both a national security lens (China competition) and a safety lens (AGI alignment), making him one of Congress's most sophisticated voices on AI policy.

Jim Banks.summary: Senator Jim Banks views AI primarily through a national security and China competition lens, describing it as 'a transformative technology' that America must dominate. His policy focus is almost entirely on preventing China from accessing advanced AI chips through export controls, with no public statements found regarding existential risk, AGI, or AI safety/alignment concerns.

quotes.quote: artificial intelligence is a transformative technology and United States policy should ensure that United States persons, including small businesses, startups, and universities, are in the best position to innovate and harness the potential of artificial intelligence
quotes.source: GAIN AI Act legislative text, 2025
quotes.context: From the 'Sense of Congress' section of Banks' GAIN AI Act, establishing his view that AI is transformative and should be prioritized for American use

quotes.quote: The GAIN AI Act helps America beat China in the artificial intelligence race
quotes.source: Statement to National Review, September 2025
quotes.context: Banks' framing of AI development as a competitive race with China that America must win

quotes.quote: It puts America First by securing AI dominance at home before sending critical technology to adversaries like China
quotes.source: Statement to National Review, September 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the rationale behind his chip export restrictions, emphasizing 'America First' approach to AI dominance

quotes.quote: The GAIN AI Act puts American companies and researchers before our adversaries like China. This is America First in action.
quotes.source: Twitter/X post, September 5, 2025
quotes.context: Public statement framing his AI policy as prioritizing American interests over adversaries

quotes.quote: The GAIN AI Act makes sure we use American-made technology to strengthen our own economy and security before sending it to adversaries overseas
quotes.source: Senate Banking Committee press release, November 2025
quotes.context: Explaining how his legislation connects AI chip access to economic and national security

quotes.quote: American customers — including small businesses and startups — shouldn't be forced to wait in line behind China's tech giants when purchasing the latest AI chips
quotes.source: Senate Banking Committee press release, November 2025
quotes.context: Justifying domestic prioritization of AI chips over foreign sales

quotes.quote: these big chip makers export chips to China they have to guarantee that those chips won't be used against America for economic purposes, against American industries, or even for other military and other national security reasons too
quotes.source: Quoted in industry analysis, September 2025
quotes.context: Banks discussing conditions for chip exports to China, focusing on economic and military security concerns

quotes.quote: The Chinese Communist Party has used our research and technology against us, strengthening their own military and preparing for war against America
