quotes.source: Preventing PLA Acquisition of U.S. Technology Act announcement, May 2025
quotes.context: Statement from related legislation targeting Chinese military use of U.S. technology including AI

quotes.quote: delivers a bi-partisan call to arms to combat the threat of adversarial AI and discusses opportunities to modernize the Pentagon
quotes.source: Homeland Security Defense Forum description, October 2020
quotes.context: Description of Banks' keynote speech on AI and defense, focusing on adversarial AI threats (likely referring to foreign adversary use)

quotes.quote: The U.S. cannot afford to fall behind in developing AI technology, adversaries are investing billions to stay competitive in this area
quotes.source: Homeland Security Defense Forum symposium materials, October 2020
quotes.context: From event materials where Banks spoke, emphasizing competitive dynamics with adversaries in AI development

analysis.overall_stance: supportive with strong national security focus

Jim Banks.notes: Jim Banks' AI policy is dominated by China competition concerns. He extensively references China and foreign adversaries when discussing AI, framing it as a strategic race America must win. His signature GAIN AI Act focuses on ensuring American companies get priority access to AI chips before they're exported to China or other adversaries. While he describes AI as 'transformative,' there is NO evidence he discusses AGI, existential risk, AI safety, or alignment issues. His 2020 keynote on 'adversarial AI' appears to refer to foreign adversaries using AI, not misaligned AI systems. He has directly engaged with AI companies, particularly criticizing Nvidia (along with Sen. Warren) regarding CEO Jensen Huang's China visit and warning about chip exports. His stance is pro-innovation for America, hawkish on China, and focused on maintaining U.S. technological dominance. The White House (David Sacks) has opposed his GAIN AI Act as overly restrictive. Industry groups have criticized the legislation as reflecting misunderstanding of how the AI industry works. Banks appears to be a traditional 'China hawk' applying national security frameworks to AI, rather than someone engaged with AI safety/alignment discourse.

Roger Marshall.summary: Senator Roger Marshall (R-Kansas) has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. As a physician and member of the Senate HELP Committee, he has participated in hearings on AI in healthcare, expressing concerns about biosecurity risks and the need for guardrails while maintaining innovation. However, comprehensive public statements about his AI views are scarce.

quotes.quote: More and more, it would seem that AI can replace animal studies. And probably even more accurate.
quotes.source: Senate HELP Committee hearing, June 4, 2025
quotes.context: Marshall questioned FDA officials about using AI to replace animal testing in drug studies, suggesting AI could be more accurate than traditional animal testing methods.

quotes.quote: I think it's said in jest... I think it's the president making fun of a couple people that didn't bring a serious request to the White House.
quotes.source: CNN's The Source, September 30, 2025
quotes.context: Marshall defended President Trump's use of AI-generated videos to mock Democrats during government shutdown negotiations, treating AI use casually as a political tool.

Roger Marshall.notes: Senator Marshall has been notably silent on AI policy despite serving on key committees where AI is discussed. While he participated in a November 2023 Senate HELP Subcommittee hearing titled 'Avoiding a Cautionary Tale: Policy Considerations for Artificial Intelligence in Health Care' as Ranking Member, his opening statement and questions focused primarily on biosecurity risks and supporting Senator Cassidy's AI framework whitepaper rather than offering his own comprehensive AI views. He has expressed general support for innovation and 'guardrails' but has not articulated detailed positions on AI safety, regulation, or transformative potential. His most concrete AI-related statement was advocating for AI to replace animal testing in pharmaceutical research. Marshall's focus remains primarily on healthcare costs, China trade policy, and traditional conservative issues rather than emerging AI policy. His engagement with AI appears pragmatic and healthcare-focused rather than reflecting deep consideration of broader AI implications.

Clay Higgins.summary: Clay Higgins views AI primarily as a threat to American freedoms when deployed by the federal government, describing it as 'an Armageddon level threat' and warning about government 'weaponization' of AI technology. His focus is almost exclusively on restricting government use of AI for enforcement and surveillance rather than on broader AI safety, AGI risks, or international competition. He has introduced multiple bills to limit federal AI deployment while requiring transparency when AI systems interact with citizens.

quotes.quote: AI is an Armageddon level threat, far more ominous than any alleged pandemic or climate crisis
quotes.source: Press release, September 10, 2023
quotes.context: Statement announcing legislation to ban government use of AI for law enforcement. This represents his strongest characterization of AI risk, though focused on government misuse rather than existential AI safety concerns.

quotes.quote: Democrats in DC love AI. They're weaponizing it.
quotes.source: Press release, September 10, 2023
quotes.context: Part of his announcement opposing federal government use of AI for enforcement. Frames AI as a partisan political issue rather than a technological challenge.

quotes.quote: Republicans will not allow government controlled AI computer programs to crawl around in the private business of free Americans.
quotes.source: Press release, September 10, 2023
quotes.context: Explaining his legislation to ban federal AI use in law enforcement, emphasizing concerns about government surveillance and control.

quotes.quote: The weaponization of AI technology is an ominous threat to our Constitutional freedoms
quotes.source: Press release on No AI Audits Act, March 19, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to restrict IRS use of AI in tax audits. Focuses on constitutional concerns rather than technical AI risks.

quotes.quote: Unelected bureaucrats in DC should not be using AI as a tool to further weaponize the federal government against the American people.
quotes.source: Press release on No AI Audits Act, March 19, 2024
quotes.context: Expressing opposition to IRS deployment of AI for tax enforcement, emphasizing distrust of government bureaucracy.

quotes.quote: We, as a Congress who have been sworn to serve the people, must think seriously about the implications of the rapid deployment of AI technology. We must focus on the balance between the power of AI and the dangers it holds for freedom-loving Americans and our national security.
quotes.source: Press release on No AI Audits Act, March 19, 2024
quotes.context: One of his few statements acknowledging broader implications of AI beyond government enforcement, though still focused on threats to American freedoms and national security.

quotes.quote: AI is being rapidly deployed throughout our federal government as a tool to enforce laws, regulations, and codes without regard to the severe risks
quotes.source: Statement on Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act, March 8, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing his TAG Act provisions requiring federal agencies to notify individuals when interacting with AI systems.

quotes.quote: The authoritarian use of AI within our federal government to control and restrict the American people is nefarious in nature and carries major implications. Moving forward, we must focus on the balance between the power of AI and its potential danger against the American people and our national security.
quotes.source: Statement on Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act, March 8, 2024
quotes.context: Characterizing government AI use as 'authoritarian' and 'nefarious,' emphasizing control and restriction concerns.

quotes.quote: I don't trust the government, and I don't trust AI. So I certainly don't trust government bureaucracy armed with AI as an investigative or enforcement weapon.
quotes.source: Statement to Nextgov/FCW, January 11, 2024
quotes.context: Explaining his support for the TAG Act, which requires agencies to disclose when using AI systems that affect citizens.

quotes.quote: The Democrat Party globalist-elite oppressors are 100% determined to control and restrict every aspect of every American's life, but We the People are awake, and We will not kneel. We're fighting back.
quotes.source: Press release, September 10, 2023
quotes.context: Part of his broader statement on AI legislation, framing AI deployment in highly partisan and conspiratorial terms.

Clay Higgins.notes: Clay Higgins' AI views are highly distinctive and narrowly focused compared to most policymakers. His primary concern is government misuse of AI for surveillance, enforcement, and control of citizens - not the technical AI safety issues typically discussed by AI policy experts. While he uses dramatic language like 'Armageddon level threat,' this refers specifically to government deployment of AI against citizens, not to existential risks from advanced AI systems or AGI. He has introduced several bills (TAG Act, No AI Audits Act, legislation banning government AI enforcement) focused exclusively on restricting federal government AI use. Notably absent from his statements: any discussion of China's AI development, AI companies like OpenAI or Anthropic, AGI/superintelligence risks, AI alignment problems, or the transformative economic potential of AI. His framing is highly partisan, characterizing AI as a tool Democrats want to use for authoritarian control. He appears to view AI primarily through the lens of his broader anti-government, libertarian political philosophy rather than engaging with the technical or global competitive dimensions of AI policy.

Mike Johnson.summary: <cite index="1-7,18-11">Mike Johnson describes himself as a 'limited government conservative' who is wary of overregulating AI and creating 'red tape' that would stifle development.</cite> <cite index="3-7,6-2">He views AI as having the potential to rapidly transform the economy and national security, and established a bipartisan task force to ensure America leads in this 'strategic arena.'</cite> <cite index="18-5,18-6,18-19,18-20">His primary concern is China as 'our biggest competitor' in AI, warning that overregulation could have 'very serious implications' for national security as China is 'advancing exponentially.'</cite>

quotes.quote: Because advancements in artificial intelligence have the potential to rapidly transform our economy and national security, Leader Jeffries and I established the Bipartisan Task Force on Artificial Intelligence to ensure America continues leading in this strategic arena.
quotes.source: December 17, 2024 - House AI Task Force Report Delivery
quotes.context: Johnson's statement upon receiving the bipartisan AI Task Force report, emphasizing the transformative nature of AI and America's need to lead

quotes.quote: Our biggest competitor is China in the space, and they are advancing exponentially with this. So, if we, if Congress, stumbles into this, or overregulates the technology, it could have very serious implications for us with regard national security.
quotes.source: September 19, 2024 - The Hill interview
quotes.context: Johnson explaining his cautious approach to AI regulation, framing China as the primary competitive threat

quotes.quote: You know, any technology can be used for evil.
quotes.source: September 19, 2024 - The Hill interview
quotes.context: Johnson discussing deepfakes and AI abuses while urging caution against overregulation

quotes.quote: The report will outline an approach where Congress doesn't create 'some massive regulatory scheme.'
quotes.source: September 19, 2024 - Axios interview
quotes.context: Johnson describing his vision for the AI Task Force recommendations, emphasizing a hands-off regulatory approach

quotes.quote: I think they need to see that it goes against our interests for the FTC to send delegations to the EU and help enforce EU regulations against American companies.
quotes.source: May 2, 2024 - Hill and Valley Forum
quotes.context: Johnson criticizing the Biden administration's approach and calling for international cooperation to keep American companies competitive against China

quotes.quote: When Donald Trump is reelected, and I believe he will be, he is going to immediately emphasize an aggressive stance towards China. He's talking about tariffs and all sorts of other things. So we have to make appropriate adjustments. Outbound investments and other things are big issues that we're discussing right now.
quotes.source: September 19, 2024 - Axios interview
quotes.context: Johnson discussing export controls and China policy in the context of AI competition

quotes.quote: They're now trying to get a leg up on us in AI as you've seen in the last day or so.
quotes.source: January 28, 2025 - Press briefing on DeepSeek
quotes.context: Johnson responding to China's DeepSeek AI developments, calling China a 'terrible trading partner' that steals intellectual property

quotes.quote: I mean, we know China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea are coordinating together. I mean, they're engaging in hot wars around the globe. So, we certainly know that they would like to undermine us with every subversive act that they can devise.
quotes.source: September 19, 2024 - The Hill interview
quotes.context: Johnson discussing foreign election interference and AI threats from adversarial nations

quotes.quote: We don't want government to usurp the role of researchers, but we want to spur on the private sector, and to the extent there are grants that can assist with that, maybe that is appropriate. But I don't think we need to be throwing billions of dollars into this.
quotes.source: September 19, 2024 - Axios interview
quotes.context: Johnson explaining his philosophy on government's role in AI development during NDAA negotiations

quotes.quote: The Speaker believes that Congress should encourage innovation, help maintain our competitive edge, and stay mindful of potential risks.
quotes.source: January 11, 2024 - Johnson's office statement after meeting with Sam Altman
quotes.context: Official statement from Johnson's office following his meeting with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman to discuss AI risks and opportunities

Mike Johnson.notes: Mike Johnson's AI stance is primarily shaped by three factors: (1) competition with China - he repeatedly frames AI policy through the lens of U.S.-China rivalry and national security; (2) anti-regulatory philosophy - as a 'limited government conservative,' he opposes what he calls 'massive regulatory schemes' and 'red tape'; and (3) industry engagement - he has met with tech leaders including Sam Altman (OpenAI) and Marc Andreessen, whose views appear to have influenced his hands-off approach. Notably absent from his public statements are discussions of existential risk, AGI timelines, AI safety/alignment research, or technical AI governance challenges. His focus is almost entirely on maintaining American competitiveness and avoiding overregulation. He established a bipartisan AI Task Force in February 2024 that delivered a 273-page report in December 2024 with 66 findings and 89 recommendations. Johnson has also been involved in debates over federal preemption of state AI laws, though his personal position on the 'AI moratorium' is not explicitly stated in the search results.

Jamie Raskin.summary: Jamie Raskin views AI as a transformative technology that requires strong regulatory oversight and transparency, particularly regarding government use. He strongly opposes unregulated AI development, criticizes Elon Musk's conflicts of interest with xAI/Grok, and emphasizes that regulations protecting Americans should not be sacrificed in the name of competing with China. He supports bipartisan AI governance legislation focused on transparency, civil rights protection, and preventing market concentration.

quotes.quote: Like the telephone, the computer, and the Internet, artificial intelligence is a revolutionary new technology that will remake our society, our commerce, our government and our lives.
quotes.source: Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act introduction, March 2024
quotes.context: Raskin introduced bipartisan legislation to govern federal AI use, emphasizing AI's transformative nature while stressing the need for constitutional protections and oversight.

quotes.quote: Artificial Intelligence – or AI – is rapidly transforming nearly every industry and even our everyday lives. From mundane things like asking ChatGPT to help me find vegan recipes and create a grocery shopping list to using AI-enabled tools to help tackle some of the world's biggest challenges, including climate change or helping law enforcement more effectively and efficiently identify child sexual abuse material, this technology is seeping into every aspect of our lives.
quotes.source: Opening Statement at Subcommittee Hearing on AI and Criminal Exploitation, July 16, 2025
quotes.context: Raskin describes AI's pervasive integration into society, acknowledging both practical benefits and serious concerns about its misuse.

quotes.quote: It would be unwise to assume that we need to become more like China to compete with China. In fact, many would argue that stronger, better products—developed in America, while protecting Americans and their data—ensure that American AI is both more advanced and more internationally competitive.
quotes.source: Opening Statement on Federal Preemption of State AI Laws, September 18, 2025
quotes.context: Raskin rejects the argument that AI regulation harms competitiveness with China, arguing that consumer protections actually strengthen American AI leadership.

quotes.quote: When other countries threaten U.S. cybersecurity, steal Americans' inventions, and conduct economic espionage against U.S. companies, as the government of China has done, that is cause for scrutiny from Congress.
quotes.source: Opening Statement on Threats to AI Innovation, May 7, 2025
quotes.context: Raskin acknowledges China as a threat to AI innovation through intellectual property theft and espionage, supporting congressional oversight of these issues.

quotes.quote: It's hard to debate the proper scope of regulation in this space when Donald Trump has reportedly granted Elon Musk unlimited access to our most private and sensitive records-data that is undoubtedly invaluable to xAI, his AI company. Today, none of us here know whether Elon Musk is using Americans' data, classified information, and other sensitive information from databases across government to train his company's AI models and gain an unfair advantage over competitors and citizens.
quotes.source: Remarks at Subcommittee Hearing on AI Innovation and Competition, April 2, 2025
quotes.context: Raskin criticizes conflicts of interest in AI development, specifically targeting Elon Musk's access to government data while running xAI.

quotes.quote: Which give you access to the private data of more than 300 million Americans while you have the power and motive to funnel it into your Artificial Intelligence program Grok and the power and motive to use it for the purposes of creating what you plan to be the world's largest financial services company?
quotes.source: Statement and Questions Posed to Elon Musk, February 27, 2025
quotes.context: Raskin directly challenges Musk about using government access to train AI models, demonstrating concern about AI companies exploiting public data.

quotes.quote: For generative AI, it's not about creating speed laws and building guard rails but creating a road to begin with.
quotes.source: Opening Statement on Federal Preemption of State AI Laws, September 18, 2025
quotes.context: Raskin argues that AI needs fundamental regulatory frameworks, not just minor adjustments, rejecting the tech industry's 'move fast and break things' approach.

quotes.quote: We're introducing the bipartisan Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act to ensure that any federal AI use promotes the fair, just, and impartial treatment of all. It would also create an oversight framework that will help Congress effectively meet the challenges of this powerful new technology over time.
quotes.source: Statement on Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act, March 2024
quotes.context: Raskin emphasizes the need for AI to uphold constitutional values and civil rights, with congressional oversight mechanisms.

quotes.quote: Jack Dorsey and Elon Musk both recently made the claim that we should 'delete all IP law.' I think that we all can emphatically reject this notion. America's intellectual property system hasn't just made us a global leader in AI's its very foundation created the careers of those two men.
quotes.source: Opening Statement on Threats to AI Innovation, May 7, 2025
quotes.context: Raskin defends intellectual property protections against tech billionaires' calls for deregulation, arguing IP law is essential for AI innovation.

quotes.quote: It's hard to think of an antitrust matter more pressing than concentration in the AI market.
quotes.source: Remarks at Subcommittee Hearing on AI Innovation and Competition, April 2, 2025
quotes.context: Raskin identifies market concentration in AI as a critical antitrust concern, advocating for stronger competition enforcement.

Jamie Raskin.notes: Jamie Raskin has been actively involved in AI policy through multiple congressional hearings and bipartisan legislation. He frequently references China as a competitor and threat to U.S. AI leadership through IP theft and espionage, but explicitly rejects the argument that this requires deregulation. He is NOT 'AGI-pilled' - his focus is on practical governance, transparency, and preventing abuses rather than speculative existential risks. He views AI as genuinely transformative (not overhyped) but emphasizes it must be developed with strong guardrails. He has been particularly vocal about Elon Musk and xAI/Grok, criticizing conflicts of interest and data access issues. His stance on safety focuses on civil rights protections, transparency in government AI use, preventing discrimination, and addressing criminal misuse rather than technical alignment or superintelligence concerns. He co-authored the Federal AI Governance and Transparency Act with Republican James Comer, demonstrating his bipartisan approach. Raskin also introduced the CAMRA Act to study AI's effects on children. His overall position is pro-regulation, pro-transparency, and focused on protecting constitutional rights while supporting American AI innovation through strong legal frameworks rather than a deregulatory 'race to the bottom.'

Jack Bergman.summary: Rep. Jack Bergman has made very limited public statements about AI. His primary engagement with AI appears to be in the context of government modernization and healthcare efficiency, particularly through his interest in AI-enabled Medicare claims processing. He views AI as a tool for improving government operations and bringing federal systems into the 21st century, but has not made substantial public statements on broader AI policy, safety, or strategic issues.

quotes.quote: With AI (Artificial Intelligence) and processes we use now, we need to be able to adapt to new technologies to deliver better results. This is about the federal government bringing itself into the 21st century.
quotes.source: UpNorthVoice.com interview, May 27, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing government reform and modernization, Bergman mentioned AI as part of adapting federal operations to new technologies

quotes.quote: What I see here is a necessary step forward in the doctor-patient interaction.
quotes.source: Med Claims Compliance demonstration, October 2024
quotes.context: After viewing a demonstration of AI-enabled healthcare documentation and claims processing technology at Med Claims Compliance in Austin, Texas

quotes.quote: I can't tell you how valuable this time was for me. It's about better outcomes for the patient. And I don't know of any physician who doesn't want better outcomes for their patients.
quotes.source: Med Claims Compliance demonstration, October 2024
quotes.context: Commenting on AI technology for medical claims processing and clinical documentation after a demonstration

Jack Bergman.notes: Congressman Jack Bergman has made remarkably few public statements about artificial intelligence despite serving in Congress since 2017 and sitting on key committees including Armed Services. His limited comments suggest a pragmatic, application-focused view of AI as a tool for government efficiency and healthcare improvement rather than engagement with broader policy debates about AI safety, competition with China, AGI, or existential risk. He has been associated with the Clean CLAIMS Act (H.R. 8283), which would create a demonstration project for AI-enabled Medicare claims processing, though he was not the primary sponsor. His background as a retired Marine Corps Lieutenant General and his committee assignments (Armed Services, Budget, Veterans Affairs) would position him to comment on AI in national security and defense contexts, but no such statements were found in the public record. The lack of substantive quotes or policy positions on AI suggests this has not been a priority issue for him, or his views have not been widely publicized.

Ted Budd.summary: Senator Ted Budd views AI as highly transformative technology critical to U.S. competitiveness, particularly against China. He strongly advocates for minimal regulation, free-market innovation, and federal preemption of state AI laws. While supportive of AI's economic potential, he has also shown concern about specific risks including AI-generated bioweapons and Chinese AI companies' security threats.

quotes.quote: To win the AI race against China, we must unleash the full potential of American innovation.
quotes.source: Senate hearing announcement, September 4, 2025
quotes.context: Announcing his subcommittee hearing on Trump's AI Action Plan, emphasizing competition with China as central to his AI policy focus

quotes.quote: AI promises to be as transformative as the internet, unleashing a new global industrial revolution that could unlock opportunities for improving quality of life, creating jobs, and stimulating economic growth.
quotes.source: Senate hearing, September 10, 2025
quotes.context: Opening statement at Senate Subcommittee on Science, Manufacturing, and Competitiveness hearing on America's AI Action Plan

quotes.quote: If developed, deployed, and employed properly, AI stands to enable Americans to make the most and the best of themselves on a daily basis.
quotes.source: Senate hearing, September 10, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI's potential benefits for everyday Americans in their work and careers

quotes.quote: I firmly believe that our country's free-market, private sector-led way of doing things will be key to remaining ahead of Chinese state-backed AI developers.
quotes.source: Senate hearing, September 10, 2025
quotes.context: Contrasting U.S. free-market approach with China's state-directed AI development strategy

quotes.quote: As AI grows in power and influence, we may face the real prospect of AI-generated threats like biological or chemical weapons. We cannot be caught flat-footed on these threats and should begin to prepare now.
quotes.source: Bipartisan bill introduction, February 11, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing the Strategy for Public Health Preparedness and Response to Artificial Intelligence Threats Act with Senator Markey

quotes.quote: The PRC has put forward plans to leverage state resources and capital to make China the global leader in AI by 2030.
quotes.source: Senate hearing, September 10, 2025
quotes.context: Warning about China's ambitious AI development goals and state-backed approach

quotes.quote: We need federal preemption on anything that we do so we don't have a patchwork problem. You don't want to choke down innovation.
quotes.source: ABA Annual Convention, October 20, 2025
quotes.context: Calling for federal regulation to preempt state AI laws to maintain U.S. competitiveness

quotes.quote: Officials have to ensure AI is more good than evil
quotes.source: Fox Business interview, April 27, 2023
quotes.context: Early comments on the need for government action on artificial intelligence

quotes.quote: The U.S. has all the necessary ingredients to keep our lead and definitively win the AI race.
quotes.source: Senate hearing, September 10, 2025
quotes.context: Expressing confidence in U.S. ability to maintain AI leadership with proper policies

quotes.quote: It's very concerning what PRC is doing in the world...if we let that become dominant, it is a means of control. That's why I think that our worldview is that of freedom and of prosperity and of personal choice.
quotes.source: White House event, November 21, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the importance of U.S. AI models dominating globally to spread American values

Ted Budd.notes: Senator Budd is Chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Science, Manufacturing, and Competitiveness. His AI policy focuses heavily on U.S.-China competition, viewing it as a technological race with geopolitical implications. He consistently opposes regulation that might slow innovation, supporting the Trump administration's repeal of Biden's AI executive order. However, he has shown bipartisan willingness to address specific AI risks, co-sponsoring legislation with Democrat Ed Markey on AI-generated bioweapon threats. He has led multiple investigations into Chinese AI company DeepSeek over security concerns. He specifically mentions Director Kratsios (White House OSTP) and supports the SANDBOX Act. While he discusses AI's transformative potential comparable to the internet, he does not appear to discuss AGI, superintelligence, or existential risk in the sense of AI alignment concerns - his 'existential' concerns are more focused on specific misuse cases (bioweapons) and geopolitical competition with China rather than recursive self-improvement or loss of control scenarios.

Don Bacon.summary: Rep. Don Bacon (R-NE), chairman of the House Armed Services Subcommittee on Cyber, Information Technologies, and Innovation, views AI primarily through a national security and defense lens. He sees AI as critical for military competitiveness against China, emphasizes the need for rapid innovation and practical deployment over theoretical strategies, and has expressed concerns about AI companies' content moderation failures while supporting practical AI applications in defense.

quotes.quote: We've got to realize we're in an intellectual war, a technology war with China, and we're in an AI [artificial intelligence] competition.
quotes.source: NewsNation's 'The Hill' interview, August 2025
quotes.context: Bacon was criticizing the Trump administration's deal allowing Nvidia and AMD to share chip technology with China, viewing it as harmful to U.S. AI competitiveness.

quotes.quote: China has replaced Russia as the most formidable cyber threat. They have much higher technology. They are using AI, which gives you a lot more capability in finding weaknesses in your adversaries' cyber defenses.
quotes.source: Face the Nation interview, November 2025
quotes.context: Discussing Chinese state-sponsored hackers' use of AI in cyber espionage operations, highlighting China as the primary AI-enabled threat.

quotes.quote: As chairman, I will continue to support enhancing our cybersecurity and will work to advance artificial intelligence and emerging technologies that will be vital for our success on the battlefields of the future.
quotes.source: Statement upon becoming CITI Subcommittee Chairman, April 2024
quotes.context: Bacon outlined his priorities as chairman, emphasizing AI's military applications and battlefield importance.

quotes.quote: We cannot afford to remain stagnant as foreign actors attempt to surpass our nation through intellectual theft, electronic supply chain monopolies, and advancements in artificial intelligence capabilities.
quotes.source: Technology Competitiveness Council bill introduction, June 2022
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to coordinate national AI strategy and maintain U.S. technological leadership.

quotes.quote: Having Nvidia providing this technology to China is a mistake.
quotes.source: NewsNation interview, August 2025
quotes.context: Bacon opposed Trump's agreement with chipmakers to share AI chip revenue from China sales, viewing it as strategically harmful.

quotes.quote: Time and time again, DoD and Congress reinvent the wheel with strategies and roadmaps for critical technology areas, and what do we really have to show for it? America can no longer afford the time and expense of producing pages and pages of strategies, pilot programs, and technology demonstration and experimentation efforts, with no meaningful follow-on production contracts or capabilities delivered to warfighters at scale.
quotes.source: Breaking Defense op-ed, February 2025
quotes.context: Bacon criticized excessive planning and insufficient action in defense technology innovation, including AI, calling for practical deployment over theoretical strategies.

quotes.quote: For most of DOD's existence, DOD led the private sector, but now it's the other way around. How do you harness this better technology that's outside of DOD? And you got to get it right now.
quotes.source: Recorded Future News interview, January 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the challenge of integrating commercial AI and technology innovations into military applications quickly.

quotes.quote: I want to get us to be more aggressive and make China pay a price for what they're doing right now.
quotes.source: Recorded Future News interview, January 2025
quotes.context: Discussing cyber deterrence strategy against China's AI-enabled cyber operations.

quotes.quote: We're asking @elonmusk to fix & to address why this happened. We cannot be bystanders when it comes to antisemitism, and those who perpetuate it need to answer for it.
quotes.source: X/Twitter post, July 2025
quotes.context: Bacon joined a bipartisan congressional probe into Elon Musk's Grok AI chatbot over antisemitic and harmful outputs, showing concern about AI safety and content moderation.

quotes.quote: In order to maintain the world's most capable and lethal military, we must make modernization and innovation a priority.
quotes.source: Statement on becoming CITI Subcommittee Chairman, April 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing the need for AI and emerging technology modernization for military superiority.

Don Bacon.notes: Rep. Don Bacon's AI views are heavily shaped by his military background (29-year Air Force career, retired Brigadier General specializing in electronic warfare and intelligence) and his current role as chairman of the House Armed Services Cyber, Information Technologies, and Innovation Subcommittee. His perspective is distinctly national security-focused rather than philosophical or safety-theoretical. Key themes include: (1) China as primary AI competitor - consistently frames AI as part of technology competition with China; (2) Practical deployment over strategy - criticizes 'innovation theater' and calls for actual warfighting capabilities; (3) Private sector integration - recognizes commercial AI now surpasses DoD and seeks faster acquisition; (4) Limited safety focus - addresses content moderation issues (Grok/Musk) but not existential risk; (5) Bipartisan approach - co-sponsored Technology Competitiveness Council with Democrats. He voted for legislation that would have prohibited state-level AI regulation for 10 years, though this was later removed. He introduced legislation to use AI/ML algorithms for military housing calculations. Not 'AGI-pilled' - no discussion of superintelligence or transformative AGI scenarios. Views AI as transformative for military capabilities and battlefield success, but within conventional defense paradigms, not as existential technology requiring special governance beyond national security contexts.

Josh Gottheimer.summary: Josh Gottheimer views AI as transformative technology critical to U.S. economic and national security competitiveness, particularly vis-à-vis China. He strongly advocates for American AI leadership through innovation-friendly policies with 'smart safeguards,' while being deeply concerned about Chinese AI threats like DeepSeek. His approach balances promoting AI innovation with protecting consumers and national security, emphasizing bipartisan cooperation and maintaining competitive AI markets.

quotes.quote: From health care to education, the potential for artificial intelligence is boundless. The key for our economy and national security is to stay ahead of the curve — and ahead of our global competitors.
quotes.source: House Commission on AI announcement, December 9, 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer made this statement upon being appointed Co-Chair of the House Commission on Artificial Intelligence and the Innovation Economy, emphasizing AI's transformative potential and the need for U.S. leadership.

quotes.quote: This is a five alarm national security fire.
quotes.source: DeepSeek ban legislation announcement, February 6, 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer's characterization of the DeepSeek AI threat when introducing bipartisan legislation to ban the Chinese AI app from U.S. government devices, citing evidence of data collection capabilities.

quotes.quote: We simply can't risk the CCP infiltrating the devices of our government officials and jeopardizing our national security. We've seen China's playbook before with TikTok, and we cannot allow it to happen again.
quotes.source: No DeepSeek on Government Devices Act, February 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer explaining the urgency of banning DeepSeek from government devices, drawing parallels to TikTok national security concerns and China's pattern of using technology for surveillance.

quotes.quote: When it comes to artificial intelligence, we need smart safeguards in place to protect consumers, prevent abuse, and ensure our families and financial systems are safe. We also must ensure that the United States continues to lead the world in innovation.
quotes.source: Unleashing AI Innovation in Financial Services Act, July 30, 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer articulating his balanced approach to AI regulation when introducing legislation to create AI Innovation Labs in financial services, emphasizing both consumer protection and American leadership.

quotes.quote: If we have only one AI provider, that scares the heck out of me.
quotes.source: CNBC Squawk Box interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer expressing concern about AI monopolies and the importance of preserving competition in the AI sector, highlighting fears about a monopolistic landscape in AI development.

quotes.quote: I am worried that we preserve competition in these areas.
quotes.source: CNBC interview on AI policy, December 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer discussing the bipartisan AI commission's priorities, emphasizing the need to maintain a competitive AI ecosystem and prevent market concentration.

quotes.quote: We must put proper safeguards in place to defend our national security and ensure that our nation remains a leading force in innovation. As American entrepreneurs continue to face threats from foreign adversaries like China, this critical legislation will help ensure that we safeguard U.S. innovation from espionage and theft.
quotes.source: Advanced AI Security Readiness Act introduction, June 12, 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer introducing legislation directing the NSA to develop an AI security playbook to defend against foreign adversaries, particularly China, attempting to steal American AI technology.

quotes.quote: We want to make sure we do it the right way, and that we lead the world with appropriate guardrails.
quotes.source: CNBC Squawk Box interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer articulating his philosophy on AI regulation - promoting American leadership while implementing responsible oversight, balancing innovation with safety concerns.

quotes.quote: I'm not opposed to federal AI law, just need state carveouts.
quotes.source: CNBC Squawk Box interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer explaining his nuanced position on AI regulation, advocating for federal baseline standards while allowing states flexibility to address unique regional concerns and challenges.

quotes.quote: The Chinese Communist Party has made it abundantly clear that it will exploit any tool at its disposal to undermine our national security, spew harmful disinformation, and collect data on Americans. Now, we have deeply disturbing evidence that they are using DeepSeek to steal the sensitive data of U.S. citizens.
quotes.source: No DeepSeek on Government Devices Act statement, February 2025
quotes.context: Gottheimer warning about China's aggressive use of AI technology for espionage and disinformation, specifically regarding DeepSeek's data collection capabilities and links to China Mobile.

Josh Gottheimer.notes: Gottheimer is extremely focused on U.S.-China AI competition, frequently referencing China and the Chinese Communist Party as threats. He has led multiple pieces of legislation targeting Chinese AI companies (DeepSeek, TikTok) and protecting American AI innovation. He mentions OpenAI in the context of intellectual property theft by DeepSeek. He does not discuss AGI or existential risk from AI, but focuses heavily on near-term national security threats, economic competitiveness, and the need for 'smart safeguards' rather than heavy regulation. His background includes working as a Microsoft executive, and he has significant tech stock holdings. He co-chairs the House Democratic Commission on AI and has introduced numerous AI-related bills covering financial services, data center cooling, defense research, and cybersecurity. His approach emphasizes bipartisan cooperation and balancing innovation with consumer protection. He is concerned about AI monopolies and preserving competition. Notably, he uses AI in his own political campaigns (AI-generated boxing ad against Trump).

Jacky Rosen.summary: Senator Rosen views AI primarily through a national security and economic competitiveness lens, with strong focus on countering China and protecting against foreign adversaries. As a former computer programmer, she emphasizes the need for U.S. leadership in AI innovation while advocating for safety regulations and consumer protections. Her approach is pragmatic and bipartisan, focusing on defense applications, international cooperation with allies, and preventing malicious uses of AI.

quotes.quote: With the field of artificial intelligence rapidly evolving, it's critical that we work with our closest intelligence partners to develop shared AI strategies and stay ahead of our adversaries.
quotes.source: Five AIs Act introduction, May 10, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to coordinate AI initiatives between the U.S. and Five Eyes intelligence partners to address weaponization of AI by adversaries.

quotes.quote: The United States cannot take its Artificial Intelligence leadership for granted. We must fully utilize the public, as well as private sector, to synchronize and develop our AI capabilities across the transportation, health care, manufacturing, and national security policy spaces.
quotes.source: Advancing American AI Innovation Act, November 2021
quotes.context: Co-sponsoring bipartisan legislation to create DoD AI data libraries, emphasizing U.S. AI leadership concerns.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is a rapidly evolving field that is poised to reshape privacy rights, national security, and our democracy in the 21st century.
quotes.source: Campaign website on Technology policy, May 2024
quotes.context: Describing her overall view of AI's transformative impact on American society.

quotes.quote: The field of artificial intelligence and the role it plays in our nation's security are rapidly changing and expanding.
quotes.source: Advancing American AI Innovation Act announcement, November 2021
quotes.context: Discussing the need for DoD AI data libraries to help private companies develop AI models for defense needs.

quotes.quote: To maintain our technological edge and enhance our competitiveness, the United States must act now to rapidly field AI systems. As the National Security Commission on Artificial Intelligence rightly points out, leveraging allied innovation advantages is critical to winning the AI era.
quotes.source: U.S.-Israel AI Research and Development Center bill, July 2021
quotes.context: Supporting international cooperation with Israel on AI development to maintain U.S. competitive advantage.

quotes.quote: The U.S. must take steps to ensure Americans' data and our government systems are protected against cyber threats from foreign adversaries. This bipartisan legislation would prevent federal contractors from using Deepseek, a CCP-linked AI platform, when carrying out government work.
quotes.source: Protection Against Foreign Adversarial AI Act, May 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to ban DeepSeek AI platform due to Chinese Communist Party ties and data security concerns.

quotes.quote: As the artificial intelligence landscape continues to rapidly expand, the U.S. must take steps to ensure Americans' data and government systems remain protected against platforms—like DeepSeek—that are linked to our adversaries.
quotes.source: No DeepSeek on Government Devices Act, February 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to ban Chinese AI platform DeepSeek from government devices due to national security risks.

quotes.quote: Recent improvements in artificial intelligence (AI) and the accumulation of specific consumer data like geographic location and demographic information are allowing large corporate retailers to raise prices artificially, inconsistently, and unfairly.
quotes.source: Letter to FTC on AI surveillance pricing, March 2025
quotes.context: Expressing concern about corporations using AI for discriminatory pricing practices that hurt consumers.

quotes.quote: China has an explicit plan to become a standards issuing country, and as part of its push to increase global influence it coordinates national standards work across government and industry. So in order for the U.S. to remain a leader in AI and maintain a national security edge, our response must be one of leadership coordination, and, above all cooperation.
quotes.source: Senate hearing on AI, May 2023
quotes.context: Proposing a multilateral AI research institute to enable like-minded countries to collaborate on AI standard setting to counter China.

quotes.quote: I'm proud to introduce bipartisan legislation to develop and coordinate AI initiatives with some of our strongest intelligence allies to keep us on the cutting edge of artificial intelligence innovation and ensure the use of AI for good.
quotes.source: Five AIs Act introduction, May 10, 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing both innovation leadership and ensuring AI is used for beneficial purposes through allied cooperation.

Jacky Rosen.notes: Senator Rosen's AI views are heavily shaped by her background as a former computer programmer and her service on national security-related committees. Her focus is distinctly geopolitical and defense-oriented, with China mentioned repeatedly as the primary adversarial concern. She consistently frames AI as a tool for maintaining U.S. global leadership and views it as transformative for national security, democracy, and privacy rights. However, she does not engage with AGI concepts, existential risk, or AI alignment issues that dominate Silicon Valley discourse. Her legislative efforts include: the Advancing American AI Innovation Act (passed into law), the Five AIs Act (allied cooperation), U.S.-Israel AI R&D Center, and multiple bills banning Chinese AI platform DeepSeek. She also addresses consumer protection issues like AI-enabled price discrimination. Her approach is pragmatic, bipartisan, and focused on practical applications rather than speculative long-term scenarios. She is a member of the Senate AI Caucus and regularly participates in tech policy discussions at CES.

Adriano Espaillat.summary: Rep. Espaillat views AI as transformative technology with significant potential but emphasizes the need for responsible development with equity and inclusion at its core. His primary focus is ensuring Latino and underserved communities are not left behind by AI advancement, and he warns against authoritarian regimes using AI for 'digital colonialism.' He advocates for U.S. AI leadership while maintaining democratic values and preventing bias.

quotes.quote: AI has the potential to revolutionize our society, but it must be developed and implemented responsibly
quotes.source: Press Release, December 18, 2024
quotes.context: Statement announcing AI roundtable on Housing and Financial Services

quotes.quote: Our discussions set the foundation for an inclusive AI future that addresses the unique needs of Latino communities while emphasizing U.S. AI competitiveness
quotes.source: Press Release, December 18, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the goals of his AI roundtable series

quotes.quote: The prevalence of AI is constantly increasing in the daily lives of Americans, however, there are very few laws currently in place to limit this powerful technology
quotes.source: Press Release on Candidate Voice Fraud Prohibition Act
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to regulate AI use in political communications

quotes.quote: Unchecked AI usage in political communications has the potential to lead to unprecedented manipulation and misinformation
quotes.source: Press Release on Candidate Voice Fraud Prohibition Act
quotes.context: Warning about AI threats to democracy and elections

quotes.quote: We have to meet communities where they are—students, working moms, seniors—and build from the ground up. That means making AI education and literacy as fundamental as reading, writing, and math
quotes.source: Statement on AI Literacy and Inclusion Act, May 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to close the AI literacy gap

quotes.quote: Letting authoritarian regimes take the lead on AI could lead to an era of 'digital colonialism'
quotes.source: Resolution on Western Hemisphere AI Strategy, August 2023
quotes.context: Warning about foreign control of AI development (implicitly referencing China)

quotes.quote: United States-led investments in the development of AI in the Western Hemisphere would promote the inclusion and representation of underserved populations...ensuring that no individual country dominates AI
quotes.source: Resolution on Western Hemisphere AI Strategy, August 2023
quotes.context: Proposing regional AI collaboration to counter authoritarian influence

quotes.quote: By championing inclusion in AI and investing in AI in the Western Hemisphere, the United States can create a future where AI technologies authentically reflect the multifaceted diversity of our societies
quotes.source: Resolution on Western Hemisphere AI Strategy, August 2023
quotes.context: Advocating for democratic values in AI development

quotes.quote: The Western Hemisphere possesses a wealth of natural resources and a skilled human workforce, making it well-positioned to develop and promote future AI technologies that prioritize safety, diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility
quotes.source: Resolution on Western Hemisphere AI Strategy, August 2023
quotes.context: Making the case for Western Hemisphere AI development

quotes.quote: AI algorithms exhibit significant accuracy disparities, working more effectively on White faces while frequently misidentifying or failing to recognize brown, Black, Indigenous, and darker skinned faces
quotes.source: Resolution on Western Hemisphere AI Strategy, August 2023
quotes.context: Highlighting research on AI bias in facial recognition systems

Adriano Espaillat.notes: Rep. Espaillat's AI focus is heavily centered on equity, inclusion, and preventing discrimination against Latino and minority communities. While he doesn't explicitly name China in his resolution, news coverage indicates his warnings about 'digital colonialism' and 'authoritarian regimes' are implicitly referencing China. He has hosted multiple AI roundtables with representatives from OpenAI, Google, Microsoft, Amazon Web Services, and Anthropic. His approach emphasizes U.S. AI competitiveness and leadership while ensuring democratic values and preventing bias. He does not discuss AGI, existential risk, or technical AI safety/alignment issues—his concerns are primarily about near-term harms like bias, misinformation, election interference, and ensuring equitable access to AI benefits and education. He introduced the AI Literacy and Inclusion Act to close education gaps and the Candidate Voice Fraud Prohibition Act to prevent AI-generated political deepfakes. His perspective is that of a progressive Democrat focused on civil rights and social justice implications of AI rather than technical safety concerns.

Brian K. Fitzpatrick.summary: Congressman Fitzpatrick's AI stance is pragmatic and security-focused, centered primarily on protecting election integrity from AI-generated deepfakes and maintaining U.S. technological competitiveness against China and Russia. He views AI as presenting both significant opportunities and challenges that require careful regulation, particularly in the electoral context, while emphasizing the need for the U.S. to remain a 'top competitor' in AI and quantum computing.

quotes.quote: As our nation and the world adjust to the presence of artificial intelligence, it is crucial that we work with technology experts to guarantee that lawmakers are prepared to address the challenges, implications, and opportunities that these innovations put before us
quotes.source: Press release, September 27, 2023 - MIT Intelligence Committee visit
quotes.context: Statement following bipartisan House Intelligence Committee visit to MIT to learn about AI and technological innovation in the context of U.S. national security

quotes.quote: I'm proud to stand with members of the committee on both sides of the aisle to protect national security and ensure the United States remains a top competitor with respect to technology and intelligence
quotes.source: Press release, September 27, 2023 - MIT Intelligence Committee visit
quotes.context: Emphasizing the importance of U.S. competitiveness in AI and technology for national security purposes

quotes.quote: With countries like Russia and China investing in these technologies, the United States needs to harness the full potential of both AI and quantum computing to drive economic growth, enhance national security, and improve the daily lives of Americans
quotes.source: Chairman Mike Turner and Ranking Member Jim Himes statement, September 27, 2023 (associated with Fitzpatrick's MIT visit)
quotes.context: Statement from Intelligence Committee leadership on the importance of AI competition with adversaries, context in which Fitzpatrick participated

quotes.quote: As technology rapidly evolves, so must our defenses against those who seek to deceive voters and undermine our democratic process
quotes.source: Press release, September 17, 2024 - AI Ads Act introduction
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to combat fraudulent AI-generated campaign advertisements

quotes.quote: Right now, the FEC does not have the teeth, the regulatory authority, to protect the election
quotes.source: Star Tribune interview, September 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the need for stronger regulatory authority to address AI-generated deepfakes in elections

quotes.quote: Our legislation will shield the American people from the dangers of deceptive AI-generated content, ensuring our elections remain free, fair, and [secure]
quotes.source: Press release, September 17, 2024 - AI Ads Act introduction
quotes.context: Describing the purpose of the AI Ads Act to ban fraudulent AI misrepresentation in political campaigns

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is rapidly becoming more powerful and popular, and while it certainly poses a lot of benefits and opportunities, it also brings significant challenges that we must address
quotes.source: Press release, September 17, 2024 - AI Ads Act introduction (from Rep. Chavez-DeRemer, co-sponsor)
quotes.context: Co-sponsor statement reflecting the balanced view of AI's dual nature that Fitzpatrick's legislation embodies

quotes.quote: With the growing potential for artificial intelligence to be utilized in elections and campaigns, it is essential that state and local officials are prepared and provided with the resources to keep the election process secure
quotes.source: Press release, May 14, 2024 - Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to help election administrators address AI risks

quotes.quote: As artificial intelligence becomes more widely utilized across our country and around the globe — including by adversaries like Russia and the Chinese Communist Party, the United States needs clear guidelines to safeguard our elections systems against adversarial uses of AI
quotes.source: Congresswoman Spanberger statement, May 14, 2024 (co-sponsor of Fitzpatrick's bill)
quotes.context: Co-sponsor statement on the Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act, reflecting the bill's focus on foreign adversary threats

quotes.quote: From deepfakes to algorithmic disinformation, AI is reshaping how voters receive information—and how bad actors can exploit it
quotes.source: Press release, September 11, 2025 - Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act
quotes.context: Co-leading legislation to protect elections from AI-generated disinformation

Brian K. Fitzpatrick.notes: Congressman Fitzpatrick's AI focus is heavily concentrated on election security and national security implications rather than broader AI philosophy. As a member of the House Intelligence Committee and former FBI agent, his perspective is shaped by national security concerns. He consistently emphasizes: (1) The competitive dimension with China and Russia in AI development; (2) The threat of AI-generated deepfakes and disinformation to electoral integrity; (3) The need for regulatory frameworks specifically around election-related AI use; (4) A balanced view acknowledging both AI's opportunities and challenges. Notably absent from his public statements are discussions of: AGI/superintelligence, existential risk, AI alignment/safety research, specific AI companies or figures (like OpenAI, Anthropic, Sam Altman, etc.), or technical AI governance beyond election security. His legislative work includes the AI Ads Act, Preparing Election Administrators for AI Act, and related election security measures. He serves as Chairman of the CIA Subcommittee and has visited MIT to learn about AI's national security implications. His stance appears to be that of a pragmatic policymaker focused on near-term, concrete risks (especially to elections) rather than speculative long-term scenarios.

Lloyd Smucker.summary: Lloyd Smucker (R-PA-11) has limited public statements specifically about AI. His involvement with AI policy appears primarily through his vote supporting a 10-year moratorium on state AI regulations as part of the 2025 budget bill, and his participation in discussions about AI's energy demands and competition with China. He appears to favor deregulation and views AI development as important for economic competitiveness with China.

quotes.quote: One of the things that we did in this bill was deregulating where we can, by encouraging new development of energy, fossil fuels, every type of energy really
quotes.source: WESA/WITF, August 20, 2025
quotes.context: Smucker discussing energy policy in relation to AI development and data centers at a BAE Systems facility tour, emphasizing the need for fossil fuel energy to support AI infrastructure

quotes.quote: There is no doubt that the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) seeks to influence and negatively impact America's national security and economy
quotes.source: Press release on TikTok legislation, March 13, 2024
quotes.context: While discussing TikTok rather than AI specifically, this reflects Smucker's broader concern about Chinese technology threats and national security

quotes.quote: This legislation will protect the American people from the CCP and foreign adversaries who seek to harm, manipulate, or control the American people
quotes.source: Press release on TikTok legislation, March 13, 2024
quotes.context: Statement about foreign technology threats, indicating concern about Chinese control of technology platforms

quotes.quote: As the United States enters into a long-term competition with China on sensitive technologies of the 21st century, it is imperative that we are doing everything possible to innovate and lead
quotes.source: Op-ed on synthetic biology, August 3, 2022
quotes.context: While discussing synthetic biology rather than AI, shows his framing of technology competition with China as a national priority

Lloyd Smucker.notes: Lloyd Smucker has very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. His AI-related positions must be inferred primarily from: (1) His vote in favor of the House budget bill containing a 10-year moratorium on state AI regulations (May 2025), though his spokesman did not respond to requests for comment about this vote; (2) His participation in an August 2025 event where colleague Scott Perry stated 'the U.S. has no choice but to win the AI race with China' and Smucker discussed energy deregulation to support AI development; (3) His membership on the Joint Economic Committee, which held a June 2024 hearing on 'Artificial Intelligence and Its Potential to Fuel Economic Growth and Improve Governance,' though no specific statements from Smucker at this hearing were found; (4) His general pattern of supporting deregulation, free enterprise, and viewing technology competition with China as a national security priority. He has made statements about China as a technology threat in the context of TikTok and synthetic biology, but has not made substantive public statements about AI safety, AGI, existential risk, alignment, or specific AI companies. His overall approach appears to favor minimal regulation to promote innovation and economic competitiveness.

David Kustoff.summary: David Kustoff has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. His primary AI-related comment concerns the misuse of AI by scammers to create fraudulent robocalls. His broader technology policy focuses heavily on protecting U.S. research and intellectual property from Chinese theft, particularly through the SECURE CAMPUS Act, and on maintaining American innovation leadership against foreign competitors, especially China.

quotes.quote: Scammers are using artificial intelligence to mimic voices and spoof Caller ID, making these calls even harder to detect
quotes.source: DO NOT Call Act introduction, December 2025
quotes.context: Kustoff's statement when introducing bipartisan legislation to crack down on illegal robocalls. This is his only direct public statement about AI technology found in the research.

quotes.quote: The Chinese Communist Party's attempts to exploit and steal our cutting-edge research and technology from inside our American universities
quotes.source: SECURE CAMPUS Act introduction, November 2024
quotes.context: Statement about protecting U.S. research institutions from Chinese espionage, particularly in STEM fields including advanced technology.

quotes.quote: Allowing China unfettered access to American research institutions is akin to granting Soviet scientists access to our critical laboratories during the Cold War
quotes.source: SECURE CAMPUS Act introduction, November 2024
quotes.context: Kustoff comparing current Chinese access to U.S. research to Cold War era threats, emphasizing national security concerns about technology transfer.

quotes.quote: With 1,000 open FBI cases regarding Chinese espionage in the United States, it is clear the Communist Party of China has exploited the openness of the American research enterprise for far too long
quotes.source: China Task Force presentation, November 2024
quotes.context: Presenting the SECURE CAMPUS Act to GOP China Task Force, focusing on Chinese theft of U.S. technology and research.

quotes.quote: China positions itself to challenge the United States as the global economic superpower, we need to ensure America remains the innovation capital of the world
quotes.source: Opinion piece, September 2022
quotes.context: Writing about keeping Tennessee and America competitive, emphasizing the need to maintain innovation leadership against China.

quotes.quote: We can stand up to our competitors and bad actors by investing in innovation to strengthen our global standing
quotes.source: Opinion piece, September 2022
quotes.context: General statement about innovation policy and competition with foreign adversaries.

quotes.quote: It is critical that the United States remains at the forefront of developing new medical technologies, treatments, and drugs
quotes.source: Small Biotech Innovation Act introduction, June 2025
quotes.context: Statement about maintaining U.S. leadership in biotech innovation, though not specifically about AI.

quotes.quote: The SECURE CAMPUS Act will help stop Chinese nationals from stealing U.S. technology, which the CCP uses against our own troops and businesses
quotes.source: SECURE CAMPUS Act introduction, 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing national security implications of technology theft by China.

quotes.quote: Student visas should be only for those who want to contribute to our research institutions and advance our national interests
quotes.source: SECURE CAMPUS Act announcement, 2020
quotes.context: Defending legislation to restrict Chinese nationals from STEM graduate programs in the U.S.

quotes.quote: As technology advances, scammers find new ways to misuse personal information and to deceive the public – particularly targeting seniors and other vulnerable people
quotes.source: DO NOT Call Act introduction, December 2025
quotes.context: Acknowledging the dual-use nature of advancing technology, including AI, for both legitimate and fraudulent purposes.

David Kustoff.notes: David Kustoff (R-TN-08) has made extremely limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. The only direct AI reference found was regarding AI-enabled voice mimicry in robocall scams. His technology policy focus is overwhelmingly on: (1) Protecting U.S. research and intellectual property from Chinese theft through the SECURE CAMPUS Act, which would ban Chinese nationals from STEM graduate programs; (2) Maintaining U.S. innovation leadership against China; and (3) General support for American technological competitiveness. He has NOT publicly discussed: AGI, AI safety, AI alignment, existential risk, transformative AI, specific AI companies, or technical AI policy. His China focus is on espionage and technology theft rather than AI competition specifically. As a member of the House Ways and Means Committee, his legislative work centers on tax, trade, and economic policy rather than technology regulation. The lack of substantive AI statements suggests this is not a priority issue for him, or he has not been publicly vocal about it.

Vicente Gonzalez.summary: Limited public information available regarding Congressman Vicente Gonzalez's views on artificial intelligence. The only AI-related statement found was a brief mention about using 'drone operations, AI and other cutting-edge industries' to supplement job losses at a naval base in his district.

quotes.quote: Drone operations, AI and other cutting-edge industries can help supplement the loss we had from the helicopter industry leaving this base.
quotes.source: Campaign kickoff speech in Corpus Christi, January 2025
quotes.context: Gonzalez mentioned AI in the context of economic development opportunities for Naval Air Station Corpus Christi after helicopter repair operations departed, suggesting AI could create jobs in his district.

quotes.quote: This bill makes critical investments that will allow America to be a leader in technology research and development. I'm proud to support this bill that will certainly strengthen our economy, promote American competitiveness, and expand opportunities for everyone, especially South Texans.
quotes.source: Statement on America COMPETES Act, February 2022
quotes.context: Voted for legislation to strengthen America's supply chain and outcompete China on technology, though AI was not specifically mentioned.

quotes.quote: Only by engaging with China can we can secure fairer market access and intellectual property protections for businesses in the 15th District of Texas.
quotes.source: Statement after meeting with China's Vice Premier, 2018
quotes.context: Discussed U.S.-China relations in context of trade and intellectual property, though not specifically about AI competition.

quotes.quote: Ending our dependence on China starts today. A reliable supply of these materials is essential to American economic and security interests.
quotes.source: Statement on RARE Act introduction, September 2020
quotes.context: Introduced legislation to reduce dependence on China for rare earth minerals used in technology, relevant to AI hardware supply chains.

quotes.quote: The future of the American workforce is rooted in the advancements we make in the STEM fields and the Congressional App Challenge is a great way to get students engaged and curious about it.
quotes.source: Congressional App Challenge announcement, December 2022
quotes.context: Promoted STEM education and coding skills for students in his district, showing support for technology education but not specifically addressing AI.

Vicente Gonzalez.notes: Congressman Vicente Gonzalez (D-TX-34) represents a South Texas district that includes Naval Air Station Kingsville and borders Mexico. His public statements focus primarily on economic development, border issues, trade, veterans affairs, and U.S.-China competition in general terms. He has mentioned China extensively in the context of trade policy, rare earth minerals, and economic competition, and voted for the America COMPETES Act to strengthen U.S. competitiveness against China. However, he has made only one identifiable public statement specifically about AI (mentioning it alongside drones as potential economic opportunities). He supports STEM education and technology development in his district. As a conservative 'Blue Dog' Democrat, his technology policy positions appear to focus on economic competitiveness and job creation rather than AI-specific issues like safety, alignment, or existential risk. More targeted outreach would be needed to understand his detailed views on AI policy.

Jodey C. Arrington.summary: Rep. Arrington's AI stance is primarily focused on economic competitiveness with China and promoting AI infrastructure investment in his Texas district. He introduced legislation (H.R. 1) that includes a 10-year moratorium on state AI regulation, positioning himself as pro-innovation and anti-regulation. His rhetoric emphasizes AI as an economic and geopolitical tool rather than engaging with technical safety or existential risk concerns.

quotes.quote: Welcome to 'Silicon Prairie,' the place where big horizons meet even bigger opportunities.
quotes.source: Stargate AI data center tour, September 2025
quotes.context: Arrington coined the term 'Silicon Prairie' while promoting the OpenAI/Oracle Stargate AI data center project in Abilene, Texas, emphasizing regional economic development.

quotes.quote: From construction jobs to cutting-edge careers, this project means opportunities for our people, billions in private investment, and a powerful reminder that America - not China - will lead in the technologies of tomorrow.
quotes.source: Press release regarding Stargate initiative, September 2025
quotes.context: Arrington explicitly frames AI development as a competition with China, emphasizing American technological leadership and job creation in West Texas.

quotes.quote: I'm very proud that West Texas is now not only the food, fuel and fiber capital of the world, where we have energy and agriculture dominance, but we're the new frontier for information technology and in support of the AI race for our great country.
quotes.source: Stargate tour remarks, September 2025
quotes.context: Arrington positions AI infrastructure as part of a technological 'race' and emphasizes his district's role in national AI competitiveness.

quotes.quote: There's no better place to build the backbone for AI than West Texas because of our abundant and reliable energy, our workforce, our hard-working, God fearing, freedom-loving people, and we have a very good environment for starting businesses and building facilities like this at this scale.
quotes.source: Interview during Stargate tour, September 2025
quotes.context: Arrington emphasizes practical infrastructure advantages for AI development, focusing on energy, workforce, and business environment rather than policy or safety considerations.

quotes.quote: We believe AI can contribute to productivity and economic gains, but also help us identify waste and fraud.
quotes.source: House Budget Committee opening remarks, 2025
quotes.context: Arrington views AI as a tool for government efficiency and budget management, introducing Jay Obernolte as chair of the House Task Force on AI.

quotes.quote: Mexico's weak investment standards have created a backdoor for China to move products into the United States tariff-free.
quotes.source: Press release on CFIUSMCA Act, December 2025
quotes.context: While not directly about AI, this shows Arrington's broader concern about China using indirect routes to access U.S. markets, which contextualizes his China-focused AI rhetoric.

quotes.quote: Now, with President Trump back in the White House, we have leadership that will hold China's feet to the fire.
quotes.source: Statement on Section 301 investigation, October 2025
quotes.context: Demonstrates Arrington's general hawkish stance on China trade and competition, which extends to his views on AI development.

quotes.quote: Representative Arrington believes that AI has the potential to be a powerful force for good.
quotes.source: Local news report on Stargate tour, September 2025
quotes.context: A general optimistic statement about AI's potential, though lacking specifics about safety, alignment, or governance.

quotes.quote: This isn't an ideological document, it isn't the left versus right, it's about returning to America's core values and restoring power back to we the people instead of we the government.
quotes.source: General quote from quotes.net
quotes.context: While not specifically about AI, this reflects Arrington's anti-regulatory philosophy that informs his approach to AI policy, including the state regulation moratorium.

quotes.quote: Shackleford vs Shanghai, Big Country vs Beijing
quotes.source: Press release title, September 2025
quotes.context: Arrington frames AI development explicitly as geographic and geopolitical competition with China, positioning West Texas counties against Chinese cities.

Jodey C. Arrington.notes: Arrington's AI engagement is notably limited to economic and geopolitical dimensions. As the sponsor of H.R. 1 (One Big Beautiful Bill Act), he introduced a controversial 10-year moratorium on state AI regulation, though there's no evidence he has publicly explained the rationale or engaged with criticism of this provision. He frequently references China as a competitor in AI development and has hosted events with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and Oracle executives. However, he has made no public statements about AGI timelines, AI safety research, alignment problems, existential risk, or technical AI governance issues. His focus is entirely on infrastructure investment, job creation, and maintaining U.S. technological superiority over China. He appears to view AI primarily through an economic development and national security lens rather than as a technology requiring careful safety considerations. His stance is strongly pro-innovation and anti-regulation, consistent with his broader conservative political philosophy.

Pramila Jayapal.summary: Pramila Jayapal approaches AI primarily through a civil rights and labor lens, focusing on protecting workers, preventing algorithmic discrimination, and ensuring fundamental rights are not compromised. She views AI as requiring strong regulatory guardrails and has been active in legislation to address bias, protect data workers, and establish an 'AI Bill of Rights.' She does not appear to engage with existential risk or AGI concepts publicly.

quotes.quote: With the rise of AI posing a clear threat to our fundamental rights, we are glad that the Biden administration is implementing new safeguards as the federal government regulates, uses, and obtains AI systems.
quotes.source: Statement on President Biden's AI Executive Order, October 30, 2023
quotes.context: Jayapal applauded Biden's AI executive order incorporating the AI Bill of Rights, emphasizing threats to civil rights rather than existential risks.

quotes.quote: Our fundamental rights are at stake, and we won't rest until they are secure in this era of artificial intelligence.
quotes.source: Statement on President Biden's AI Executive Order, October 30, 2023
quotes.context: Jayapal emphasized the need for Congressional action to protect rights in the AI era, focusing on privacy, discrimination, and workers' rights.

quotes.quote: AI systems must be developed with guardrails.
quotes.source: Letter to President Biden urging AI Bill of Rights implementation, October 2023
quotes.context: Co-led letter with Senator Markey calling for federal policy requiring AI systems to have protective guardrails.

quotes.quote: Tech companies must not build AI on the backs of exploited workers.
quotes.source: Letter to AI company CEOs, September 13, 2023
quotes.context: Jayapal led colleagues in demanding answers from Google, OpenAI, Anthropic, Meta, Microsoft, Amazon, and other AI companies about working conditions of data workers.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence has become a part of our everyday lives and grown into a projected $244 billion industry. A major risk of this new technology is the biases and discrimination that are built into algorithms – denying people housing or jobs based on race or gender.
quotes.source: AI Civil Rights Act reintroduction, December 2, 2025
quotes.context: Jayapal co-led legislation to prevent discriminatory AI algorithms in critical life decisions.

quotes.quote: Our bill would place critical guardrails to ensure that the technologies of the future do not harden the injustices of the past.
quotes.source: AI Civil Rights Act reintroduction, December 2, 2025
