quotes.context: Introducing the Decoupling America's Artificial Intelligence Capabilities from China Act, which would ban AI technology imports/exports with China and prohibit U.S. companies from conducting AI research with Chinese entities.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is already replacing American workers, and experts project AI could drive unemployment up to 10 to 20% in the next five years.
quotes.source: Bill announcement, December 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to track AI-attributed layoffs, expressing concern about mass unemployment from AI automation.

quotes.quote: We will find ourselves facing a new kind of caste system — genetically modified, 'perfect' humans ruling over the imperfect ones, all with the help of the most powerful technology yet known to man.
quotes.source: National Conservatism Conference, September 4, 2025
quotes.context: Warning that unchecked AI development would concentrate unprecedented power in tech elites while hollowing out the working class.

quotes.quote: Congress can and should act to protect Americans' privacy, stave off the harms of unchecked AI development, insulate kids from harmful impacts, and keep this valuable technology out of the hands of our adversaries.
quotes.source: AI principles announcement, June 2023
quotes.context: Announcing five guiding principles for AI legislation, including private rights of action, licensing requirements, and protecting children.

quotes.quote: That is the vision—the religion and ideology—that animates so much of the breathless race for artificial intelligence … and for artificial general intelligence … and super-intelligence, and beyond: for the day when humans are no longer embodied beings at all but live infinitely in the cloud.
quotes.source: National Conservatism Conference, September 4, 2025
quotes.context: Describing what he sees as the ideological motivations behind AI development, explicitly referencing AGI and superintelligence as goals of tech companies.

quotes.quote: AI companies are robbing the American people blind while leaving artists, writers, and other creators with zero recourse. It's time for Congress to give the American worker their day in court.
quotes.source: Bipartisan legislation announcement, July 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to allow Americans to sue AI companies for using their copyrighted works and personal data without permission.

quotes.quote: Congress must act on AI regulation, and these principles should form the backbone. Our American families, workers, and national security are on the line.
quotes.source: Bipartisan framework announcement with Sen. Blumenthal, September 2023
quotes.context: Announcing a comprehensive legislative framework calling for licensing, oversight body, accountability for harms, and national security protections.

quotes.quote: There is increasing evidence that AI chatbots pose a grave harm to children. More than seventy percent of American children are now using AI chatbots, which exposes minors to a host of concerning material and mental health risks.
quotes.source: Document request to tech companies, September 2025
quotes.context: Following a hearing where parents testified about children who committed suicide after interactions with AI chatbots, Hawley demanded documents from Character.AI, OpenAI, Meta, Google, and Snap.

quotes.quote: Simply stated, Congress must not allow our national security, civil liberties, and labor protections to take a back seat to AI.
quotes.source: AI Risk Evaluation Act introduction, September 2025
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation requiring advanced AI systems to undergo government testing for risks including 'loss-of-control scenarios' and potential weaponization before deployment.

Josh Hawley.notes: Hawley is one of the most active congressional voices on AI regulation. He explicitly references AGI and superintelligence as real goals of AI companies and frames this as driven by 'transhumanist ideology.' He has introduced multiple bills addressing: (1) China decoupling, (2) tracking AI layoffs, (3) copyright protection, (4) children's safety from chatbots, (5) licensing and oversight regimes, (6) liability for AI harms, and (7) risk evaluation programs. His AI Risk Evaluation Act specifically mentions evaluating 'loss-of-control scenarios' and 'the potential for controlled AI systems to reach artificial superintelligence.' He works extensively in bipartisan fashion with Sen. Blumenthal (D-CT). His framing is populist, anti-Big Tech, and explicitly concerned with protecting workers, children, and American sovereignty. He has questioned Sam Altman (OpenAI), Dario Amodei (Anthropic), and Mark Zuckerberg (Meta) in hearings. He views tech companies' AI development as 'the largest intellectual property theft in American history' and believes AI will create a 'caste system' favoring elites.

Jared F. Golden.summary: Congressman Jared Golden (D-ME-02) has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. His only identifiable AI-related legislative activity is co-sponsoring the bipartisan SPEED Act, which aims to streamline federal permitting for energy infrastructure projects, including those needed for AI data centers. His statements focus on infrastructure and economic development rather than AI policy, safety, or regulation.

quotes.quote: lead the world in the AI race
quotes.source: SPEED Act introduction statement, July 2025
quotes.context: Golden stated that the SPEED Act would help America 'meet skyrocketing energy demands, lead the world in the AI race and work in harmony with our natural environment.' This brief reference to AI was in the context of permitting reform for infrastructure.

quotes.quote: strengthen our ability to compete in the global race for AI innovation
quotes.source: SPEED Act floor debate, December 2025
quotes.context: Mentioned as part of broader infrastructure modernization goals, emphasizing competition but not discussing AI technology, safety, or policy specifics.

quotes.quote: A country as advanced as the United States must be nimble enough to build what we need, when we need it
quotes.source: SPEED Act introduction, July 2025
quotes.context: While discussing infrastructure and energy projects (including those for AI), Golden emphasized the need for faster permitting processes to support economic development and competitiveness.

Jared F. Golden.notes: After extensive research, I found that Congressman Jared Golden has made virtually no substantive public statements about artificial intelligence policy, safety, regulation, or its societal implications. His only identifiable AI-related activity is co-sponsoring the SPEED Act with Rep. Bruce Westerman (R-AR), which focuses on streamlining federal permitting for energy and infrastructure projects. In this context, he briefly mentions 'leading the world in the AI race' and competing in 'global race for AI innovation,' which suggests awareness of international competition (particularly with China, as mentioned by other supporters of the bill). However, these are passing references in the context of infrastructure policy rather than substantive AI policy positions. Golden has not made public statements about: AGI, existential risk, AI safety, AI alignment, AI regulation, specific AI companies, transformative potential of AI, or detailed views on AI development. His focus appears to be on the infrastructure and energy needs to support AI development rather than the technology itself. Golden announced in September 2025 that he will not seek reelection in 2026, which may explain limited engagement with emerging technology policy issues. I was unable to find the 10 quotes requested because they simply do not exist in the public record.

Gregory F. Murphy.summary: Representative Gregory F. Murphy has made limited public statements specifically about AI. His primary AI-related focus has been on healthcare applications, where he advocates for balanced FDA regulation that encourages innovation while protecting consumers. He has not made extensive public statements on broader AI policy issues.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is set to transform health care dramatically, and its emergence in the field of medicine is happening rapidly
quotes.source: Letter to FDA Commissioner, January 3, 2024
quotes.context: Murphy wrote to the FDA Commissioner regarding regulatory frameworks for AI in healthcare, emphasizing the transformative potential in medicine.

quotes.quote: As a physician of over 30 years, I am thrilled by the potential of AI to improve the efficiency and quality of patient care in more ways than we could have imagined just ten years ago
quotes.source: Letter to FDA Commissioner, January 3, 2024
quotes.context: Expressing optimism about AI's medical applications from his perspective as a practicing urologist.

quotes.quote: We must be judicious in cultivating a regulatory environment that both protects consumers and encourages innovation
quotes.source: Letter to FDA Commissioner, January 3, 2024
quotes.context: Advocating for balanced regulation of AI in healthcare that doesn't stifle innovation.

quotes.quote: The agency must be prepared for explosive growth in artificial intelligence in the health care industry which is set to grow tenfold by 2030
quotes.source: Letter to FDA Commissioner, January 3, 2024
quotes.context: Warning the FDA about the rapid growth trajectory of AI in healthcare.

Gregory F. Murphy.notes: IMPORTANT CLARIFICATION: Representative Gregory F. Murphy (R-NC-3) has made very limited public statements about AI, focusing primarily on healthcare applications and FDA regulation. He has NOT made public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI competition with China, or AI companies like OpenAI. His stance appears generally supportive of AI innovation in healthcare with appropriate regulatory guardrails. As a physician, his interest in AI appears limited to medical applications. There is insufficient public information to provide 10 quotes about his AI views. NOTE: There is a different politician, Senator Chris Murphy (D-CT), who has made extensive statements about AI risks, AGI, and AI companies - these should not be confused with Representative Gregory Murphy.

Kweisi Mfume.summary: Rep. Mfume has expressed concern about AI's implications, particularly regarding national security, while simultaneously supporting AI education and workforce development at HBCUs. His focus appears to be on ensuring equitable access to AI opportunities for underrepresented communities rather than on existential risks or technical AI safety issues. He views AI as transformative and emphasizes the government's role in creating opportunities.

quotes.quote: This, for lack of a better term, has scared the hell out of me.
quotes.source: House Oversight and Accountability Subcommittee hearing 'Advances in AI: Are We Ready For a Tech Revolution?', March 8, 2023
quotes.context: Mfume expressed alarm after hearing testimony about AI's implications, particularly regarding national security concerns during a congressional hearing on AI.

quotes.quote: I thought I knew something about AI. I'm bopping around on the campus talking to students in a classroom now and then teaching them, but what I have heard today is unlike anything I have ever heard, particularly in terms of our national security.
quotes.source: House Oversight and Accountability Subcommittee hearing, March 8, 2023
quotes.context: Continuing his remarks at the AI hearing, Mfume acknowledged that despite his familiarity with AI from teaching, the security implications were more serious than he had realized.

quotes.quote: We stand today between two worlds — the dying old and the emerging new.
quotes.source: Howard University event 'Shaping the Future: AI, Tech Innovation, and the Next-Generation Workforce', November 2025 (quoting Martin Luther King Jr.)
quotes.context: Mfume used this MLK quote to frame AI as a transformative moment for humanity during a discussion about AI education and workforce development at Howard University.

quotes.quote: I hope you all realize that the government has control to help create, stabilize and ensure that the opportunities are there.
quotes.source: Howard University AI workforce event, November 2025
quotes.context: Speaking to HBCU students about AI's impact on the workforce, emphasizing the government's role in ensuring equitable access to AI opportunities.

quotes.quote: All of you have a sphere of influence. So many people believe you have the answer. Your opinion has real value.
quotes.source: Howard University AI workforce event, November 2025
quotes.context: Encouraging students to recognize their power to shape AI's development and its impact on society.

quotes.quote: Climate change is real. As we work to understand and manage the effects of climate change, the federal government, academia, nonprofits, and the private sector must work as partners in every community going forward.
quotes.source: Press release on Morgan State University receiving $3M for AI climate research, September 12, 2023
quotes.context: Announcing NSF funding through the CHIPS and Science Act for AI research focused on combating climate change at Morgan State University.

quotes.quote: We fought to pass the CHIPS and Science Act to boost our competitiveness in critical emerging technologies, keep America at the forefront of innovation and discovery.
quotes.source: Press release on CHIPS and Science Act funding, September 2023
quotes.context: Discussing the CHIPS and Science Act in relation to AI and technological competitiveness, implicitly referencing competition with other nations.

quotes.quote: I think you are encountering a great deal of inattentive or unattentive population groups who just, for whatever reason, are not paying attention to what is going on.
quotes.source: House Oversight hearing on AI, March 8, 2023
quotes.context: Expressing concern that the general public is not paying sufficient attention to AI developments and their implications.

Kweisi Mfume.notes: Limited public statements available. Mfume's AI-related activities primarily focus on: (1) Supporting CHIPS and Science Act funding for AI research and education, particularly at HBCUs and minority-serving institutions; (2) Concerns about national security implications of AI; (3) Ensuring equitable access to AI education and workforce opportunities for underrepresented communities. He served on the Select Committee on the Coronavirus Pandemic (not the China committee) but supported CHIPS Act which explicitly addresses U.S. competitiveness against China. His March 2023 hearing testimony shows genuine concern about AI's implications, but he has not made extensive public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, or specific AI companies/figures. His primary lens appears to be equity, workforce development, and ensuring government plays a role in democratizing AI access rather than technical safety or governance issues.

Thomas P. Tiffany.summary: Rep. Thomas P. Tiffany (R-WI-7) has made extremely limited public statements about artificial intelligence. The only identified reference to AI was a brief mention in August 2025 regarding wildfire detection technology. There is no evidence of substantive engagement with AI policy, safety, or regulation issues in his public record.

quotes.quote: Between satellites, early detection cameras, artificial intelligence (AI), and drones, there is more than enough wildfire technology available to help turn the tide on this issue.
quotes.source: The Tiffany Telegram newsletter, August 8, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing wildfire management in Canada and advocating for increased use of technology including AI for early wildfire detection. This represents his only identified public statement mentioning AI.

Thomas P. Tiffany.notes: Rep. Tiffany has not made substantive public statements about AI policy, regulation, safety, or development. His legislative record shows no AI-related bills or co-sponsorships. His primary focus areas include Taiwan relations, immigration, border security, and natural resources management. While he co-sponsored the 'Countering Communist China Act' in 2021, this bill did not specifically address AI technology. The single mention of AI in his public communications was purely utilitarian, referencing it as one of several technologies for wildfire detection. There is insufficient evidence to determine his views on: AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, AI companies (OpenAI, DeepSeek, etc.), transformative potential of AI, or China's AI development. He does not appear to be actively engaged in AI policy debates in Congress as of January 2026.

Mark Kelly.summary: Senator Mark Kelly views AI as highly transformative technology that requires proactive government intervention to protect workers and ensure shared prosperity. He is deeply concerned about job displacement and infrastructure strain, emphasizing U.S.-China competition while warning of potential economic bubble risks. His approach focuses on pragmatic workforce protection rather than existential AI risks.

quotes.quote: I think AI is going to be huge for our economy, and we have a competition here with another rather huge country out here, China, that we often compete with in technology. And if we don't have the right framework in place to lead the world in AI, they will, and we will fall behind.
quotes.source: Axios AI+ Summit, September 17, 2025
quotes.context: Kelly emphasizing the importance of U.S.-China competition in AI while pitching his 'AI for America' roadmap

quotes.quote: There is a possibility we could have millions of people put out of work by artificial intelligence. Hey, AI companies need customers. You're not going to have customers if people don't have jobs.
quotes.source: Axios AI+ Summit, September 17, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the workforce impact of AI and the need for companies to invest in worker retraining

quotes.quote: As a nation, we must seize this moment to build an AI boom for all, not another tech bubble for the few.
quotes.source: AI for America roadmap, September 2025
quotes.context: Central theme of his AI policy proposal calling for tech companies to fund worker retraining and infrastructure

quotes.quote: I kind of felt like we were lacking a real plan. I think we're going to be regretful about it and say we should have gotten ahead of this.
quotes.source: Punchbowl News interview, September 2025
quotes.context: Explaining his motivation for releasing the AI for America roadmap

quotes.quote: And if there's a big bubble and that bubble bursts in a really, really bad way, it's going to be harmful to the broader economy. It might make the downturn in 2008 look like a party.
quotes.source: Center for American Progress speech, December 4, 2025
quotes.context: Warning about potential economic risks if AI investment doesn't pay off

quotes.quote: If we get it right—sometimes we don't always get everything right—but if we can get this right, we can grow the economy, we can create more jobs, we can solve some of the world's hardest problems in medicine, chemistry, material science, physics, biology, biotech… the hardest things that we have probably had no hope in solving in the next 50 years, we could figure out in the next five.
quotes.source: Semafor AI Safety event, September 30, 2025
quotes.context: Expressing optimism about AI's potential benefits if properly managed

quotes.quote: We do not want to find ourselves in a situation where 10 million people have lost their jobs to AI, and they don't have a good option. That's not good for any of us.
quotes.source: Axios AI+ Summit, September 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the need for comprehensive retraining programs to prevent mass job displacement

quotes.quote: I don't think that message is resonating, because right now, people are dealing with rising costs... You can tell somebody, 'In the future, AI is going to solve all these medical problems.' But when your kid can't play soccer because you don't have the money, that's your problem.
quotes.source: Axios interview, January 14, 2026
quotes.context: Acknowledging that voters are more concerned about affordability than the AI race with China

quotes.quote: We have to strengthen our infrastructure and we have to support smart, responsible laws that keep this technology safe and true to our values, because American leadership doesn't happen by accident.
quotes.source: Center for American Progress speech, December 2025
quotes.context: Calling for rigorous testing and safety standards for AI models

quotes.quote: If this deal succeeds, the offshoring of frontier American AI will be recorded as an historic American blunder. People around the world deserve to enjoy the benefits we will reap from AI. However, AI chips must only be exported to trusted companies, in reasonable numbers, and in concert with credible security standards and assurances.
quotes.source: Joint statement on Trump's Middle East AI deals, May 16, 2025
quotes.context: Criticizing deals to export advanced AI chips to UAE and Saudi Arabia, warning about China access

Mark Kelly.notes: Mark Kelly is one of the most active Democratic senators on AI policy. He frequently references China as a competitor and emphasizes the need for U.S. leadership. However, he is NOT 'AGI-pilled' - he focuses on practical workforce impacts rather than superintelligence scenarios. He does NOT discuss existential risk from AI in any of his public statements. Instead, his concerns center on: (1) job displacement affecting millions of workers, (2) infrastructure strain from data centers, (3) potential economic bubble comparable to or worse than 2008, and (4) ensuring AI benefits are broadly shared rather than concentrated among tech companies. He supports safety measures like rigorous testing and 'red teaming' but frames these as consumer protection and competitive advantage rather than existential safety. His 'AI for America' roadmap proposes an 'AI Horizon Fund' paid for by tech companies to retrain workers and build infrastructure. He has consulted with companies like OpenAI and Duolingo. Kelly views AI as highly transformative but warns it could be overhyped economically (bubble risk). He's positioned himself as a leading Democratic voice on AI policy and is considered a potential 2028 presidential candidate.

Cynthia M. Lummis.summary: Senator Lummis views AI as a transformative technology with significant potential for America, but emphasizes the need to balance innovation with accountability. She is heavily focused on U.S.-China AI competition, advocating for American energy dominance and federal regulatory frameworks that don't stifle innovation. Her approach prioritizes transparency, professional responsibility, and maintaining America's competitive edge over concerns about existential risks.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is a transformative technology with incredibly positive potential for our country, but I am gravely concerned Google's Gemini is being cultivated to tilt the politic[al landscape]
quotes.source: Senate press release regarding Google Gemini, June 3, 2024
quotes.context: Lummis co-signed a letter with Senators Lee and Vance demanding answers from Google about political bias in their Gemini AI model, expressing concerns about AI being used to manipulate information for ideological purposes.

quotes.quote: America will lead the artificial intelligence revolution, or we will cede our future to the Chinese Communist Party
quotes.source: Op-ed in Cowboy State Daily, September 2025
quotes.context: Discussing President Trump's AI initiative and the importance of Wyoming's energy resources in powering America's AI infrastructure to compete with China.

quotes.quote: The AI technological arms race isn't coming. It's here, and it's moving fast. America's victory depends entirely on the reliable, affordable, abundant power that Wyoming can provide at the scale this challenge demands
quotes.source: Op-ed in Cowboy State Daily, September 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing the urgency of the AI competition with China and positioning Wyoming's energy resources as critical to American AI leadership.

quotes.quote: The Chinese Communist Party is betting everything on a simple wager: that America's environmental extremists will successfully cripple our energy sector while China builds technological superiority on mountains of coal and rivers of oil
quotes.source: Op-ed in Cowboy State Daily, September 2025
quotes.context: Framing the AI race as intertwined with energy policy and criticizing environmental regulations that she believes could hamper U.S. competitiveness against China.

quotes.quote: We need to make sure that the AI infrastructure isn't getting siphoned off to China
quotes.source: Statement supporting the Chip Security Act, July 2025
quotes.context: Supporting bipartisan legislation to prevent advanced U.S. AI chips from being smuggled into China to fuel their military and surveillance capabilities.

quotes.quote: Wyoming values both innovation and accountability; the RISE Act creates predictable standards that encourage safer AI development while preserving professional autonomy
quotes.source: Press release introducing the RISE Act, June 2025
quotes.context: Introducing her AI liability legislation that balances protecting AI developers with ensuring professional accountability.

quotes.quote: This legislation doesn't create blanket immunity for AI – in fact, it requires AI developers to publicly disclose model specifications so professionals can make informed decisions about the AI tools they choose to utilize
quotes.source: Statement on RISE Act, June 2025
quotes.context: Explaining that her legislation requires transparency from AI developers while shielding them from certain civil liabilities when professionals use their tools.

quotes.quote: AI is transforming professional industries including medicine, law, engineering, and finance, with these tools increasingly being utilized in critical decision-making processes that impact millions of Americans
quotes.source: RISE Act press release, June 2025
quotes.context: Describing the widespread adoption and impact of AI across professional sectors as justification for clear liability frameworks.

quotes.quote: China appears to be fast-tracking AI development... Only 6 months ahead of China... Need Federal only. Light touch
quotes.source: Senate AI hearing testimony, May 2025
quotes.context: During questioning at a Senate hearing, emphasizing the competitive threat from China and advocating for streamlined federal regulation rather than state-by-state approaches.

quotes.quote: We want to make sure that we're not helping create monopolistic situations in emerging industries and AI is an emerging industry
quotes.source: NBC News interview, September 2023
quotes.context: Expressing concern about ensuring smaller innovators aren't shut out by regulations that favor large tech companies like Elon Musk's and Mark Zuckerberg's firms.

Cynthia M. Lummis.notes: Senator Lummis is strongly focused on the geopolitical dimension of AI, particularly U.S.-China competition. She consistently frames AI development as an 'arms race' or 'war' with China and emphasizes energy infrastructure as critical to winning. Her legislative approach (RISE Act) focuses on practical liability issues rather than existential risks or alignment concerns. She advocates for 'light touch' federal regulation that promotes innovation over safety restrictions, and has criticized both political bias in AI systems (Google Gemini) and state-level regulatory patchworks. She shows no evidence of being 'AGI-pilled' or concerned about existential risks – her focus is entirely on maintaining American competitiveness, supporting innovation, and ensuring transparency. She has engaged with AI company leaders including OpenAI's Greg Brockman and Sam Altman. Notably, she announced in December 2025 that she will not seek reelection in 2026.

Darrell Issa.summary: Rep. Darrell Issa views AI as having 'limitless potential' for American innovation and leadership, while emphasizing the need to protect intellectual property rights, particularly for artists and creators. His focus is heavily on China as a strategic AI competitor and IP theft threat, with a pro-innovation stance that favors minimal regulation while addressing specific harms like deepfakes and digital replicas.

quotes.quote: If China wins the AI arms race, their ability to steal technology and harm not just our country but the free world will be permanent.
quotes.source: Washington Times, October 2023
quotes.context: Statement during congressional hearing on China's IP theft, cybersecurity, and AI, expressing concerns about the geopolitical stakes of AI competition with China.

quotes.quote: The limitless possibility of AI is here, and with it, the next opportunity for incomparable American leadership in technology and innovation. These are the stakes, and rather than looking to regulate right away, now is the time for the government to listen, learn, and resolve to bring out the best AI has to offer so it can change our lives for the better.
quotes.source: Statement upon selection to Congressional AI Task Force, February 2024
quotes.context: Expressing his philosophy on AI regulation - favoring a cautious, pro-innovation approach over immediate regulation.

quotes.quote: If Congress is going to develop a full understanding of A.I. and our legislative role in its current state and future development, it's imperative that we hear directly from the corporations, creators, and developers already using it and who stand to be the most impacted by its limitless potential.
quotes.source: Statement after Los Angeles roundtable, February 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing the need for Congress to understand AI from industry stakeholders before legislating.

quotes.quote: As AI continues its integration into every facet of our lives, its inherent perils and potential become more evident by the day.
quotes.source: Statement introducing PADRA legislation, December 2024
quotes.context: Acknowledging both the risks and benefits of AI while introducing legislation to protect against misuse of digital replicas.

quotes.quote: The advent of generative AI technologies has sparked a profound transformation in the creation, distribution, and consumption of creative works. We must strike a delicate balance—a balance that upholds the rights of copyright holders, while fostering an environment that encourages creativity and collaboration.
quotes.source: Opening statement for AI and IP hearing, May 2023
quotes.context: Framing his approach to AI regulation as seeking balance between protection and innovation.

quotes.quote: It will take a number of years to get our members to where more than a handful really understand where AI is going and, quite frankly, how it can hurt us.
quotes.source: Fox News Digital interview, May 2023
quotes.context: Acknowledging Congress's limited understanding of AI and the need for education, while expressing concern about potential harms.

quotes.quote: As AI technology continues to emerge, expand, and take hold, we must at the same time protect the ownership rights of artists and safeguard the creative process.
quotes.source: Statement after Nashville AI roundtable, June 2023
quotes.context: Emphasizing intellectual property protection for artists in the age of AI.

quotes.quote: AI is here to stay – and with it all the benefits and risks that are coming into view. We developed this legislation to give individuals the best opportunity to protect their image and likeness and stop its use without their permission for commercial gain.
quotes.source: Statement on PADRA legislation, August 2024
quotes.context: Accepting AI as inevitable while focusing on protecting individuals from specific harms like unauthorized digital replicas.

quotes.quote: I worry that GAI could eventually have broad implications across all areas of IP and essentially swallow creativity and innovation. Computers can generate an infinite amount of combinations of copyrighted material. They could create a body of copyright that could eclipse future innovation.
quotes.source: House IP Subcommittee AI hearing, May 2023
quotes.context: Expressing concern about generative AI's potential to overwhelm the intellectual property system and stifle human creativity.

quotes.quote: Every committee of Congress needs to be wary of how AI could be used to suppress legitimate thought, promote disinformation as well as take and create copyright.
quotes.source: Fox News interview, May 2023
quotes.context: Warning about multiple potential harms from AI including censorship, disinformation, and IP violations.

Darrell Issa.notes: Darrell Issa, as Chairman of the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet and member of the House AI Task Force, has been heavily involved in AI policy. His approach is distinctly focused on: (1) China competition - he frequently frames AI as an 'arms race' with China and emphasizes IP theft concerns; (2) Intellectual property protection - his primary legislative focus is protecting artists, creators, and individuals from unauthorized AI-generated replicas; (3) Pro-innovation stance - he consistently opposes heavy-handed regulation, favoring a 'listen and learn' approach; (4) Practical harms over existential risk - he focuses on concrete issues like deepfakes, copyright, and disinformation rather than AGI or existential threats. He has mentioned OpenAI CEO Sam Altman in context of congressional education efforts. His rhetoric emphasizes AI's 'limitless potential' while acknowledging 'inherent perils,' but he does not engage with AI safety/alignment discourse or discuss existential risk scenarios. His concerns are primarily geopolitical (China), economic (innovation/competitiveness), and legal (IP rights).

Pete Sessions.summary: Pete Sessions (R-TX-17) has limited public statements specifically about AI. His involvement centers on bipartisan transparency legislation (the REAL Act) requiring government AI content labeling, participation in congressional AI hearings, and support for Texas AI data center infrastructure development. He has not made extensive public statements about AI's transformative potential, existential risks, or AGI.

quotes.quote: I'm proud to Co-lead the REAL Act, which brings greater transparency and accountability to the federal government's use of artificial intelligence.
quotes.source: Press release, December 10, 2025
quotes.context: Sessions co-sponsored bipartisan legislation with Rep. Bill Foster requiring federal agencies to clearly label AI-generated content released to the public.

quotes.quote: This legislation protects agencies' ability to use AI internally while ensuring that anything released publicly is clearly and consistently labeled. It is a commonsense step to maintain trust and strengthen transparency in government communications.
quotes.source: Press release, December 10, 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the REAL Act's approach to balancing AI innovation with transparency requirements for government use.

quotes.quote: [Sessions said the bill] brings greater transparency and accountability to the federal government's use of artificial intelligence.
quotes.source: Fox Business, December 11, 2025
quotes.context: Brief statement about the REAL Act's purpose in requiring AI content labeling by federal agencies.

quotes.quote: [Discussion of] how his state is handling increasing demand for artificial intelligence data centers
quotes.source: Fox Business 'Making Money', December 2025
quotes.context: Sessions appeared on Fox Business to discuss Texas's response to massive AI data center demand, describing it as 'a lot of work' though full quotes from this appearance were not available.

Pete Sessions.notes: Pete Sessions has very limited public statements specifically about AI policy or philosophy. His involvement is primarily procedural: (1) Co-sponsoring the bipartisan REAL Act for AI transparency in government, (2) Serving on the House Oversight Committee during AI hearings in 2023-2025, and (3) Discussing Texas infrastructure for AI data centers. He has not made public statements about: China/AI competition, AGI/existential risk, AI safety/alignment, transformative potential, or specific AI companies. His committee membership places him in AI hearings, but he does not appear to be a vocal thought leader on AI policy. He purchased Nvidia stock (November 2024), showing personal investment interest. His priority commitment includes 'Ensure the U.S. stays competitive with a renewed commitment to Research and Development' but this is general, not AI-specific. The lack of substantive AI quotes suggests AI is not a primary policy focus for him compared to other issues.

David G. Valadao.summary: Representative Valadao has extremely limited public statements on AI policy. His only identified AI-related positions involve practical applications: supporting AI automation for VA claims processing and co-sponsoring legislation to certify AI software safety in agriculture. He has made no public statements on broader AI policy issues, national security implications, existential risks, or AI companies.

quotes.quote: To speed up disability claims, the VA has used automation tools like AI to draft letters and gather documents. But that same technology hasn't been applied to other types of claims, such as pensions or survivors' benefits.
quotes.source: House floor speech, September 2025 (Healthcare IT News)
quotes.context: Valadao introduced H.R. 3854, the Modernizing All Veterans and Survivors Claims Processing Act, to expand AI automation in VA claims processing

quotes.quote: As new technology like artificial intelligence becomes more common in our agriculture operations, we need to make sure these new tools are safe for consumers and producers alike.
quotes.source: Statement on Farm Tech Act, December 2023 (Fox News)
quotes.context: Co-sponsoring bipartisan legislation with Rep. Randy Feenstra to establish USDA certification program for agricultural AI software

quotes.quote: The VA's current claims system is inefficient, creates backlogs and burdens veterans and their families with unnecessary paperwork.
quotes.source: Statement on VA claims bill passage, September 2025
quotes.context: Explaining rationale for AI-powered automation in veterans benefits processing

David G. Valadao.notes: Representative Valadao (R-CA-22) represents California's 22nd Congressional District in the Central Valley and is a dairy farmer by profession. His AI-related legislative activity is extremely limited and focused entirely on practical, domain-specific applications rather than broader AI policy. The two areas where he has engaged with AI are: (1) veterans' benefits automation and (2) agricultural technology safety certification. He has not participated in broader congressional discussions about AI safety, national competitiveness with China, existential risks, or regulation of frontier AI models. His approach appears purely utilitarian—supporting AI where it can improve government efficiency or agricultural operations, with emphasis on safety standards and certification. There is no evidence he has engaged with the broader AI policy debate occurring in Congress, including discussions about AGI, alignment, or competition with China. His legislative focus remains on traditional Central Valley issues: agriculture, water, veterans, and immigration.

Tommy Tuberville.summary: Senator Tuberville views AI primarily through a national security and China competition lens. He emphasizes the need for American AI dominance, warns against overregulation that could harm U.S. competitiveness, and consistently raises concerns about China's AI capabilities and energy advantage. His focus is pragmatic rather than philosophical—seeing AI as a tool for military modernization and economic growth.

quotes.quote: We've got AI coming. We've got all the things that are going to go with AI. It's going to take some jobs, but it's also going to create some jobs.
quotes.source: Fox Business Network's 'Kudlow,' October 29, 2025
quotes.context: Tuberville discussing the economic impact of AI, taking a balanced view that AI will disrupt but also create employment opportunities.

quotes.quote: I hope we all understand too that for AI and all the future big tech stuff, we're gonna need energy, big time. China doubles our energy every three years that we have in this country. We're way behind.
quotes.source: Senate Armed Services Committee hearing, June 5, 2025
quotes.context: Tuberville questioning Army officials about AI implementation, emphasizing energy infrastructure as a critical national security issue for AI development.

quotes.quote: Unless we have energy, which is gonna be, should be, a national security threat, then we're gonna have huge problems.
quotes.source: Senate Armed Services Committee hearing, June 5, 2025
quotes.context: Continuing his emphasis on energy capacity as essential for AI infrastructure and data centers.

quotes.quote: Everything we read obviously is China's using AI on almost everything that they do. They can build a bridge in three months that takes us three years. I'm sure ship building is part of that.
quotes.source: Senate Armed Services Committee hearing on Naval operations, June 10, 2025
quotes.context: Expressing concern about China's use of AI for rapid infrastructure and military development, urging U.S. military to adopt AI faster.

quotes.quote: We applaud President Trump's commitment to ensuring American dominance in the tech sector. American companies dominate in crucial areas that will define tomorrow's economy including semiconductor design, compute infrastructure, and artificial intelligence (AI).
quotes.source: Letter to Commerce Secretary regarding AI Diffusion Rule, April 15, 2025
quotes.context: Co-signed letter opposing Biden administration's AI export restrictions, arguing they would harm American competitiveness while not effectively countering China.

quotes.quote: Therefore, we urge you to withdraw this rule and propose an alternative that is effective in preventing Communist China from capturing the world market in a leading technology without compromising American advantages.
quotes.source: Letter to Commerce Secretary, April 15, 2025
quotes.context: Advocating for less restrictive AI export controls that balance security concerns with maintaining U.S. technological leadership.

quotes.quote: Future conflicts will be dominated by artificial intelligence emerging technologies like quantum computing.
quotes.source: Senate Armed Services Committee hearing with Vice Chairman nominee, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the military's future technological needs with General Mahoney, viewing AI as central to future warfare.

quotes.quote: We don't have enough electricity to put all this into effect in terms of AI and building more jobs and building up our country.
quotes.source: Fox Business Network interview, October 2025
quotes.context: Linking AI development to domestic energy policy and manufacturing growth.

quotes.quote: We write to express our concern that Department of Defense (DOD) employees accessed the Chinese artificial intelligence application DeepSeek on their work devices and, as a result, Chinese servers.
quotes.source: Letter to Pentagon about DeepSeek, February 19, 2025
quotes.context: Co-signed bipartisan letter raising cybersecurity concerns about DOD personnel using Chinese AI applications, viewing Chinese AI as a national security threat.

quotes.quote: They'll go after whatever they can to get their hands on: wind turbines, airplane designs, underwater drones, chemicals, or artificial intelligence technology.
quotes.source: Senate floor speech on China, May 17, 2021
quotes.context: Discussing China's strategy of stealing American intellectual property, including AI technology, as part of broader economic espionage concerns.

Tommy Tuberville.notes: Tuberville's AI views are heavily focused on three main themes: (1) U.S.-China competition and maintaining American technological dominance, (2) energy infrastructure as a prerequisite for AI development, and (3) military/defense applications of AI. He does not appear to engage with philosophical questions about AGI, existential risk, or AI safety/alignment in the technical sense. His stance is pragmatic and nationalist—he supports AI development to maintain U.S. competitiveness and opposes regulations he views as hampering American companies. He consistently frames AI through a national security lens, particularly regarding China's capabilities. He has co-sponsored some bipartisan AI oversight legislation but his public statements focus almost entirely on military applications and China competition rather than broader societal impacts. He appears to view AI as transformative for jobs and the economy (acknowledging disruption but emphasizing job creation), and as essential for future military capabilities. No evidence found of him discussing AI alignment, safety research, or existential risk scenarios.

John W. Hickenlooper.summary: Senator Hickenlooper views AI as a transformative technology with enormous potential that requires sensible guardrails and regulation. He emphasizes the need for transparency, third-party auditing, and protecting consumers while maintaining U.S. competitive advantage. He frequently references China as a competitor in AI development and focuses on practical regulation rather than speculative existential risks.

quotes.quote: AI is a revolutionary technology that has the potential to improve health care, agriculture, logistics and supply chains, and countless other industries.
quotes.source: Press release on AI Research, Innovation, and Accountability Act
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan AI legislation to establish framework for AI development

quotes.quote: We're entering a new era of Artificial Intelligence. Development and innovation will depend on the guardrails we put in place. This is a commonsense framework that protects Americans without stifling our competitive edge in AI.
quotes.source: Press release on AI Research, Innovation, and Accountability Act
quotes.context: Explaining his approach to AI regulation that balances innovation with safety

quotes.quote: We can't let an industry with so many unknowns and potential harms police itself. We need qualified third parties to effectively audit generative AI systems and verify their claims of compliance with federal laws and regulations.
quotes.source: Silicon Flatirons Flagship Conference keynote speech, February 5, 2024
quotes.context: Proposing framework for AI regulation including third-party auditing standards

quotes.quote: It's obvious that AI is a powerful technology that will revolutionize our economy. Just like the first car or personal computer, AI is a transformative technology that has both benefits and risks for consumers.
quotes.source: Senate Commerce Committee hearing on AI transparency, September 2023
quotes.context: Chairing hearing on increasing transparency in AI technologies for consumers

quotes.quote: AI is moving faster than any of us thought it would two years ago. But we have to move just as fast to get sensible guardrails in place to develop AI responsibly before it's too late.
quotes.source: Press release on VET AI Act introduction
quotes.context: Introducing legislation for third-party audits of AI systems

quotes.quote: What begins today as Generative AI may one day become Artificial General Intelligence.
quotes.source: Silicon Flatirons speech, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the long-term trajectory of AI development and need for early guardrails

quotes.quote: AI has enormous potential to boost American innovation. But without sensible guardrails or standards, it's the Wild West out there.
quotes.source: Senate Commerce Committee passage of AI bills, July 2024
quotes.context: Celebrating bipartisan passage of AI legislation including his VET AI Act

quotes.quote: Generative AI will forever transform our economy and our daily lives. The World Economic Forum went into some detail and made assessments that AI could add trillions of dollars to the global economy in the near future.
quotes.source: Silicon Flatirons speech, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the economic impact and transformative potential of AI

quotes.quote: While China is striving to win the AI battle, America must lead the way on the development and deployment of AI to ensure it is implemented responsibly across the globe.
quotes.source: TechNet response to Hickenlooper-Blackburn letter on AI
quotes.context: Industry response to his work with Senator Blackburn on AI safeguards

quotes.quote: A number of countries, principally China, are moving very, very quickly to catch up, and they're making heavy investments. They have their own significant industrial strategies around this, around AI, around other technologies.
quotes.source: CSIS event on U.S. Leadership in AI, November 2024
quotes.context: Discussing global competition in AI and how U.S. should think about partnerships and competition

John W. Hickenlooper.notes: Hickenlooper takes a pragmatic, regulatory-focused approach to AI. He chairs the Senate Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Consumer Protection, Product Safety and Data Security, making AI oversight a key priority. He has introduced multiple bipartisan AI bills including the VET AI Act (third-party auditing), AI Research, Innovation, and Accountability Act (ARIA), and Future of AI Innovation Act. He frequently emphasizes: (1) the need for transparency and third-party auditing similar to financial audits; (2) protecting consumer data and privacy; (3) building international coalitions; (4) maintaining U.S. competitive advantage against China; (5) protecting consumers from deepfakes and AI-enabled fraud. He mentions AGI only once in passing ('What begins today as Generative AI may one day become Artificial General Intelligence') but does not focus on speculative existential risks. Instead, he focuses on immediate harms like deepfakes, fraud, cybersecurity threats, and the need for workforce training. He has sent letters to Meta and X about AI-generated explicit content, worked with the Department of Labor on AI workforce preparation, and met with the FTC chair about AI guardrails. His approach is collaborative and bipartisan, working with senators from both parties. He compares AI regulation to past technologies (cars, personal computers) and emphasizes it will 'revolutionize our economy' while requiring 'reasonable rules of the road.'

Bill Hagerty.summary: Senator Bill Hagerty views AI primarily through a national security and economic competitiveness lens, with a strong focus on China as a strategic competitor. He consistently opposes heavy-handed regulation of AI, advocating instead for a 'light touch' approach to maintain American innovation and technological dominance. His AI stance is centered on protecting U.S. technology from Chinese military applications while avoiding domestic overregulation.

quotes.quote: That's why I think Xi Jinping came to San Francisco for the APEC Conference: wanting to negotiate with Joe Biden to slow down our progress in AI, to slow down our deployment of AI in military applications.
quotes.source: Fox Business Kudlow interview, November 21, 2023
quotes.context: Hagerty discussing the need to maintain competitive advantage in AI against China, linking Chinese diplomatic efforts to attempts to slow U.S. AI military development.

quotes.quote: Despite the pressing need to restrict the PLA's advancement in key technology areas, our government has done little to impede the flow of U.S. exports and investment to Chinese AI companies with PLA ties.
quotes.source: Letter to Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo, November 16, 2021
quotes.context: Co-signed letter with Republican senators urging blacklisting of Chinese AI companies helping arm the People's Liberation Army.

quotes.quote: Technological dominance is a key pillar of national security, and this partnership will ensure that the Department of Defense can utilize this developing technology in a secure, robust, continuous and dependable fashion.
quotes.source: Statement on Vanderbilt-Oak Ridge AI partnership, May 30, 2024
quotes.context: Supporting AI development for military applications and national security purposes.

quotes.quote: My point is that Congress and the Biden Administration should not engage in heavy-handed regulation with uncertain impacts that I believe pose a great risk to limiting political speech.
quotes.source: Senate Rules Committee hearing, September 28, 2023
quotes.context: Warning against premature AI regulation that could violate First Amendment rights and limit political speech.

quotes.quote: Rather than stifle it, let's understand it, and let's try to use a light touch as we move forward, rather than come in and try to have all encompassing regulation that at this point in time, I think, far overshoots the mark.
quotes.source: CNBC Squawk Box interview, February 6, 2024
quotes.context: Opposing SEC's proposed AI regulation for financial markets, advocating for minimal regulatory intervention.

quotes.quote: I want to see this innovation happen here in America.
quotes.source: CNBC Squawk Box interview, February 6, 2024
quotes.context: Expressing concern that overregulation could put the United States behind other nations in AI development.

quotes.quote: American consumers will ultimately bear the cost of yet another SEC attempt to overregulate financial markets. The agency should demonstrate the ability to securely manage its own technology before seeking to micromanage and hinder innovative technologies at private firms.
quotes.source: Statement on Protecting Innovation in Investment Act, February 6, 2024
quotes.context: Co-introducing bill with Ted Cruz to block SEC AI regulation, criticizing regulatory overreach.

quotes.quote: Given these troubling gaps in the United States' strategy to protect its core technologies, we urge BIS to emulate the Intelligence Community by identifying key American technologies that need to be safeguarded from the Chinese Communist Party.
quotes.source: Letter to Commerce Secretary, November 16, 2021
quotes.context: Urging stronger export controls on AI technology to prevent transfer to Chinese military.

quotes.quote: While AI has rapidly ascended to become one America's most important policy priorities, Michael had the foresight to see this technology's potential nearly a decade ago.
quotes.source: Introduction of Michael Kratsios for OSTP Director, February 25, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing Trump's nominee for science and technology policy, emphasizing AI as a critical policy priority and praising expertise in AI strategy.

quotes.quote: Is there a risk then, in your view, that hastily regulating in a very uncertain and rapidly growing concept like AI might actually chill political speech?
quotes.source: Senate Rules Committee hearing, September 28, 2023
quotes.context: Questioning witness about risks of premature AI regulation on free speech rights.

Bill Hagerty.notes: Senator Hagerty's AI views are heavily focused on geopolitical competition with China rather than existential risk or AGI concerns. He consistently frames AI as critical for national security and military dominance, specifically citing China's People's Liberation Army as a key threat. His regulatory philosophy strongly favors minimal government intervention in domestic AI development while advocating for strict export controls to prevent technology transfer to adversaries. He has mentioned OpenAI and Sam Altman in the context of discussing the competitive landscape. While he supports AI safety in the military context (ensuring DoD can use AI reliably), he does not engage with broader AI safety/alignment concerns or existential risk discussions that dominate some AI policy debates. His stance on AI copyright issues (protecting Nashville musicians) shows some willingness to consider regulation in specific contexts. Overall, his approach is pragmatic and competition-focused rather than philosophically concerned with transformative AI scenarios.

Barry Moore.summary: Rep. Barry Moore (R-AL) has made very limited public statements about AI. His primary AI-related legislative action is co-sponsoring the FAIR Act to prevent bias in federal AI procurement. His only other documented AI comment focuses on protecting children from online predators, not broader AI policy concerns.

quotes.quote: The American people don't want AI that pushes propaganda, they want tools they can trust
quotes.source: Press release for FAIR Act, September 2025
quotes.context: Moore co-sponsored the FAIR Act (H.R. 5315) with Rep. Harriet Hageman to ensure federal AI procurement is truthful and neutral

quotes.quote: We have to look at some regulations to protect young kids online and I don't know exactly what that looks like. There's something we have to do from a federal level to prevent young kids from being targeted by predators online in blue states.
quotes.source: Interview with Washington Reporter, December 2025
quotes.context: When asked about federal AI regulation and state preemption, Moore focused on child safety rather than broader AI policy

Barry Moore.notes: Rep. Barry Moore has an extremely limited public record on AI policy. Only two quotes could be found from extensive research. He co-sponsored the FAIR Act focused on preventing bias and propaganda in federal AI systems, and made one brief comment about protecting children online when asked about AI regulation. He does not appear to have made statements about: China/foreign competition in AI, AGI or transformative AI, existential risks, AI safety/alignment, or specific AI companies like OpenAI or Anthropic. His focus appears to be on traditional conservative priorities (immigration, Second Amendment, abortion, veterans) rather than emerging technology policy. This lack of public statements suggests AI is not a priority issue for him, or he has not been asked about it extensively. The research included searches of his congressional website, press releases, interviews, social media, and legislation, but yielded minimal AI-related content.

Jay Obernolte.summary: Jay Obernolte is a pro-innovation Republican congressman with a graduate degree in AI who chairs the House AI Task Force. He views AI as highly transformative—potentially bigger than the internet—and emphasizes U.S. leadership against China while advocating for balanced, incremental regulation focused on mitigating harms rather than hypothetical existential risks.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is one of the most transformative technologies of our time, but currently the tools needed to develop it are out of reach for most Americans.
quotes.source: CREATE AI Act press release, April 3, 2025
quotes.context: Obernolte introducing legislation to democratize AI research access and maintain U.S. competitiveness

quotes.quote: I think we're at the same place as we were at the birth of the internet, where no one really could really conceptualize all the changes that were going to occur as a result of the internet... I think that's going to prove true of AI as well.
quotes.source: Orange County Register interview, April 7, 2024
quotes.context: Comparing AI's potential impact to the internet revolution

quotes.quote: Maintaining American leadership in AI development and deployment is not only an economic imperative but also a national security requirement.
quotes.source: Opening statement on DeepSeek hearing, April 8, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the strategic importance of U.S. AI leadership

quotes.quote: We cannot allow DeepSeek and other CCP-controlled entities to access this information. This risk will only grow as we enter the era of agentic AI, where AI systems will actively book our travel, manage our finances, analyze our health records and handle other sensitive personal affairs on our behalf.
quotes.source: Congressional hearing on DeepSeek, January 2026
quotes.context: Warning about Chinese AI access to American data and the national security implications

quotes.quote: We must ensure that Chinese AI, which operates under these flawed standards, does not come to dominate the global market. The United States must take the lead in developing the most advanced AI systems while also fostering a light-touch governance model that safeguards against malicious use while simultaneously encouraging innovation.
quotes.source: Opening statement on DeepSeek, April 8, 2025
quotes.context: Contrasting U.S. and Chinese approaches to AI governance

quotes.quote: The biggest risk posed by artificial intelligence is not 'an army of evil robots with red laser eyes rising to take over the world.' It's the 'less obvious' and more mundane issues such as data privacy, antitrust issues and AI's potential to influence human behavior.
quotes.source: Washington Post interview, May 17, 2023
quotes.context: Dismissing sci-fi existential risk scenarios in favor of practical concerns

quotes.quote: But there are other deeper existential risks that we need to pay attention to. Risks like massive job losses in industries made obsolete by AI, programs that retrieve biased or inaccurate results, or deepfake images, video and audio.
quotes.source: Associated Press article, April 11, 2024
quotes.context: Defining what he considers real existential risks from AI

quotes.quote: We think it is foolish to believe that we know enough about AI and the direction AI is going to move in the next few years to be able to do an effective job completely regulating with one bill next year.
quotes.source: Capitol Hill Cloud Day remarks, December 4, 2024
quotes.context: Advocating for incremental, bite-sized regulatory approach rather than comprehensive legislation

quotes.quote: It is our hope that this report will inform the Congress and the American people on the advantages, complexities, and risks of artificial intelligence. We have made our best efforts based on the information we have, but with the rapid pace of change in both AI software and hardware, we are fully aware that we don't know what we don't know.
quotes.source: AI Task Force Report release, December 18, 2024
quotes.context: Acknowledging uncertainty about AI's trajectory while presenting bipartisan recommendations

quotes.quote: China and the European Union have already launched efforts similar to NAIRR to catch up with the United States. Absent a government-led program like NAIRR, the U.S. risks falling behind in the AI competition.
quotes.source: CREATE AI Act press release, April 3, 2025
quotes.context: Framing international AI competition as urgent and requiring government intervention

Jay Obernolte.notes: Obernolte is uniquely positioned as the only member of Congress with a graduate degree in AI (from UCLA). He frequently references China and the CCP as strategic competitors in AI development, particularly regarding DeepSeek. While he acknowledges 'existential risks,' he defines these pragmatically (job displacement, deepfakes, bias) rather than sci-fi scenarios of AI ending humanity. He explicitly rejects 'Terminator' scenarios. He's not 'AGI-pilled' in the sense of being focused on superintelligence risks, though he does discuss the era of 'agentic AI.' He advocates for light-touch, sectoral regulation rather than comprehensive frameworks like the EU AI Act. He has received political donations from Sam Altman (OpenAI CEO) and works closely with AI companies including OpenAI, Scale AI, and IBM through the task force process. His approach is decidedly pro-innovation while emphasizing the need for guardrails, particularly around national security and competition with China.

Young Kim.summary: Rep. Young Kim views AI primarily through a national security and economic competition lens, with heavy emphasis on maintaining U.S. leadership against China. She advocates for a balanced approach that promotes innovation while addressing risks, particularly focused on workforce enhancement rather than replacement. Her statements are pragmatic and geopolitically focused rather than focused on transformative or existential aspects of AI.

quotes.quote: It's been reported that China is already the world's second-leading country in AI research and technology, and they are on track to be the AI world leader by 2030. This is all the more reason why we need to remain the leader in developing these emerging technologies in the right way.
quotes.source: Statement on joining House Financial Services AI Working Group, January 2024
quotes.context: Kim emphasized the competitive threat from China when discussing her appointment to the bipartisan AI Working Group, framing AI development as a race for global leadership.

quotes.quote: We know they're spying and controlling its own population, and we know their intent is different than ours. That's why we need to be a leader in this emerging technologies development areas in the right way and preserve the American values.
quotes.source: Spectrum News interview, January 2024
quotes.context: Kim contrasted China's authoritarian use of AI with American values, emphasizing the importance of developing AI according to democratic principles.

quotes.quote: AI has tremendous potential to transform our lives for the better, but we also need to address the potential risks associated with it.
quotes.source: Statement on AI Working Group appointment, January 2024
quotes.context: Kim expressed a balanced view acknowledging both opportunities and risks when discussing the Financial Services Committee's AI Working Group objectives.

quotes.quote: Developments in artificial intelligence have already proven to present both opportunities and risks. I look forward to productive discussions on this bipartisan AI Working Group that will lead to substantive policies that promote innovation, protect consumers, facilitate access to capital for all communities, and ensure American values – not the Chinese Communist Party's – lead the way in emerging technologies.
quotes.source: Official statement, January 12, 2024
quotes.context: Kim's formal statement upon joining the AI Working Group, highlighting her priorities of innovation, consumer protection, and values-based AI development in competition with China.

quotes.quote: I know people are looking at AI, a lot of them are already applying it. There are concerns that maybe AI is going to replace and take over all of the workforce that we have. It's a legitimate concern. But I would like to say that rather than the workforce being replaced by AI, I want to see the workforce improved by AI.
quotes.source: Spectrum News interview, January 2024
quotes.context: Kim addressed concerns about AI's impact on jobs, advocating for AI as a tool to enhance rather than replace workers, particularly in financial services and housing industries.

quotes.quote: Without tackling this issue head-on, Kim — who chairs the Subcommittee on Indo-Pacific — says she is concerned it could put the U.S. at risk on the global stage.
quotes.source: News coverage of AI Working Group appointment, January 2024
quotes.context: Kim connected AI development to national security concerns, viewing it through her role as chair of the Indo-Pacific Subcommittee.

quotes.quote: The PAID Act would require the Secretary of Commerce to identify and report on foreign adversary entities, including those affiliated with the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), Russia, North Korea, and Iran, using American IP related to a critical or emerging technology area, including hypersonic systems, artificial intelligence, and space technology, without a license.
quotes.source: Statement on Protecting American Innovation and Development Act, July 2024
quotes.context: Kim led legislation to protect U.S. intellectual property in AI and other emerging technologies from theft by foreign adversaries, particularly China.

quotes.quote: We must ensure our policies work to support U.S. innovation and counter the Chinese Communist Party's coercive economic tactics. The Strengthening Exports Against China Act bolsters American leadership in emerging technologies and increases our competitiveness against the CCP.
quotes.source: Statement on Strengthening Exports Against China Act, February 2025
quotes.context: Kim emphasized supporting U.S. competitiveness in emerging technologies including AI through export policy to counter China's economic influence.

quotes.quote: This is all the more reason why we need to remain the leader in developing these emerging technologies in the right way and preserve the American values.
quotes.source: Spectrum News interview, January 2024
quotes.context: Kim reiterated the importance of values-driven AI development as a counterpoint to authoritarian approaches.

quotes.quote: And that's what this working group is going to review, we're going to look at, especially in the financial services and housing industries, we're going to look at how AI impacts that.
quotes.source: Spectrum News interview, January 2024
quotes.context: Kim outlined the practical focus of the AI Working Group on specific industry sectors rather than broader philosophical or existential questions about AI.

Young Kim.notes: Rep. Young Kim's AI statements are heavily dominated by geopolitical concerns, particularly competition with China. She repeatedly emphasizes that China is on track to become the 'AI world leader by 2030' and frames AI development as a national security imperative. Her approach is pragmatic and industry-focused (financial services, housing), with emphasis on balancing innovation with consumer protection. She does not discuss AGI, existential risks, alignment problems, or specific AI companies/researchers. Her statements suggest she views AI as transformative for the economy and national power, but not in the radical/singularity sense. She serves on the House Financial Services Committee's AI Working Group and chairs the Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Indo-Pacific, which shapes her China-centric perspective. Kim also led legislation (PAID Act) to protect U.S. intellectual property in AI from foreign adversaries. Her stance is pro-innovation but with an emphasis on American values and democratic principles versus authoritarian uses of AI.

Sara Jacobs.summary: Rep. Sara Jacobs is a pragmatic, safety-focused AI advocate who views AI as transformative technology with both significant opportunities and risks. She emphasizes the need for balanced governance that encourages innovation while establishing guardrails to protect against bias, discrimination, and dangerous applications. Her approach is notably focused on practical near-term harms rather than speculative existential risks, with particular attention to global equity, civil rights, and military AI safety.

quotes.quote: As one of the youngest Members of Congress, I'm painfully aware of how outdated our laws are and how we've largely failed to keep up with technology.
quotes.source: Press release upon joining Bipartisan Task Force on AI, 2024
quotes.context: Explaining her motivation for joining the AI Task Force and her focus on technology policy as a young legislator

quotes.quote: Technologies like AI have so much potential – to solve big challenges like poverty and health care access – but there are also big risks. And it's up to us, in Congress, to make sure we set the rules of the road that help encourage the former and protect against the latter.
quotes.source: Press conference on AI Task Force Report, 2024
quotes.context: Articulating her balanced view of AI's transformative potential and need for governance

quotes.quote: We've seen that AI consistently makes more aggressive and escalatory decisions than humans in war game simulations, including launching nuclear weapons.
quotes.source: Statement on nuclear weapons AI provision in NDAA, 2024
quotes.context: Justifying her amendment to prevent AI from autonomously launching nuclear weapons, demonstrating concern about specific AI safety risks

quotes.quote: If we get the governance right on the little things, then it will also protect against that big risk. And I think that there's so much focus on that big risk, that we're actually...
quotes.source: TIME Magazine interview, February 2024
quotes.context: Suggesting focus should be on addressing immediate, practical AI harms rather than speculative existential risks

quotes.quote: The United States can't fully deliver on its national security mission, lead in responsible AI, and compete in the AI race if our federal agencies don't have the talent to meet this moment.
quotes.source: Statement on AI Talent Act introduction, December 2025
quotes.context: Discussing U.S. competitiveness in AI and the need for government capacity building, referencing the 'AI race'

quotes.quote: Donald Trump's White House is always pay-to-play, so I'm not surprised in the slightest that after Big Tech donated to his ballroom project and lavished him with praise for months, he's now eliminating the rules trying to keep them in line.
quotes.source: Statement on Trump executive order blocking state AI laws, January 2025
quotes.context: Criticizing Big Tech's influence on AI policy and defending state-level AI regulations

quotes.quote: I know the importance of distributing the benefits of AI equitably on a global scale and ensuring that no community is overlooked, forgotten, or exploited by this technology. To do that, we need to include civil society organizations and governments from the Global South in a global AI governance system.
quotes.source: Press conference on AI Task Force Report, 2024
quotes.context: Emphasizing global equity in AI governance and inclusion of Global South perspectives

quotes.quote: With thoughtful and deliberate rules, AI can help strengthen democracy and uphold human and civil rights around the world – instead of being a tool for further democratic backsliding.
quotes.source: Statement on joining AI Task Force, 2024
quotes.context: Expressing concern about AI's potential to undermine democracy without proper governance

quotes.quote: Congress has abdicated its responsibility to establish federal guardrails on AI to protect rights and safety while encouraging innovation. That's why I, and millions of young Americans, are grateful that states like California have stepped up to address priorities like deepfakes, election disinformation, AI-generated child porn, unsafe chatbots, and more.
quotes.source: Statement on Trump executive order, January 2025
quotes.context: Listing specific near-term AI harms that require immediate regulatory attention

quotes.quote: AI and autonomous systems also have major implications for the future of the battlefield – some of which can help save our service members' time and lives and others which can be incredibly dangerous.
quotes.source: Statement on AI Task Force Report, 2024
quotes.context: Acknowledging both benefits and risks of military AI applications

Sara Jacobs.notes: Rep. Sara Jacobs demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of AI policy focused on practical governance rather than speculative scenarios. While she explicitly references 'competing in the AI race' and U.S. competitiveness, she does not specifically mention China by name in available quotes, though the competitive framing implies international rivalry. Her TIME interview quote suggests she deliberately de-emphasizes existential risk concerns in favor of addressing 'the little things' - immediate harms like bias, discrimination, deepfakes, and unsafe chatbots. She is particularly focused on: (1) Military AI safety, especially preventing autonomous nuclear weapons; (2) Global equity and inclusion of Global South voices in AI governance; (3) Civil rights, bias, and discrimination issues; (4) Big Tech accountability and influence; (5) Building government capacity to regulate AI effectively. She passed legislation preventing AI from autonomously launching nuclear weapons and introduced the AI Talent Act. She serves as Vice Chair of the New Democrat Coalition's AI Working Group and was a member of the Bipartisan Task Force on AI. Her approach is notably pragmatic, bipartisan, and focused on establishing 'rules of the road' rather than either promoting unchecked innovation or calling for AI development pauses.

Lauren Boebert.summary: Lauren Boebert has made minimal public statements specifically about AI policy. Her primary AI-related comment found in congressional records focused on energy policy as it relates to AI infrastructure, emphasizing that Biden Administration energy policies hindered AI development in the United States. She serves on the House Oversight Committee which has held multiple AI hearings, but direct quotes from her on AI topics are extremely limited.

quotes.quote: the Biden Administration's anti-American energy policies hindered the development and rise of AI in the United States
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing 'America's AI Moonshot: The Economics of AI, Data Centers, and Power Consumption,' April 2025
quotes.context: Boebert's statement during a hearing on AI infrastructure and energy needs, linking AI development to energy policy rather than discussing AI technology itself

quotes.quote: It is reported that data centers will need an entire state's worth of power production to run AI. This is so crucial with AI's rise, I think it's imperative that we have that reliable source of energy and stop demonizing fossil fuels
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing, April 2025
quotes.context: Question to witness Mark Mills about energy policy and AI infrastructure needs

quotes.quote: Do you believe that the energy policies that we've seen in recent years have actually kind of slowed down the progress in AI's development?
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing, April 2025
quotes.context: Question posed to witness regarding the relationship between energy policy and AI development

Lauren Boebert.notes: Despite serving on the House Oversight and Accountability Committee's Subcommittee on Cybersecurity, Information Technology, and Government Innovation, which held multiple AI hearings in 2023-2025 including 'Advances in AI: Are We Ready for a Tech Revolution?' (March 2023), 'How Are Federal Agencies Harnessing Artificial Intelligence?' (September 2023), 'White House Overreach on AI' (March 2024), and 'Addressing Real Harm Done by Deepfakes' (March 2024), Lauren Boebert has not made substantial public statements about AI policy, technology, or governance. Her committee membership suggests exposure to AI policy discussions, but she has not emerged as a vocal participant in AI debates. The only documented statements relate AI to energy policy rather than addressing AI technology, safety, regulation, or geopolitical competition. This represents an insufficient record to characterize her views on AI comprehensively. It is possible she has made statements in venues not captured by congressional records or major news sources, but based on available public information, she has not established a clear public position on artificial intelligence policy.
