Kat Cammack.summary: <cite index="4-3,21-3">Kat Cammack views AI as transformative technology that will be a very big part of every aspect of our lives for the foreseeable future</cite>. <cite index="4-1,21-1">She opposes overregulation because she fears it will stamp out innovation</cite>, while emphasizing the need for <cite index="4-5,21-5">"digital liberty versus digital authoritarianism"</cite> in AI development. <cite index="2-4,31-4">She advocates for "healthy and smart adoption" of AI to position the U.S. to lead globally</cite>.

quotes.quote: AI is not going anywhere; it's going to be a very big part of every aspect of our lives for the foreseeable future. So we have to make sure that we're doing everything right on the front end.
quotes.source: FedScoop, March 4, 2024
quotes.context: <cite index="4-3,4-4">Cammack discussing the inevitability and importance of AI in future society during an interview about her role on the House AI task force</cite>

quotes.quote: I don't want us to overregulate because I'm fearful that that will stamp out innovation. I'm fearful that if you don't address the philosophical issue in these language models, that we're gonna see real implications immediately and long term.
quotes.source: FedScoop, March 4, 2024
quotes.context: <cite index="4-1,4-2">Cammack expressing concerns about both overregulation and the need to address bias in AI language models</cite>

quotes.quote: Language models need to be a position of digital liberty versus digital authoritarianism.
quotes.source: FedScoop, March 4, 2024
quotes.context: <cite index="4-5">Cammack's core philosophy on how AI systems should be developed, emphasizing freedom over authoritarian control</cite>

quotes.quote: Healthy and smart adoption of AI will position the U.S. to lead globally, foster competitiveness, and deliver tangible benefits to communities nationwide.
quotes.source: American Bazaar Online, August 13, 2025
quotes.context: <cite index="2-4">Cammack's vision for U.S. AI leadership through balanced adoption on the Regulating AI podcast</cite>

quotes.quote: I think Gemini rolling out was one of the most disastrous rollouts we've seen… you have extreme bias on both sides and you have to… find that sweet spot. There are real-world consequences… where there are consequences for models that have deliberate bias or a predetermined outcome.
quotes.source: American Bazaar Online, August 13, 2025
quotes.context: <cite index="2-11,14-2">Cammack criticizing Google's Gemini AI rollout for bias issues and emphasizing the importance of ethics in AI development</cite>

quotes.quote: With the rescission of the Biden executive order, President Trump said, 'we're going to lead in this space…,' we've seen over five trillion dollars of private investment being announced.
quotes.source: American Bazaar Online, August 13, 2025
quotes.context: <cite index="2-14,22-25">Cammack praising the Trump administration's approach to AI investment and contrasting it with the Biden administration's regulatory approach</cite>

quotes.quote: If you don't… have a basic understanding of the technology, you have really no business trying to regulate it.
quotes.source: American Bazaar Online, August 13, 2025
quotes.context: <cite index="2-16,31-21">Cammack explaining her priority as chair of the Emerging Technologies Task Force to educate lawmakers on AI and other emerging technologies</cite>

quotes.quote: The 2024 cycle is going to be America's first real up-close encounter with AI in a bad way.
quotes.source: FedScoop, March 4, 2024
quotes.context: <cite index="4-6,21-6">Cammack warning about AI's potential negative impact on elections through deepfakes and disinformation</cite>

quotes.quote: We can't keep up with how fast the AI industry and the technology is evolving, so it's better for us to be on the side of … [letting] industry do what they do best, and that's innovate.
quotes.source: FedScoop, January 21, 2025
quotes.context: <cite index="28-6,48-1">Cammack advocating for an industry-driven approach to AI development over heavy-handed government regulation</cite>

quotes.quote: Without foresight, AI could easily slip into a 'Wild West' scenario, with doomsdayers… [wanting] to shut everything down, which is terrible for innovation.
quotes.source: American Bazaar Online, August 13, 2025
quotes.context: <cite index="2-11">Cammack warning against both unregulated AI development and excessive doomsday thinking that could stifle innovation</cite>

Kat Cammack.notes: <cite index="1-4,8-4">Rep. Kat Cammack (R-FL) serves on the House Bipartisan Task Force on Artificial Intelligence</cite> and <cite index="3-1,5-1">chairs the Republican Study Committee's Emerging Technologies Task Force</cite>. Her AI stance is characterized by strong support for innovation with minimal regulation, while emphasizing the need to address bias in AI systems. <cite index="11-1,17-1">She has questioned TikTok CEO about an internal memo asking employees to downplay China association and AI</cite>, showing concern about Chinese influence in technology. <cite index="22-23">She praised Nvidia's rapid innovation in chip manufacturing</cite> and <cite index="6-23,43-14">has advocated for blockchain authentication for AI-generated content</cite>. <cite index="28-5,48-7">Cammack called the Biden administration's approach to AI "more heavy-handed than I would have liked to have seen"</cite> and prefers an industry-driven approach. She does not discuss AGI or existential risk from AI, instead focusing on practical concerns like election integrity, bias in language models, and maintaining U.S. competitiveness. <cite index="42-14">She has criticized AI systems that "will write a poem about Nancy Pelosi but not Donald Trump"</cite>, viewing political bias in AI as a key concern.

Scott Franklin.summary: Rep. Scott Franklin (R-FL) views AI primarily through a competitive lens focused on U.S.-China rivalry and economic applications, particularly in agriculture. He emphasizes American leadership in AI standards-setting to counter Chinese influence, while advocating for practical AI applications in weather forecasting, agriculture automation, and labor solutions. He takes a cautious but innovation-friendly approach to regulation, seeking a 'Goldilocks spot' that avoids stifling innovation.

quotes.quote: Advances in Artificial Intelligence will play an increasingly defining role in U.S. global competitiveness.
quotes.source: Press release, August 9, 2021
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to support American businesses in creating global AI standards

quotes.quote: From a national security standpoint, the Chinese Communist Party has openly stated its desire for China to dominate the AI field by 2030. The U.S. must take a leadership role in ensuring China does not set the standards on AI.
quotes.source: Press release, August 9, 2021
quotes.context: Explaining the national security rationale for his AI standards legislation

quotes.quote: AI is a powerful tool with the potential to progress humankind's technological journey or suppress billions under the thumb of the CCP. Whoever sets this technology's standards will determine the course it takes in the future.
quotes.source: The Hill op-ed, September 29, 2021
quotes.context: Co-authored opinion piece with Rep. Jay Obernolte on AI standards

quotes.quote: In the AI arena, the world requires Congress to step up and lead.
quotes.source: Statement, February 20, 2024
quotes.context: Upon being named to House Speaker Johnson's bipartisan AI Task Force

quotes.quote: If AI can help us do better weather prediction, that's going to have massive implications for agriculture.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 25, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing AI applications for his agricultural district in Florida

quotes.quote: We want to be careful not to squelch innovation and be … overly burdensome with regulation. So where's that fine, Goldilocks spot on this.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 25, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing his approach to AI regulation and governance

quotes.quote: AI is going to enable our adversaries to be much more pervasive in their efforts to try to hack into our systems.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 25, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing cybersecurity concerns related to AI

quotes.quote: Defense-wise, a question I get a lot is, 'do we envision a future where we're going to have these autonomous machines where a human's not in the loop making decisions?' I don't see us getting to that level of AI, at least in a generation.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 25, 2024
quotes.context: Addressing concerns about autonomous weapons systems

quotes.quote: AI is going to be able to help fix [labor shortages] and we can retrain. There'll be other big initiatives that are going to be necessary to retrain folks and changes in the workforce to re-deploy people into different areas.
quotes.source: FedScoop interview, March 25, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing AI's impact on labor and workforce displacement

quotes.quote: I applaud President Trump and his administration for rescinding this rule to protect our national security interests and preserve America's leadership in AI and advanced technology.
quotes.source: Statement, August 11, 2025
quotes.context: Supporting rescission of Biden administration's AI export controls

Scott Franklin.notes: Scott Franklin is a Republican congressman from Florida's 18th District who serves on the House AI Task Force. His AI focus is heavily oriented toward: (1) U.S.-China competition, frequently citing China's 2030 AI dominance goals; (2) practical agricultural applications including weather forecasting, crop automation, and pest management; (3) establishing American leadership in global AI standards. He does NOT discuss AGI, existential risk, or AI safety/alignment in the technical sense. His mentions of AI companies are limited to brief references to ChatGPT experimentation. He advocates for incremental, sector-specific regulation rather than comprehensive frameworks. His military background (26 years as Naval aviator) influences his national security perspective. He secured $4.5 million for an AI center at University of Florida focused on agricultural applications. Overall, his approach is pragmatic, business-friendly, and focused on maintaining U.S. competitive advantage rather than philosophical or safety-oriented concerns about advanced AI.

Byron Donalds.summary: Byron Donalds has made very limited public statements specifically about AI. He serves on the House Financial Services Subcommittee on Digital Assets, Financial Technology, and Artificial Intelligence, and has participated in oversight hearings on AI. His few public comments suggest support for American AI dominance and opposition to heavy-handed regulation, aligning with the Trump administration's approach.

quotes.quote: I am not supportive of a blanket moratorium from the federal level in the U.S. I think there are privacy and safety concerns that should be addressed, and I think that states are uniquely positioned to do that
quotes.source: NOTUS interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Donalds expressed opposition to Trump's executive order preventing state-level AI regulation, arguing states should have a role in addressing AI privacy and safety concerns

quotes.quote: In an effort to maintain American AI dominance and innovation, the First Lady's challenge aims to empower educators and the next generation of students
quotes.source: Press release announcing Presidential AI Challenge, August 2025
quotes.context: Donalds announced support for a national K-12 AI education challenge, emphasizing American AI dominance

Byron Donalds.notes: CRITICAL LIMITATION: Byron Donalds has made extremely few public statements specifically about AI despite serving on the House Financial Services Subcommittee on Digital Assets, Financial Technology, and Artificial Intelligence. The research found only 2 usable quotes directly from him about AI. Most search results showed: 1) He was mentioned in context of China using AI to profile Congress members (he was targeted, not making statements); 2) He serves on relevant committees and attended AI hearings but did not make substantive public remarks captured in transcripts; 3) His wife (Erika Donalds) has spoken more publicly about AI in education than he has; 4) He is much more vocal about cryptocurrency and digital assets than AI specifically. The 'mentions_china' is marked true only because a Chinese AI company built profiles on him, not because he has spoken about China and AI. His actual policy positions on AI safety, AGI, existential risk, transformative potential, or specific AI companies remain largely unknown based on available public statements. This represents insufficient information to meaningfully assess his AI stance beyond general support for 'American AI dominance' and opposition to federal preemption of state AI regulation.

Carlos A. Gimenez.summary: Rep. Carlos Gimenez views AI primarily through a national security and geopolitical lens, framing it as a critical race against China that the U.S. must win. His focus is almost exclusively on China's AI capabilities as a military and surveillance threat, with concerns about data collection, quantum computing combined with AI, and technology transfer through universities and companies. He does not appear to discuss AI safety, alignment, existential risk, or transformative potential beyond military applications.

quotes.quote: China is pursuing AI, but they're also pursuing quantum computing, and it's a lethal combination
quotes.source: Fox News Digital, February 2024
quotes.context: Gimenez warning about China's technological capabilities in an interview about the AI race

quotes.quote: And in terms of artificial intelligence, the more data that they gather, the faster they'll advance…AI is a race that we need to win
quotes.source: Fox News Digital, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the importance of data collection in AI development and the competitive nature of AI advancement

quotes.quote: We have to win the race for AI because of the applications of AI in everything, including military hardware. So it's important for us to win that race, or else that technology will be used against us in the future
quotes.source: Fox News Digital, February 2024
quotes.context: Explaining why the U.S. must maintain AI superiority over China

quotes.quote: Many of their weapons will be superior to ours, and that causes me great concern
quotes.source: Fox News Digital, February 2024
quotes.context: When asked about his concerns regarding China coming out ahead in AI

quotes.quote: And so we need to look at every single Chinese company as basically an extension of the Chinese military. That's extremely concerning to me, and the fact that American universities and Western universities that…could be transferring technology
quotes.source: Fox News Digital, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing concerns about Chinese companies and universities with AI research ties

quotes.quote: We must win the race for Artificial Intelligence (AI) to maintain and expand our economic & military might to protect America from foreign adversaries! President Trump is making America's AI GREATER than EVER BEFORE!
quotes.source: Twitter/X, July 23, 2025
quotes.context: Tweet emphasizing AI as critical to national security and economic power

quotes.quote: The US must decouple from Communist China NOW!
quotes.source: Twitter/X, July 23, 2025
quotes.context: Tweet posted same day as AI race statement, emphasizing his position on U.S.-China relations

quotes.quote: By leveraging AI-driven technologies, TSA can enhance its ability to detect threats, optimize staffing levels, and lower the likelihood of human error
quotes.source: Letter to GAO, January 2025
quotes.context: Joint letter with Chairman Green requesting review of TSA's AI and biometric technology implementation

quotes.quote: However, as TSA invests heavily in these technologies, it is crucial to ensure that they deliver a meaningful return on investment while safeguarding traveler privacy and adhering to federal data protection regulations
quotes.source: Letter to GAO, January 2025
quotes.context: Expressing concern about privacy safeguards in AI implementation for homeland security

quotes.quote: American money must never be used to fuel Communist China's war machine, their repressive surveillance state, and the genocide of the Uyghur people
quotes.source: Statement on U.S. VC firms investing in China, February 2024
quotes.context: Responding to findings that U.S. venture capital firms invested $3 billion in Chinese AI and tech companies

Carlos A. Gimenez.notes: Rep. Gimenez (R-FL) serves on the House Select Committee on Strategic Competition between the US and the Chinese Communist Party, House Armed Services Committee, and Homeland Security Committee. His AI statements are almost exclusively focused on China as a competitor and adversary. He frames AI primarily as a military/national security technology and emphasizes: (1) the 'race' against China, (2) concerns about data collection via TikTok feeding Chinese AI, (3) quantum computing + AI as a 'lethal combination', (4) Chinese companies as extensions of the military, and (5) technology transfer through universities. He supports AI development for U.S. military and security applications (TSA biometrics, threat detection) but emphasizes privacy protections. Notably absent from his public statements: discussion of AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment concerns, AI ethics beyond privacy, or mentions of AI companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, or key AI figures. His stance is 'supportive' of U.S. AI development specifically to maintain military and economic superiority over China, advocating for decoupling from China and banning Chinese investment in U.S. AI. He appears to view AI as a strategic weapon in great power competition rather than as a potentially transformative or existentially risky technology.

Maria Elvira Salazar.summary: Rep. Maria Elvira Salazar (R-FL) has focused her AI legislative efforts primarily on combating AI-generated deepfakes and protecting intellectual property rights, particularly through the NO AI FRAUD Act and TAKE IT DOWN Act. Her approach emphasizes protecting individuals from AI abuse while balancing innovation, with statements about maintaining U.S. leadership in AI. She does not appear to have made public statements about AGI, existential risk, or AI safety in the technical sense.

quotes.quote: It's time for bad actors using AI to face the music
quotes.source: Press release, January 10, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing the NO AI FRAUD Act to protect Americans' likeness and voice from unauthorized AI-generated content

quotes.quote: This bill plugs a hole in the law and gives artists and U.S. citizens the power to protect their rights, their creative work, and their fundamental individuality online
quotes.source: Press release, January 10, 2024
quotes.context: Statement on the NO AI FRAUD Act establishing federal protections against deepfakes

quotes.quote: In this new era of AI, we need real laws to protect real people. The NO FAKES Act is simple and sacred: you own your identity—not Big Tech, not scammers, not algorithms. Deepfakes are digital lies that ruin real lives, and it's time to fight back
quotes.source: Press release, September 12, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing the NO FAKES Act to protect voice and likeness from AI-generated recreations

quotes.quote: As policymakers begin to tackle the issue of AI, it is vital that we maintain the agility of our technology and strike a careful balance between protecting consumers and protecting innovation
quotes.source: Ripon Forum profile, April 2024
quotes.context: General statement about Congressional approach to AI regulation

quotes.quote: The rapid rise of artificial intelligence has made it easier than ever for predators to create fake, explicit content that destroys lives. The TAKE IT DOWN Act finally gives victims real legal tools to fight back
quotes.source: Campaign website, May 2025
quotes.context: Statement on passage of the TAKE IT DOWN Act addressing AI-generated deepfake pornography

quotes.quote: The American people need clear rules that empower individuals to control their own faces and voices while encouraging innovation and ensuring that the United States remains the world leader on artificial intelligence
quotes.source: Press release, September 12, 2024
quotes.context: Statement on the NO FAKES Act emphasizing U.S. AI leadership

quotes.quote: Artificial Intelligence has immense potential to create and develop remarkable products when used responsibly. However, AI poses a threat not just to the originality of artists, but also by opening the door generally to nefarious actors
quotes.source: Co-sponsor Rep. Moran quoted in press release, September 2024
quotes.context: Statement from co-sponsor describing the dual nature of AI technology in the NO FAKES Act

quotes.quote: The abuse of this quickly advancing technology has affected everyone from musical artists, actors, sports professionals, and even high school students whose personal rights have been violated. These developments fundamentally undermine the United States' most basic individual liberties
quotes.source: Press release, January 10, 2024
quotes.context: Describing the threats posed by AI deepfakes in introducing the NO AI FRAUD Act

quotes.quote: By voting for the TAKE IT DOWN Act, the Senate took a stand to protect women and girls victimized by bad actors stealing their likenesses to create fake revenge porn
quotes.source: Statement, December 2024
quotes.context: Urging House passage of the TAKE IT DOWN Act after Senate approval

quotes.quote: If you exploit someone online, you will face consequences—including jail time. No more excuses
quotes.source: Campaign website, May 2025
quotes.context: Statement on criminal penalties in the TAKE IT DOWN Act for AI-generated non-consensual imagery

Maria Elvira Salazar.notes: Rep. Salazar's AI policy work is narrowly focused on specific harms—primarily deepfakes, non-consensual intimate imagery, and intellectual property theft. She has led bipartisan efforts on the NO AI FRAUD Act, NO FAKES Act, and TAKE IT DOWN Act (which became law in 2025). While she mentions U.S. AI leadership and the need to balance innovation with consumer protection, she has not made public statements about: artificial general intelligence (AGI), existential risk from AI, AI alignment or safety research, AI competition with China specifically, or major AI companies/figures. Her approach is pragmatic and harm-focused rather than philosophical or strategic. As Chair of the Western Hemisphere Subcommittee, she has spoken extensively about China in other contexts (particularly regarding Latin America), but has not connected these concerns to AI competition. Her legislative record shows 11 bills signed into law, demonstrating effectiveness in passing targeted legislation.

Nikema Williams.summary: Based on available public records, Congresswoman Nikema Williams has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. She serves on the House Financial Services Committee and was a member during a 2021 hearing on AI and algorithmic fairness in housing and financial services. Her most notable AI-related action was proposing an amendment in January 2025 to bar federal agencies from purchasing commercial AI systems from companies where government employees have significant ownership stakes, indicating concern about conflicts of interest in AI procurement.

quotes.quote: Georgia Tech is a partner in creating economic opportunity for traditionally marginalized communities with cutting-edge technologies.
quotes.source: U.S. Department of Commerce press release, September 2022
quotes.context: Commenting on a $65 million federal grant for Georgia Tech's AI Manufacturing coalition to accelerate AI adoption in manufacturing industries

quotes.quote: I look forward to working more with Georgia Tech and Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo as we help everyone to share in the promise of America–no matter your ZIP Code, no matter your bank account.
quotes.source: U.S. Department of Commerce press release, September 2022
quotes.context: Statement on the GA-AIM coalition receiving federal funding to integrate AI technologies in industry

quotes.quote: [Amendment] Adding a provision barring the Department of Commerce from purchasing commercial AI systems that any government employee or special government employee has an ownership stake of more than 5%
quotes.source: Congressional amendment proposal, January 2025
quotes.context: One of 16 amendments Williams introduced to Republicans' tax bill, focusing on preventing conflicts of interest in AI procurement

quotes.quote: [Amendment] Adding a provision barring the Department of Health and Human Services from purchasing commercial AI systems that any government employee or special government employee has an ownership stake of more than 5%
quotes.source: Congressional amendment proposal, January 2025
quotes.context: Similar amendment for HHS to prevent government employee conflicts of interest in AI purchases

Nikema Williams.notes: Congresswoman Nikema Williams (D-GA-05) has made extremely limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence policy. While she serves on the House Financial Services Committee and was listed as a member during a May 2021 Task Force on Artificial Intelligence hearing titled 'Equitable Algorithms: How Human-Centered AI Can Address Systemic Racism and Racial Justice in Housing and Financial Services,' no direct quotes or questions from her during that hearing were found in the public record. Her most substantive AI-related actions include: (1) Supporting a 2022 federal grant for Georgia Tech's AI manufacturing initiative, framing it through her consistent lens of economic opportunity and equity; and (2) Proposing amendments in January 2025 to prevent conflicts of interest in government AI procurement. Her approach appears to focus on ensuring AI benefits marginalized communities and preventing corruption, consistent with her broader legislative priorities around voting rights, economic justice, and good governance. However, she has not made public statements on AGI, existential risk, AI safety, international AI competition, or specific AI companies. This lack of detailed AI policy positions makes it impossible to characterize her views on most technical AI policy questions.

Andrew S. Clyde.summary: Rep. Andrew S. Clyde (R-GA-09) has made very limited public statements about AI. His only documented AI-related legislative action was introducing a bill in October 2024 to block FCC regulations requiring disclosure of AI-generated content in political advertising, which he characterized as regulatory overreach and an infringement on political speech.

quotes.quote: The FCC's last-ditch effort to regulate campaign advertising before the most important election in our nation's history is undoubtedly rooted in partisan politics.
quotes.source: Statement on H.R. 9913 (Ending FCC Meddling in Our Elections Act), October 2024
quotes.context: Clyde introduced legislation to prohibit federal funding for FCC rules requiring disclosure of AI-generated content in political radio and TV advertisements.

quotes.quote: This clearly marks an abuse of regulatory authority, which is why we must prohibit Americans' hard-earned tax dollars from funding the FCC's misguided attempt to regulate political speech.
quotes.source: Statement on H.R. 9913, October 2024
quotes.context: Clyde argued that FCC regulations on AI disclosure in political ads represented government overreach into political expression.

Andrew S. Clyde.notes: Rep. Andrew S. Clyde has made minimal public statements about artificial intelligence. His only documented AI-related legislative activity concerns opposition to FCC regulation of AI-generated political advertising, which he framed as a free speech and anti-regulatory-overreach issue rather than a technology policy matter. He has not made public statements about: AI safety, existential risk, AGI, transformative potential of AI, China's AI development, AI companies or key figures in the field, or AI alignment. His focus appears to be primarily on limiting federal regulatory authority rather than engaging with substantive AI policy questions. As a Republican representing Georgia's 9th Congressional District since 2021, his legislative priorities center on gun rights, limiting federal authority, and conservative social issues. Without additional hearings, speeches, or legislative actions specifically addressing AI technology policy, it is not possible to determine his views on the technical, strategic, or safety dimensions of artificial intelligence development.

Ashley Hinson.summary: Rep. Ashley Hinson (R-IA) views AI primarily through the lens of economic competitiveness with China and child safety. She frames AI as critical infrastructure for rural economic development while emphasizing the need to 'dominate' this technology to beat China. Her AI policy focus centers on protecting children from exploitation, combating deepfakes, and ensuring workforce readiness rather than existential risks or technical alignment challenges.

quotes.quote: We need to dominate these emerging technologies.
quotes.source: Punchbowl News interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Speaking about preparing Iowa's workforce for the AI economy and Industry 4.0, emphasizing U.S. competitiveness

quotes.quote: The [Chinese Communist Party] is trying to, in essence, weaponize this technology and right now they're just trying to exploit our loopholes in our policy. We cannot afford to underestimate what their intentions are or their capabilities.
quotes.source: Punchbowl News interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Discussing China's AI capabilities as a member of the House Select Committee on China

quotes.quote: This is especially important as we work to compete with China. This is a battle we must win, and investments like this one will help us to stay ahead in this game.
quotes.source: Google $7B investment announcement, May 2025
quotes.context: Speaking at Google's data center announcement in Cedar Rapids about AI infrastructure investments

quotes.quote: As a mom, I am concerned about child predators misusing AI to exploit our kids and believe we need to be proactive – not reactive – about this potential danger.
quotes.source: Press release, April 2024
quotes.context: Introducing the Child Exploitation and Artificial Intelligence Expert Commission Act

quotes.quote: We've already seen heinous uses of AI – protecting our kids needs to be a top priority as this technology gains traction.
quotes.source: Press release, April 2024
quotes.context: Supporting legislation to combat AI-generated child exploitation

quotes.quote: We know deepfakes and other AI-altered and AI-generated content present a significant and growing threat to our ability to trust what we see online, as well as the potential for bad actors to create malicious deepfake content that can cause serious harm to victims.
quotes.source: Press conference, August 2024
quotes.context: Introducing the Intimate Privacy Protection Act to combat AI deepfakes

quotes.quote: I think it's just become way too easy for these bad actors to not only create this content, but circulate these inappropriate images, these deepfakes, online. As a mom, this really worries me.
quotes.source: The Gazette interview, August 2024
quotes.context: Discussing concerns about AI-generated deepfake pornography and its impact on children

quotes.quote: When we talk about where Congress needs to act, it's about making sure that our next generation of skilled workers are ready.
quotes.source: Punchbowl News interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Calling for workforce development to prepare for the AI economy

quotes.quote: This isn't just about Silicon Valley. When we look at rural America and these kinds of investments coming in — the data centers, the economic driver of the infrastructure that needs to go in — we're seeing AI really make a difference.
quotes.source: Punchbowl News interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Discussing how AI investments are transforming rural Iowa's economy

quotes.quote: When I hear that China is continuing to get these advanced chips, they're clearly circumventing laws and so I'm focused on trade enforcement and empowering the DOJ under President Trump to be able to go after these bad guys.
quotes.source: Punchbowl News interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Advocating for stronger export controls on AI chips to China

Ashley Hinson.notes: Ashley Hinson serves on the House Select Committee on China and frames AI primarily as a national security and economic competitiveness issue. Her AI policy agenda focuses on three main areas: (1) beating China in AI development through export controls and domestic investment, (2) protecting children from AI-generated exploitation and deepfakes, and (3) preparing Iowa's workforce for the AI economy. She strongly supports AI infrastructure investments in Iowa (Google, Microsoft data centers) and views AI as transformative for rural economic development. However, she shows no engagement with existential risk concerns, AGI timelines, or technical AI safety/alignment issues. Her approach is pragmatic and economy-focused rather than concerned with long-term AI risks. She emphasizes the need for 'guardrails' around child safety but generally promotes innovation and investment. As a mother of two, she frequently frames AI safety concerns through the lens of protecting children online.

Mariannette Miller-Meeks.summary: Miller-Meeks views AI primarily through the lens of national security and healthcare applications. She emphasizes America's need to maintain AI leadership against China, sees AI as transformative for healthcare delivery (especially for rural communities and veterans), but also raises concerns about AI safety particularly regarding chatbots and their impact on young people.

quotes.quote: As we speak, China is going all out to usurp our dominance in AI.
quotes.source: Opinion piece 'Making AI A Priority', January 31, 2022
quotes.context: Miller-Meeks framed AI development as a competitive race with China, emphasizing the national security implications of falling behind.

quotes.quote: We cannot take America's AI leadership for granted and must continue to work and grow in this space.
quotes.source: Opinion piece 'Making AI A Priority', January 31, 2022
quotes.context: Expressing concern about maintaining U.S. technological superiority in AI development.

quotes.quote: If we allow other countries to take the lead on AI development we risk falling behind and potentially compromising our national security.
quotes.source: Opinion piece 'Making AI A Priority', January 31, 2022
quotes.context: Linking AI leadership directly to national security concerns.

quotes.quote: AI is quickly becoming an indispensable part of our economy and society.
quotes.source: Opinion piece 'Making AI A Priority', January 31, 2022
quotes.context: Acknowledging the transformative and pervasive nature of AI technology.

quotes.quote: The integration of artificial intelligence or augmented intelligence in health care offers this opportunity [to push our boundaries out significantly].
quotes.source: Congressional hearing on VA AI, February 19, 2024
quotes.context: Speaking about AI's transformative potential in healthcare delivery at the Veterans Administration.

quotes.quote: If the data A.I. learns from is incorrect or biased, it can make incorrect predictions that result in over or under diagnosis or mistreatment.
quotes.source: Congressional hearing on VA AI, February 19, 2024
quotes.context: Raising concerns about AI safety and the importance of data quality in healthcare applications.

quotes.quote: I'm thinking of maternal morbidity and mortality... how can we use wearable technology or remote monitoring with artificial intelligence to help streamline that service and get women the care that they need?
quotes.source: Axios interview, March 2, 2023
quotes.context: Discussing practical applications of AI for improving healthcare access in rural areas.

quotes.quote: AI is not a doctor, it is not a therapist and it cannot replace parents, family or the human connections young people need.
quotes.source: Congressional hearing on chatbots, September 4, 2025
quotes.context: Warning about the limitations of AI chatbots after citing a tragic case of a teen suicide linked to chatbot use.

quotes.quote: It does not pass the smell test... [showing] clear signs of attempt at regulatory capture.
quotes.source: House Energy and Commerce Health Subcommittee hearing, 2024
quotes.context: Expressing skepticism about the Coalition for Health AI (CHAI) and potential conflicts of interest with Google and Microsoft as founding members.

quotes.quote: Today marks our subcommittee's first hearing dedicated to exploring the transformative potential of artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare, specifically in the VA.
quotes.source: VA Health Subcommittee hearing opening remarks, February 15, 2024
quotes.context: Characterizing AI as having transformative potential while chairing a hearing on AI in veterans' healthcare.

Mariannette Miller-Meeks.notes: Miller-Meeks, a physician and Army veteran, approaches AI primarily from healthcare and national security perspectives. She strongly emphasizes the U.S.-China AI competition and views maintaining American AI leadership as critical to national security. She sees AI as genuinely transformative, particularly for healthcare applications in rural areas and veterans' care, including diagnostic accuracy, remote monitoring, and addressing provider shortages. However, she has raised significant safety concerns, particularly regarding AI chatbots and their impact on youth mental health, citing tragic suicide cases. She has also expressed skepticism about potential regulatory capture by major tech companies (Google, Microsoft) in healthcare AI governance. Her stance is pragmatic rather than ideological - supportive of AI innovation while advocating for clear guidelines, human oversight, and safety standards. She does not discuss AGI, existential risk, or AI alignment in the technical sense, focusing instead on practical applications and immediate safety concerns. As Chair of the House Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Health, she has held multiple hearings on AI in healthcare and advocates for public-private partnerships to advance AI development.

Randy Feenstra.summary: Rep. Randy Feenstra (R-IA) has a pragmatic, sector-specific approach to AI focused primarily on agricultural applications and U.S. competitiveness against China. He views AI as offering 'huge opportunities' while emphasizing the need for safety standards, particularly in farming technology. His AI stance is framed through the lens of protecting American farmers and maintaining technological leadership over foreign adversaries.

quotes.quote: There are huge opportunities for artificial intelligence when it comes to health care, education and some areas of manufacturing, but there should be protections in place and reliable energy resources to power AI.
quotes.source: Newton Daily News, January 2026
quotes.context: Feenstra, as a Republican candidate for Iowa governor, discussing AI's potential applications and need for safeguards

quotes.quote: There's also gotta be guardrails in making sure it's safe and that it's real and we're not pushing out stuff that's false and stuff that's not reliable. That's what we're working with at the federal level and we'll have to work with it at the state level also.
quotes.source: Newton Daily News, January 2026
quotes.context: Discussing the need for AI safety measures and combating misinformation

quotes.quote: From precision agriculture to veterinary software, the latest developments in agricultural technology – including artificial intelligence – have the power to lower input costs for farmers, protect the health of livestock and poultry, and make farming operations more efficient.
quotes.source: Farm Tech Act Press Release, December 2023
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to certify AI agricultural technology

quotes.quote: However, we must be equally active in certifying that these new technologies, products, and processes work as they should and uphold the highest industry standards.
quotes.source: Farm Tech Act Press Release, December 2023
quotes.context: Emphasizing the need for AI standards and certification in agriculture

quotes.quote: My Farm Tech Act protects our farmers from faulty or misleading technologies by requiring the USDA to verify the legitimacy and effectiveness of agricultural software and other technologies that are increasingly used on farms across Iowa and the United States.
quotes.source: Farm Tech Act Press Release, December 2023
quotes.context: Explaining his legislation to establish USDA certification for AI agricultural software

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is fundamentally changing the way we solve some of our society's biggest challenges. From healthcare to transportation; commerce to cybersecurity; A.I. technologies are revolutionizing almost every aspect of daily life.
quotes.source: House Science Committee Hearing, September 2022
quotes.context: Opening statement as Ranking Member at hearing on Managing the Risks of Artificial Intelligence

quotes.quote: But with every new and emerging technology comes new and evolving challenges and risks.
quotes.source: House Science Committee Hearing, September 2022
quotes.context: Acknowledging AI risks during congressional hearing

quotes.quote: We cannot allow China to dominate the international standards for the technologies of tomorrow.
quotes.source: House Science Committee Hearing on Technical Standards, March 2022
quotes.context: Discussing China's stated goal to set global standards for next-generation technologies including AI by 2035

quotes.quote: The United States must continue to play an active role in international standards-setting and work to counter undue foreign influence within standards development organizations. As new technology innovations such as AI and quantum sciences evolve, new technical standards will be needed.
quotes.source: House Science Committee Hearing on Technical Standards, March 2022
quotes.context: Emphasizing U.S. leadership in AI standards to counter foreign influence

quotes.quote: By restoring full funding for CIRAS, we can continue to invest in our manufacturing might, sustain good-paying jobs in Iowa, and remain at the cusp of innovation and ingenuity, including in AI and other emerging technologies.
quotes.source: Press Release on NIST Funding, April 2025
quotes.context: Connecting AI innovation to manufacturing competitiveness and strategic position against China

Randy Feenstra.notes: Randy Feenstra's AI views are notably sector-specific, focusing heavily on agricultural applications given his rural Iowa district. He consistently frames AI through two lenses: (1) practical benefits for farmers and manufacturers, and (2) U.S.-China technological competition. His office uses ChatGPT Pro subscriptions, indicating practical adoption. He emphasizes 'trustworthy AI' with standards for accuracy, privacy, reliability, transparency, fairness, and accountability. However, he does not discuss AGI, existential risks, or AI alignment in the technical safety sense. His approach is regulatory and standards-focused rather than concerned with advanced AI capabilities or long-term risks. He mentions Google in passing regarding nuclear power for data centers but doesn't make substantive statements about AI companies or key figures in the field. His stance is pragmatically supportive with emphasis on guardrails, particularly protective of agricultural interests.

Mary E. Miller.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or policy positions from Representative Mary E. Miller regarding artificial intelligence were found. Her legislative focus has been on agriculture, education, family policy, immigration, and social conservative issues.
Mary E. Miller.notes: Representative Mary E. Miller (R-IL-15) has been serving in Congress since January 2021. She sits on the House Committee on Agriculture, Committee on Education and Workforce, and Committee on House Administration. Her legislative activity and public statements have focused primarily on: immigration policy, abortion and pro-life issues, agriculture and farming policy, parental rights in education, LGBTQ+ issues, and traditional family values. No speeches, press releases, legislative actions, or social media posts related to artificial intelligence, AI policy, AI companies, or technology policy were found in the public record. She did co-sponsor H.R. 6202, the American Tech Workforce Act of 2021, which addressed H-1B visa programs, but this was focused on immigration policy rather than AI technology itself. It is possible that Representative Miller has not taken a public position on AI issues, or that such statements exist but are not readily available in public sources.

Frank J. Mrvan.summary: Based on extensive research, Representative Frank J. Mrvan (D-IN-01) has not made substantial public statements about artificial intelligence. His only documented AI-related action is voting in favor of the AI Training Act in 2022, a bipartisan bill focused on training federal acquisition workforce on AI capabilities and risks.
Frank J. Mrvan.notes: Representative Mrvan's legislative focus appears to be primarily on veterans' affairs, organized labor, steel industry issues, healthcare, and infrastructure for his Northwest Indiana district. As Chairman of the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Technology Modernization, his technology-related work has focused on electronic health records modernization rather than artificial intelligence policy. His only documented AI-related vote was for S.2551 (Artificial Intelligence Training for the Acquisition Workforce Act) in September 2022, which passed with bipartisan support. No press releases, speeches, congressional floor statements, or media interviews discussing AI policy, AI safety, AGI, China's AI development, or AI companies could be found. This suggests AI policy is not currently a priority issue for his office or district.

Victoria Spartz.summary: Based on extensive research, Victoria Spartz has made extremely limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. The only identified reference is a November 2025 appearance where she discussed 'oligopoly problems' in the AI market, consistent with her broader focus on anti-competitive practices in various industries. Her general political philosophy emphasizes deregulation and opposition to government over-regulation, particularly in healthcare and innovation sectors.
Victoria Spartz.notes: Victoria Spartz (R-IN-5), a Ukrainian-born U.S. Representative serving Indiana's 5th district since 2021, has not made substantive public statements about AI policy that could be located through comprehensive research. The only AI-related reference found was a November 2025 Forbes video where she reportedly discussed 'oligopoly problems' in the AI market, but the actual content and quotes were not accessible. Her legislative focus has been primarily on healthcare competition, anti-monopoly efforts (particularly regarding hospital systems), China-related national security concerns (especially regarding dependencies on China for critical supplies), and general deregulation. Her consistent political philosophy emphasizes limiting government regulation to promote innovation and competition, which could theoretically extend to AI policy, but she has not articulated specific AI positions publicly. She has spoken extensively about China as a national security threat in other contexts (pharmaceuticals, strategic competition) and has supported the Select Committee on China, but has not connected these concerns to AI specifically in available public statements. Without direct quotes or substantive policy statements about AI, it is not possible to accurately characterize her views on AGI, AI safety, existential risk, or transformative potential.

Tracey Mann.summary: Rep. Tracey Mann (R-KS) has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. The only documented AI-related activity is his introduction of bipartisan legislation to integrate predictive analytics and AI technologies into roadway safety programs. He has not made substantive public statements about broader AI policy, AGI, existential risks, or AI competition with China.

quotes.quote: For too long, our transportation network has relied on systems to evaluate road safety after tragic accidents happen.
quotes.source: Press Release, Roadway Safety Modernization Act, December 19, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to use predictive analytics and AI for proactive roadway safety, representing his only documented engagement with AI policy

quotes.quote: The Roadway Safety Modernization Act allows states and local communities to take a proactive, not reactive, posture by leveraging modern, data-driven tools to spot risks early on and make our roads safer.
quotes.source: Press Release, Roadway Safety Modernization Act, December 19, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the use of predictive analytics, AI technologies, and telematics for transportation safety - his sole legislative initiative involving AI

Tracey Mann.notes: Rep. Tracey Mann represents Kansas's 1st Congressional District and serves on the House Agriculture and Transportation & Infrastructure Committees. Despite extensive research, only two quotes related to AI could be found, both from a single press release about transportation safety legislation. He has not participated in AI-focused hearings, has not made floor speeches about AI, and has not issued statements on AI policy, competition with China, existential risk, or AI safety. His focus appears to be primarily on agricultural policy, rural issues, and transportation infrastructure. The lack of public statements on AI may reflect either a lack of engagement with the issue or that his district priorities lie elsewhere. This stands in contrast to many other members of Congress who have been actively engaged in AI policy discussions.

Jake Auchincloss.summary: Rep. Jake Auchincloss is a tech-forward Democrat who views AI as a potentially transformative 'general purpose technology' that requires proactive regulation. He emphasizes U.S. competition with China, advocates for industry-specific regulation rather than blanket approaches, and calls for a 'public counterweight' to big tech firms. He is notably pragmatic about AI's capabilities, viewing current systems as 'prediction engines' rather than true intelligence, while avoiding existential risk rhetoric.

quotes.quote: They are not intelligence in the way humans conceive of it. What these are, are models with more than a trillion parameters that predict the next word in a sentence or next pixel in an image. They are incredibly good at that and getting better. But they are prediction engines, they are not intelligence. They are tools.
quotes.source: CBS Boston, January 26, 2023
quotes.context: Auchincloss explaining his understanding of AI systems like ChatGPT during the week he became the first member of Congress to deliver an AI-written speech on the House floor.

quotes.quote: AI might become a general purpose technology: foundational in every sector. I delivered the first AI-drafted congressional speech yesterday as a call to action. Policymakers need to be purposeful and proactive.
quotes.source: Twitter, January 2023
quotes.context: Auchincloss explaining his motivation for using ChatGPT to write his congressional speech, emphasizing the transformative potential of AI.

quotes.quote: I'm the youngest parent in the Democratic caucus, AI is going to be part of my life and it could be a general purpose technology for my children.
quotes.source: WBUR News, January 26, 2023
quotes.context: Auchincloss, then 34 years old, explaining why he's personally invested in ensuring proper AI regulation for future generations.

quotes.quote: Congress needs to get ahead of the curve on regulation, ethics and considerations about this high-potential technology.
quotes.source: January 2023
quotes.context: Auchincloss explaining why he used ChatGPT to write his speech - to draw attention to the need for proactive AI policy.

quotes.quote: He said he doesn't want to see a repeat of the advent of social media, which started small and ballooned faster than Congress could react.
quotes.source: WBUR News, January 26, 2023
quotes.context: Auchincloss drawing lessons from Congress's failure to regulate social media quickly enough, and warning against making the same mistake with AI.

quotes.quote: In particular, he argued that the country needs a 'public counterweight' to the big tech firms that would help guarantee that smaller developers and universities have access to the same cloud computing, cutting edge algorithms and raw data as larger companies.
quotes.source: WCVB, January 26, 2023
quotes.context: Auchincloss calling for democratization of AI infrastructure to prevent monopolistic control by major tech companies.

quotes.quote: We must collaborate with international partners like the Israeli government to ensure that the United States maintains a leadership role in AI research and development and responsibly explores the many possibilities evolving technologies provide.
quotes.source: ChatGPT-generated speech read on House floor, January 25, 2023
quotes.context: From the AI-written speech about the U.S.-Israel AI Center Act, emphasizing international collaboration and U.S. leadership in AI.

quotes.quote: We're going to win by running faster than China
quotes.source: American Bazaar Online, April 2025
quotes.context: Auchincloss articulating his approach to AI competition with China - focusing on American innovation rather than solely defensive measures.

quotes.quote: I strongly believe that the path forward for sound guard rails for AI is going to be industry specific; it's going to look different in education than it does in healthcare than it does in financial services—as it should.
quotes.source: American Bazaar Online, April 2025
quotes.context: Auchincloss advocating for sector-specific AI regulation rather than a one-size-fits-all approach, and criticizing the EU's regulatory model.

quotes.quote: So now the US government is financially motivated to sell AI to China? Makes me shudder to think what a TikTok deal might look like.
quotes.source: Twitter/X, August 10, 2025
quotes.context: Auchincloss criticizing the Trump administration's decision to allow AI chip sales to China, expressing concern about national security implications.

Jake Auchincloss.notes: Jake Auchincloss is notably pragmatic and tech-literate in his AI views. He serves on the House Select Committee on Strategic Competition between the United States and China, which heavily influences his framing of AI as a competitive technology race. He frequently emphasizes China competition, having stated the U.S. should 'run faster than China' rather than adopt EU-style restrictive regulation. He views AI as potentially 'general purpose technology' (comparing it to electricity or the internet) but is careful to characterize current systems as 'prediction engines' rather than true intelligence, pushing back against AGI hype. He does NOT engage with existential risk or AI safety/alignment discourse - his concerns are more practical: misinformation, deepfakes, election security, and monopolistic control by big tech. He advocates for proactive, industry-specific regulation and has introduced legislation on deepfakes (Intimate Privacy Protection Act) and AI education for minors (AWARE Act). He mentions OpenAI specifically and has criticized the Trump administration's decision to allow AI chip sales to China. His signature move was becoming the first member of Congress to deliver an AI-written speech (using ChatGPT) in January 2023, which he used as a publicity stunt to draw attention to the need for AI regulation. He's been consistent in warning Congress not to repeat its failures with social media regulation.

Lisa C. McClain.summary: Rep. Lisa McClain (R-MI), House Republican Conference Chairwoman, has limited public statements specifically about AI policy beyond national security and economic competitiveness concerns. Her AI-related activities focus primarily on protecting U.S. technological advantage against China through export controls on AI chips, and she has personal financial connections to AI companies through investments in xAI and BigBear.ai.

quotes.quote: The Stop Stealing our Chips Act is about protecting America's technological edge and holding bad actors accountable. By cracking down on illegal exports and empowering whistleblowers, we will make sure U.S.-made AI chips strengthen our future, not our adversaries.
quotes.source: Stop Stealing Our Chips Act press release, December 2025
quotes.context: McClain co-sponsored bipartisan legislation to prevent smuggling of American AI chips to China, framing AI as a national security and competitive issue against adversaries.

quotes.quote: 100 percent [sure we had no insider information]. Because if it was, we wouldn't have bought 100,000 shares, we would've bought a heck of a lot more.
quotes.source: NewsNation interview, January 14, 2026
quotes.context: McClain defending her husband's $100,000-$250,000 investment in Elon Musk's xAI just days before the Pentagon announced integration of Grok AI into military systems.

quotes.quote: The Pentagon doesn't release that information, but I can 100% assure you that we didn't have the insider information beforehand.
quotes.source: NewsNation interview, January 14, 2026
quotes.context: McClain addressing questions about potential insider trading related to xAI stock purchase before Pentagon's Grok integration announcement.

quotes.quote: In America, we will not tolerate the exploitation of our children. This law will protect our children and families from becoming targets of digital predators.
quotes.source: TAKE IT DOWN Act signing statement, May 19, 2025
quotes.context: McClain's statement on legislation addressing AI-generated deepfake content, particularly nonconsensual images of children, showing concern about harmful AI applications.

quotes.quote: Our nation is facing significant security threats from dangerous nations such as China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea.
quotes.source: McClain's official House website
quotes.context: General statement on national security priorities that frames her approach to technology competition, including AI.

Lisa C. McClain.notes: INSUFFICIENT PUBLIC INFORMATION: Rep. McClain has very limited public statements specifically about AI policy, safety, or transformative potential. Her AI-related public record consists primarily of: (1) Co-sponsoring the Stop Stealing Our Chips Act focused on preventing AI chip smuggling to China, framing AI as a national security competition issue; (2) Supporting the TAKE IT DOWN Act addressing AI-generated deepfake content exploiting children; (3) Personal financial investments in AI companies (xAI and BigBear.ai) that raised ethics questions. She is a member of the Taiwan Caucus, Border Security Caucus, and Special Operations Forces Caucus, suggesting national security focus. She does not appear to have made substantive public statements about: AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, AI safety research, transformative AI potential, AI regulation beyond export controls, or philosophical views on AI development. Her stance appears focused narrowly on U.S.-China technological competition and protecting American economic/military advantage rather than broader AI governance questions. As House Republican Conference Chairwoman (#3 House Republican), she has significant influence but has not been a vocal thought leader on AI policy compared to other members of Congress.

Michelle Fischbach.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or positions from Representative Michelle Fischbach specifically addressing artificial intelligence were found. Her legislative focus has been on rural communities, agriculture, trade policy, healthcare, and traditional conservative issues.
Michelle Fischbach.notes: Representative Michelle Fischbach (R-MN-07) has served in the U.S. House since 2021 and sits on the House Ways and Means Committee (including Trade and Oversight subcommittees), the Rules Committee, the Budget Committee, and the Ethics Committee. Despite extensive searches of congressional records, press releases, committee testimony, speeches, and news coverage, no public statements about artificial intelligence were identified. Her legislative priorities focus on rural Minnesota issues including agriculture, biofuels, trade policy (particularly USMCA enforcement), broadband access, healthcare (especially rural nursing facilities), and law enforcement. While the Ways and Means Committee has jurisdiction over some technology and innovation policy, and despite her interest in issues like broadband infrastructure and innovation in agriculture, Fischbach has not made public statements specifically about AI policy, regulation, safety, China's AI development, or related topics as of January 2026. This absence of public statements on AI is notable given the increasing prominence of AI policy discussions in Congress during her tenure.

Deborah K. Ross.summary: Rep. Deborah Ross (D-NC) views AI as having profound transformative potential but emphasizes the critical need for security guardrails, safety measures, and ethical frameworks. She compares AI to nuclear power in its dual-use nature and references watching 'Oppenheimer' while thinking about AI throughout. She focuses on practical legislation around AI security, vulnerability tracking, and protecting against misuse while fostering innovation.

quotes.quote: AI has the potential to enhance the lives of our people – from driving discoveries in new scientific domains to propelling cutting-edge medical research and more
quotes.source: Press release, September 2024
quotes.context: Introducing the Secure Artificial Intelligence Act with Rep. Beyer to regulate AI security and mitigate risk incidents

quotes.quote: AI has the profound potential to improve the lives of our people, but we must enact necessary guardrails to address risks associated with this evolving field
quotes.source: House Science Committee statement, September 2024
quotes.context: Speaking about the AI Incident Reporting and Security Enhancement Act passing committee

quotes.quote: I just watched 'Oppenheimer.' And all I was thinking about was AI, the whole time.
quotes.source: Durham AI meeting, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing how to hold tech companies responsible for AI use, comparing AI to nuclear power in having both positive uses and destructive applications

quotes.quote: Ross compared it to nuclear power, in having great positive uses as well as destructive applications
quotes.source: WRAL report, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing accountability for AI use at a meeting with NC tech experts

quotes.quote: She suggested there should be more emphasis on training new computer scientists on 'using those skills for good, not the dark side.'
quotes.source: Durham meeting, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing ethical training for AI developers and computer scientists

quotes.quote: Students learning how to use AI are some of the most important stakeholders in the future of technological ethics, and that they need to learn responsibility in using these skills
quotes.source: NCCU roundtable, February 2024
quotes.context: Speaking at a roundtable with Biden administration officials about AI education

quotes.quote: AI research should focus on developing AI for good
quotes.source: NCCU roundtable, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the direction of AI research priorities

quotes.quote: However, as we cross this new frontier, it is essential that we implement smart policies to address security and safety risks while continuing to foster innovation and competitiveness
quotes.source: Press release, September 2024
quotes.context: Introducing the Secure AI Act legislation

quotes.quote: The Genesis Mission has the potential to double American research productivity within a decade by connecting national labs, universities, and industry to develop powerful AI platforms for science
quotes.source: House Science Committee hearing, December 2025
quotes.context: Opening statement on the Department of Energy's Genesis Mission using AI for scientific research

quotes.quote: It is critical for Congress to act now to ensure the U.S. can safely and responsibly remain at the forefront of the rapidly growing AI industry
quotes.source: Attributed statement, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing the need for federal AI policy and America's competitive position

Deborah K. Ross.notes: Rep. Ross represents North Carolina's 2nd District, which includes the Research Triangle Park, a major tech hub. She serves on the House Science, Space, and Technology Committee and is a member of the Bipartisan Task Force on Artificial Intelligence. Her approach is notably pragmatic and focused on concrete legislative action rather than theoretical concerns. Key legislative efforts include: 1) The Secure Artificial Intelligence Act (with Rep. Beyer and Senators Warner/Tillis) establishing AI security centers and incident reporting; 2) The AI Incident Reporting and Security Enhancement Act addressing vulnerability management; 3) The Protect Working Musicians Act addressing AI's impact on creative industries. While she references China implicitly through discussions about U.S. competitiveness and 'remaining at the forefront,' she does not engage in explicit China-focused rhetoric. Her Oppenheimer comparison is notable - she explicitly stated she watched the film while thinking about AI throughout, drawing parallels to nuclear technology's dual-use nature. However, she does not discuss AGI, superintelligence, or existential risk scenarios. Her focus is on: security vulnerabilities, ethical AI development, protecting against deepfakes and misinformation, supply chain risks, and ensuring proper education/training. She emphasizes collaboration between government, academia, and private sector, particularly leveraging North Carolina's university research capabilities.

Teresa Leger Fernandez.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or quotes from Representative Teresa Leger Fernandez specifically addressing artificial intelligence policy, regulation, safety, or related topics could be found. Her public focus appears to be on other policy areas including tribal advocacy, water rights, broadband access, and community development.
Teresa Leger Fernandez.notes: Representative Leger Fernandez (D-NM-03) has been serving in Congress since January 2021 and sits on the Natural Resources Committee and the Rules Committee. Her legislative priorities and public statements focus primarily on issues affecting her New Mexico district, including: tribal sovereignty and Native American rights, water infrastructure, broadband access, climate change and renewable energy, community development, and civil rights. While she has supported technology innovation initiatives (such as the CHIPS Act and technology commercialization through national laboratories like Los Alamos and Sandia), no specific public statements about artificial intelligence policy, regulation, or related concerns were found in press releases, committee testimony, speeches, interviews, or social media. She is listed as a member of the Rules Committee's Subcommittee on Legislative and Budget Process, but no AI-specific testimony or statements were identified. The lack of public statements on AI does not necessarily indicate a lack of interest or knowledge, but rather that AI policy has not been a prominent focus of her public communications or legislative work as of January 2026.

Andrew R. Garbarino.summary: Rep. Garbarino views AI primarily through a cybersecurity and national security lens, focusing heavily on China as an adversarial threat using AI for cyberattacks. He sees AI as transformative for both offense and defense in cyberspace, advocating for its integration into U.S. cyber defenses while warning that human intervention alone cannot counter AI-enabled threats. His approach emphasizes flexible regulation, public-private partnerships, and 'secure by design' principles rather than restrictive oversight.

quotes.quote: For the first time, we are seeing a foreign adversary use a commercial AI system to carry out nearly an entire cyber operation with minimal human involvement. That should concern every federal agency and every sector of critical infrastructure.
quotes.source: Statement on Anthropic Chinese cyberattack, November 2025
quotes.context: Responding to China's use of Anthropic's Claude AI tool to conduct automated cyberattacks, calling for Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei to testify before Congress

quotes.quote: We cannot expect to counter autonomous, machine-speed cyber aggression from adversaries like China with human response times alone.
quotes.source: Statement to Axios, November 2025
quotes.context: Explaining why AI must be integrated into U.S. cyber defenses to match the speed and scale of AI-enabled attacks from adversaries

quotes.quote: I'll tell you right now, with our adversaries, the way they're going to use AI, we can't defend with human intervention alone. AI is going to have to be part of our cyber defense.
quotes.source: McCrary Institute event, December 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the necessity of AI in cybersecurity defense at a Washington D.C. event on cyber and critical infrastructure security

quotes.quote: If the bad guys are going to be using AI to attack us, we should be using AI…in our cyber defenses because it's not going to be possible to fight this aggressive use of AI and cyberattacks by just human intervention and defense alone.
quotes.source: Bloomberg 'Balance of Power' interview, November 2025
quotes.context: Discussing how AI can be a force multiplier for both the U.S. and adversaries in cyberspace following the Chinese AI-orchestrated cyberattack

quotes.quote: China is believed to have used AI to stage a major cyberattack. The technology we're dealing with is used in drones and cell phones. There's a lot to keep our eyes on.
quotes.source: Interview with The Messenger, December 2025
quotes.context: Discussing global geopolitical threats and the need to remain vigilant against China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea

quotes.quote: People are finding ways to use AI that I didn't expect, but that's the thing. You have creative people who push the limits. Unfortunately, you're seeing AI being used for cyberattacks or deepfakes, but we're also seeing it used for beneficial purposes, like defense against cyberattacks.
quotes.source: Interview with The Messenger, December 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the dual-use nature of AI technology and the balance between innovation and security concerns

quotes.quote: My role in the oversight of AI is the regulation. If we're going to issue protections or requirements, we need to make sure that what we write down on paper works in the real world. You don't want to be too specific that it takes too long to change when it moves quickly. You don't want the law to be behind technology.
quotes.source: Interview with The Messenger, December 2025
quotes.context: Explaining his philosophy on AI regulation - emphasizing flexibility and adaptability over rigid rules

quotes.quote: Legislation should be broad enough to allow quick responses and should 100,000% include a committee of experts in advice.
quotes.source: Interview with The Messenger, December 2025
quotes.context: Discussing his approach to AI regulation and the importance of expert input in policymaking

quotes.quote: While the advancement of artificial intelligence could provide new tools to America's adversaries and cybercriminals, AI can also be a tool to enhance our nation's detection and defense against threats to our networks.
quotes.source: Hearing announcement, June 2025
quotes.context: Opening statement for hearing on 'Securing AI in the US Cybersecurity Mission'

quotes.quote: We must avoid reactive and scattershot regulation as our nation's AI innovators work to win the global AI race. It is important for Congress, the Department of Homeland Security, interagency partners, and the private sector to work together to ensure that we don't fall behind our adversaries in AI innovation while safeguarding our national security and civil liberties.
quotes.source: CyberScoop op-ed, October 2025
quotes.context: Writing about the need for balanced AI policy that promotes innovation while maintaining security

Andrew R. Garbarino.notes: Rep. Garbarino (R-NY) chairs the House Homeland Security Committee and previously chaired the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Protection Subcommittee. His AI focus is almost entirely centered on cybersecurity applications rather than broader AI safety or AGI concerns. He frequently references China and other adversaries (Russia, Iran, North Korea) as threats using AI for cyberattacks. He has directly engaged with AI companies, calling Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei and Google Cloud CEO Thomas Kurian to testify about Chinese exploitation of Claude AI. His office subscribes to ChatGPT Pro. He advocates for 'secure by design' principles in AI development and emphasizes that AI can serve as a 'force multiplier' for cyber defense. He shows no evidence of being concerned about existential risk or AGI scenarios - his focus is pragmatic and security-oriented. He supports AI innovation and opposes heavy-handed regulation, preferring flexible frameworks that include expert input. His view is that AI is transformative for cybersecurity but he does not discuss broader societal transformation or superintelligence scenarios.

Nicole Malliotakis.summary: Based on extensive research, Rep. Nicole Malliotakis has made very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. The only direct AI reference found was a suggestion to use AI for redistricting to eliminate gerrymandering. Her technology-related comments focus primarily on Big Tech censorship, Chinese technology threats (particularly regarding Lenovo/Lexmark purchases and TikTok), and Section 230 reform.

quotes.quote: I think we need to find a way to move forward with, perhaps we need to start using artificial intelligence or some type of computerized mapping system where it is completely competitive and it's done in a fair and balanced manner to give you the most competitive seats, districts, throughout the country in each state.
quotes.source: CBS News New York interview, August 24, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing gerrymandering and redistricting, suggesting AI as a tool for creating fair electoral districts

quotes.quote: To support this transition, it provides funding for research institutions to develop and implement non-animal alternatives such as organ-on-chip technology, human-cell-based models, and AI-driven computational research.
quotes.source: SPARE Act legislation press release, April 2, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to end federal animal testing, mentioning AI as one of several alternative research methods

quotes.quote: Big Tech seems focused on acting as an extension of big government, quashing content from those who oppose their liberal ideology.
quotes.source: Wall Street Journal op-ed, August 2021
quotes.context: Criticizing YouTube's censorship of her press conference, advocating for Section 230 reform

quotes.quote: It's time for Congress to rein them in and reform Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act to require transparency for content-enforcement decisions and disclosure of appeals processes—and to remove liability protections for companies who censor constitutionally protected speech.
quotes.source: Wall Street Journal op-ed, August 2021
quotes.context: Calling for Big Tech regulation following YouTube removing her video

quotes.quote: [TikTok] threatens our way of life
quotes.source: Fox News interview, December 26, 2022
quotes.context: Supporting TikTok ban on federal devices, expressing concerns about Chinese technology

quotes.quote: This is a 'disturbing trend' from the CCP
quotes.source: Fox News interview, September 3, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing a former aide to NY Governor being charged with acting as an illegal agent of the Chinese government

quotes.quote: We must continue to invest in our health care system to keep up with medical innovation and new technology
quotes.source: Press release about Richmond University Medical Center funding, April 26, 2022
quotes.context: Supporting $1.8 million for biplane imaging technology at a hospital, showing general support for medical technology advancement

quotes.quote: The COVID-19 pandemic made clear the urgent need to restore our domestic supply chain so that we are not dependent on adversaries like Communist China for critical pharmaceutical and medical supplies
quotes.source: MMEDS Act press release, May 3, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to revitalize U.S. medical manufacturing, focusing on reducing China dependence

Nicole Malliotakis.notes: Rep. Malliotakis has made remarkably few public statements specifically about artificial intelligence policy. Her technology-related focus has been primarily on: (1) Chinese technology threats and supply chain security (TikTok, Lenovo, Lexmark); (2) Big Tech censorship and Section 230 reform; and (3) general support for technological innovation in healthcare and research. She has not publicly engaged with AI-specific policy debates around AGI, existential risk, AI safety, alignment, or major AI companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, or DeepMind. The single direct AI quote found was a practical suggestion to use AI for redistricting, not a substantive policy position on AI development or governance. As a member of the House Ways and Means Committee and former Foreign Affairs Committee member, her focus has been on China competition broadly rather than AI specifically. Her advocacy for reducing reliance on Chinese technology and her concerns about Big Tech censorship suggest she would likely approach AI policy through a national security and free speech lens, but she has not articulated specific AI policy positions.

Ritchie Torres.summary: Rep. Ritchie Torres views AI as 'the most revolutionary technology of our time' with transformative potential but also serious risks. He focuses heavily on China competition and national security concerns related to AI, while advocating for practical regulatory approaches starting with transparency and disclosure requirements. He explicitly discusses existential risks from AI and emphasizes the need for long-term regulatory frameworks.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is the most revolutionary technology of our time. It has the potential to be a weapon of mass disinformation, dislocation, and destruction.
quotes.source: AI Disclosure Act of 2023 announcement, June 2023
