His AI policy focus is primarily on: (1) K-12 AI literacy through his bipartisan LIFT AI Act, (2) combating AI-driven misinformation and deepfakes as threats to democracy, and (3) maintaining U.S. technological superiority over China, particularly regarding AI chip exports. He describes AI as one of the most 'disruptive' and 'meaningful technologies' of our time. He supports the AI Safety Institute and calls for regulatory oversight, but his statements focus on near-term risks (misinformation, job displacement, national security) rather than existential or AGI-related concerns. He has specifically criticized Nvidia H200 chip sales to China and co-sponsored legislation (H.R. 6879) to prohibit sales of advanced AI chips to countries of concern. His approach emphasizes responsible development, education, and democratic safeguards rather than viewing AI as either overhyped or an existential threat. Notably, his legislation has support from major tech companies including IBM, Google, and the Information Technology Industry Council.

Celeste Maloy.summary: Rep. Celeste Maloy (R-UT) has made very limited public statements about AI. Her only significant AI-related legislative work is co-sponsoring the Deepfake Liability Act (December 2025), which addresses harmful AI-generated content, particularly nonconsensual deepfake pornography. Her statements focus narrowly on platform accountability rather than broader AI policy, safety, or competitiveness issues.

quotes.quote: Abusive deepfakes and cyberstalking are harming people across the country, and victims deserve real help.
quotes.source: Press release announcing Deepfake Liability Act, December 2025
quotes.context: Introducing bipartisan legislation to hold platforms accountable for AI-generated deepfakes

quotes.quote: Our bill creates a straightforward duty of care and a reliable process to remove harmful content when victims ask for help.
quotes.source: Press release announcing Deepfake Liability Act, December 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the mechanism of the Deepfake Liability Act

quotes.quote: Companies that take this seriously will keep their protections under the law. Those that do nothing will be held accountable.
quotes.source: Press release announcing Deepfake Liability Act, December 2025
quotes.context: Describing how Section 230 protections would be conditional on platform action

quotes.quote: They don't have any reason to do enough [to protect users] because of the immunities afforded under Section 230.
quotes.source: KSL interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Explaining why platforms fail to adequately address deepfake pornography

quotes.quote: They will still have Section 230 immunities, but under this bill, those immunities are predicated on their duty to act.
quotes.source: KSL interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Clarifying that the bill doesn't eliminate Section 230 but makes it conditional

quotes.quote: So, they have to have a duty to be making sure they don't have deepfakes, revenge porn kind of stuff on their websites. And as long as they're doing that, they're still covered.
quotes.source: KSL interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Describing platform responsibilities under the proposed legislation

Celeste Maloy.notes: Rep. Maloy's public statements on AI are extremely limited and focused exclusively on one narrow application: harmful AI-generated content (deepfakes). She has not made public statements about: (1) AI competitiveness with China or other nations, (2) AGI or transformative AI, (3) existential risk from AI, (4) AI safety or alignment research, (5) specific AI companies or industry figures, or (6) broader AI policy questions around innovation, regulation, or national security. Her committee assignments (Appropriations and Natural Resources) do not have primary jurisdiction over AI policy. Her legislative focus has been primarily on public lands, natural resources, and veterans issues. The Deepfake Liability Act represents her only known engagement with AI-related policy as of January 2026. Note: There was also a Senate bill called the RAISE Act (Recommending Artificial Intelligence Standards in Education) introduced in 2025, but Rep. Maloy was not associated with this legislation - it was introduced by Senators Husted and Blunt Rochester.

Thomas R. Suozzi.summary: Rep. Thomas Suozzi has limited public statements specifically about AI policy. His primary AI-related engagement has been co-leading bipartisan efforts to address harmful AI outputs from Elon Musk's Grok chatbot and securing federal funding for AI-powered cancer diagnostics research. He views AI as beneficial for healthcare and economic growth but emphasizes the need for vigilance against bias in AI systems.

quotes.quote: AI companies, in their race to create the most innovative and commercially successful product, must be vigilant in combatting biased, slanted, bigoted and antisemitic outputs. It's a very slippery and dangerous slope.
quotes.source: Statement to Jewish Insider, August 2025
quotes.context: Response to xAI's explanation of Grok chatbot's antisemitic outputs, warning about the dangers of biased AI systems

quotes.quote: I am encouraged that the Musk team gave such [a] thorough response. However, their investigation highlights a critical point: AI companies, in their race to create the most innovative and commercially successful product, must be vigilant in combatting biased, slanted, bigoted and antisemitic outputs.
quotes.source: Statement regarding xAI's response to congressional inquiry, August 2025
quotes.context: After xAI responded to bipartisan letter about Grok's problematic outputs

quotes.quote: The groundbreaking work at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, combining neuroscience with AI, is truly remarkable. I am proud to have played a pivotal role in securing a $2 million NIH grant to help establish computational modeling to further AI-based diagnostic and predictive tools for advanced cancer diagnostics.
quotes.source: Press release, October 2024
quotes.context: Announcing $2 million in federal funding for AI cancer research at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory

quotes.quote: Community Project Funding (CPF) grants, such as this one for Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, are not only furthering advancements in AI diagnostics but simply saving lives. We must work together to continue supporting cutting-edge research such as what is happening right here at CSHL.
quotes.source: Press release, October 2024
quotes.context: Supporting AI research funding for cancer diagnostics

quotes.quote: The SHARE Plan Act is a creative, common sense, concrete way to build wealth for the middle class and those aspiring to it. It helps build an ownership society, which is especially crucial with the rise of AI in the workplace.
quotes.source: Press release on SHARE Plan Act, July 2025
quotes.context: Bipartisan legislation to increase employee stock ownership, acknowledging AI's impact on the workplace

Thomas R. Suozzi.notes: Rep. Suozzi has very limited public statements specifically about AI policy, AGI, or existential risk. His AI-related activity consists primarily of: (1) Co-leading a bipartisan letter to Elon Musk/xAI regarding Grok's antisemitic outputs in July 2025, expressing concerns about AI bias and harmful content; (2) Securing $2 million in federal funding for AI-powered cancer diagnostics at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory; (3) Acknowledging AI's impact on the workplace in the context of employee stock ownership legislation. He does not appear to have made public statements about China and AI competition, AGI timelines, existential risk, AI safety research organizations, or specific AI companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, or DeepSeek. His focus appears pragmatic—supporting beneficial AI applications (healthcare) while addressing immediate harms (bias, hate speech). As a moderate Democrat and co-chair of the bipartisan Problem Solvers Caucus, his approach to AI seems consistent with his general legislative style: practical, bipartisan, and focused on specific problems rather than broader philosophical or existential questions. More extensive research would be needed to determine if he has made additional AI-related statements in committee hearings, floor speeches, or other venues not captured in readily available online sources.

Timothy M. Kennedy.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or positions on artificial intelligence could be found for Representative Timothy M. Kennedy (D-NY-26). Kennedy, who was elected to Congress in April 2024 after serving in the New York State Senate from 2011-2024, has focused his legislative efforts on homeland security, veterans affairs, transportation infrastructure, healthcare workforce issues, and gun violence prevention. He serves on the House Homeland Security Committee (including the Subcommittee on Emergency Management and Technology) and Veterans Affairs Committee, but has not made public statements about AI policy.
Timothy M. Kennedy.notes:
Representative Timothy M. Kennedy has been in Congress since May 2024 (elected in a special election to replace Brian Higgins). Prior to Congress, he served in the New York State Senate from 2011-2024, where he chaired the Transportation Committee. His legislative priorities include:

- Homeland Security and border issues (Co-Chair of Northern Border Caucus)
- Veterans healthcare and benefits
- Transportation infrastructure
- Healthcare workforce issues (he is a licensed occupational therapist)
- Emergency management (FEMA, disaster preparedness)
- Gun violence prevention
- Student loan access for healthcare professionals

While Kennedy serves on the Homeland Security Subcommittee on Emergency Management and Technology, no public statements about artificial intelligence, AI regulation, or technology policy could be found through searches of:
- His official House website (kennedy.house.gov)
- Congressional voting records and bill sponsorships
- Press releases and public statements
- His previous New York State Senate record
- Media interviews and coverage

As a relatively new member of Congress (less than 2 years in office), Kennedy may not have yet developed or articulated positions on AI policy. His committee assignment that includes 'Technology' relates primarily to homeland security technology and emergency management systems rather than AI policy specifically.

Vince Fong.summary: Congressman Vince Fong views AI as economically transformative and critical for U.S. competitiveness, with a strong focus on AI education and workforce development. He emphasizes the importance of America maintaining AI leadership over adversaries like China and Europe, while supporting regulatory guardrails for consumer protection. His approach is pragmatic and focused on practical applications in agriculture, manufacturing, and education rather than existential concerns.

quotes.quote: This bill will help future generations learn the advantages of AI and will benefit those in industries like agriculture and manufacturing in the Central Valley. These resources will be for college students, both in their undergraduate and graduate programs, but the bill will also encourage AI learning in K-12 students and will keep America at the forefront of this cutting-edge technology.
quotes.source: Press release, August 23, 2024
quotes.context: Introducing the NSF AI Education Act of 2024 with Rep. Andrea Salinas

quotes.quote: As AI continues to reshape the landscape of work and education, it's critical that we equip our workforce with the skills necessary to thrive in an AI-driven world.
quotes.source: House Science, Space, and Technology Committee remarks, September 11, 2024
quotes.context: Speaking about the NSF AI Education Act before committee vote

quotes.quote: As emerging technologies like AI reshape the global economy, it's critical that rural communities, like those in California's Central Valley, are empowered.
quotes.source: Press release, September 16, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing the NSF AI Education Act of 2025

quotes.quote: Together, we recognize that this bill would enhance America's leadership in AI by cultivating the next generation of innovators, educators, and professionals.
quotes.source: Committee remarks, September 11, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing bipartisan support for AI education legislation

quotes.quote: While Europe and China are rapidly integrating autonomous trucks into their supply chains, America is asleep at the wheel, hamstrung by a confusing patchwork of state regulations that threaten public safety, innovation, and economic growth.
quotes.source: Press release on AMERICA DRIVES Act, July 24, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing autonomous vehicle legislation

quotes.quote: This is about making sure America — not China or Europe — sets the global standard for autonomous vehicle deployment, while protecting our workers and public safety. The longer we delay, the more we cede ground to other nations who are moving quickly to integrate autonomous technologies into their economies.
quotes.source: The Hill op-ed, August 21, 2025
quotes.context: Championing the AMERICA DRIVES Act

quotes.quote: American cannot afford to lose the AI race.
quotes.source: NextTech Kern conference keynote, October 3, 2025
quotes.context: Speech at Cal State Bakersfield to students and educators

quotes.quote: If the United States falls behind in the development of AI, the country runs the risk of becoming reliant on a technology controlled by our adversaries.
quotes.source: NextTech Kern conference, October 3, 2025
quotes.context: Warning about AI competition during keynote speech

quotes.quote: While advocating against state-by-state regulation of AI, which Fong said would lead to limiting applications of the technology, he agreed controls were necessary to achieve goals such as protecting consumer privacy.
quotes.source: Bakersfield.com report on NextTech Kern, October 3, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing regulatory approach to AI

quotes.quote: At a time of national division, he said, agreement that schools should prepare students for AI-powered workplaces 'is the one thing bringing us together.'
quotes.source: Yahoo News report on NextTech Kern, October 3, 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing bipartisan consensus on AI education

Vince Fong.notes: Congressman Fong's AI focus is primarily economic and educational rather than philosophical or safety-oriented. He consistently frames AI in terms of: (1) U.S.-China competition and maintaining American technological leadership; (2) workforce development and education, especially for rural and underserved communities; (3) practical applications in agriculture, manufacturing, and autonomous vehicles; (4) the need for federal regulatory frameworks rather than state-by-state approaches. He does not appear to discuss AGI, existential risk, alignment problems, or specific AI companies/figures. His rhetoric emphasizes opportunity over danger, though he acknowledges the need for 'regulatory guardrails' for consumer protection. He has secured funding for AI initiatives in defense appropriations, including AI-powered command and control systems. His legislative work is bipartisan and focuses on education infrastructure rather than AI safety or ethics.

Michael A. Rulli.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or policy positions from Congressman Michael A. Rulli regarding artificial intelligence were found. Rulli has been in Congress since June 2024 and serves on the House Energy and Commerce, Judiciary, and Education and Workforce Committees, but has not made public comments on AI policy.
Michael A. Rulli.notes: Michael A. Rulli is a Republican U.S. Representative for Ohio's 6th Congressional District who was sworn into Congress on June 25, 2024. He previously served in the Ohio State Senate from 2019-2024. His primary legislative focus has been on energy policy (particularly coal and natural gas), immigration, border security, education, and healthcare. He serves on the House Energy and Commerce Committee (starting in the 119th Congress), House Judiciary Committee, and House Education and Workforce Committee. While he has co-sponsored legislation to prevent Chinese Communist Party influence in American K-12 schools (the CLASS Act), he has not made any identified public statements specifically about artificial intelligence, AI policy, AI safety, or related technology issues. His district (Ohio's 6th) is focused on energy production, producing 90% of Ohio's natural gas. Rulli's policy priorities center on 'America First' principles, energy independence, manufacturing, and reducing regulations, but AI has not been a stated focus area.

LaMonica McIver.summary: Rep. LaMonica McIver has very limited public statements on AI. Her primary engagement with AI policy has been co-sponsoring the Workforce of the Future Act in December 2025, which focuses on preparing workers for AI's economic impact. Her statements emphasize protecting workers from job displacement and ensuring AI benefits working people rather than just technology companies.

quotes.quote: Working people deserve innovation that expands opportunity—not eliminates it.
quotes.source: Press release on Workforce of the Future Act, December 11, 2025
quotes.context: Statement when reintroducing legislation to study AI's impact on the workforce and provide training resources

quotes.quote: Strengthening our understanding of how AI is impacting jobs in real time and investing directly in education makes sure Americans are not caught flat-footed as AI accelerates
quotes.source: Press release on Workforce of the Future Act, December 11, 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the rationale for the Workforce of the Future Act

quotes.quote: By prioritizing training that delivers economic gains to young people and underrepresented communities, the Workforce of the Future Act puts power back where it belongs: with the people who keep our economy running.
quotes.source: Press release on Workforce of the Future Act, December 11, 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing the equity and worker-focused aspects of AI workforce legislation

quotes.quote: I'm proud to join Rep. Emanuel Cleaver to put forward a plan to better integrate emerging technologies into school curricula and support workers as AI enters their industry.
quotes.source: Congressman Larson press release, December 15, 2025
quotes.context: Statement supporting comprehensive AI workforce preparation legislation

quotes.quote: We can't let big tech moguls make billions on this disruptive technology without investing our workforce.
quotes.source: Congressman Larson press release, December 15, 2025
quotes.context: Expressing concern about tech companies profiting from AI while workers face displacement

quotes.quote: The Congress urgently needs to act to pass nationwide AI regulations and standards that preserve jobs, protect children, and advance global technological competitiveness.
quotes.source: Congressman Larson press release, December 15, 2025
quotes.context: Calling for federal AI regulation and standards

quotes.quote: AI technology should work for us, not the other way around and this bill takes an important step in that direction.
quotes.source: Congressman Larson press release, December 15, 2025
quotes.context: Articulating her philosophy that AI should serve people, not the reverse

LaMonica McIver.notes: Rep. LaMonica McIver has been in Congress only since September 2024 (elected in a special election), which significantly limits her public record on AI policy. Her AI-related statements are almost entirely focused on workforce impacts and economic equity rather than technical AI safety, AGI, or existential risk. She mentions 'global technological competitiveness' which implies awareness of international competition but does not specifically name China or other countries. Her references to 'big tech moguls' suggest skepticism toward AI companies profiting without worker protections. Her stance is worker-centric and focused on practical economic concerns rather than long-term transformative or existential AI issues. The Workforce of the Future Act she co-sponsored is endorsed by both AI companies (OpenAI, Anthropic, Microsoft) and labor unions (AFT, SAG-AFTRA), suggesting a pragmatic approach. No evidence was found of her discussing AGI, AI alignment, AI safety research, or existential risk from AI.

Tony Wied.summary: Tony Wied is a newly elected Republican congressman from Wisconsin (sworn in November 2024) with very limited public statements on AI. His only identified comment on AI suggests he views it as requiring oversight and safe implementation, though he provided minimal detail. He has expressed views on technology innovation more broadly, emphasizing U.S. leadership over China and Russia in emerging technologies like crypto and blockchain.

quotes.quote: That's a difficult question, but it's really providing oversight; that is important because it is a very impactful situation with AI. We need to continue to work hard on that to do it in a safe way.
quotes.source: Washington Reporter interview, December 2025
quotes.context: When asked about federal preemption of state AI regulation during a congressional debate on whether the federal government should override state-level AI laws

quotes.quote: He believes the United States should lead the world in the development of crypto and blockchain technology in the 21st century, rather than adversarial countries like Russia and China.
quotes.source: Campaign platform/Meet the Freshmen profile, 2024
quotes.context: Statement about technology innovation as a national security issue, though focused on crypto/blockchain rather than AI specifically

Tony Wied.notes: Tony Wied is a freshman congressman who only took office in November 2024, which explains the extremely limited public record on AI policy. His single identified statement on AI was brief and non-committal, acknowledging AI as 'impactful' and requiring 'oversight' to be done in a 'safe way,' but providing no substantive detail about his views on regulation, existential risk, AGI, or other key AI policy questions. His technology-related statements have focused more on crypto/blockchain and general innovation competitiveness with China and Russia. He sits on the House Agriculture, Small Business, and Transportation & Infrastructure committees, none of which are primary AI policy committees. Given his very recent entry to Congress and lack of detailed public statements, it is not possible to meaningfully characterize his AI views beyond acknowledging he sees it as important and requiring some form of oversight. More public statements would be needed to assess his position on the specific questions about AGI, existential risk, AI safety, or views on major AI companies.

Cleo Fields.summary: Congressman Cleo Fields, a Louisiana Democrat serving on the House Financial Services Committee, has not made substantial public statements about AI policy, safety, or regulation. While he serves on subcommittees overseeing AI regulation and has made significant investments in AI-related stocks (Alphabet, Palantir, CoreWeave, Iris Energy), there is no publicly available record of speeches, quotes, or policy positions specifically addressing artificial intelligence.
Cleo Fields.notes: Congressman Cleo Fields was sworn into the House of Representatives on January 3, 2025, after a 28-year absence from Congress. He serves on the House Financial Services Committee, including subcommittees overseeing capital markets, fintech, and AI regulation. Despite this committee assignment, extensive research found no public speeches, press releases, floor statements, or media interviews where Fields discusses AI policy, safety, regulation, or his views on the technology. His most notable AI-related activity has been stock purchases in October 2025 of AI and cloud computing companies including Alphabet (Google), Palantir Technologies, CoreWeave, and Iris Energy, which drew criticism regarding potential conflicts of interest. He was a cosponsor of H.R.6159, the Artificial Intelligence Literacy and Education Commission Act, introduced in November 2025, but this appears to be his only legislative connection to AI policy. As a newly returned member of Congress who has been in office for approximately one year, he may not yet have developed or articulated comprehensive public positions on AI.

Marlin A. Stutzman.summary: Rep. Marlin Stutzman (R-IN-3) serves on the House Financial Services Subcommittee on Digital Assets, Financial Technology, and Artificial Intelligence, but has made very limited public statements specifically about AI policy. The only documented quote found relates to his support for federal preemption of state AI regulations to maintain U.S. competitiveness. His overall AI stance remains largely unknown due to lack of public statements on the topic.

quotes.quote: I don't think states should have the ability to regulate an AI. That way we put America at the forefront and leading on that issue rather than being divided amongst ourselves.
quotes.source: Multiple news outlets, December 2025, regarding Trump's executive order on AI
quotes.context: Stutzman expressed support for Trump's executive order limiting state-level AI restrictions, arguing for federal uniformity to maintain U.S. competitiveness

Marlin A. Stutzman.notes: Despite serving on the House Financial Services Subcommittee on Digital Assets, Financial Technology, and Artificial Intelligence since the 119th Congress (2025), Rep. Stutzman has made extremely few public statements about AI policy. Only one direct quote was found in available sources. His position on the subcommittee suggests interest in AI issues related to financial services, and he has been noted as championing permitting reform that aligns with tech companies' interests in AI infrastructure (particularly energy for data centers). However, he has not made public statements addressing: China/foreign competition in AI, AGI development, transformative potential of AI, existential risks, safety/alignment concerns, or specific AI companies or figures. More public statements or testimony from committee hearings may exist but were not accessible through available sources. His general political profile suggests a pro-business, limited regulation approach that likely extends to AI policy, but this cannot be confirmed without additional direct statements.

Gilbert Ray Cisneros, Jr..summary: Based on available public information, Rep. Cisneros has made minimal public statements specifically about AI. His only identified position mentions AI in the context of military modernization and national defense, advocating for integrating cutting-edge technologies including artificial intelligence to ensure U.S. military readiness against 21st century threats. He has not made substantive public statements about AGI, AI safety, existential risk, or specific AI policy positions.

quotes.quote: In Congress, Gill will advocate for advancements in technology, including artificial intelligence and space exploration, to ensure that the U.S. military remains adaptable and prepared to counter emerging threats in the 21st century.
quotes.source: Campaign website (gilonthehill.com), accessed 2024-2026
quotes.context: This statement appears on his campaign platform under national security and defense policy. It represents his only publicly available statement specifically mentioning artificial intelligence.

Gilbert Ray Cisneros, Jr..notes: Gilbert Ray Cisneros, Jr. is a U.S. Representative for California's 31st Congressional District (since 2025), former Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness (2021-2023), and former Representative for California's 39th District (2019-2021). Despite his senior defense position and current congressional role, he has made remarkably few public statements about artificial intelligence. His only identified AI-related statement is a brief mention on his campaign website about supporting AI for military modernization. He has not testified before Congress on AI issues, has not issued press releases about AI policy, and has not made public speeches addressing AI as a major policy concern. His stock trading activity shows he has bought and sold shares in AI-related companies (NVIDIA, Super Micro Computer, Fair Isaac) but these appear to be routine portfolio management rather than policy positions. The lack of substantive AI policy statements is notable given his defense background and current congressional service. It is possible he has internal views or classified briefings on AI in military contexts that are not publicly available, but no public record of his AI policy positions exists beyond the single campaign statement about military technology modernization.

Angela D. Alsobrooks.summary: Senator Alsobrooks has demonstrated a pragmatic, governance-focused approach to AI, emphasizing responsible and ethical use while recognizing its transformative potential for innovation and economic development. Her AI engagement has been primarily through executive action as County Executive and questions about AI challenges as Senator, focusing on equity, ethical implementation, and ensuring technology benefits all Americans rather than just the wealthy.

quotes.quote: This Executive Order underscores our commitment to harnessing the potential of AI technology while ensuring that its deployment is guided by principles of responsibility, ethics, and equity.
quotes.source: Prince George's County Executive Order on AI, April 19, 2024
quotes.context: Alsobrooks issued an executive order on responsible AI use across county agencies, establishing frameworks for ethical AI deployment in government services.

quotes.quote: By establishing comprehensive frameworks and standards, we aim to maximize the benefits of AI while mitigating potential risks and safeguarding the interests of our residents.
quotes.source: Prince George's County Executive Order on AI, April 19, 2024
quotes.context: Statement accompanying her executive order emphasizing a balanced approach to AI adoption that prioritizes both innovation and risk management.

quotes.quote: County Executive Alsobrooks acknowledged the transformative potential of AI in revolutionizing various aspects of society and emphasized the importance of ensuring its responsible and equitable deployment.
quotes.source: Prince George's County press release, April 2024
quotes.context: From the announcement of her AI executive order, recognizing AI as transformative while stressing equity concerns.

quotes.quote: The number one goal of every jurisdiction has to be to continue doing the work of building the current economy and being prepared for the new economy we're going to see.
quotes.source: CSM Velocity Center visit, October 31, 2025
quotes.context: Speaking about technology and economic development, including AI's role in preparing for future economic changes.

quotes.quote: I hosted a 'Seizing the Moment' panel where we heard from leaders in AI, digital assets, and more. It's critical that we work to ensure every American can benefit from these new marketplaces.
quotes.source: Stand With Crypto statement, date unspecified
quotes.context: Discussing the importance of making emerging technologies like AI accessible to all Americans, not just the wealthy.

quotes.quote: You shouldn't have to be a billionaire to harness the power of new technologies.
quotes.source: Stand With Crypto statement, date unspecified
quotes.context: Emphasizing democratic access to AI and emerging technologies as part of her broader economic equity agenda.

quotes.quote: Whether you want to open a small business, invest and expand, or start something on the cutting edge of technology, we are making our community an attractive place for people of every background to bring their greatest ideas to life. These are the ideas that will define the next century.
quotes.source: State of the Economy Address, June 13, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing support for technology innovation including cutting-edge tech companies in Prince George's County.

quotes.quote: [Alsobrooks] asked the community leaders about the challenges AI may pose as the regional technology industry advances.
quotes.source: CSM Velocity Center visit, October 31, 2025
quotes.context: As Senator, actively inquiring about AI challenges including ethics, security, privacy, policy, and environmental factors during a technology corridor visit.

quotes.quote: It's critical that we work to ensure every American can benefit from these new marketplaces.
quotes.source: Technology panel discussion, date unspecified
quotes.context: Emphasizing the importance of inclusive access to AI and digital asset technologies.

quotes.quote: The Executive Order recognizes the evolving landscape of AI technology and aims to establish comprehensive frameworks and standards to guide its development and implementation within county operations.
quotes.source: Prince George's County AI Executive Order, April 2024
quotes.context: Acknowledging AI's rapid evolution and the need for adaptive governance frameworks.

Angela D. Alsobrooks.notes: Limited public statements specifically about AI are available. Alsobrooks' AI engagement has been primarily through governance actions rather than extensive public commentary. As Prince George's County Executive, she issued one of the early local government executive orders on responsible AI use (April 2024), emphasizing ethics, equity, and risk mitigation. Her approach appears focused on practical implementation, economic opportunity, and ensuring equitable access rather than theoretical concerns about AGI or existential risk. She has not made public statements about China's AI development, specific AI companies, or key AI figures. Her stance reflects a pragmatic, governance-oriented Democrat who sees AI as transformative technology requiring responsible oversight. She co-signed a 2025 Senate letter questioning FAA's use of AI for aviation safety analysis, showing continued engagement with AI policy issues. Her emphasis on equity and ensuring technology doesn't only benefit billionaires is consistent with her broader political messaging about economic justice.

Tim Sheehy.summary: Senator Tim Sheehy has shown limited public engagement with AI policy issues. His primary AI-related activity involves co-sponsoring the TAME Extreme Weather and Wildfires Act, which promotes using AI for weather forecasting and disaster prediction. He also co-sponsored legislation to prevent AI bots from infiltrating federal public comment systems, particularly regarding concerns about foreign adversaries like China.

quotes.quote: By incorporating leading-edge artificial intelligence into our forecasting and disaster threat prediction modeling, we will have the ability to know where, how big, and how bad weather is going to be, and can take preventative measures long before the impact is realized.
quotes.source: TAME Extreme Weather and Wildfires Act announcement, April 2025
quotes.context: Co-sponsoring bipartisan legislation with Senator Brian Schatz to use AI for weather forecasting and wildfire prediction

quotes.quote: Now is the time for transformational innovation and leadership to prevent future tragedies and protect American families, homes, and communities from disaster quickly and effectively.
quotes.source: TAME Extreme Weather and Wildfires Act announcement, April 2025
quotes.context: Statement about using AI technology for disaster prevention and response

quotes.quote: Extreme weather and wildfires cost us hundreds of billions of dollars in economic impact and harm countless Americans each year, yet our government response – particularly to wildfire – hasn't changed in decades.
quotes.source: TAME Extreme Weather and Wildfires Act announcement, April 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the rationale for adopting AI technology in government weather forecasting

Tim Sheehy.notes:
INSUFFICIENT DATA: Senator Tim Sheehy has very limited public statements specifically about artificial intelligence. The available evidence shows:

1. He co-sponsored the TAME Extreme Weather and Wildfires Act (S.1378), which directs NOAA to use AI for weather forecasting and emphasizes not relying on foreign (European) datasets.

2. He co-sponsored S.2262 (American Voices in Federal Lands Act) to prevent AI bots and foreign adversaries from sabotaging BLM public comment systems.

3. He has spoken extensively about China as a military and technological competitor, noting China is now a 'peer to peer competitor' rather than 'near peer,' and expressing concerns about Chinese technology and surveillance.

4. His technology background is in defense/aerospace (founded Ascent Vision Technologies, which developed counter-drone technology).

However, he has NOT made public statements about:
- AGI or transformative AI capabilities
- AI safety or alignment concerns
- Existential risk from AI
- Specific AI companies or key figures in the field
- Broader AI policy beyond narrow applications (weather, public comments)
- AI regulation or governance frameworks

His AI stance appears pragmatic and application-specific rather than reflecting deep engagement with AI policy debates. Only 3 substantive quotes about AI could be found, far short of the requested 10.

Bernie Moreno.summary: Senator Bernie Moreno views AI primarily as a tool for government efficiency, economic growth, and maintaining U.S. competitiveness. He strongly opposes state-level AI regulation in favor of federal oversight, emphasizes the need for energy infrastructure to power AI development, and focuses on practical applications rather than existential concerns. His background as a blockchain entrepreneur shapes his tech-forward, deregulatory approach.

quotes.quote: AI doesn't understand state borders, so it is extraordinarily important for the federal government to be the one that sets interstate commerce. It's in our Constitution. You can't have a patchwork of 50 states.
quotes.source: Multiple news outlets, May 2025
quotes.context: Moreno defending the proposed 10-year federal ban on state-level AI regulation, arguing for uniform federal standards rather than allowing individual states to create their own AI rules.

quotes.quote: Think about that for a second [how passport issuing could be sped up by AI].
quotes.source: NOTUS interview, August 2025
quotes.context: Moreno explaining how AI could make government operations more efficient, particularly in bureaucratic processes like passport issuance, as part of Republican efforts to use AI to shrink government.

quotes.quote: Ohio is extraordinarily well-positioned for the future. We have abundant energy to power innovation, the very foundation of the AI revolution.
quotes.source: MidwestCon Policy Luncheon at University of Cincinnati, September 2025
quotes.context: Moreno emphasizing Ohio's advantages in the AI race, particularly focusing on energy resources and infrastructure needed for AI development, while discussing the state's commitment to Intel's chip manufacturing facility.

quotes.quote: So do you think it's outrageous that last year, because of the policies of the Biden administration, that 90% of new power generation in this country was windmills and solar panels and we absolutely knee capped American energy. That's not affordable, it's not abundant and it's not reliable.
quotes.source: Senate hearing with Sam Altman and tech executives, May 2025
quotes.context: Moreno criticizing Biden administration energy policies during a hearing on AI competitiveness, arguing that renewable energy is insufficient to power AI infrastructure and chip manufacturing.

quotes.quote: We are cultivating an ecosystem of talented people across Ohio who know how to harness and unleash these transformative technologies.
quotes.source: MidwestCon Policy Luncheon, September 2025
quotes.context: Discussing Ohio's position in AI and advanced manufacturing, emphasizing human capital and the state's role in developing AI talent alongside infrastructure.

quotes.quote: America is the birthplace of innovation, and we should be leading in the responsible development of blockchain.
quotes.source: Deploying American Blockchains Act introduction, April 2025
quotes.context: While introducing blockchain legislation, Moreno expressed his broader views on U.S. technological leadership and innovation, which extends to his AI policy positions.

quotes.quote: We don't want to overregulate, but we can't repeat the mistakes of the internet and social media era where children got harmed.
quotes.source: Senate hearing with Sam Altman, May 2025
quotes.context: Moreno discussing the need for appropriate AI regulation, particularly around protecting children, while maintaining his general preference for light-touch regulation.

quotes.quote: This idea of AI and social relationships. I think this is a new thing that we need to pay a lot of attention to. People are relying on AI more and more for life advice, sort of emotional support, that kind of thing.
quotes.source: Senate hearing with Sam Altman, May 2025
quotes.context: Moreno expressing concern about AI's role in replacing human relationships and providing emotional support, acknowledging both potential benefits and risks that need monitoring.

quotes.quote: And without chips, this just doesn't work. If we don't have the highest-performance chips made here in the United States, this is not going to happen here.
quotes.source: Senate hearing with AMD CEO Lisa Su, May 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing the critical importance of domestic semiconductor manufacturing for U.S. AI competitiveness, linking it to broader discussions about competing with China.

quotes.quote: Let me just end the myth right here: The crypto industry does not want no regulation. That's totally false.
quotes.source: Campaign trail statement, 2024
quotes.context: While discussing cryptocurrency, this quote reflects Moreno's broader technology policy philosophy that applies to AI—he supports 'regulatory certainty' and appropriate frameworks rather than complete deregulation.

Bernie Moreno.notes: Senator Bernie Moreno is a freshman Republican senator from Ohio (sworn in January 2025) with a strong technology background as a blockchain entrepreneur and former car dealership owner. His AI views are shaped by his business experience and focus heavily on practical applications rather than theoretical concerns. Key themes in his AI stance include: (1) Strong opposition to state-level regulation in favor of federal preemption; (2) Emphasis on energy infrastructure, particularly criticism of renewable energy as insufficient for AI needs; (3) Focus on government efficiency and using AI to streamline bureaucracy; (4) Support for U.S. competitiveness in chip manufacturing and AI development; (5) Concern about protecting children from AI harms while avoiding overregulation; (6) Recognition of AI's transformative potential for Ohio's economy. Notably absent from his public statements: any discussion of AGI, existential risk, AI safety research, alignment problems, or deep technical AI policy issues. He references China implicitly through discussions of competitiveness and chip manufacturing but doesn't make it a central talking point. He has interacted with Sam Altman during Senate hearings and generally supports the tech industry's preference for light-touch federal regulation. His approach is business-friendly, deregulatory, and focused on economic growth and practical applications rather than speculative risks.

David McCormick.summary: Senator David McCormick views AI as a transformative technology comparable to the Industrial Revolution, framing it primarily through the lens of U.S.-China competition. He emphasizes that AI leadership is 'existential' for America's future, advocating for Pennsylvania to become a national AI hub through massive energy infrastructure investments. While acknowledging AI's disruptive potential, he favors light-touch regulation to maintain American competitiveness against China.

quotes.quote: This is a battle that America has to win. If we lose the AI leadership, we literally put China in a position of being the global superpower. Military capability, economic capability. I mean, it is this is existential.
quotes.source: WGAL interview, August 20, 2025
quotes.context: McCormick discussing AI competition with China during a visit to York County defense contractor BAE Systems, explicitly using the term 'existential' to describe the stakes of AI leadership

quotes.quote: If the United States does not lead this revolution on our own terms, we will hand control of our infrastructure, our data, our leadership, and our way of life to the Chinese Communist Party.
quotes.source: Pennsylvania Energy and Innovation Summit, Carnegie Mellon University, July 15, 2025
quotes.context: Opening remarks at the summit announcing $90 billion in AI and energy investments for Pennsylvania

quotes.quote: I think if you look at the industrial revolution and all the good it brought, but all the disruption it brought, I think we're facing the next industrial revolution, but on steroids.
quotes.source: Lehigh University Compelling Perspectives talk, December 4, 2025
quotes.context: Describing the transformative nature of AI during a fireside chat about Pennsylvania's AI future

quotes.quote: We need to win the battle for AI innovation in America, and Pennsylvania is at the center of it.
quotes.source: Fox News interview, July 14, 2025
quotes.context: Promoting the Pennsylvania Energy and Innovation Summit ahead of the announcement of $90 billion in investments

quotes.quote: AI is going to be disruptive. It's going to affect jobs. And, at least for the foreseeable future, it's going to affect white-collar jobs more than blue-collar jobs.
quotes.source: Telephone town hall, July 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI's economic impact and job displacement during a constituent call

quotes.quote: Data is the new strategic currency. It's the underlying thing that one needs to drive innovation in the world of artificial intelligence.
quotes.source: Lehigh University talk, December 4, 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the three pillars (talent, technology, and data) necessary for AI leadership from his book 'Superpower in Peril'

quotes.quote: In his book 'Superpower in Peril,' he casts the competition as an 'existential battle' the United States must win.
quotes.source: Lehigh Valley News coverage of Lehigh University talk, December 5, 2025
quotes.context: McCormick's 2023 book frames U.S.-China competition with AI as a central component of technological supremacy

quotes.quote: I don't think there is an anti-regulatory sentiment in the Congress or in the administration. I do think there is a caution about over-regulating.
quotes.source: Lehigh University talk, December 2025
quotes.context: Discussing his approach to AI regulation, favoring a light-touch framework to avoid stifling innovation

quotes.quote: I'm concerned. I'm not clear on why that is the right path for us... Beijing is on its way toward an 'independent' AI capacity and lifting export controls 'would accelerate' that quest.
quotes.source: Aspen Security Forum, December 11, 2025
quotes.context: Breaking with Trump administration's decision to allow Nvidia to sell H200 chips to China, showing concern about China's AI capabilities

quotes.quote: It is a monumental time for America's future and Pennsylvania's future. It's something akin to the Industrial Revolution, where there was so much change in the way production and the economy work, but maybe more extreme! Certainly, it's moving more quickly than the Industrial Revolution happened, because we're locked in a battle with China for leadership in artificial intelligence and energy innovation.
quotes.source: RealClearPennsylvania Podcast, October 27, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing Pennsylvania's role in leading the AI revolution and the urgency of U.S.-China competition

David McCormick.notes: McCormick's AI views are heavily shaped by his national security and business background. His 'existential' framing refers specifically to U.S.-China geopolitical competition rather than AI safety/alignment concerns about AGI itself. He repeatedly mentions China as the primary adversary in AI development. He has organized major AI infrastructure initiatives ($90+ billion investments) and sponsored legislation like the 'Liquid Cooling for AI Act.' While he acknowledges job displacement concerns, he emphasizes economic opportunity and energy infrastructure. He has met with AI company leaders (Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, Anthropic representatives) and broke with Trump on allowing advanced chip exports to China. He does NOT discuss: AGI timelines, AI alignment problems, existential risk from AI itself (only from losing to China), or technical AI safety concerns. His focus is entirely on industrial policy, economic competitiveness, and maintaining American technological superiority.

Nicholas J. Begich III.summary: Rep. Begich approaches AI from a pro-innovation, competitive lens focused on ensuring the U.S. maintains global leadership. He emphasizes the need for balanced regulation that doesn't hamstring American AI development relative to other jurisdictions, advocating for globally harmonized standards while maintaining speed in development until international agreements are reached.

quotes.quote: We need to have an effective set of regulations, a globally harmonized set of rules of the road. We don't have that right now. And I think the United States Congress in particular has to be careful not to hamstring artificial intelligence development in a way that would push that work to other jurisdictions.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast, April 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the balance between innovation and regulation in AI development

quotes.quote: Without global agreement, the only defense we have is speed. So, until international standards are achieved, we cannot slow down on the development of AI.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast, April 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing the competitive nature of AI development in the absence of international coordination

quotes.quote: We've got base AI, agentic AI, and physical robotics. These three intersecting curves create real challenges for regulators.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast, April 2025
quotes.context: Identifying the three key technological J-curves that regulators must address

quotes.quote: I think small business wins here because AI has the potential to reduce barriers to entry dramatically. It's never been easier to start a company than it is today, and AI makes it even easier.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast, April 2025
quotes.context: Expressing optimism about AI's democratizing effect on entrepreneurship

quotes.quote: When AI starts to work on behalf of an individual, we have to start thinking about whether we should empower agentic AI to, for example, enter into a contract relationship that would perhaps bind someone financially.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast, April 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the challenges of agentic AI and personhood validation

quotes.quote: The base requirement for tapping into AI is connectivity.
quotes.source: Regulating AI podcast, April 2025
quotes.context: Highlighting infrastructure challenges for AI adoption, particularly in rural Alaska

quotes.quote: In addition to continued automation and AI integration, downward trajectories on consumption due to collapsing populations in East Asia and China have offset industrialization-driven demand.
quotes.source: Social media post on tariffs, June 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI and automation's role in economic productivity in the context of China trade policy

Nicholas J. Begich III.notes: Limited public information available. Begich's AI statements focus primarily on: (1) International competition - he frequently references the need to maintain U.S. competitiveness and not cede leadership to 'other jurisdictions'; (2) China is mentioned specifically in the context of trade/tariffs and AI's role in productivity; (3) His approach is pragmatic and pro-innovation, emphasizing that regulation should not stifle development; (4) He shows technical sophistication in discussing agentic AI, robotics, and the challenges regulators face; (5) No public statements found regarding AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, or specific AI companies/figures like OpenAI, Anthropic, or key researchers. His background as a tech entrepreneur and investor (Ford Motor Company, founded FarShore Partners) informs his technology-forward perspective. As a freshman congressman elected in 2024, his public record on AI policy is still developing.

Shomari Figures.summary: Insufficient public information available. Congressman Shomari Figures, who took office in January 2025, has made public statements supporting digital innovation, particularly cryptocurrency and blockchain technology, but has not made substantial public statements specifically about artificial intelligence, AI safety, or related policy issues.

quotes.quote: Embrace the new landscape around digital assets, like Cryptocurrency, to stimulate innovation and technological advancement
quotes.source: Campaign website, 2024
quotes.context: From his campaign website's issues page, discussing his approach to digital assets and blockchain, with mention of applications in supply chain management, healthcare, and identity verification

quotes.quote: take a forward-looking approach to digital assets and blockchain technology
quotes.source: Letter to DNC and VP Harris, July 2024
quotes.context: Co-signed letter asking the Democratic National Committee to adopt pro-innovation policies for digital assets, including selecting a 'pro-innovation' SEC chair

quotes.quote: I believe that innovation is, in blockchain technology, particularly is something that has enormous potential
quotes.source: Alabama Reflector interview, April 2024
quotes.context: Discussing blockchain technology and his support from crypto PACs, emphasizing he believes in informed regulation

Shomari Figures.notes: Rep. Shomari Figures is a freshman congressman who took office on January 3, 2025. While he has expressed support for technological innovation, particularly in the cryptocurrency and blockchain space (serving on the House Agriculture Committee's Subcommittee on Commodity Markets, Digital Assets, and Rural Development), there is no substantial public record of him discussing artificial intelligence specifically. His public statements have focused on civil rights, voting rights, healthcare, infrastructure, and economic development. The crypto PAC 'Protect Progress' spent $2.7 million supporting his campaign. As a new member of Congress, he may not yet have developed or publicly articulated positions on AI policy, safety, or regulation. More time in office may be needed before substantive AI policy positions emerge.

Yassamin Ansari.summary: Rep. Yassamin Ansari's AI stance appears pragmatic and focused on infrastructure, regulation, and national security concerns. Her public statements emphasize the need for U.S. leadership in AI while addressing practical challenges like data center water usage and AI misuse through impersonation. She views AI as important for national security and economic competitiveness but focuses on immediate regulatory needs rather than long-term transformative or existential concerns.

quotes.quote: For our national security and economic prosperity, we absolutely need to be global leaders on the artificial intelligence front.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing on AI data centers, April 2025
quotes.context: Testifying about AI data center infrastructure needs in Arizona, emphasizing U.S. competitiveness

quotes.quote: To do that, we will need to keep building more data centers and the infrastructure to support them, but we also need to do that in a way that's smart, ensuring lasting resiliency in these systems and our energy and water.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing on AI data centers, April 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the need for sustainable AI infrastructure development

quotes.quote: If we really do want to dominate this industry as a country, we need it to be future-proof.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing, reported by MeriTalk
quotes.context: Speaking about water resource management for AI data centers in Arizona

quotes.quote: [Data centers aren't] only straining an already limited resource in our state, but the result also means that water rates are going up for families.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing, reported by MeriTalk
quotes.context: Expressing concern about AI data centers' impact on Arizona's water supply and families

quotes.quote: There have been multiple recent incidents of AI being used to falsely impersonate federal officials, posing a grave threat to our national security.
quotes.source: Press release for AI Impersonation Prevention Act, 2025
quotes.context: Announcing legislation to prohibit AI-generated impersonation of federal officials

quotes.quote: AI will only continue to become more powerful and accessible, so we must act now to establish stringent guardrails and accountability–that's why we need my AI Impersonation Prevention Act.
quotes.source: Press release for AI Impersonation Prevention Act, 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the rationale for her AI regulation bill focused on preventing misuse

quotes.quote: I do strongly believe that the greatest energy source is the energy that we don't use, and the best way to ensure energy reliability is to innovate.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing on AI data centers, April 2025
quotes.context: Discussing energy efficiency approaches for AI infrastructure

quotes.quote: A deeply racist AI video posted by the president of the United States—on the brink of a government shutdown and a health care crisis he created.
quotes.source: X/Twitter post, 2025
quotes.context: Criticizing President Trump for posting AI-generated content she deemed racist

quotes.quote: By 2028, it is expected to be the nation's second largest concentration of data centers behind only Northern Virginia.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing on AI data centers, April 2025
quotes.context: Describing Arizona's growing role in AI infrastructure

quotes.quote: Arizona public Service, which is the largest power provider in my state, has projected that data centers will account for 55% of its power needs by 2031.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee hearing on AI data centers, April 2025
quotes.context: Highlighting the massive energy demands AI infrastructure will place on Arizona

Yassamin Ansari.notes: Rep. Ansari's public statements on AI are limited and primarily focused on practical policy concerns rather than philosophical or long-term implications. Her main areas of focus include: (1) U.S. competitiveness and the need to be 'global leaders' in AI; (2) Infrastructure challenges, particularly water and energy usage by data centers in Arizona; (3) Immediate regulatory needs like preventing AI impersonation of federal officials. She introduced the AI Impersonation Prevention Act of 2025 as her primary AI legislation. She sits on the House Oversight Committee's Cybersecurity, Information Technology, and Government Innovation Subcommittee. Notably absent from her public statements are discussions of: AGI timelines, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, China as a competitor, or specific AI companies or leaders. Her stance appears pragmatic and focused on constituent concerns (water rates, energy costs) while supporting U.S. AI development. She recognizes AI as 'powerful' and important for national security but hasn't engaged publicly with deeper philosophical or safety questions. As a freshman member of Congress (sworn in January 2025), her AI policy positions may still be developing.

Abraham J. Hamadeh.summary: Limited public information available on AI-specific views. Hamadeh has focused primarily on Big Tech censorship concerns and has questioned Meta's relationship with China regarding technology cooperation, but has not made substantial public statements specifically about artificial intelligence policy, development, or risks.

quotes.quote: promote peace through strength by reestablishing Trump-era sanctions on China and Iran

quotes.context: Foreign policy position emphasizing confrontational stance toward China

Abraham J. Hamadeh.notes: Abraham Hamadeh is a freshman U.S. Representative (R-AZ-8) who took office in January 2025. While he has expressed concerns about Big Tech censorship and China's technological competition with the United States, he has not made substantial public statements specifically about artificial intelligence, machine learning, AGI, AI safety, or related technical issues. His technology-related statements focus primarily on: (1) opposition to social media censorship by tech companies, (2) concerns about Meta's alleged cooperation with the Chinese Communist Party, and (3) general awareness of US-China technology competition in areas like space-based solar and directed energy weapons. As a member of the House Armed Services Committee with a background as an Army intelligence officer, he may engage with AI issues in military/defense contexts, but no public statements on AI military applications, autonomous weapons, or AI in intelligence were found. The limited record suggests he has not yet developed or articulated a comprehensive position on AI policy, regulation, or development. Given his recent entry to Congress and focus on other issues (border security, election integrity, veterans affairs), AI does not appear to be a priority policy area for him at this time.

Lateefah Simon.summary: Lateefah Simon has expressed limited public statements specifically about AI. Her primary AI-related position is support for innovation in emerging technologies including cryptocurrency, artificial intelligence, and blockchain, with an emphasis on establishing regulatory frameworks that balance technological progress with consumer protection. She has also raised concerns about CSU partnerships with AI companies and Kaiser's potential use of AI to replace therapists.

quotes.quote: committed to embracing the new landscape of innovation, which includes cryptocurrency, artificial intelligence, and blockchain
quotes.source: Campaign website/Meet the Freshmen profile, November 2024
quotes.context: Simon's campaign platform on innovation and technology, expressing openness to emerging technologies while calling for regulatory frameworks.

quotes.quote: hopes to help establish a regulatory framework that creates an environment to allow for technological progress and consumer protection
quotes.source: Campaign website/Meet the Freshmen profile, November 2024
quotes.context: Her approach to technology regulation, emphasizing both innovation and protection.

quotes.quote: I opposed the GENIUS Act because I have strong concerns about conflicts of interest and the lack of meaningful guardrails
quotes.source: Congressional statement on cryptocurrency legislation, July 2025
quotes.context: While focused on cryptocurrency, this shows her regulatory approach to emerging technologies, emphasizing the need for guardrails and protection against conflicts of interest.

quotes.quote: We need regulation rooted in justice... protecting those in our communities who already utilize these technologies
quotes.source: Congressional statement on digital assets, July 2025
quotes.context: Her framework for approaching technology regulation with an equity lens.

quotes.quote: concerns about ICE on campuses, the partnership of the CSU with different AI companies
quotes.source: California Faculty Association organizing conference, February 2025

quotes.quote: Not only is Kaiser still under state monitoring, it's now trying to set the stage to lay off therapists, push patients into AI-based therapies
quotes.source: NUHW website discussing Kaiser healthcare issues
quotes.context: Reference to concerns about Kaiser Permanente's potential use of AI in mental health care to replace human therapists, an issue relevant to her district and labor advocacy.

quotes.quote: It's the home of 21st century technology companies and life-saving medical innovation
quotes.source: Working Families Party response speech, March 2025
quotes.context: Describing her district which includes Oakland, Alameda, and Berkeley, acknowledging the technology sector's presence.

quotes.quote: The phone calls, they matter; the letters matter, the actions matter
quotes.source: CFA organizing conference, February 2025
quotes.context: Speaking at a conference where AI in education was a concern, emphasizing grassroots organizing and advocacy.

Lateefah Simon.notes: Lateefah Simon, who took office in January 2025 as Representative for California's 12th Congressional District (Oakland, Berkeley, Alameda), has made very limited public statements specifically about AI. Her district is home to major technology companies, and she previously served as president of MeadowFund (created by Patricia Quillin, wife of Netflix co-founder Reed Hastings) and on the CSU Board of Trustees. Her AI-related positions appear to focus on: 1) Supporting innovation in emerging technologies while calling for consumer protection and regulatory frameworks; 2) Concerns about equity and justice in technology regulation; 3) Implicit concerns about CSU partnerships with AI companies (raised at a faculty conference she attended); and 4) Concerns about Kaiser Permanente potentially using AI to replace human therapists. She has not made public statements about AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, or international AI competition. Her overall approach appears pragmatic and focused on worker protection, equity, and preventing corporate conflicts of interest rather than on the transformative potential or risks of AI itself. As a freshman congresswoman who just took office, she may develop more detailed AI policy positions over time.

Adam Gray.summary: After extensive research, no public statements or positions on artificial intelligence could be found for Congressman Adam Gray. He has only been in Congress since January 2025 and his legislative focus has been primarily on agriculture, water rights, healthcare, and immigration issues relevant to California's Central Valley.
Adam Gray.notes: Adam Gray is a freshman congressman who took office on January 3, 2025, representing California's 13th Congressional District. He is a moderate Democrat and whip of the Blue Dog Coalition. His legislative priorities have focused on agriculture, water resources, healthcare access, and immigration reform - issues critical to his Central Valley district. While he serves on the House Agriculture Committee's Subcommittee on Commodity Markets, Digital Assets, and Rural Development (which could involve some technology policy), no public statements about AI have been identified. One source mentioned 'AI regulation' as a top issue during his 2024 campaign, but no specific positions or quotes could be found. His district includes Merced County where UC Merced is located, and he has supported agricultural technology initiatives including a groundbreaking for an AgTEC Innovation Center focused on agricultural technology and automation. However, these efforts appear focused on traditional agricultural technology rather than AI specifically. Given his recent arrival in Congress and focus on district-specific issues, he has not yet developed or articulated a public position on AI policy, regulation, or related concerns.

Sam T. Liccardo.summary: Sam Liccardo is a pro-innovation, moderate Democrat who views AI as transformative technology requiring a 'Goldilocks approach' between excessive regulation and unchecked development. He emphasizes competition with China, advocates for incremental regulation focused on outcomes rather than technology itself, and prioritizes practical AI applications over speculative concerns, while supporting safety standards and transparency.

quotes.quote: Artificial Intelligence (AI) will transform our economy and our lives in ways unlike any other technology in memory.
quotes.source: Campaign website - Innovation Economy platform, October 2024
quotes.context: Liccardo's foundational statement on AI's transformative potential, emphasizing its unprecedented impact compared to previous technologies.

quotes.quote: Either you've got the tech-bashers, and the bed's too cold. Or you've got the oligarch prostrators, and the bed's too warm. And we're looking for the Goldilocks approach.
quotes.source: GovAI Coalition Summit panel, November 2025
quotes.context: Describing his philosophy of balanced AI regulation that avoids both excessive tech-bashing and uncritical acceptance of tech industry positions.

quotes.quote: This agenda is about empowering innovators, not oligarchs.
quotes.source: Interview with Decoded, September 2025
quotes.context: Explaining his approach to AI policy and distinguishing between supporting innovation broadly versus catering to large tech companies.

quotes.quote: Rather than imposing licensing and registration mandates or strictly regulating model development, Congress should define undesirable outcomes and regulate incrementally
quotes.source: New Democrat Coalition Innovation Agenda, September 2025
quotes.context: Outlining his preferred regulatory approach that focuses on harmful outcomes rather than restricting AI development itself.

quotes.quote: Regulations should penalize harmful misuse of AI, including fraud, deception, and invasions of individual privacy, rather than penalizing the underlying tools, with case-by-case exceptions for the development of models that may inherently pose some form of threat (i.e., Artificial General Intelligence).
quotes.source: New Democrat Coalition Innovation Agenda, September 2025
quotes.context: One of the few instances where Liccardo specifically mentions AGI, acknowledging it as a potential exception requiring special consideration.

quotes.quote: The important issue, seems to me, is for us to recognize as policymakers that we need to accelerate our work, rather than pretending that we can slow down the rest of the world.
quotes.source: Axios interview, July 2025
quotes.context: Responding to concerns about rapid AI deployment and worker displacement, emphasizing the futility of trying to slow AI development.

quotes.quote: Trade policy must reflect China's status as a competitive adversary, but recognize that stalling U.S.-China trade undermines U.S. growth, and hurts both American consumers and tech manufacturers.
quotes.source: New Democrat Coalition Innovation Agenda, September 2025
quotes.context: Acknowledging China as a competitor while advocating for nuanced trade policy rather than complete decoupling.

quotes.quote: There appears no assurance that European legislators will tweak their rules to accommodate the imperative of competitive innovation in a moment when many global actors—in China or Russia, for example—will simply ignore the regulations that bind responsible actors.
quotes.source: Campaign website - Innovation Economy platform, October 2024
quotes.context: Warning about the competitive disadvantage of overregulation when adversaries like China and Russia won't follow the same rules.

quotes.quote: DeepSeek's advances in AI compute efficiency as America's 2025 'Sputnik moment.' In fact, we've witnessed several 'Sputniks' in recent years, with growing Chinese technological advantage in areas such as energy storage, hypersonic missiles, solar manufacturing, biotechnology, and electric vehicles—indeed, in 7 out of 10 key advanced industries.
quotes.source: New Democrat Coalition Innovation Agenda, September 2025
quotes.context: Framing Chinese AI advances as a wake-up call for American competitiveness, drawing parallels to the Cold War space race.

quotes.quote: Congress needs to step in to address the negative outcomes–fraud and malicious use of AI– without meddling in the regulation of the technology in ways that will undermine innovation necessary for medical research, climate change mitigation, and a host of other critical uses.
quotes.source: Campaign website - Innovation Economy platform, October 2024
quotes.context: Articulating his view that regulation should target harmful applications while preserving AI's beneficial uses for solving major challenges.

Sam T. Liccardo.notes:
Sam Liccardo is a freshman Democratic Congressman representing Silicon Valley (CA-16) and chairs the New Democrat Coalition's Innovation & Technology Working Group. His AI stance is notably pragmatic and pro-innovation while maintaining concerns about safety:

China/Foreign Competition: Extensively references China as a competitive adversary in AI, citing DeepSeek as a 'Sputnik moment' and noting Chinese advantages in 7 out of 10 key advanced industries. Also mentions Russia and Europe as regulatory concerns.

AGI Views: Not 'AGI-pilled' in the traditional sense. Makes only one explicit mention of AGI in his policy documents, noting it as a 'case-by-case exception' that may require special regulatory treatment. Does not engage with AGI timelines or transformative AGI scenarios.

Transformative vs. Overhyped: Strongly believes AI is transformative ('unlike any other technology in memory') but focuses on practical applications (medical research, climate change, government efficiency) rather than speculative futures.

Existential Risk: Acknowledges AGI as potentially requiring special consideration but does not extensively discuss existential risk. His focus is on immediate harms (fraud, privacy violations, bias) rather than catastrophic scenarios.

Safety/Alignment: Advocates for safety through 'incremental regulation,' transparency standards, and outcome-based rules. Supports voluntary collaboration with industry, NIST standards, and avoiding regulations that favor large companies over startups. Mentions meeting with Sam Altman and Jensen Huang.

Key Relationships: Has met with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman and Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang. Consulted 'a couple hundred' people in Silicon Valley including researchers, startup founders, and VCs before crafting his Innovation Agenda.

Regulatory Philosophy: Advocates for the 'Goldilocks approach' - avoiding both tech-bashing and 'oligarch prostration.' Prefers regulating harmful outcomes rather than restricting model development. Opposes licensing mandates and strict development regulations.

Notable: Used AI voice cloning technology (Speechify) during his 2024 campaign when he had laryngitis, demonstrating practical comfort with AI tools.

George Whitesides.summary: George Whitesides is a newly elected congressman (sworn in January 2025) with extensive aerospace and technology background. While he strongly advocates for American leadership in science, technology, and innovation, there is very limited public record of specific statements about artificial intelligence. His most notable AI-related comment came in a January 2026 hearing where he criticized budget cuts to scientific agencies.

quotes.quote: I think what's happened to American science is reprehensible, and the cuts that have been proposed –– and that I fear are about to be proposed again in a second presidential budget –– are attacking one of the core pillars of American strength
quotes.source: House Science, Space and Technology Committee hearing on AI Action Plan, January 14, 2026
quotes.context: Whitesides was expressing concern about proposed budget cuts to agencies like NIST that would impact AI-related efforts and scientific research during a hearing on the Trump administration's AI Action Plan

quotes.quote: I think it is crucial that all of us who believe in the importance of science and innovation and technology speak up against the attacks that we have seen in the past year, both against funding, but more importantly, against the dedicated Americans who both in public service and funded by public funds are doing the work to make our world better
quotes.source: House Science, Space and Technology Committee hearing, January 14, 2026
quotes.context: Continuing his remarks at the AI Action Plan hearing, defending scientific workforce and funding in the context of AI development

quotes.quote: As an entrepreneur, he is firmly committed to maintaining American leadership in innovation and its accompanying job creation engine
quotes.source: Congressional website - Committees and Caucuses page
quotes.context: Description of his commitment to American technological leadership on his official House website

quotes.quote: While technology has provided incredible opportunities for connection and communication, it has also introduced huge new challenges, including online safety risks, cyberbullying, and the proliferation of deepfake AI-generated imagery
quotes.source: Campaign website policy page, 2024
quotes.context: From his campaign platform discussing teenage mental health and social media, one of the few direct mentions of AI technology (deepfakes)

quotes.quote: Rep. Whitesides focuses on the importance of cutting-edge technology and cybersecurity in maintaining national defense superiority, especially in areas like aerospace innovation and defense technologies
quotes.source: Official House website describing his committee work
quotes.context: Description of his role on the House Armed Services Cyber, Information Technologies, and Innovation Subcommittee

quotes.quote: I am honored to serve on the Science, Space, and Technology Committee, where I will work to ensure that the US remains at the forefront of innovation in space exploration, technology, and research
quotes.source: Statement upon joining House Science, Space, and Technology Committee, January 2025
quotes.context: Announcement of committee assignment emphasizing American technological leadership

quotes.quote: research and innovation as crucial elements to America's future competitiveness
quotes.source: Official House website
quotes.context: Description of his understanding from serving on advisory committees for Caltech and Princeton

quotes.quote: By formalizing NASA's partnership with the Department of Energy through bipartisan legislation, we can ensure greater efficiency, oversight, and progress in space exploration and energy innovation
quotes.source: Statement on DOE and NASA Interagency Research Coordination Act, March 2025
quotes.context: Discussing his bipartisan legislation to strengthen collaboration between agencies, emphasizing innovation and American leadership

quotes.quote: Our nation faces evolving challenges in global security and technological advancement, and I am committed to working across the aisle to ensure that our military is equipped to meet these challenges and that the U.S. remains at the forefront of innovation
quotes.source: Statement upon joining House Armed Services Committee, January 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing technological advancement in national defense context

quotes.quote: We made a deliberate decision to build a modern police department powered by technology, intelligence, and accountability
quotes.source: Lancaster Mayor Rex Parris, quoted in press release about Whitesides securing funding, January 2026
quotes.context: While not Whitesides' own words, this relates to his support for technology-powered public safety initiatives

George Whitesides.notes: George Whitesides is a freshman congressman who was only sworn in on January 3, 2025.
