quotes.quote: The second fastest growing industry in Northeastern Pennsylvania is energized land, which will help power these data centers. I look forward to these investments and encourage companies to look to Northeastern Pennsylvania as a home for economic and technological advancements
quotes.source: Times Leader, April 2025
quotes.context: Promoting his region as a destination for data center development

Robert P. Bresnahan, Jr..notes: Rep. Bresnahan's public statements about AI are almost exclusively focused on economic development and job creation through data center infrastructure in his Pennsylvania district. He has not made substantive public statements about AI capabilities, AGI, existential risk, safety, alignment, or the transformative potential of AI technology itself. His mentions of China relate to general national security legislation (the Time to Choose Act) rather than AI-specific competition. He appears to view AI primarily through an economic lens - as an infrastructure investment opportunity requiring reduced regulation and increased private sector development. His stock trading in AI-related companies (Credo Technology) while promoting data centers has generated controversy. He has worked with EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin and the Trump administration to promote natural gas development to power AI data centers, including efforts to overturn fracking bans. No evidence of engagement with AI safety community, technical AI policy debates, or concerns about AI risks beyond general economic regulation.

Pablo Jos\u00e9 Hern\u00e1ndez.summary: Pablo José Hernández views AI as a transformative technological revolution that Puerto Rico must actively engage with rather than be a passive bystander. He demonstrates a balanced, pragmatic approach, acknowledging both opportunities (job creation, healthcare breakthroughs, energy innovation) and challenges (job displacement, threats to artists). He has taken concrete legislative action by sponsoring the AI in Health Care Efficiency and Study Act and advocating for U.S. leadership in AI through data center expansion.

quotes.quote: Puerto Rico cannot be a passive bystander in the technological revolution that is already transforming the world.
quotes.source: Press release after meeting with Sam Altman, July 28, 2025
quotes.context: Hernández's opening statement on employment impacts after meeting with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, emphasizing the need for Puerto Rico to engage with AI actively.

quotes.quote: AI will eliminate certain jobs, particularly in repetitive fields like customer service, but it will also create new professions we can't even imagine yet—just as social media gave rise to influencers and digital content creators.
quotes.source: Press release after meeting with Sam Altman, July 28, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI's impact on employment, showing understanding of both job displacement and creation.

quotes.quote: Moreover, it's already boosting productivity and making life easier for many small and mid-sized businesses.
quotes.source: Press release after meeting with Sam Altman, July 28, 2025
quotes.context: Highlighting current practical benefits of AI for businesses.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence consumes enormous amounts of electricity and will, out of necessity, drive the development of new energy technologies—especially renewable sources like solar.
quotes.source: Press release after meeting with Sam Altman, July 28, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI's energy demands and potential benefits for renewable energy development.

quotes.quote: This can be strategically integrated into the reconstruction of our electrical grid, potentially creating energy abundance that finally helps stabilize electricity costs in Puerto Rico.
quotes.source: Press release after meeting with Sam Altman, July 28, 2025
quotes.context: Connecting AI energy needs to Puerto Rico's infrastructure challenges and opportunities.

quotes.quote: As a Puerto Rican, I voiced concerns about our artistic community. How will our musicians, writers, and creators compete if a machine can imitate their style and produce nearly identical art more cheaply and accessibly?
quotes.source: Press release after meeting with Sam Altman, July 28, 2025
quotes.context: Expressing concerns about AI's impact on Puerto Rican artists and cultural creators during the meeting with Sam Altman.

quotes.quote: It is projected that AI will accelerate medical breakthroughs that would normally take ten years in just one. For a people with so many chronic conditions, this is not science fiction: it is real hope.
quotes.source: Press release (Spanish version) after meeting with Sam Altman, July 28, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI's potential to dramatically accelerate healthcare innovations, particularly relevant for Puerto Rico's health challenges.

quotes.quote: Congress must uphold public policies that support the expansion of data centers and the use of renewable energy, in order to maintain U.S. leadership in artificial intelligence.
quotes.source: Congressional hearing 'Unleashing a New Golden Age: Using Federal Lands to Power Technological Innovation,' March 2025
quotes.context: Testifying before Congress on the need for infrastructure to support AI development and maintain U.S. competitiveness.

quotes.quote: Puerto Rico must actively engage in the AI revolution to thrive in the evolving landscape.
quotes.source: Summary of meeting with Sam Altman, July 27, 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing the imperative for Puerto Rico to participate in AI development rather than remain on the sidelines.

quotes.quote: AI poses both challenges and opportunities for Puerto Rico.
quotes.source: Summary of meeting with Sam Altman, July 27, 2025
quotes.context: Overall assessment showing balanced understanding of AI's dual nature.

Pablo Jos\u00e9 Hern\u00e1ndez.notes: Pablo José Hernández is the Resident Commissioner of Puerto Rico (Democrat, elected 2024, youngest ever at age 33). He has demonstrated active engagement with AI policy through: (1) Meeting with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman in July 2025 along with ~20 members of Congress; (2) Sponsoring H.R. 7064, the 'AI in Health Care Efficiency and Study Act' (introduced January 14, 2026); (3) Testifying before Congress on AI infrastructure and data centers. His approach is pragmatic and focused on practical applications (healthcare, energy, employment) rather than theoretical concerns about AGI or existential risk. He specifically mentions Sam Altman/OpenAI but not other AI companies or figures. His focus is on ensuring Puerto Rico and the U.S. maintain competitiveness in AI development. Notably absent from his public statements: discussions of China or international AI competition, AI safety/alignment concerns, existential risk, or AGI scenarios. His perspective is grounded in near-term economic and social impacts, particularly as they affect Puerto Rico's unique challenges (healthcare needs, energy infrastructure, economic development).

Sheri Biggs.summary: No public statements or positions on AI could be found for Congresswoman Sheri Biggs. Despite serving on the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology (including the Research and Technology Subcommittee), she has not made documented public comments about artificial intelligence as of January 2026.
Sheri Biggs.notes: Congresswoman Sheri Biggs was sworn into office on January 3, 2025, representing South Carolina's 3rd Congressional District. She serves on the House Committee on Science, Space, and Technology (including the Research and Technology Subcommittee), Committee on Foreign Affairs (East Asia and Pacific, Western Hemisphere), and Committee on Homeland Security (Border Security and Enforcement, Transportation and Maritime Security). Despite her committee assignments that would naturally involve AI policy discussions, no public statements about AI could be located through searches of her official congressional website, press releases, or public remarks from her first year in office. Her public focus has primarily been on border security, Second Amendment rights, veterans' affairs, fiscal conservatism, and faith-based initiatives. She has discussed China in the context of critical minerals and U.S. dependence, and the Development Finance Corporation's role in countering China's Belt and Road Initiative, but not in relation to AI or technology competition.

Craig A. Goldman.summary: Insufficient information available. Craig A. Goldman is a newly elected U.S. Representative from Texas's 12th Congressional District (assumed office January 2025) who serves on the House Energy and Commerce Committee and is part of a Data Privacy Working Group. However, no public statements, speeches, or quotes specifically about artificial intelligence have been found in available sources.
Craig A. Goldman.notes: Craig A. Goldman is a freshman congressman who was sworn into office on January 3, 2025. He serves on the House Energy and Commerce Committee and its subcommittees on Commerce, Manufacturing, and Trade; Communications and Technology; and Energy. He is also a member of the House Data Privacy Working Group established in February 2025. His legislative focus to date has been on energy policy (Homeowner Energy Freedom Act), broadband infrastructure (SPEED for Broadband Infrastructure Act), and Middle East policy (Abraham Accords Caucus co-chair). Given that he is very early in his congressional career and his committee assignments touch on technology policy, he may address AI issues in the future, but no such statements are currently available in the public record. The House Energy and Commerce Committee has held hearings on AI in manufacturing, which Goldman would have attended as a committee member, but no specific quotes or statements from him on AI topics have been documented.

Brandon Gill.summary: Congressman Brandon Gill (R-TX-26), who took office in January 2025, has not made substantial public statements specifically about artificial intelligence policy. While he supports STEM education and technology innovation generally, there is insufficient public record of his views on AI-specific issues.
Brandon Gill.notes: Brandon Gill is a freshman congressman who was sworn in on January 3, 2025. He is the youngest Republican member of Congress and serves on the House Judiciary, Budget, and Oversight Committees, including the DOGE Subcommittee. His legislative focus has been primarily on immigration, border security, and government operations. He has participated in the Congressional App Challenge to encourage STEM education among students in his district, making general statements about supporting 'technology and innovation,' but has not made specific public statements about artificial intelligence policy, regulation, safety, or strategic competition. As a new member of Congress, he may not yet have developed or publicly articulated detailed positions on AI-related issues. His background includes working as an investment banker and founding the DC Enquirer, a conservative news outlet, before entering politics.

Julie Johnson.summary: Rep. Julie Johnson views AI primarily through the lens of national security and election integrity. Her public statements focus on protecting American technological leadership from foreign adversaries, particularly China, and preventing AI-generated disinformation from undermining democratic elections. She has not made public statements about AGI, existential risk, or AI safety/alignment.

quotes.quote: The health of our democracy is on the line as deepfakes and AI-generated content are being used to manipulate voters.
quotes.source: Press release introducing Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Johnson introduced bipartisan legislation to ban misleading AI-generated content in political ads and protect election integrity.

quotes.quote: If we don't act now, our elections will be flooded with increased misinformation that threatens our ability to determine fact from fiction.
quotes.source: Press release on Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the urgency of regulating AI use in elections to prevent voter manipulation.

quotes.quote: artificial intelligence is the next major challenge we must confront
quotes.source: Press release on Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Describing AI as a critical issue for election reform alongside deepfakes and algorithmic disinformation.

quotes.quote: AI is reshaping how voters receive information—and how bad actors can exploit it
quotes.source: Press release on Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the transformative impact of AI on information dissemination and its potential for misuse.

quotes.quote: America's technological leadership is one of our greatest strategic advantages — and we cannot allow foreign adversaries to steal it, risking our national security.
quotes.source: Press release on Stop Stealing Our Chips Act, December 3, 2025
quotes.context: Co-introducing legislation to prevent smuggling of American AI chips to China and other adversaries.

quotes.quote: This is especially important in my district, home to Texas Instruments headquarters — one of the top semiconductor companies in the world — as well as Qorvo, which produces critical components for F-35s and other key defense technologies.
quotes.source: Press release on Stop Stealing Our Chips Act, December 3, 2025
quotes.context: Highlighting the importance of protecting semiconductor companies in her district from technology theft.

quotes.quote: Trust in our elections is the foundation of the peaceful transfer of power, and without it, our democracy is at risk.
quotes.source: Press release on Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Emphasizing the democratic stakes of preventing AI-generated election misinformation.

quotes.quote: My Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act protects every American's right to cast a ballot based on truth, not manufactured deception.
quotes.source: Press release on Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Describing her legislation as protecting voters from AI-generated deception.

quotes.quote: We are living in the Wild West era of AI practices in political campaigns.
quotes.source: Endorsement quote from End Citizens United in press release, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Quote from an organization endorsing Johnson's bill, reflecting the unregulated nature of AI in politics.

quotes.quote: As AI gets more advanced and deeply integrated into our daily lives, it's becoming increasingly difficult to separate fact from fiction.
quotes.source: Press release on Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act, September 11, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the growing sophistication of AI technology and its implications for truth and misinformation.

Julie Johnson.notes: Rep. Julie Johnson (D-TX-32) is a freshman congresswoman sworn in January 2025. Her AI-related public statements are limited to two main areas: (1) election security and preventing AI-generated deepfakes/disinformation, and (2) national security concerns about China obtaining advanced U.S. AI chips. She co-sponsored the 'Stop Stealing Our Chips Act' with Rep. Tom Kean to prevent AI chip smuggling to China, emphasizing protection of companies like Texas Instruments and Qorvo in her district. She also introduced the bipartisan 'Protect Elections from Deceptive AI Act' to ban misleading AI content in political ads. Johnson frames AI as transformative technology that requires regulation but has not publicly discussed AGI, existential risk, AI safety/alignment, or specific AI companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, or DeepMind. Her approach is pragmatic and focused on immediate threats (election integrity, technology theft by adversaries) rather than long-term AI risks. She emphasizes bipartisan cooperation on AI issues and views technology leadership as a strategic national advantage.

Mike Kennedy.summary: Congressman Mike Kennedy (R-UT), a physician and attorney, views AI as transformative technology that should augment rather than replace human capabilities, particularly in healthcare. He advocates for careful, precise regulation that balances innovation with responsibility, and is deeply concerned about Chinese threats to American AI leadership and intellectual property. Kennedy has introduced multiple AI-related bills focusing on algorithmic accountability, scientific discovery acceleration, and protecting U.S. research from foreign adversaries.

quotes.quote: We need surgical precision when we're doing these things, especially when it comes to an extremely valuable technology that could be used for bad but it also could be used for good
quotes.source: Regulating AI Podcast interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy discussing the need for careful AI regulation while acknowledging AI's dual-use nature

quotes.quote: Data is power, and if we can have accurate data and analysis from AI, I'm very excited about the possibilities not only in healthcare but throughout our country
quotes.source: Regulating AI Podcast interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy expressing enthusiasm about AI's transformative potential across sectors

quotes.quote: I don't see artificial intelligence as replacing but augmenting what a doctor does
quotes.source: Regulating AI Podcast interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy's view on AI in healthcare as a tool to enhance rather than replace human expertise

quotes.quote: Social media companies have built powerful algorithms that prioritize engagement and profit, too often overlooking their role in amplifying dangerous content
quotes.source: Algorithm Accountability Act press release, November 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy introducing legislation to hold platforms accountable for algorithmic harms

quotes.quote: The Algorithm Accountability Act is a responsible step that establishes a clear duty of care for these platforms, ensuring they are accountable for preventing foreseeable harm caused by their algorithmic feeds
quotes.source: Algorithm Accountability Act press release, November 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy describing his bipartisan legislation to modernize Section 230

quotes.quote: I am proud to introduce the GENESIS Act to codify President Trump's Genesis Mission into law. This is a pivotal step toward unleashing American ingenuity through artificial intelligence
quotes.source: GENESIS Act press release, December 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy introducing legislation to accelerate AI-driven scientific discovery at national laboratories

quotes.quote: The legislation empowers the federal government to harnesses artificial intelligence to accelerate scientific discovery, strengthen national security, and keep America ahead in the global AI race
quotes.source: GENESIS Act press release, December 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy describing his bill's goals to maintain U.S. AI leadership

quotes.quote: This is about protecting our universities, our businesses, our national labs and our future from foreign regimes that seek to harvest the fruits of our innovation while eroding our competitive edge
quotes.source: Salt Lake Tribune op-ed, August 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy discussing Chinese threats to American research and innovation, including AI capabilities

quotes.quote: For more than a decade now, I have called attention to and warned that the CCP represents a serious and persistent threat to our national security
quotes.source: Salt Lake Tribune op-ed, August 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy's long-standing concern about Chinese Communist Party threats to U.S. technology and research

quotes.quote: The idea that the best surgeon in the country could remote in… and actually do a surgery on somebody is a really interesting possibility
quotes.source: Regulating AI Podcast interview, April 2025
quotes.context: Kennedy discussing AI-enabled telemedicine and robotic surgery to expand healthcare access

Mike Kennedy.notes: Congressman Mike Kennedy (R-UT-3) is a family physician and attorney elected to Congress in 2024. His AI policy focus centers on three main areas: (1) Healthcare applications where AI augments medical professionals; (2) Algorithmic accountability for social media platforms to prevent harm; and (3) Protecting American AI research and innovation from Chinese theft and espionage. He frequently references China and the CCP as threats to U.S. AI leadership and has introduced the U.S. Research Protection Act to safeguard American research. Kennedy emphasizes the 'dual-use' nature of AI technology - capable of both good and harm - and advocates for 'surgical precision' in regulation. He introduced the GENESIS Act to accelerate AI-driven scientific discovery and the Algorithm Accountability Act to hold platforms accountable for algorithmic harms. He serves on the House Science, Space, and Technology Committee. Notably absent from his public statements: discussions of AGI, existential risk, AI safety alignment research, or specific AI companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, or Google. His approach is pragmatic and focused on near-term applications, competition with China, and preventing algorithmic harms rather than long-term speculative risks.

John J. McGuire III.summary: Rep. John McGuire (R-VA-5) has made very limited public statements about AI. His primary focus appears to be on AI's energy requirements and competition with China, particularly concerning energy infrastructure. He appears interested in AI superintelligence as a practical tool but has not articulated comprehensive views on AI safety, alignment, or existential risk.

quotes.quote: Yesterday, I asked an AI chat box, how many acres of solar panels would you need to power AI in the U.S. by 2030? Anyone take a guess how much that would be? A thousand acres? Actually, let me see here. It's way more than a thousand acres. It's 500,000 acres. That's half the size of Delaware.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee Hearing 'Shaping Tomorrow: The Future of Artificial Intelligence,' September 17, 2025
quotes.context: McGuire was questioning witnesses about AI's energy demands and making the case for fossil fuels and nuclear power over solar energy to power AI infrastructure.

quotes.quote: We should be investing in fossil fuels and nuclear. Small modular nuclear reactors. As we discussed earlier, we only need 500 acres to do the same job nationally. By 2030, we should be using coal, natural gas, traditional nuclear power until [small nuclear reactors] are ready, not solar panels.
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee Hearing 'Shaping Tomorrow: The Future of Artificial Intelligence,' September 17, 2025
quotes.context: McGuire advocating for traditional energy sources to power AI development rather than renewable energy.

quotes.quote: Is China building thousands of solar farms to power their AI? Yes, or no?
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee Hearing 'Shaping Tomorrow: The Future of Artificial Intelligence,' September 17, 2025
quotes.context: McGuire questioning witnesses about China's approach to powering AI infrastructure, framing AI development as a competitive issue with China.

quotes.quote: Mr. Hammond and Ms. Fabrizio, what are some of the ways AI superintelligence might actually help us solve the energy problem?
quotes.source: House Oversight Committee Hearing 'Shaping Tomorrow: The Future of Artificial Intelligence,' September 17, 2025
quotes.context: McGuire asking witnesses about potential applications of AI superintelligence, specifically regarding energy solutions.

quotes.quote: The United States must prioritize quantum technology in order to promote peace through strength. Quantum technology is critical to our national security.
quotes.source: Press release regarding Quantum Encryption Readiness and Resilience Act, August 2025
quotes.context: While about quantum computing rather than AI specifically, this shows McGuire's focus on technology competition with adversaries from a national security perspective.

John J. McGuire III.notes: Rep. McGuire has made extremely limited public statements about AI. His only substantive comments come from a single congressional hearing in September 2025 where he served on the Cybersecurity, Information Technology, and Government Innovation Subcommittee. His questions focused almost exclusively on: (1) AI's energy infrastructure requirements, (2) competition with China, and (3) advocacy for fossil fuels/nuclear over renewable energy for powering AI. He used the term 'AI superintelligence' in his questioning, suggesting some familiarity with advanced AI concepts, but did not elaborate on views about AGI timelines, risks, or governance. He did not discuss AI safety, alignment, existential risk, AI companies, or key figures in the field. His technology-related legislative activity includes co-sponsoring the Quantum Encryption Readiness and Resilience Act, which focuses on quantum computing threats from adversaries. Overall, insufficient public statements exist to characterize his comprehensive views on AI policy, though his limited comments suggest a focus on national competitiveness and energy policy rather than AI-specific governance or safety concerns.

Eugene Simon Vindman.summary: Eugene Vindman views AI primarily through a national security and economic competitiveness lens, with particular focus on China as a strategic competitor. He supports AI innovation for economic growth while advocating for clear regulations and consumer protections, emphasizing the need to maintain U.S. technological leadership against foreign adversaries.

quotes.quote: AI has the potential to fuel our economic growth for the coming decades but also presents a host of dangers.
quotes.source: Campaign website/Meet the Freshmen profile, 2024
quotes.context: Vindman's core position on AI balancing opportunity with risk

quotes.quote: It is important that Congress and regulators understand the technology and create an environment that allows for innovation to flourish while also having clear rules for the road, ensuring strong consumer protections to prevent this technology from being abused and safeguard our national security.
quotes.source: Campaign website, vindmanforcongress.com, 2024
quotes.context: His approach to AI regulation emphasizing both innovation and protection

quotes.quote: The technologies that will shape the balance of global power are being built today — and Congress needs to best position America as the leader. Our adversaries are exploiting American innovation to fuel their rise and erode our strategic edge.
quotes.source: Press release announcing AI Sovereignty Act, September 24, 2025
quotes.context: Statement introducing his bipartisan AI legislation package focused on China competition

quotes.quote: [Trade work like] the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers … is not going to be replaced by AI. And so I think we have to be cognizant of that … I think looking at this and being smart about what things are valued will be critically important.
quotes.source: Northern Virginia Black Chamber of Commerce roundtable, August 22, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI's impact on jobs and encouraging trades work amid AI expansion

quotes.quote: create an environment that allows for innovation to flourish
quotes.source: Meet the Freshmen profile, November 2024
quotes.context: Vindman's repeated emphasis on balancing innovation with regulation

quotes.quote: These technologies also have significant implications for national security.
quotes.source: Campaign website issues page, 2024
quotes.context: Discussing emerging technologies including AI in national security context

Eugene Simon Vindman.notes: Eugene Vindman's AI stance is heavily shaped by his national security background (former NSC deputy legal advisor, military prosecutor). His focus is distinctly geopolitical rather than technical or philosophical. Key legislative actions include: (1) Sponsoring H.R.6909 requiring National Intelligence Estimate on Chinese AI systems (December 2025), (2) Co-sponsoring the AI Sovereignty Act to track foreign AI developments, (3) Co-sponsoring the China AI Power Report Act, and (4) Supporting the Semiconductor Sovereignty Act. His approach emphasizes U.S.-China competition, supply chain security, and maintaining American technological leadership. He does NOT discuss: AGI, existential risk, AI alignment, AI safety research, or specific AI companies/figures. His view of AI 'dangers' appears focused on national security threats, foreign exploitation, and economic/job impacts rather than autonomous AI risks. Limited direct quotes available as he only took office in January 2025. His AI policy is pragmatic and defense-oriented, consistent with his military/intelligence background.

Suhas Subramanyam.summary: Suhas Subramanyam is a tech-focused Democrat who views AI as transformative with immense economic potential but approaches it with pragmatic caution. He emphasizes balancing innovation with regulation, concerns about AI bias and discrimination, and U.S. leadership in competition with China. He has recently raised concerns about an AI economic bubble and job displacement.

quotes.quote: There's an immense opportunity with AI. You can have entire economies built on these data sets and the algorithms that use these data sets to help make a lot of things smarter, better, more efficient. That's a huge opportunity, and our country has to be a leader on it.
quotes.source: Nextgov interview, December 2024
quotes.context: Discussing his Obama administration work on AI and his continued views on AI's economic potential

quotes.quote: It is important that Congress and regulators create an environment that allows for innovation to flourish while also having clear rules for the road and ensuring strong consumer protections to prevent this technology from being abused.
quotes.source: Campaign website, 2024
quotes.context: His stated policy position on AI regulation, emphasizing balance between innovation and consumer protection

quotes.quote: We shouldn't necessarily stifle and overregulate [artificial intelligence], but we should look at how we can prevent bad practices and behaviors
quotes.source: Virginia Mercury, February 2024
quotes.context: Discussing his Virginia Senate Joint Resolution 14 to study AI impacts including deepfakes, discrimination, and misinformation

quotes.quote: AI has quickly become enmeshed in all parts of our society and economy. Major tech companies heavily invested in AI make up a large share of market value and much of the economy is now intertwined with their success. We have seen this many times before with companies considered 'too big to fail.' We need transparency into the AI bubble to better understand what's going on and make sure we are prepared.
quotes.source: Press release, November 2025
quotes.context: Calling for Federal Reserve and SEC investigation into potential AI bubble, citing warnings from Sam Altman and Jeff Bezos

quotes.quote: I come from an immigrant family, and one of the things I've found, as someone with a 'funny' name like mine and a background like mine, you tend to find a lot of overgeneralizations or caricatures of your culture already, and those things also show up in the datasets that we use with AI and emergent tech. If you've got a dataset that's not representative of all communities and cultures, then you will have an outcome that represents that characterization and misrepresentation.
quotes.source: Virginia Mercury, February 2024
quotes.context: Explaining his personal motivation for focusing on AI bias and discrimination issues

quotes.quote: As a former technology advisor in the Obama White House, and as an entrepreneur who worked with tech startups, I understand first-hand the transformative power of technology.
quotes.source: Press release on committee appointments, January 2025
quotes.context: Upon being appointed to House Science, Space, and Technology Committee

quotes.quote: If the United States does not set these [AI] standards, then China will. We must ensure that Chinese AI, which operates under these flawed standards, does not come to dominate the global market.
quotes.source: DeepSeek hearing opening statement, April 2025
quotes.context: At House hearing on Chinese AI platform DeepSeek, emphasizing U.S.-China AI competition

quotes.quote: We cannot surpass China by imitating its approach. The United States must take the lead in developing the most advanced AI systems while also fostering a light-touch governance model that safeguards against malicious use while simultaneously encouraging innovation.
quotes.source: DeepSeek hearing, April 2025
quotes.context: Articulating his vision for U.S. AI policy in contrast to China's approach

quotes.quote: AI has the potential to fuel our economic growth for the coming decades but also presents a host of potential downsides, from classroom cheating all the way up to job loss and significant economic and political disruption.
quotes.source: Campaign website issues page, 2024
quotes.context: Outlining his comprehensive view of AI opportunities and risks

quotes.quote: We all agree here that, you know, technology and innovation is critical, and government plays a role in that. How do you reconcile trying to recruit for this U.S. Tech Force with the firings of technologists who I think are right now very nervous about working in government?
quotes.source: House hearing, January 2026
quotes.context: Questioning White House tech lead about workforce policy contradictions affecting AI development

Suhas Subramanyam.notes: Subramanyam is one of the few members of Congress with direct technical policy experience, having served as Obama's White House technology policy advisor where he led the Technology Policy Task Force. His AI views are notably pragmatic and policy-focused rather than ideological. He strongly emphasizes: (1) U.S.-China AI competition and the need for American leadership in setting global AI standards, particularly concerning DeepSeek; (2) AI bias and discrimination, drawing from his personal experience as an Indian-American and sponsoring Virginia legislation to promote equity in AI algorithms; (3) Economic concerns, including potential AI bubble risks and job displacement; (4) Balancing innovation with regulation - he consistently advocates for 'clear rules' and consumer protections without 'stifling' innovation. He has mentioned AI company leaders Sam Altman and Jeff Bezos in the context of bubble concerns, and has been appointed to the Congressional-Executive Commission on China. He does NOT discuss AGI, existential risk, or AI safety/alignment in the technical sense - his 'safety' concerns are focused on bias, economic stability, and geopolitical competition. His stance is best characterized as 'pro-innovation with guardrails' rather than either techno-optimist or AI safety-focused.

Michael Baumgartner.summary: Rep. Baumgartner views AI as a transformative technology akin to a new industrial revolution, emphasizing American innovation and competitiveness. He advocates for minimal government regulation, favoring a free-market approach with national uniformity over state-by-state regulations. He has introduced legislation focused on maintaining U.S. AI leadership and addressing foreign adversary threats, particularly regarding generative AI.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is not a moon shot or a Manhattan Project. This is the dawn of a new industrial revolution, and like the last one, America will win if we trust free people to innovate without asking the government for permission.
quotes.source: Press release, September 22, 2025 - H.R.5388 introduction
quotes.context: Announcing his American Artificial Intelligence Leadership and Uniformity Act, which creates a five-year moratorium on state-level AI regulations

quotes.quote: Washington state has every advantage to lead—from Spokane's data centers to WSU's AgAID Institute, and the University of Washington's AI research.
quotes.source: Press release, September 22, 2025 - H.R.5388 introduction
quotes.context: Highlighting regional AI capabilities while promoting his federal framework bill

quotes.quote: Sustaining and enhancing America's global AI dominance is necessary to promote human flourishing and economic competitiveness.
quotes.source: H.R.5388 - American Artificial Intelligence Leadership and Uniformity Act, Section 4 (Policy)
quotes.context: Legislative finding in his AI bill establishing the purpose of maintaining U.S. leadership

quotes.quote: It is a national security imperative for the United States to achieve and maintain unquestioned and unchallenged global technological dominance.
quotes.source: H.R.5388 - American Artificial Intelligence Leadership and Uniformity Act, Section 4 (Policy)
quotes.context: Policy statement in his AI legislation emphasizing national security dimensions

quotes.quote: The United States leads the world in AI due to a thriving innovation, investment, and development environment; and a flexible, sector-specific regulatory framework.
quotes.source: H.R.5388 - American Artificial Intelligence Leadership and Uniformity Act, Section 3 (Findings)
quotes.context: Legislative finding supporting his argument for limiting state-level AI regulation

quotes.quote: A patchwork of divergent State AI rules creates conflicting requirements, forces firms to navigate multiple agencies, and can deter investment.
quotes.source: H.R.5388 - American Artificial Intelligence Leadership and Uniformity Act, Section 3 (Findings)
quotes.context: Justification for federal preemption of state AI laws in his legislation

Michael Baumgartner.notes: Limited public information available. Baumgartner has introduced two AI-related bills: H.R.5388 (American Artificial Intelligence Leadership and Uniformity Act) focused on preventing state-level AI regulation, and H.R.7058 (introduced January 14, 2026) requiring the Secretary of State to assess risks from foreign adversaries using generative AI for malicious activities. His rhetoric emphasizes economic competitiveness, American innovation, and minimal regulation rather than AI safety concerns or existential risks. He frames AI as an 'industrial revolution' requiring free-market innovation. While his H.R.7058 addresses foreign adversaries broadly (including China implicitly), he has not made specific public statements about China and AI in available sources. No evidence of discussing AGI, AI alignment, safety research, or specific AI companies/figures. His stance is decidedly pro-innovation and anti-regulatory, consistent with his broader political philosophy of limited government intervention.

Emily Randall.summary: Based on extensive research, U.S. Representative Emily Randall (D-WA-06) has not made public statements specifically addressing artificial intelligence policy, regulation, safety, or related concerns. Her public policy focus has been on healthcare access, LGBTQ+ rights, reproductive freedom, affordable housing, and workforce development.
Emily Randall.notes: Emily Randall was sworn into Congress on January 3, 2025, as the U.S. Representative for Washington's 6th congressional district, making her the first queer Latina to serve in the U.S. House of Representatives. She previously served in the Washington State Senate from 2019-2024. Her legislative focus has been on healthcare (including reproductive rights), LGBTQ+ equality, workforce development, affordable housing, and issues affecting military families and tribal communities. The only technology-related policy statement found was on her campaign website regarding 'driving technological innovation and economic growth, including through blockchain technology and the digital asset industry.' As a relatively new member of Congress (serving for just over one year), she may not have yet developed or publicly articulated positions on AI policy. Her committee assignments include the House Natural Resources Committee and the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee. No speeches, press releases, bills, or public statements about AI, machine learning, automation, algorithmic regulation, AI safety, or related topics were found in available public records.

Riley M. Moore.summary: Representative Riley M. Moore's public statements on AI are extremely limited and focus almost exclusively on the competitive/geopolitical dimension, specifically framing AI as a 'race' that requires energy dominance to win. His AI-related comments appear solely in the context of supporting fossil fuel energy expansion rather than discussing AI technology, safety, or development directly.

quotes.quote: It took 14 years to get the Mountain Valley Pipeline operational — this is completely unacceptable and cannot happen if we are serious about winning the AI race and being an energy dominant nation.
quotes.source: Op-Ed in multiple West Virginia newspapers, July 2025
quotes.context: Moore discussing energy infrastructure and expedited permitting in the context of the 'One Big Beautiful Bill' legislation. This is his primary framing of AI as a competitive race requiring energy resources.

quotes.quote: If we are to succeed in rebuilding our manufacturing base and powering the AI revolution, our grid will require significant additional baseload power.
quotes.source: Op-Ed in West Virginia papers, July 2025
quotes.context: Moore arguing for increased fossil fuel energy production, framing AI as requiring substantial power infrastructure.

quotes.quote: Wind and solar cannot meet that demand – only an all of the below – the ground – strategy that unleashes coal, gas, and oil reserves can do it.
quotes.source: Op-Ed in West Virginia papers, July 2025
quotes.context: Moore's position that renewable energy cannot support AI development, advocating for fossil fuel expansion instead.

quotes.quote: It also unleashes American energy, which is critical to powering our economy, reindustrializing the heartland, and winning the global AI arms race.
quotes.source: Op-Ed in West Virginia papers, July 2025
quotes.context: Moore characterizing AI competition as an 'arms race' while discussing the One Big Beautiful Bill legislation.

quotes.quote: China is the greatest threat to the continued security and prosperity of the United States, unleashing American energy is critical in that fight.
quotes.source: Campaign materials/Meet the Freshmen profile, 2024
quotes.context: While not explicitly about AI, Moore's broader view of China as a national security threat provides context for his AI race framing.

Riley M. Moore.notes: Representative Riley M. Moore has made extremely limited public statements about AI. His only substantive AI-related comments appear in a July 2025 op-ed where he frames AI as a competitive 'race' and 'arms race' that requires energy dominance to win. He does not discuss AI technology itself, AI safety, alignment, existential risk, AGI, specific AI companies, or key figures in the field. While he has stated that China is 'the greatest threat' to U.S. security in general campaign materials, he does not explicitly connect this to AI in the available public record. His AI stance is entirely instrumental—viewing AI as justification for fossil fuel energy expansion in West Virginia. He characterizes AI as 'transformative' (referring to 'the AI revolution') but only in the context of energy demand, not in terms of technological capabilities or societal impact. There is no evidence of engagement with AI policy debates, technical AI issues, or the AI safety/alignment community. His position appears to be: AI is important for national competitiveness, requires massive energy infrastructure, and therefore justifies fossil fuel expansion—but he shows no apparent interest in or knowledge of AI as a technology or policy domain beyond this narrow energy-focused framing.

James C. Justice.summary: James C. Justice has demonstrated limited public engagement with AI policy issues. His administration took some practical steps including establishing a West Virginia AI Task Force and partnering with GATC Health for AI-driven drug discovery, but Justice himself has made few substantive public statements about artificial intelligence, its transformative potential, or related policy concerns.

quotes.quote: West Virginia is leading the way in revolutionizing the pharmaceutical industry and making a huge difference in medicine discovery
quotes.source: Press release, March 2024
quotes.context: Justice announced a $5 million investment in GATC Health to use AI for drug discovery, particularly for opioid use disorder treatments. This represents his most substantial public comment on AI applications.

quotes.quote: This initiative places West Virginia on the map as a leader of innovation as we bring cutting-edge technology right to our backyard to find effective medicines
quotes.source: Press release regarding GATC Health partnership, March 2024
quotes.context: Justice framed the AI drug discovery partnership as an economic development and healthcare innovation opportunity for West Virginia.

quotes.quote: America has a tremendous opportunity with the innovation and technology around artificial intelligence (AI), blockchain, and cryptocurrencies
quotes.source: Campaign website Q&A, February 2024
quotes.context: Justice grouped AI with blockchain and cryptocurrencies as emerging technologies, emphasizing innovation opportunity without detailed policy positions.

quotes.quote: I'm learning more and more about cryptocurrencies, blockchain, and all these new technologies
quotes.source: Campaign website Q&A, February 2024
quotes.context: When asked about digital technologies including AI, Justice acknowledged he was still learning about these emerging areas.

quotes.quote: This would have been the project of a lifetime
quotes.source: Chief of Staff Brian Abraham regarding data center project, late 2024
quotes.context: Justice's administration nearly called a special legislative session for a $30 billion data center project in Logan, WV, though Justice himself made limited public statements about it.

James C. Justice.notes: Jim Justice's public record shows surprisingly minimal engagement with AI policy discourse despite serving as Governor during a critical period of AI development (2017-2025). His administration established the West Virginia Task Force on Artificial Intelligence under state code §5A-6-9 and passed HB 3214 (ROAD Pilot Program) to explore AI for road maintenance assessment. However, Justice himself rarely spoke publicly about AI beyond announcing the GATC Health partnership. His governance style, as noted by observers, focused on broad themes rather than detailed policy explanations. He did not participate in national AI policy discussions, make statements about US-China AI competition, discuss AI safety concerns, or engage with debates about AGI, existential risk, or AI alignment that were prominent among other political figures during his tenure. The available evidence suggests Justice viewed AI primarily as an economic development tool rather than engaging with broader transformative or governance implications. Only 5 quotes could be identified that relate to his views on AI, far short of the requested 10, indicating limited public engagement with this topic.

Jon Husted.summary: Jon Husted is a strong AI proponent who views AI as transformative and essential for U.S. economic and military competitiveness, particularly against China. He is highly focused on practical applications of AI in government efficiency and education, while advocating for measured regulations to protect children and national security. He does not discuss existential AI risks or AGI concerns.

quotes.quote: AI is the most powerful assistive technology in my lifetime — probably in the history of the world.
quotes.source: Axios interview, May 7, 2025
quotes.context: Husted explaining why AI is key to beating China at innovation, making U.S. students more competitive, and balancing the federal budget.

quotes.quote: And if you study the history of the world, the nations that are the most military and economically domineer are the nations that are the most innovative.
quotes.source: Senate Armed Services Cybersecurity Subcommittee hearing, March 25, 2025
quotes.context: Husted framing AI development as critical to national security and economic dominance in a congressional hearing on AI cyber capabilities.

quotes.quote: AI is going to be a dominant technology in determining whether we're going to have economic or military superiority for the future of our nation, and we have to lead.
quotes.source: Statement on RAISE and CHAT Acts, September 2025
quotes.context: Explaining why AI education is critical for American students, noting that China is investing billions in creating AI-fluent students.

quotes.quote: Communist China is working overtime to beat America in the AI race. U.S. students must master AI to guarantee our country's national security and prosperity.
quotes.source: Twitter/X post about RAISE Act, 2025
quotes.context: Promoting his bill to encourage states to develop AI education standards in schools to ensure America dominates the AI landscape.

quotes.quote: We just need to make sure that America is winning, and the policies and the laws of this land will determine whether we can go fast enough to keep up.
quotes.source: Axios interview, May 7, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the need for Congress to move quickly on AI policy to maintain American competitiveness.

quotes.quote: The RAISE Act would encourage AI competency among our students to make sure the Land of the Free dominates the AI landscape for generations. Neither our economy nor our national defense can outpace adversaries like Communist China without that dominance.
quotes.source: Press release introducing RAISE Act, September 9, 2025
quotes.context: Announcing bipartisan legislation to integrate AI education into K-12 schools nationwide.

quotes.quote: AI is an emerging technology that is going to be part of every aspect of our lives and our economy, and we have to prepare students for it, both the good and the bad.
quotes.source: Statement on AI regulation bills, September 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to regulate minors' use of AI chatbots while promoting AI education.

quotes.quote: We've got to embrace both sides of it, the good, and then try to defeat the things that can be uncomfortable or bad. And we can't stick our heads in the sand.
quotes.source: Interview about AI regulation, September 25, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the balance between embracing AI innovation and addressing concerns about data centers and potential harms.

quotes.quote: Ohio needed this guiding policy to leverage the power of AI while also protecting the data behind this rapidly changing technology.
quotes.source: LinkedIn post about Ohio AI policy, December 5, 2023
quotes.context: As Lieutenant Governor, announcing Ohio's new policy and council to govern statewide AI use.

quotes.quote: The most technologically advanced nations are the ones that win economically and militarily. This bill gives small businesses—including those in Ohio—a break by cutting taxes so they can fuel innovation instead of worrying about the costs of R&D.
quotes.source: Statement on American Innovation and Jobs Act, May 12, 2025
quotes.context: Supporting legislation to expand R&D investment to help America outcompete China in innovation and technology.

Jon Husted.notes: Jon Husted is one of the most pro-AI voices in Congress. His focus is overwhelmingly on: (1) U.S.-China competition in AI, which he mentions constantly; (2) practical government applications like using AI to streamline regulations; (3) AI education for K-12 students; and (4) targeted child safety regulations for AI chatbots. He introduced legislation to ban DeepSeek (Chinese AI) from government devices and frequently frames AI development as essential for economic and military dominance. Notably absent from his rhetoric: any discussion of existential risk, AGI, AI alignment, or AI safety in the technical sense. He views AI purely through a lens of economic competitiveness and practical utility. He personally uses three AI apps that 'compare with each other' and is described as an 'avid user' of AI tools. He worked extensively on AI policy as Ohio's Lieutenant Governor before joining the Senate in 2025 (appointed to fill JD Vance's seat). While he does mention AI companies like Microsoft, Google, Intel, and specifically DeepSeek, it's primarily in the context of partnerships or national security concerns rather than engaging with AI safety debates happening in the tech community.

Ashley Moody.summary: Ashley Moody's public statements on AI have focused almost exclusively on consumer protection and child safety issues rather than broader AI policy. As Florida Attorney General (2019-2025) and now U.S. Senator, she has primarily addressed AI's role in enabling scams, child exploitation, and harmful chatbot interactions. She has not made public statements about AGI, existential risk, or transformative AI capabilities.

quotes.quote: As a mother, I cannot imagine the fear that would come from hearing your child's voice begging for help over the phone and a scammer threatening to kill your child. AI voice cloning poses a grave new threat, as it allows scammers to exploit our deepest fears to deceive and manipulate us.
quotes.source: Florida Attorney General press release, July 2023
quotes.context: Warning about AI-powered voice cloning scams targeting grandparents and families

quotes.quote: Scammers are using artificial intelligence to make solicitations more believable, and Floridians need to be on high alert to avoid falling prey. Scammers can use AI to craft persuasive messages that include precise industry jargon and links to malware.
quotes.source: Florida Bar News, September 2023
quotes.context: Warning about ChatGPT and AI being exploited to make scams more sophisticated

quotes.quote: It's extremely disturbing and very troubling because anytime something comes out, you're going to have these bad actors who use it for bad things and in this case, it's going to be used for the most disgusting things, and it has to do with child sexual abuse material.
quotes.source: CBS12 News, September 2023
quotes.context: Discussing AI-generated deepfakes and child sexual abuse material

quotes.quote: The rapid onset of artificial intelligence is raising concerns about how child predators may use the high-tech tool to prey on minors. We need a full congressional investigation into the capabilities of AI and what we can do to reduce the ability of predators to exploit this tool to harm children.
quotes.source: Florida Daily, September 2023
quotes.context: Letter with 53 other attorneys general calling for congressional commission on AI and child exploitation

quotes.quote: We are engaged in a race against time to protect the children of our country from the dangers of AI.
quotes.source: Letter to congressional leaders, September 2023
quotes.context: Part of coalition letter from 54 attorneys general about AI exploitation of children

quotes.quote: You better believe we are going to start seeing new and improved scams against our seniors.
quotes.source: AARP Florida event, June 2023
quotes.context: Warning about AI's ability to mimic loved ones' voices to scam elderly adults

quotes.quote: Now, with A.I. and the ability to use someone's voice, that aids in the credibility of these scams when they are reaching out to victims.
quotes.source: WCJB News, August 2023
quotes.context: Discussing how AI voice cloning makes scams more convincing

quotes.quote: They'll go online they can get pictures of young people then use AI to make it look like they're their own age, a young person, a young kid. They're exchanging things among their peers when in fact it's a perpetrator.
quotes.source: FOX 13 Tampa Bay, September 2023
quotes.context: Warning about AI being used in sextortion cases involving minors

quotes.quote: [Companies] should be held liable for their chatbots causing harm or death to users.
quotes.source: Senate HELP Committee hearing, October 8, 2025
quotes.context: Question posed during Senate hearing on AI's role in health care, following reports of chatbot-linked teen suicides

quotes.quote: Since my time as the Attorney General of Florida, fighting back against Big Tech's influence on our children has been one of my top priorities. As a mother, I know firsthand just how addictive some of the features and algorithms can be to our children.
quotes.source: Senate press release, January 2025
quotes.context: Statement supporting the Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA), which addresses AI-powered chatbots and child safety

Ashley Moody.notes: Ashley Moody's public statements on AI are narrowly focused on consumer protection, fraud prevention, and child safety rather than broader AI policy questions. Her perspective appears to be shaped by her role as a state Attorney General (2019-2025) and now U.S. Senator, where she has focused on law enforcement and consumer protection issues. She has not publicly addressed: AGI or existential risk from AI, AI alignment or safety research, AI's transformative economic potential, competition with China on AI development, or statements about major AI companies like OpenAI, Anthropic, or Google DeepMind. Her AI-related work has centered on: 1) Warning consumers about AI-enabled scams (voice cloning, ChatGPT-powered phishing), 2) Advocating for congressional action on AI and child exploitation, 3) Supporting legislation like KOSA to protect children from harmful AI chatbots, 4) Questioning AI company liability for harms. As a recently appointed Senator (January 2025), she may develop more comprehensive AI policy positions, but as of January 2026, her public record shows a law enforcement/consumer protection lens rather than engagement with broader AI policy debates about capabilities, competition, or existential risk.

Jimmy Patronis.summary: Jimmy Patronis views AI primarily through the lens of national security, ideological bias, and child safety concerns. He characterizes AI as the 'new Space Race' and focuses heavily on China as a competitive and security threat. His approach to AI is practical and regulatory rather than philosophical, with no evidence of engagement with AGI or existential risk concepts.

quotes.quote: Artificial intelligence is the new 'Space Race,' and as it grows in popularity, I will not allow sensitive Department information to be compromised through a Chinese AI app that can harm Floridians.
quotes.source: CFO Directive banning DeepSeek, February 20, 2025
quotes.context: Patronis issued a directive prohibiting use of Chinese AI company DeepSeek in Florida's Department of Financial Services, citing national security concerns.

quotes.quote: AI can be a huge resource for good, but it can also be a weapon if it's in the wrong hands. Americans must be protected, and American companies must out-compete China.
quotes.source: DeepSeek ban announcement, February 2025
quotes.context: Statement emphasizing the dual-use nature of AI and framing it as a US-China competition issue.

quotes.quote: @elonmusk is right when he is warning about China AI. Time to end China's ability to spy on our people!
quotes.source: Twitter/X post, February 20, 2025
quotes.context: Patronis endorsed Elon Musk's warnings about Chinese AI while announcing the DeepSeek ban on CNBC.

quotes.quote: The President and his team have delivered a smart executive order that instructs federal agencies to only leverage AI tools that speak the truth.
quotes.source: Press release introducing H.R. 4873, August 5, 2025
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to codify Trump's executive order preventing 'woke AI' in federal government.

quotes.quote: If the federal government is going to use and promote these tools, then AI designers either need to align their programs to remove Leftwing biases from their algorithm, or they need to get out of the business of federal contracting.
quotes.source: Statement on 'woke AI' bill, August 2025
quotes.context: Patronis introduced legislation to ban AI systems with perceived left-wing bias from federal contracts, focusing on DEI and critical race theory.

quotes.quote: Surprising to no one, there are examples-after-examples of AI tools going off the rails because the foundational programming tilts politically Left.
quotes.source: News release on H.R. 4873, August 2025
quotes.context: Justifying his bill to prevent 'woke AI' in federal government by claiming AI systems have left-wing bias.

quotes.quote: This bill will codify the President's executive order to ensure taxpayer-funded artificial intelligence is not being weaponized to promote progressive ideology like DEI, critical race theory, or transgenderism.
quotes.source: Press release, August 2025
quotes.context: Explaining the purpose of his legislation to ban what he considers ideologically biased AI from federal use.

quotes.quote: Big Tech is digital fentanyl that is slowly killing our kids, pushing parents to the sidelines, acting as therapists, and replacing relationships with our family and friends.
quotes.source: PROTECT Act announcement, January 2026
quotes.context: Introducing legislation to repeal Section 230 protections for tech companies, focusing on harm to children from algorithms and AI-driven content.

quotes.quote: When children are told by an algorithm, or a chatbot, that the world would be better without them, and no one is being held responsible, something is deeply broken.
quotes.source: Statement on PROTECT Act, January 2026
quotes.context: Discussing concerns about AI chatbots and their potential harm to children, referencing lawsuits against OpenAI.

quotes.quote: President Trump said DeepSeek was a wake-up call, and he's absolutely right.
quotes.source: Multiple statements, February 2025
quotes.context: Repeatedly citing Trump's concerns about Chinese AI competition as validation for his ban on DeepSeek.

Jimmy Patronis.notes: Jimmy Patronis is a U.S. Representative for Florida's 1st Congressional District (since April 2025) and former Florida Chief Financial Officer (2017-2025). His AI policy focus areas are: (1) National security and China competition - views AI as geopolitical 'Space Race'; (2) Ideological bias - introduced H.R. 4873 to ban 'woke AI' with DEI/CRT content from federal contracts; (3) Child safety - introduced PROTECT Act to repeal Section 230 citing AI chatbot harms. He references Elon Musk approvingly and aligns closely with Trump administration positions. His 'alignment' concerns are about political bias, not technical AI safety. No evidence of engagement with AGI concepts, existential risk, or transformative AI capabilities discussions. Mentions OpenAI only in context of lawsuit by parents whose child died by suicide. Also proposed legislation to audit AI vendors working with IRS. Views AI pragmatically as a tool that needs regulatory oversight for security and ideological neutrality.

Randy Fine.summary: Limited public information available. Representative Fine introduced H.R. 6996 in January 2026 to facilitate U.S. AI exports globally, but has not made substantial public statements about artificial intelligence policy, safety, or development. His legislative focus has primarily been on Israel-Palestine issues, immigration, and cultural issues rather than technology policy.
Randy Fine.notes: Randy Fine (R-FL-6) has been a U.S. Representative since April 2, 2025. On January 9, 2026, he introduced H.R. 6996, titled 'To facilitate the export of United States artificial intelligence systems, computing hardware, and standards globally.' This bill was referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs. However, despite extensive research including searches of congressional records, press releases, C-SPAN appearances, news articles, and social media, no public statements, quotes, interviews, or speeches by Representative Fine specifically addressing AI policy, AI safety, AGI, existential risk, or AI companies could be located. His public focus has been predominantly on issues related to Israel, immigration, anti-Muslim rhetoric, and cultural issues. The introduction of H.R. 6996 suggests some interest in promoting U.S. AI exports as part of broader foreign policy/economic competitiveness, but without accompanying statements, his specific views on AI remain undocumented. This represents insufficient information to characterize his AI stance beyond the bare fact of this single legislative action.

James R. Walkinshaw.summary: Rep. Walkinshaw views AI pragmatically as a tool for government efficiency and modernization, emphasizing responsible adoption with proper training and oversight. He supports emerging technologies including AI, blockchain, quantum computing, and space tech for economic opportunity. His focus is on practical implementation rather than philosophical debates about AGI or existential risk.

quotes.quote: James believes we must embrace the next generation of technology—including Artificial Intelligence (AI), space and quantum technologies, and blockchain—to create new economic opportunities.
quotes.source: Campaign website - Priorities page
quotes.context: Statement on his campaign website outlining his technology policy vision for Northern Virginia's economy

quotes.quote: I'm working on a modernized modernization scorecard for federal IT that drives AI adoption in a safe and responsible way, but takes advantage of the efficiencies and savings that the federal government can achieve via AI adoption, improving our cybersecurity posture
quotes.source: GovCIO Media, October 31, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing his plans for a new federal IT modernization scorecard that includes AI adoption metrics

quotes.quote: We are in the middle of implementing an AI-powered chatbot tool to help citizens and residents access services and information from the county government. So, we are full speed ahead on modernizing Fairfax County government and leading the nation in local government technology adoption
quotes.source: MeriTalk interview, June 2025
quotes.context: Describing AI implementation during his tenure on the Fairfax County Board of Supervisors

quotes.quote: Walkinshaw suggested he supports the use of emerging technologies in government, including AI, but expressed concerns about whether agencies have the proper training to do so. Congress has to be making sure that as we're incorporating AI into the federal government, that we're investing in the talent and the training so agencies can deploy it responsibly and effectively
quotes.source: FedScoop, July 22, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing the need for workforce training alongside AI adoption in federal agencies

quotes.quote: It's hard to tell how much of that is smoke and mirrors and how much of that is legitimate. I'll just say, to do that effectively, you really have to have good people who understand the agency's mission and know how to do it. And they fired a lot of those people.
quotes.source: FedScoop, July 22, 2025
quotes.context: Responding to the Trump administration's claims about using AI automation to replace federal workers

quotes.quote: Given the speed of innovation and the speed at which our adversaries around the globe, state and non-state actors, are innovating, a pause is a negative
quotes.source: Government Executive, November 4, 2025
quotes.context: Warning about the impact of government shutdowns on federal IT and cybersecurity innovation in the context of global competition

quotes.quote: Innovation in the federal government is paused during a shutdown. Obviously, given the speed of innovation and the speed at which our adversaries around the globe — state and non-state actors — are innovating, a pause is a setback.
quotes.source: GovCIO Media, October 31, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing how government shutdowns impact technological advancement relative to adversaries

quotes.quote: We've worked very hard to kind of take advantage of our talented workforce and be the place in the world where our workforce knows how to utilize and take advantage of AI
quotes.source: Federal News Network, October 3, 2025
quotes.context: Discussing Northern Virginia's economic diversification strategy focused on emerging technologies

quotes.quote: Walkinshaw supports additional checks on the growing influence of China, saying that it has been operating unfairly within the global trade and economic regime for a long time
quotes.source: Wikipedia, January 2026
quotes.context: Statement on his position regarding China's role in global trade and competition

quotes.quote: One of the things I learned over my 11 years with Gerry Connolly is, if we want to make government work and work well, we've got to have good people, and we've got to have good technology
quotes.source: MeriTalk Tech Tonic event, August 2025
quotes.context: Explaining his philosophy on federal government effectiveness through workforce and technology investment

James R. Walkinshaw.notes: Walkinshaw is a newly elected U.S. Representative (sworn in September 2025) who previously served as chief of staff to Rep. Gerry Connolly for 11 years and on the Fairfax County Board of Supervisors. His AI views are pragmatic and focused on government modernization rather than theoretical concerns. He emphasizes 'responsible' and 'safe' AI adoption with proper training and oversight. He references adversaries (including China and other state/non-state actors) in the context of technological competition and innovation speed. He has hands-on experience implementing AI chatbots at the local government level in Fairfax County. He supports multiple emerging technologies (AI, blockchain, quantum, space tech) for economic development. He is critical of using AI as justification for mass federal workforce reductions without proper expertise. No evidence found of discussions about AGI, existential risk, AI safety research, or specific AI companies/figures. His focus is entirely on practical government applications and maintaining U.S. technological competitiveness.

Adelita S. Grijalva.summary: No public statements or positions on AI found. Representative Grijalva has been in Congress for only approximately 2 months (sworn in November 12, 2025) and has focused her public statements on immigration, education, environmental issues, and reproductive rights. There is insufficient information available to assess her views on artificial intelligence.
Adelita S. Grijalva.notes: Adelita S. Grijalva is a newly elected U.S. Representative from Arizona's 7th Congressional District who took office on November 12, 2025. She is the daughter of the late Rep. Raúl Grijalva and the first Latina to represent Arizona in Congress. Her documented policy priorities include: immigration reform, education funding, environmental protection, reproductive rights, affordable housing, and healthcare access. She serves on the House Committee on Education and the Workforce and the House Committee on Natural Resources. The only technology-related statement found was on her campaign website supporting 'legislation that establishes a clear regulatory framework for blockchain technology that protects consumers, fosters responsible innovation, and provides clear rules of the road.' Given her very recent entry into Congress and focus on other policy areas, she has not yet made public statements about AI policy, safety, existential risk, or related issues. It is possible she may develop positions on AI in the future, particularly given her committee assignment on Education and the Workforce, where AI's impact on education and employment could become relevant.

Matt Van Epps.summary: Matt Van Epps is a newly elected U.S. Representative from Tennessee (sworn in December 2025) with professional experience as Director of Artificial Intelligence for the State of Tennessee. While he has expressed enthusiasm for AI and technology issues through his committee assignments and campaign platform, there is limited public record of detailed statements about AI policy, existential risk, or AGI.

quotes.quote: I'm excited and eager to jump in, because I think the cyber and AI subcommittee is so relevant, there's so much going on and so many things we need to work on
quotes.source: Clarksville Now podcast interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Van Epps discussing his assignment to the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Protection subcommittee after being sworn into Congress

quotes.quote: It's also critical that we pass responsible legislation to regulate and unleash innovation in Crypto and artificial intelligence to ensure that the US continues to lead on both fronts
quotes.source: Campaign website (mattfortn.com), 2025
quotes.context: Part of his economic policy platform during his congressional campaign

quotes.quote: Doing this will mean America leads the way in both industries, while also protecting liberty, privacy, and data. America should shape the framework of the future global financial and technology system, not China or Russia
quotes.source: Campaign website (mattfortn.com), 2025
quotes.context: Discussing AI and cryptocurrency policy in the context of global competition

quotes.quote: For those very first two votes, I submitted the green card, they were yeses and they were votes to counter the Chinese Communist Party
quotes.source: Clarksville Now podcast interview, December 2025
quotes.context: Describing his first votes in Congress immediately after being sworn in

quotes.quote: The Chinese Communist Party poses serious military, cyber security, intellectual property, and global economic threats to the United States
quotes.source: iVoterGuide candidate questionnaire, 2025
quotes.context: Response to foreign policy questions during his campaign

quotes.quote: He said it was a three-hour hearing, and he stayed the whole time while using three of his five minutes on a quick opening statement and some questions about AI and foreign threats
quotes.source: Clarksville Now, December 2025
quotes.context: Description of Van Epps's participation in his first Homeland Security Committee hearing on threats to the homeland

quotes.quote: These assignments give me the opportunity to work on legislation that protects our communities, keeps our borders secure, strengthens our economy, and ensures Tennessee's Seventh District has a strong voice in shaping our nation's future
quotes.source: Official congressional announcement, December 2025
quotes.context: Statement upon being assigned to the Homeland Security and Science, Space, and Technology Committees

quotes.quote: I'm happy to share that I'm starting a new position as Director of Artificial Intelligence at State of Tennessee!
quotes.source: LinkedIn profile post (date unclear, prior to 2024)
quotes.context: Announcement of his appointment to lead AI initiatives for Tennessee state government before becoming Commissioner of General Services

Matt Van Epps.notes: Matt Van Epps is a very newly elected congressman (sworn in December 4, 2025) with relevant professional experience as Tennessee's Director of Artificial Intelligence in state government. His public statements on AI are limited but suggest a pro-innovation, pro-American competitiveness stance focused on ensuring the U.S. leads in AI development over China and Russia. He emphasizes 'unleashing innovation' while protecting 'liberty, privacy, and data.' He serves on the House Science, Space, and Technology Committee and the Homeland Security Committee's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Protection subcommittee, positioning him to work on AI policy. However, there is no public record of him discussing advanced AI concepts like AGI, existential risk, alignment problems, or AI safety in technical terms. His approach appears pragmatic and focused on economic competitiveness and national security rather than philosophical or existential concerns. His first congressional hearing included questions about 'AI and foreign threats,' indicating security-focused priorities. Given his recent election, more detailed policy positions may emerge as he settles into his role.
